HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
Peace Talks Suspended Pending Efforts by U.S.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The next round of talks in Geneva among the three warring factions in Bosnia has been put off while diplomats from the European Union and the United Nations wait to see whether Washington can broker a separate peace between Bosnian Croats and Muslims.
Officials of Croatia, Bosnia and the Bosnian Croats met today for a third day in Washington with State Department officials to discuss a United States proposal to unite Croats and Muslims in a federation that would cover just over 50 percent of Bosnia. 
 Although the plan excludes Serbs, the European Union mediator, Lord Owen, said on Sunday night that he fully supported the effort and wanted to give Washington time to try to develop the idea.
"My attitude is that I am genuinely pleased that the United States is engaged," he said. "I've felt all along it would be incredibly difficult to see a settlement with the United States as bystanders."
 
Scattered Reports of Fighting
 He added that the final success would turn on the details, from the precise lines on the maps to the question of who controls the police forces.
Last week the commanders of the Bosnian Croats' militia and the mostly Muslim Bosnian Army signed a cease-fire agreement. There have been scattered reports of fighting, but generally, the cease-fire appears to be holding.
The Geneva talks had been scheduled to resume in late February or early March. The last round broke up in mid-February, when NATO was threatening air strikes against Serbian gunners surrounding Sarajevo.
Lord Owen described the American proposal as broadly consistent with efforts undertaken in Geneva to date, even though some United Nations and European officials have been dismissive of the American effort. "My only reservation," Lord Owen said in an interview, "is that it must be done in a way that the Serbs can live with it too."
Under the current plan, the entity created by Bosnia's Muslims and Croats -- nominal allies against the Serbs until they began fighting each other in April -- would be joined in an economic federation with neighboring Croatia. The last plan on the table in Geneva calls for the division of Bosnia into three ethnic republics.
Washington has had little direct involvement in diplomatic efforts to stop the fighting, and the Administration has been unhappy with proposals that would partition Bosnia.
 
Contemptuous of U.S. Plan
 Some officials of the United Nations and the European Union have ridiculed the American proposal for a Croatian-Muslim union in Bosnia as ill conceived because it does nothing to address Serbian grievances. Asked for his reaction to the proposal, one top United Nations official said, "You don't really want to know what I think."
Washington's determination to take an increasingly active role in Bosnia is broadly welcomed in Europe. But there continues to be a frustration that the United States is still not willing to commit ground troops to United Nations peacekeeping efforts in the country.
In an interview, Yasushi Akashi, the United Nations special envoy to Yugoslavia and its former republics, said the major challenge facing the peacekeeping operation was finding the troops necessary to separate and disarm the warring factions.
Although he did not criticize Washington for its refusal to send ground troops to Bosnia, he said international powers had "to put their money and their troops where their mouth is."
"If they are very interested in bringing about peace in Bosnia," Mr. Akashi added, "it is quite clear that agreements reached have to be implemented on the ground," and to that end American troops would be especially helpful.

HEADLINE: Clinton Travels for Rostenkowski, and Major

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28

 BODY:
President Clinton divided his time today between two leaders in political peril, flying to Chicago to offer an effusive tribute to Representative Dan Rostenkowski and then moving on for a rendezvous here with Prime Minister John Major of Britain.
Both stops were preceded by some tension. Mr. Rostenkowski, a Chicago Democrat who faces a difficult primary election on March 15, is the subject of a Federal criminal investigation. White House officials had debated whether Mr. Clinton should be seen as taking sides in the race. 
 Mr. Major, who is under pressure to call elections sooner than the April 1997 deadline, has watched his popularity plunge to 13 percent in public opinion polls. British officials have complained that Mr. Clinton has contributed to the Prime Minister's plight by giving short shrift to what leaders of the two countries have long referred to as their special relationship.
 
Speaking With Fervor
 But no signs of friction were evident today, particularly in Chicago, where Mr. Clinton shared a limousine with Mr. Rostenkowski, slung an arm around his shoulders and repeatedly praised him, saying he had shown courage and leadership as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
"It is not up to me to know or make judgments about all the things that are of concern to the people of Chicago," Mr. Clinton told an audience at Wright Junior College. But the President spoke with fervor in saying that had it not been for Mr. Rostenkowski's help on the budget and other legislation last year "this economy today would not be on the right path it's on."
Urging the crowd to demand that their political leaders stiffen their spines and act, Mr. Clinton said: "The one person you don't have to say it to is Dan Rostenkowski; it's in his bones, and he will do it, too."
Mr. Rostenkowski, who has been under Federal investigation for 19 months, faces accusations that he misused money from the House post office and his campaign. The White House regards his support as important for passage of health care legislation.
 
Not an Endorsement
 At a news conference last week, Mr. Clinton noted that the 18-term Congressman had "not yet been charged with anything." But he also emphasized that his visit did not constitute an endorsement of Mr. Rostenkowski, who in the most recent public opinion poll was running just ahead of his main Democratic rival, State Senator John J. Cullerton.
The official purpose of the President's trip to Chicago was to give two speeches on crime, one at a high school.
Mr. Clinton is only the latest of top Administration officials and lawmakers to go to Chicago on behalf of Mr. Rostenkowski. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich made an appearance with him last week, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, and former Mayor David N. Dinkins have helped him raise money.
Today, even as Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago joined Mr. Clinton in lauding him, Mr. Rostenkowski responded with characteristic dourness, slouching in his chair and wearing a perpetual grimace.
In Pittsburgh, President Clinton greeted Mr. Major at the Air Force Reserve's section of Pittsburgh International Airport and then spent the evening playing gracious host to his Conservative counterpart.
It was Mr. Clinton, the White House said, who suggested that the two leaders meet so informally. The visit included a working dinner in the scenic Tin Angel restaurant, which the men reached by a funicular railway, the Duquesne Inclined Plane. From the top, they looked down on a fireworks display from the point where the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers join to form the Ohio. The two leaders were accompanied only by their national security advisers.
 
Evening Talks
 Mr. Major recently returned from Russia, and the two leaders planned to spend the evening discussing, among other topics, the situations there and in Bosnia.
The leaders were to fly to Washington tonight aboard Air Force One, and Mr. Major was to spend the night in the Lincoln Bedroom, the first foreign leader to stay in the White House as Mr. Clinton's guest.
Since Mr. Clinton took office, British officials have bristled at what they regard as insufficient American attention to British concerns and even insensitivity toward them. Relations were particularly strained last month, when the United States granted an entry visa to Gerry Adams, the political leader of the Irish Republican Army.
Although White House officials have privately pointed to Britain's diminishing importance in the world, Mr. Clinton sought to show that relations between the two countries remain warm and strong by wearing a tie adorned with representations of the American and British flags. Nonetheless, the White House did not schedule a joint news conference during Mr. Major's two-day visit, a courtesy usually extended to visiting foreign leaders.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton visited Chicago yesterday to speak about crime and to pay tribute to Representative Dan Rostenkowski, who faces a primary election on March 15 and who is expected to play an important role in efforts to pass major health care legislation. Mr. Rostenkowski, right foreground, and Mr. Clinton listened to a roundtable discussion at Wilbur Wright Junior College on crime. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
A glimpse of television's future is here now -- on the screens of millions of home computers, some experts say. Computer disks known as CD-ROM's are offering an eclectic array of video clips, animation, sound and text. The disks have made their way into the home office and rumpus room as the fastest-growing segment of the $29 billion annual software industry. [Page A1.] 
 MCI is investing $1.3 billion in Nextel Communications, a fast-growing competitor to cellular telephone companies. [D1.]
Whittle Communications suspended the television programming it produces for doctors' waiting room. [D5.]
John Malone, who heads both Liberty Media and Tele-Communications, is considering an investment in Blockbuster, even though the video rental company plans to merge with Viacom. [D5.]
Ford formed a new unit to concentrate on increasing its presence in China and named a senior executive to run it. [D5.]
The I.R.S. has chosen an I.B.M. subsidiary to develop a scanning system to convert tax returns, documents and letters into electronic images for faster processing. [D9.]
The Chicago Sun-Times is being sold to a company controlled by Conrad Black, the Canadian financier. [D18.]
An examination of America Works shows that the company has a poor track record in finding jobs for people on welfare. [A1.]
New York State's consumer protection chief clashed with Lilco over a recent advertising campaign. [B6.]
 
The Economy
If revived inflation is just around the corner, as many seem to believe, consumers probably won't be finding that much of it soon at many businesses. A survey of companies disclosed relatively little upward pressure on prices. [D1.]
The Congressional Budget Office concluded that the Government might claim stock options in the sales of mutual savings institutions to banks or investors. [D2.]
 
International
Immunity has been granted to a major figure in a case involving billions of dollars in federally guaranteed loans to Iraq made by the Banca Nazionale de Lavoro's Atlanta branch. [D1.]
The U.S. is concerned that Mexico wants to keep other Latin American countries out of the North American trade zone. [D2.]
India's Finance Minister proposed tax cuts and other measures aimed at increasing foreign investment in India. [D8.]
NEC and Samsung are forming a joint venture to design and manufacture advanced computer chips. [D9.]
 
Markets
A phenomenal bull market in the stocks and bonds of developing countries has halted, especially those in Latin America. The correction has produced losses of hundreds of millions of dollars among banks and brokerage firms that deal in the securities. [D1.]
Treasury bond prices jumped and yields declined, as the market was buoyed by signs that inflation was easing. [D18.]
The stock market received a boost from the bond market rally, although the Dow Jones industrials lost 6.76 points. [D10.]
The dollar fell against most other currencies after the weekend meeting of the Group of Seven failed to produce a currency agreement. [D20.] Wheat prices tumbled. [D20.]
 
Today's Columns
Analysts are split on the fortunes of the Starter Corporation, which lost 21 percent of its market value in a single day in January and has not recovered much since then. Market Place. [D10.]
One viewer found the advertising on CBS's coverage of the Winter Olympics to be an overwhelmingly banal and boring barrage. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D22.]

HEADLINE: NEW HEALTH PLAN STRESSES MEDICARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The chairman of an important Congressional subcommittee is drafting a proposal to expand Medicare to cover millions of people who lack insurance, as an alternative to President Clinton's health care plan.
Under the proposal, devised by Representative Pete Stark, chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, the Government would collect premiums from consumers and employers through the Internal Revenue Service. The proposal would give most Americans the option of enrolling in the new expanded Medicare program or in a private health insurance plan. 
 Mr. Stark said he intended to use his proposal as a basis for negotiation when his panel begins drafting health legislation next week. He briefed White House officials about the proposal on Friday and is trying to round up support on his subcommittee.
There is no guarantee that the proposal, the opening shot in what is likely to be a yearlong Congressional battle over health legislation, will be approved by Mr. Stark's subcommittee, much less by the full Ways and Means Committee, the House or the Senate. But Mr. Stark is in a strong position to push for the ideas in his proposal.
 
Goals Are Shared
 The goals of the Stark proposal are identical to those of President Clinton's health plan: to guarantee health insurance for all Americans and to control medical spending so it is growing no faster than the economy as a whole after the year 2000. But under the Stark plan, the Government would collect insurance premiums and provide health insurance directly to millions more Americans than would be covered by the Government under Mr. Clinton's proposal.
The Stark plan focuses on the 39 million people without health insurance, and he says his proposal would be far less disruptive to people who already have coverage.
In an interview tonight, Mr. Stark, Democrat of California, said, "My goal is to start with the uninsured, to guarantee that they have health insurance as simply and inexpensively as possible, and to leave alone the 180 million people who are privately insured."
A confidential summary of Mr. Stark's proposal, which he prepared with his staff, says: "All individuals would be covered under a private health plan meeting Federal insurance standards or in a Federal plan, which would be called Medicare Part C. Enrollment in Medicare Part C would be automatic, unless an individual is enrolled in a private health plan."
 
Alike and Different
 Mr. Stark said that under his proposal employers with more than 100 employees would have to buy private insurance meeting Federal standards.
Medicare covers 36 million people who are at least 65 years old or disabled. Part A of Medicare covers hospital care; Part B covers doctors' services. Mr. Stark's proposal would open Medicare to people who are unemployed, people who have no connection to the labor force and low-income people now in the Medicaid program, regardless of age.
Mr. Stark's proposal resembles the Clinton plan in some ways. The Congressman would, for example, require employers to pay 80 percent of insurance premiums for employees, regardless of whether they enrolled in private health plans or Medicare.
The Stark proposal differs from the Clinton plan in fundamental ways. Under Mr. Stark's proposal, employers and consumers could voluntarily buy private insurance through purchasing pools, or health alliances, but would not have to do so. Premiums would be paid to the Federal Government under Mr. Stark's proposal, not to the alliances as under Mr. Clinton's plan.
Under Mr. Stark's bill, the Secretary of Health and Human Services would set premiums for the comprehensive package of health benefits envisioned under Part C of Medicare. "Employers would pay the premiums to the I.R.S. in the same fashion as payroll taxes are paid," the summary says. Employers would withhold the employees' share of premiums, just as they now withhold Social Security payroll taxes.
Under Mr. Stark's proposal, the Federal Government would set annual goals for public and private health spending, enforced through fee schedules like those used for doctors and hospitals under Medicare.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Hardest Task of the 1990's: Raising Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
If revived inflation is just around the corner, as many seem to believe, you probably won't be finding any at your local KFC chicken restaurant.
"We haven't had a price increase at the retail level since 1989," said Gary Gerdemann, a spokesman for the 5,000-restaurant chain, once known as Kentucky Fried Chicken. "When we see an increase coming, we go and engineer it out." 
 He says the company expects its basic costs to rise about five-tenths of a percent in 1994, but it plans to "engineer out" this amount to hold its own prices steady. This means KFC might switch suppliers, reduce packaging, ship materials in bigger lots, even change a recipe.
When might menu prices go up? In this climate "I could not entertain the thought," Mr. Gerdemann said.
To be sure, the size of KFC, a Pepsico subsidiary, gives it immense bargaining power and it also operates in one of the nation's most ferociously competitive industries.
Yet the forces holding prices down among the giants of fast food -- at McDonald's, a spokesman said his company expected to hold the line for at least the next several months -- are at work throughout the economy. A survey of a random dozen companies disclosed relatively little upward pressure on prices apart from a few highly visible pockets, notably steel, lumber and other building materials.
And even steel may have peaked. "We're beginning to see the price recede already" for scrap, said Terry S. Lisenby, controller for the Nucor Corporation, a steel producer based in Charlotte, N.C.
This suggests that the Federal Reserve can take its time lifting short-term interest rates, which are still barely above zero when adjusted for inflation, while still reassuring long-term investors that the buying power of their capital will be preserved.
"We don't see any threat of inflationary pressures in 1994," Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, said. He noted that wage growth had slowed to a creep and that long-term interest rates are nearly two percentage points lower than they were 15 months ago.
These various findings, sketchy as they are, were supported by figures published yesterday by the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago. Although its overall business barometer posted a small gain for February, the component showing prices paid by corporate buyers fell to 56.7 from 59.3 in January.
National figures on purchasing managers' activity, which normally track local surveys, are to be published today.
With the Federal Reserve in a publicly avowed stance of seeking to prevent a revival of inflation -- as opposed to responding when it appears -- markets have become extraordinarily sensitive in recent weeks to every scrap of price data.
Thus, bond prices tumbled on Feb. 17 when the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported that 30.4 percent of the companies it surveyed in its region were paying higher prices, and none were paying lower prices. An even larger proportion expected higher, rather than lower, prices six months ahead.
On the day of that report, the markets seemed largely to ignore the report that the national Consumer Price Index rose not at all in January, a reaction that might be partly explained by the perception that the Philadelphia survey was more current than the consumer data.
A spokeswoman for the Philadelphia Fed, Rossana Mancini, said yesterday that officials there were surprised by the reaction to the survey, which is confined to about 150 companies having at least 350 employees each, but she added that there was no reason to think the results were skewed.
Many analysts say the findings were simply "overinterpreted," a view shared by some Fed officials in Washington.
Recent data certainly would seem to provide little cause for price worries. For example, producers of goods ready for sale to final users managed to raise prices a mere two-tenths of 1 percent in the last 12 months. And goods in earlier stages of the production pipeline -- raw materials and intermediate goods -- each rose less than 1 percent.
Even in steel, which unlike fast food has enjoyed robust demand during this upturn in the business cycle, the price pressure is blunted. Just ask Woody Brown, president of Kingsbury Inc., a Philadelphia producer of bearings for large machinery.
General Electric, a large customer, told Kingsbury that it wanted a 10 percent price reduction this year. Kingsbury's response has been twofold: to try to get G.E. to accept a higher-quality product at the same price and to try to get concessions from Kingsbury's own suppliers, what Mr. Brown calls "kind of a dominoes effect."
One Kingsbury supplier is Delaware Valley Steel, a service center, which stocks and cuts products to customer specifications. Sometimes, said Michael Weiser, a vice president there, specifications can be changed. In other cases, he leans on the mills he buys from to cut prices or maybe he "eats" an increase himself. And sometimes, as of late when bad weather, high car production and sharply higher tariffs on imports have caused a scramble for supplies, prices just have to be raised.
But while Mr. Weiser expects further increases this year -- perhaps up to 10 percent -- he recognizes the existence of a strong counterforce. "Everybody's under pressure" to keep prices down, he said.
The executives surveyed generally described minimal-to-moderate cost pressures consistent with economists' predictions of a fourth straight year in which the Consumer Price Index rises only about 3 percent.
"We have not been able to fully recover the increases we've been seeing," mainly in wood and steel, said Ken Sendelweck, assistant treasurer for Kimball International, a Jasper, Ind., maker of office furniture with revenues of $625 million a year.
"Certainly there are more signs of inflation now than six months ago," he added, referring to what he sees in everyday life. "But the culture has evolved to the point where if you don't see it on sale, you don't buy it."
 
A 'No Problem' Outlook
 At the Haws Drinking Faucet Company, a producer of fountains and water coolers based in Berkeley, Calif., Patrick T. Kelly said prices of metals, the company's main raw material, are well behaved.
"We do not anticipate a problem, at least in the near term," said Mr. Kelly, who is vice president for sales and marketing. He said the 2 to 3 percent price increases the company put through on its industrial lines earlier this month would probably stand for the whole year and that increases on its commercial products would probably come to 2 to 4 percent when they were decided in April.
In Wichita, Kan., Tory Lehr, controller for Kreonite Inc., described as "fairly steady" the prices of plastics and metals his company uses to make photographic equipment. Even though Kreonite is relatively debt free, Mr. Lehr fretted that the Federal Reserve had added to business costs, including those of its customers, when it raised short-term interest rates recently.
 
A Dissenting View
 The most vociferous exception to the general belief that there is little risk of inflation taking off was expressed by A. C. Phillips, chairman of the Phillips Lumber Company in Cedar Hill, Tex., a suburb of Dallas.
"It's just as crazy as it can be," he said of lumber prices, which rose again recently after a late-1993 pullback and are now 25 percent higher than they were six months ago.
The soaring prices result mainly from a boom in housing, from rebuilding after the summer's Midwest floods and the January earthquake, and from environmental restrictions on logging in the Northwest. Raw materials used for construction have jumped 15.3 percent in the last 12 months, the Producer Price Index shows.
But while Mr. Phillips predicts that the overall inflation rate will be "at least 4 percent" this year, builders he talks to are expressing concern about their houses remaining affordable, especially if the Federal Reserve tightens further.
"I think raising the interest rates was a bit premature," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Buoyed by an Inflation Index

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities moved higher yesterday, buoyed by the Chicago purchasing managers index, which showed an easing of inflation in February, and by more reassuring comments from Federal Reserve officials.
The purchasing managers' report is not the best barometer of future inflation, traders said, but because Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said last week that the report was something the Fed paid attention to, the market did also. 
 The bond market received another lift in spirits from remarks by a Fed official, Lawrence B. Lindsey, who indicated that the quarter-point increase in the Federal funds rate would be enough to quell inflationary pressures.
Both the data and remarks by Mr. Lindsey appeared to have a calming effect on bond investors, whose nerves have become frayed since the central bank's Feb. 4 interest rate increase drove up short-term rates by 25 basis points. A basis point is one- hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Second-Guessing Fed
 The move by the Fed to increase rates and stem inflation before it could pick up steam caused investors to wonder whether the central bank actually did see inflation pressures building. Last week, that investor concern turned into a selloff, and the Fed tried to reassure the markets that inflation was not an immediate threat, adding that short-term interest rates would probably go higher.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 21/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.65 percent, from 6.71 percent on Friday. Interest rates on intermediate maturities were also down, with a three-year note at 5 percent, from 5.05 percent, and a five-year note at 5.57 percent, from 5.63 percent.
The Chicago purchasing managers index, which measures economic activity in the Chicago area, shows a strong economy when it is over 50. It rose to 60.3 in February, compared with 59.6 in January. Its employment component slipped to 52 from 53.3, and the inflation component declined to 56.7 from 59.3
Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at Kemper Securities Inc., said he was happy with the market yesterday, as the long bond backed away from its 6.75 percent resistance level. "Interest rates today," he said, "while a lot higher in yield than a few months ago, were much better than in the recent carnage when the yield on a long term bond was up as high as 6.73 percent."
 
Little Selling Noted
 Last week, a number of cash-pressed foreign investors sold Treasury securities, while there was little such selling in the market yesterday, Mr. Chalasani noted.
This week the market will wade its way through more economic data, including numbers from the National Association of Purchasing Management, expected today. Also scheduled are a revision of the fourth-quarter gross domestic product and personal income for February.
"With today's positive tilt in the market," Mr. Chalasani said, "the upward-revised G.D.P. to a forecast 6.5 percent will have no impact considering the market's gyrations of last week. Perhaps no further tightening will come."
At the Government's regular weekly auction of short-term bills yesterday, the average rates were moderately higher compared with those at last week's auction, with the three-month at 3.40 percent, up 7 basis points, and the six-month at 3.61 percent, up 8 basis points.

HEADLINE: Staten Island Secession, the Debate That Wouldn't Die, Now Reaches Albany

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
The Staten Island secession movement -- a five-year quest that began as a quixotic dream but somehow survived referendums, court tests, political deals and the scorn of doomsayers -- moved toward a climax in the State Legislature yesterday with the unveiling of a bill to make the borough an independent city.
The bill's prospects were not highly rated, even by its chief sponsor, State Senator John J. Marchi, the father of the movement and chairman of a commission that has laid plans for a City of Staten Island, complete with mayor, council, comptroller, courts, schools and other trappings of a modern municipality. 
 The Republican-controlled Senate is expected to support the bill, but not the Democratic-dominated Assembly, mainly because half its members come from the city and are loath to see it divided. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has maintained a studied neutrality, and Senator Marchi conceded yesterday that a vote on the measure was at least a year off.
 
'This Is Very Serious'
 But the Senator and other secessionists, buoyed by overwhelming support among Staten Islanders in a crucial charter referendum last November and the survival of a movement many political observers regarded as a joke when it began, predicted intense negotiations in the Legislature.
"It's not part of a game," Senator Marchi declared at a news conference in the State Capitol in Albany after introducing his measure in the Senate. "This is very serious. This is the business of democracy."
The bill, which would transform the city's smallest borough, with 375,000 people, into the state's second-largest city and about the 40th in the nation, presents legislators and the Governor with choices none relish -- to dismember a city consolidated in 1898, or to rescind the right of self-determination they granted in 1989 by approving legislation that let the secession process begin.
The charter provisions incorporated into the bill introduced yesterday call for a city led by an elected mayor, a 15-member city council and a comptroller as chief financial officer. The officials would be elected in November 1995 and take office on Jan. 1, 1996.
It also calls for a nine-member board of education elected by cumulative voting, in which each voter would have nine ballots and could cast them for any number of candidates or all for one candidate. The system, which strengthens minority candidates, was championed by Lani Guinier, whose nomination to head the Justice Department's civil-rights division was withdrawn by President Clinton last year amid criticism of her writings.
The bill also would set up courts, but retain sitting judges in criminal and civil courts, superior courts and family and surrogate courts. It would shift the College of Staten Island from the City University to the State University of New York and would retain the rights of all civil-service employees.
 
Victories in the Courts
 When the idea of allowing Staten Island residents to vote on secession was raised at that time, legislative leaders expected the plan to die quietly. But largely for political reasons, the Senate, the Assembly and the Governor failed to kill it, and in a 1990 vote the residents opted to secede.
New York City challenged the process in court, saying the secession vote, without the city's consent, violated the "home rule" provision of the state constitution. The state's highest court rejected the city's claim, ruling that the referendum creating a Staten Island charter commission was merely advisory. But it left open whether secession by Staten Island was constitutional.
In the next three years, the 13-member charter commission named by the Governor mapped a plan for a new city. Last Nov. 2, in a second referendum, Staten Island residents voted 2 to 1 to approve the charter.
Secession raises many political and economic issues. Staten Island voters gave Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani his narrow election-victory margin last fall and he would not like to lose the borough. Staten Island gets nearly $200 million more in services from the city than it gives the city in revenues, according to a city study, and secession opponents say that independence would mean huge tax increases and service reductions.
Staten Island could charge the city to use the landfill at Fresh Kills, but might have to pay to use the city's water supply. Beyond such questions, the borough remains linked to the city in intricate ways, from bus and ferry lines to bridges and less tangible ties, including senses of identity and historical continuity.

HEADLINE: Big Losses As Emerging Markets Fall

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The stock and bond markets of the developing countries have lured both big and small investors in search of higher returns in recent months, despite their reputation for high risk and volatility.
That volatility was in evidence last week as these markets -- mainly in Latin America -- fell sharply, ending a phenomenal yearlong bull market and causing hundreds of millions of dollars in losses among leading banks and brokerage firms that deal in their securities. 
 Small investors were hurt as well as many of the new mutual funds that invest in the market fell sharply, leading to a rush of redemptions.
 
 
Dealers Post Losses
 Many of the major dealers in emerging market securities lost $30 million to $100 million in recent weeks, traders estimated yesterday. The largest dealers include J. P. Morgan & Company, Chemical Bank, Merrill Lynch, Salomon Brothers and ING Securities. But the effect of the market drop will not be seen until these companies release their first-quarter reports in April.
Morgan, among the largest dealers in the market, with a reputation for taking large trading positions, was said by traders at other firms to be especially hard hit. A Morgan spokesman declined to comment.
"It was a pretty tough week," said Peter R. Geraghty, president of ING Securities, a unit of a large Dutch bank and a major dealer in emerging markets debt securities. "I'm sure that everybody lost money. People went into the downturn fairly long."
Most dealers keep large inventories of emerging market securities. And those positions -- unlike those in more established markets -- are difficult to hedge, for example, by selling some securities short. Moreover, most dealers continue to be optimistic about the long-term prospects of the markets.
The selloff was initiated by the aftershocks from the Federal Reserve's move to raise American short-term interest rates in early February, an action that has roiled other, more established bond and currency markets around the world.
But the emerging markets fell faster and further than many traders had expected when the rate cut was announced. Brady bonds, the securities created out of restructured bank loans to developing countries, fell 6 percent last week, but rebounded about 1.5 percent yesterday, according to a J. P. Morgan index. Brady bonds rose by 44 percent in 1993.
Emerging market stocks fell by 6 percent last week, according to a Baring Securities index, with stock markets in Mexico, Argentina and Brazil down about 10 percent.
Traders said that the largest dealers handled more than $2 billion of securities on Thursday, the busiest day of the week.
Stephen W. Dizard, the head of emerging markets trading at Salomon Brothers, said his firm was able to keep losses to a minimum.
"We were one of the few houses to take a cautious view," he said. "We were maintaining the positions we needed to serve our customers. Otherwise we were basically out of it."
Salomon was cautious, Mr. Dizard said, because technical indicators showed that many emerging markets investors had become overextended. Many of the banks that hold portfolios of Latin debt securities took the fall in the market as a sign to sell their holdings and take profits, he said.
While the recent losses may hurt the first-quarter results of the leading firms, it is unlikely to lessen their commitment to what has been an extraordinarily profitable business.
J. P. Morgan, for example, had estimated trading revenue from emerging markets activities of $200 million in the fourth quarter of 1993.
Indeed, dealers have grown used to volatile markets, having weathered big declines in 1991 and 1992.
"Most of the big houses have been there, done that, and experienced the good times as well as the bad," Mr. Geraghty said.
Traders said that many hedge funds -- aggressive investment companies that typically manage money raised outside of the United States -- had heavily leveraged positions in emerging markets debt and faced margin calls last week, causing some to sell. Some hedge funds had borrowed as much as 90 percent of their positions, traders said.
The emerging markets problems come at a time when hedge funds also face substantial losses from the volatility in European interest rates and the fall of the dollar against the yen after the United States and Japan recently broke off negotiations over trade.
 
Questions for Mutual Funds
 Among the biggest questions for the future of the emerging markets is how the recent decline will affect investors who have been pouring money into emerging markets as opportunities in the developed world have looked meager. In particular, traders worry that mutual fund investors in particular may get scared off by the sharp decline and redeem their shares.
Fidelity's New Market Income Fund, which invests in emerging market debt securities, fell by 9.5 percent last week. As a result, by last Friday, investors sold a net of about $32 million in the fund, or about 10 percent of its assets, according to figures provided by Jane Jaimieson, a spokeswoman for Fidelity. And they sold more over the weekend, she said.
"A lot of people have been attracted to the fund based on its strong performance are now reacting to the volatility in the market," she said.
Some mutual fund managers suggest, however, that the market drop is actually an opportunity for them to improve their performance.
"We've been buying all last, taking advantages of values we haven't seen for months," said Isabel Saltzman, a portfolio manager at Scudder, Stevens & Clark.
 
Mexican Bond Trading
 Mexican par bonds, one of the most widely traded forms of Mexican Government debt, now trade at a yield of 2.4 percentage points above the equivalent United States Treasury bond, that's an increase from 1.7 percentage points a week ago, Ms. Saltzman said. "To me that's incredible," she added, noting the bonds had fallen to the levels they were at before the signing of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which was seen to improve Mexico's credit rating.
Most emerging market specialists said they expected the markets to rebound slowly over the coming weeks and months because the long-term economies of most developing nations are improving.
"We still believe in the fundamental values in Mexico and Argentina," Ms. Saltzman said. Brazil and Venezuela, she added, will recover more slowly.
Dealers in the emerging markets, however, said they are likely to be more cautious for much of the rest of the year, largely because they have been surprised about how volatile the market remains. Moreover, there has been a recognition that some of the positive events that investors had been expecting -- such as an upgrade of Mexican debt and a completion of the Brazilian debt restructuring -- would be delayed until the end of this year, Mr. Dizard said. "When the time horizon strategy stretches out it makes speculators like broker dealers and hedge funds better sellers than buyers," he said.

HEADLINE: Bond Market Rally Helps Most Stocks Rise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Heartened by some soothing words from a governor of the Federal Reserve Board and some good news on inflation, the bond market rallied yesterday and carried a depressed stock market with it.
The one exception was the Dow Jones industrial average. It rose for much of the day but was dragged down in the session's last 30 minutes. Most of the fall was attributed to a single tobacco stock, Philip Morris, which was hurt by negative comments last Friday by a Government regulator. 
 And some investors were still nervous about inflation, at least judging by the price of gold, which Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, recently cited as an important barometer of inflation fears. In New York, spot gold futures specifying April delivery rose $2.70, to $382.50 an ounce.
 
Economically Sensitive Stocks
 Nonetheless, economically sensitive stocks like United Technologies, Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, and Pacific Gas and Electric benefited from the stock rally, as well as technology stocks like MCI Communications, Nextel, and Comcast, which announced a new alliance.
But the stock market will have to stage several powerful rallies to regain the ground it lost during February, which ended yesterday. By the end of the month, the Dow industrials had lost more than 143 points, or 3.6 percent, and the Standard & Poor's 500 nearly 15 points, or nearly 3 percent. But the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index lost only 7 points, or less than 1 percent.
What may be more important than last month's losses, however, is the fact that the Dow, the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq index have lost only a fraction of the 5 percent or more "correction" that most analysts expect to see in the stock market.
Yesterday, the Dow fell 6.76 points, to 3,832.02, but the S.& P. 500 rose 1.07 points, to 467.14. The Nasdaq index rose 8.72 points, to 792.50, in part because of the MCI-Nextel alliance.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index rose 0.66 point, to 259.23, on moderate volume of 267.6 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,457 to 727. The American Stock Exchange Market Value Index rose 3.89 points, to 471.34.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve Board governor said in a speech to the Credit Union National Association, a trade group, that the central bank may not have to raise interest rates again. The market for the 30-year Government bond rose 21/32 , with a yield of 6.65 percent, down from 6.71 percent on Friday.
Also, February's Chicago purchasing managers index indicated a drop in prices paid by purchasing executives. And traders' demand was strong for about $25 billion of Treasury short-term notes, further underscoring traders' emerging confidence that long-term rates would not rise.
Philip Morris, which is held by many large institutional investors, was the fourth-most-active stock yesterday at 4.3 million shares and accounted for much of the drop in the Dow industrials. Philip Morris dragged down the index 4.5 points and the overall index fell 6.76 points.
Last Friday, the Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, David Kessler, asserted that nicotine was addictive and speculated about stricter Government regulation of cigarettes as a drug.

HEADLINE: For Job-Finding Concern, a Troubled Past

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Its promotion sounds irresistible. The company finds jobs for people on welfare, and, according to its news releases, the government pays nothing for the service until the applicants are hired and working in full-time permanent jobs.
Both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have hailed the company, America Works, as a profit-making solution to the welfare burden. Last month both were on hand as New York City announced that it was joining the state in an arrangement that would double the number of people the company would seek to place in jobs. 
 But an examination of the company's performance shows that America Works has left a trail of unhappy officials in other states. The company performed poorly and cost too much, those officials said, and in one case was accused of improperly billing expenses to the state. Cuomo and Giuliani administration officials say they knew nothing of this discontent before hiring America Works.
Moreover, the company's contracts show that contrary to its assertions that it is paid for job placement alone, America Works gets nearly 20 percent of its $5,500 fee simply for enrolling clients in its program -- whether or not the welfare recipients get jobs.
And some social-policy experts have begun to question whether America Works is cost-effective, saying no scientific studies have been done to evaluate how many of the welfare recipients the company placed could have found jobs on their own or through less expensive programs.
America Works got its first contract with New York State in 1989 to place several hundred welfare recipients a year with private employers. After four years, it had signed up more than 1,000 people, most of whom were still on the job three months after being hired.
Both the Mayor and the Governor have lauded America Works for turning some of the city's nearly 1.1 million government dependents into taxpayers. "The best thing about this place is the free-enterprise system," Mr. Cuomo said of the company, while Mr. Giuliani called it "one of New York and America's success stories."
The Governor even reveled in the ripple effect New York's support for the company would have nationwide. "If, as the governor or the mayor of New York, you say America Works on TV, they hear it out there and it's gold," he said.
But the praise stands in contrast with the experiences during the 1980's described by officials in Ohio, in Erie County, N.Y., and in Massachusetts.
Ohio slashed its contract with America Works in 1986, saying that the company charged too much and had found jobs for too few people in the two years it had been operating there. One board member said placement costs came to $24,000 per person.
Ohio officials estimated that they lost millions of dollars dealing with America Works. "We had a very bad experience," said Gayle Channing, who was executive assistant for human services to former Gov. Richard F. Celeste when the state signed a contract with the company in 1984.
Peter Cove, the founder of America Works, who is now mainly responsible for its marketing and promotion, said his company's problems in Ohio resulted from political sabotage in which the company was forced by a supportive Democratic governor onto Republican-run counties set on seeing it stumble.
Erie County, N.Y., decided not to renew a contract with America Works in 1986 amid criticism by local officials that the company did not find jobs for as many people as it had promised and that it would only work with the most motivated clients.
 
'Serious Problems' In Massachusetts
 And in 1987 Massachusetts canceled its contract with a nonprofit employment agency started in Boston by Mr. Cove and later run by Lee Bowes, Mr. Cove's wife and now the chief operating officer of America Works.
An investigation by the state's Inspector General and an independent audit found that money from the nonprofit group, Transitional Employment Enterprises, had been improperly used to help start America Works and that the state was wrongly billed for expenses like singing telegrams and health club dues.
"There were very serious problems about ethics and financial practices," said Philip W. Johnston, who was the Secretary of Human Services in Massachusetts during the investigation. "The experience was not a happy one for us."
America Works is now exploring the possibility of getting a contract with Massachusetts, but its efforts are being resisted by officials who recall the state's experiences with Mr. Cove and Transitional Employment Enterprises.
Joseph Gallant, the state Commissioner of Public Welfare, wrote a memo last September to Charles D. Baker, the State Secretary for Health and Human Services, outlining his concerns about America Works. In the memo he cited the company's fee, which he said was $2,200 higher in New York and $900 higher in Connecticut than similar job-placement programs used by Massachusetts. He also recounted the state's history with Transitional Employment Enterprises and America Works.
Mr. Cove denied that he, Dr. Bowes, his company or T.E.E. had been involved in any wrongdoing, including the Inspector General's allegation that health club dues and singing telegrams were charged to the state. He said the allegations were "a personal political vendetta" by local officials against him, and he noted that the state investigation never resulted in an indictment.
Abraham Levovitz, a businessman from Brookline, Mass., who owns America Works, said he had heard "rumors and innuendo" about the company when he first considered investing in it in 1986. But after exploring the matter, he said, he concluded that the criticism stemmed from "jealous competitors" and politicians unwilling to concede that a profit-making venture should have a place in getting people off welfare. He strongly defended Mr. Cove and Dr. Bowes.
 
Fees for Training Before Placement
 Since coming to New York, America Works has attracted considerable attention both from the news media and national politicians, who point to a range of benefits for the government, which moves people off welfare, and businesses, which get a tax credit and have a four-month trial period in which the new employee is not on the payroll. Much of the acclaim centers on statements by America Works that it charges only for permanent job placements.
But the company's contracts with New York call for it to be paid about $980 of its $5,500 fee for simply enrolling applicants in a weeklong training course, and $3,855 only two days after a person is hired for a permanent job.
In fact, since 1989 New York State has paid nearly $1 million to America Works for people who never found permanent work -- about $133,000 for people who entered the course but never found jobs and about $857,000 for people who did not stay in their full-time jobs for more than three months.
Dr. Bowes said the company does not actually take money for enrollment unless it makes a placement. But she later said the company "made an exception" in certain cases to recoup the costs of a failed pilot project with the state to place and house homeless people. The project, which she said the company took on at the state's request, "was a disaster, and we invested a lot of time, effort and money."
John Haley, the contract manager for the New York's Office of Employment Programs, said, however, that the America Works contract calls for a payment upon enrollment "and they have always charged us for it."
"They may have made up some of the money they lost at the back end on the homeless project by loading up on the front end," he said. "But they did charge for enrollments that did not result in jobs."
 
Keeping the Promise Of Employment
 Even so, the company has fulfilled its promise of helping the state move people off welfare. Through December, America Works had enrolled 1,058 welfare recipients in the city and had helped 923 of them find jobs. Of these, 767 were still working three months after they were hired permanently.
"We feel we've done a great job and delivered a great product," Dr. Bowes said.
State officials say it costs the government about $9,700 a year to keep a family of three on welfare. But people who have studied welfare reform said that it was virtually impossible to measure the cost-effectiveness of America Works without a controlled examination of whether the people the company placed could have found jobs by themselves or through other programs.
"How much of their success is because the population they work with is more motivated?" said Douglas J. Besharov, an expert on welfare reform at the American Enterprise Institute.
New York officials said that while perhaps they should have been better informed about what happened with America Works elsewhere, they were pleased with the company's performance.
The state is currently in its fourth contract with America Works to find jobs for people receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children, most of whom are women. Until now the state has paid 40 percent of the costs, with the Federal Government paying 60 percent. The city will now split the state's share for 450 new clients, at a cost of about $500,000 for the city.
Ilene Marcus, the city's director of social services, said the administration did little if any research into the company and relied heavily on the state's confidence in America Works when the Mayor decided to join the state contract.
Michael J. Dowling, the state's Commissioner for Social Services, said he learned about the company after reading an article in 1987, and after speaking to people familiar with the company's work in Hartford, where it has been operating since 1985.
Connecticut officials said the company found permanent jobs for only 25 percent of the 3,311 people it enrolled. But given the poor state of the local economy, they said they were satisfied with its performance. Audrey Rowe, Connecticut's Commissioner for Social Services, said the success of America Works was comparable to other training and placement programs that the state uses. But she added that it was the most expensive.
After talking to Connecticut officials, Mr. Dowling met with Mr. Cove and encouraged him to bid for a job-placement contract with the state. America Works won the contract, and Mr. Dowling continues to praise it for being placement-oriented and having performance-based payments.
 
Making Money In Several Ways
 But while most other job-placement programs get paid only after a person has been on the job for 60 to 90 days, city and state officials said, America Works gets the bulk of its fee -- $3,855 -- two days after a person has been placed. The remaining $650 comes if the person is still there after three months.
In addition to the placement fee, America Works also makes money in several other ways. During the four months that their clients are working for a private company on a trial basis, the clients are on the America Works payroll, receiving $4.25 an hour, minimum wage. But America Works collects the worker's market-rate salary from the private employer, usually about $7.25 an hour, Dr. Bowes said.
During those four months America Works is also entitled to collect about $1,000 per person from the Federal Government, under an incentive program to share welfare savings with those who employ people on public assistance. And America Works is also entitled to about half the $2,400 Federal tax credit that businesses get for each disadvantaged worker they hire. The rest goes to the companies that hire the employees from America Works.
Mr. Levovitz said that because of the corporate structure of America Works, he is able to use only about 10 percent of the tax credits.
America Works has recently begun working in Indianapolis and is negotiating to open offices elsewhere. Several social-policy analysts said they worry that other cities and states might invest millions of public dollars in America Works because of its reputation alone.
"The truth is we just don't know whether, even if what they do is good, it is worth the price," said Bob Greenstein, the executive director of the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research organization. "We need to know more about the return on taxpayers' dollars."

HEADLINE: Amnesty of Foes Brings Disarray To Yeltsin Team

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 28

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin suddenly dismissed the chief of the secret police today and canceled a nationwide television address amid signs that his Government was in deep disarray over a parliamentary amnesty for his opponents.
Nikolai M. Golushko, the spy chief, was apparently fired for refusing Mr. Yeltsin's orders to delay the release of prisoners after Parliament granted them amnesty, Russian officials said today, speaking on condition of anonymity. 
 The confusion over Mr. Yeltsin's plan to address the nation began when one of his aides, Georgi Satarov, told reporters at the lower house of Parliament today that the President would make a nationally televised address tonight and announce a decree aimed at "calming passions" after the amnesty for the leaders of the revolt against Mr. Yeltsin's Government in October.
 
Yeltsin Fails to Give Speech
 But there was no address tonight, and television news said no speech had ever been scheduled. However, officials at the television center said plans for an address had been canceled.
The ouster of Mr. Golushko, who has the title of head of the Federal Counterintelligence Service, was almost certainly unrelated to Moscow's tit-for-tat expulsion today of an American official, James L. Morris, listed as a counselor at the United States Embassy.
Mr. Yelstin had broken the old K.G.B., or Committee for State Security, into two parts: foreign intelligence, led by Yevgeny M. Primakov, and the Security Ministry. Recently, Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Golushko to reorganize the Security Ministry into the Federal Counterintelligence Service, supposedly stripping the ministry of border troops and domestic political surveillance.
The Russian officials' view of Mr. Golushko's dismissal was supported indirectly by Aleksei I. Kazannik, an ally of Mr. Yeltsin's who resigned as Prosecutor General two days ago after refusing a similar order from the President.
Mr. Kazannik said today that he had refused a direct order from Mr. Yeltsin to keep in prison seven of the men who led the October revolt. Mr. Yeltsin's aides argued that Parliament had exceeded its powers and had granted a pardon to those not yet tried instead of an amnesty to convicted criminals.
Mr. Kazannik said Mr. Golushko had received a similar order.
 
Leaders of Revolt Released
 On Saturday, former Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, former parliamentary Speaker Ruslan I. Khasbulatov and other leaders of the rebellion walked out of the prison where they had languished since early October, when Mr. Yeltsin sent in tanks to shell the Parliament building. More than 140 people died.
Elections on Dec. 12 produced a new Parliament dominated by nationalists and Communists who supported the amnesty as a direct political challenge to Mr. Yeltsin. Under the new Constitution that Mr. Yeltsin pushed for, he has no right to veto an amnesty declaration and it requires no vote in the upper house, where he has more supporters.
Mr. Rutskoi and Mr. Khasbulatov view the elections and the amnesty as a justification of their actions in opposing Mr. Yeltsin's dissolution of the old Parliament and Constitution. Mr. Yeltsin's recent, more nationalist tone and support for a softer, slower transition to market economics are also closer to Mr. Rutskoi's and Mr. Khasbulatov's previous political positions.
Mr. Morris, who arrived in Moscow only recently and is presumed to be the C.I.A. station chief here, was given seven days to leave Russia after Moscow's chief intelligence officer in the United States, Aleksandr Lysenko, was expelled by Washington in response to the case of Aldrich H. Ames, a C.I.A. official who is charged with spying for Moscow.
 
No Further Expulsions Now
 The White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said today that while Washington regretted the expulsion of Mr. Morris, there were no plans for now to expel any other Russian official.
The C.I.A.'s Moscow station, counter to the notion bred by spy fiction, has always been relatively small given the intensity of Soviet surveillance, former intelligence officials say. During the cold war there were as few as two operative C.I.A. agents in Moscow, and during the 1950's there was no station chief, the officials say.
In the early 1960's a respected officer named Paul Garbler became station chief, under the cover of assistant naval attache. But he fell under suspicion from the agency's chief counterintelligence officer, James J. Angleton. Mr. Garbler was compensated by the C.I.A. in the 1980's for the damage done to his reputation by Mr. Angleton.
Yeltsin spokesmen said today that Mr. Golushko's dismissal was for "personal reasons." But Lefortovo prison, where the amnestied prisoners were held, was under the control of Mr. Golushko's agency until transferred by presidential decree on Saturday to the Prosecutor General. That suggests that Mr. Yeltsin thought Mr. Kazannik would keep the prisoners after Mr. Golushko refused to do so.
The likely replacement for Mr. Golushko will be his deputy, Sergei Stepashin, the Itar-Tass news agency said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Protests Expulsion
 WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (Special to The New York Times) -- A State Department spokesman said today that the United States "protested in the strongest possible terms" the expulsion of Mr. Morris.
The spokesman, Mike McCurry, said Washington's decision on Friday to expel Mr. Lysenko "was an entirely justified action in light of the involvement of the Russian intelligence service in the Ames espionage case."
By contrast, he said, "the expulsion of the U.S. diplomat from Moscow is purely an act of unjustified retaliation."
The spokesman would not identify Mr. Morris by name or title, referring to him only as "an embassy officer."
"We reserve the right to take further action if there are others who are implicated in connection with the Ames case," Mr. McCurry said. "We will continue to assess, as that investigation and prosecution develops, what further measures might be necessary."

HEADLINE: Mexico Seen as Barrier To a Broader Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is concerned that the Mexican Government may seek to block its plans to bring more Latin American countries into the North American Free Trade Agreement, an internal Administration document shows.
Congress has required President Clinton to list by the end of June those countries with which the White House plans to negotiate free trade deals. 
 But a lengthy memorandum reviewing the Administration's trade policy plans for Latin America shows hidden concerns, not expressed publicly by American officials, that Mexico could block those plans.
At the heart of the concerns is a worry, born of Clinton and Bush Administration contacts with Mexican officials, that Mexico will not want to share its special access to the United States economy with other countries that have similar low-wage economies and compete with Mexico.
 
Fears of an Alliance
 The chief worry is that Mexico will ally itself with the next entrant into the free trade pact and the two countries will together prevent the United States and Canada from proceeding with their plans for a giant free trade area covering the Western Hemisphere, with potential extensions into Asia.
"Mexico reportedly is not interested in allowing other countries in the region into an arrangement that offers considerable benefits, which were achieved because of its relationship to the United States," the document says, with the word "not" printed in boldface type. "Obtaining consensus to expand the Nafta could become increasingly difficult if Mexico's reluctance were overcome for the admission of a couple more countries (e.g. Chile) and one of these newly acceded nations blocks further FTA negotiations."
The document also suggests a way to get around such objections by limiting the voting power of future entrants to the North American pact. While the United States, Canada and Mexico would have equal votes on decisions to expand the pact, future entrants would only receive votes based on the volume of their trade.
 
A Strong Denial
 A copy of the memorandum was obtained from a person involved in the Administration's decision-making on trade policy. The document was part of the basis for an inconclusive White House discussion in mid-February of United States trade policy regarding Latin America, said an official who insisted on anonymity.
Mexico's Ambassador to the United States, Jorge Montano, strongly denied in a recent interview that Mexico would seek to block expansion of the North American pact. He pointed out that Mexico had negotiated a separate free trade pact with Chile.
Charlene Barshefsky, one of three deputies for Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, wrote the memorandum to her counterparts at six other agencies, including the State Department, Treasury Department and the National Economic Council. She declined to comment on the document.
Anne Luzzatto, the press secretary for the Office of the United States Trade Representative, said a review of trade policy regarding Latin America was under way, but she declined to discuss the memorandum.
The internal document proposes that the President publicly offer membership in the North American pact to solidly democratic governments in Latin America -- and possibly Asian countries like Singapore -- that meet several criteria, including following several years of economic reforms approved by the International Monetary Fund.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
The Inventive Meets the Tailored in Italy

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, Feb. 28

 BODY:
With the local economy scraping bottom and recovery spotty in prime markets like the United States and Japan, Italian designers faced a quandary as they prepared their fall collections. Should they jolt the world with wildly inventive designs or focus on the expert tailoring and luxurious sportswear that made their reputations? Both approaches were evident as the shows for fall, the most important selling season of the year, began over the weekend.
Perhaps more important than these design decisions was the emphasis most major houses placed on their secondary collections. These lower-priced and generally younger-looking clothes are projected to raise interest in fashion, which seems to have lost the priority it enjoyed in the world market in pre-recession days. 
 The single biggest trend in the first days of the shows was the emphasis on men's styling. The clothes range from classic pants suits by Antonio Fusco, which are worn conventionally with a handkerchief in the breast pocket and a tie, to the frock coats of Dolce & Gabbana.
With their use of corsetry details and their revival of Beatles styles, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana established their house as a major trend-setter. Now, they are pushing the men's wear look, with black fitted jackets or long coats, pipestem pants and white shirts. It works just fine.
 
Coral and Apple Green
 They make other fashion suggestions, like patchwork dresses, clear plastic jackets and tweedy shorts to keep their reputation as avant-gardists. But it is their neat black suits that will be remembered as their main contribution to fashion for fall.
The mannish pants suit turns up at Gucci, too, but the emphasis is on long fitted jackets over short fluttery skirts, and colors like coral and apple green. With high-heel ankle boots and opaque white tights, the effect is feminine despite the crisp tailoring.
Gianni Versace introduced his two secondary collections, Istante and Versus, in a luxurious tent set up in the courtyard of his home in the center of Milan. Both shows had a lively, upbeat feeling.
The surprise at Istante was the return of the dress, always very short and usually with a high waistline. For a generation of women brought up on jackets and skirts or pants, these shapely dresses in colors like apple green and aqua suggest a different way to put themselves together.
Versus is a jazzier collection of fake fur pieces imitating spotted cats, along with leathers in colors like bubble-gum pink. Most of the skirts are astonishingly short. When a mid-length style appears on the runway, it's an eye-opener. Perhaps Mr. Versace is just testing the waters.
Valentino's Oliver collection mixes fragile chiffon with sturdy wool or velvet. The chiffon is used for wispy short skirts or easy pants, and it contrasts with the thicker wool jackets. For added impact, the thin fabric is shaded in bands from yellow to pink or blue to purple. The idea works best when the contrasts are not too extreme, as in a gray flannel jacket over chiffon pants in different shades of gray. A big knitted cardigan over the jacket adds another gray element to the interplay of textures.
 
Revitalizing the Missonis
 A year ago, the daughter of Ottavio and Rosita Missoni branched out on her own, making clothes to attract women in their 20's and 30's. Calling her venture Team Angela Missoni, she avoided the intricate knitwear patterns that are her parents' signature. In fact, her best styles are all black or all white: long skinny jumpers over sheer blouses. Tunics that fall in handkerchief points, wrapped waists and hips, and bra-like tops pulled over knitted cardigans are some of her lively ideas.
Buoyed by their daughter's success, the Missonis have revitalized their own collection. In addition to their intricate knitted patterns, as dense as Persian carpets, they have introduced broad stripes in colors like terra cotta and blue. Fish-net panels and three-dimensional effects vary the textures. A metal thread woven through or a flash of sequins adds a special glow for evening.
The stripes look young and uncomplicated in short skirts with waist-length jackets for day. Scoop-neck dresses with flippy skirts can be worn over bare skin or T-shirts. Long knitted coats wrap everything up cozily.
Minimalism has come to Milan. Alan Cleaver and Keith Varty, two British designers who have made Byblos a young, swinging Milanese company, stick to basic colors like silver, white and medium blue. Fitted jackets in varied lengths, easy coats and an occasional bolero are key pieces. Everything looks neat and wearable. So what if all the models wore tousled blond wigs. This is fashion, after all.

GRAPHIC: Photos: High-waist dress with short skirt is from Istante, one of Gianni Versace's secondary lines. Gucci's men's wear look includes a miniskirt. Isabella Rossellini models a long fitted jacket and narrow pants from Dolce & Gabbana. Simple wool jumper dress from Team Angela Missoni is worn over a sheer blouse. Sport swingy tank-top dress by Ottavio and Rosita Missoni is worn over opaque tights. (Photographs by Vittoriano Rastelli for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Obstacle-Strewn Road to Rethinking the Numbers on AIDS

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 28

 BODY:
Determining how many Americans are infected with the virus that causes AIDS is an imprecise science at best. But Federal health officials are trying again, and it appears that the current estimate of one million will be lowered.
The estimate, made in 1989, represents the midpoint of the range reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. It set the figure at 800,000 to 1.2 million. The widely cited one million midpoint figure has been attacked as too low or too high, depending on the critic's point of view. 
 The centers plan to make a new estimate in July, and in preparation the agency invited independent experts to meet last week to report and review relevant data. Although some of their estimates went as high as a million, most ranged from 600,000 to 800,000.
The new estimate could have critical health, political and economic ramifications. For planning purposes, health officials need to know where and how many new cases of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, are occurring. Determining the national trend in H.I.V. infections and identifying geographical hot spots is crucial to making budgets, developing sound public health policy, evaluating the success of prevention programs and determining research needs and priorities.
There are various reasons why it has been so difficult to obtain accurate information about H.I.V. Laws around the nation preclude testing a person for H.I.V. without permission. Furthermore, many people at high risk refuse to take part in household surveys because of concerns about protecting confidentiality and insurance coverage. Proposals for mandatory testing have met with strong resistance from civil libertarians, advocacy groups and others.
Another obstacle to making accurate national estimates is the fact that the United States is battling not one but several AIDS epidemics, and they are not behaving in the same way.
The main epidemic has been and still seems to be among white gay men. But among that group, the incidence of new H.I.V. infections seems to be leveling off, if not declining. Meanwhile, other epidemics, particularly the one involving black women in the South, seem to be rising. The various patterns of the epidemics add to the complexities of determining how many Americans are infected with H.I.V. and how the number has changed over recent years.
Projecting a national total from small, focused studies is fraught with risk. Participants at the meeting pointed to many gaps in the available data as they assessed the strengths and weaknesses of the various statistical methods for making the estimates.
"There's no one way to do it that is right," said Dr. Meade Morgan, an expert with the centers, explaining why his team would check results from several methods against each other before making an estimate.
To health officials, the absolute number of H.I.V. infections is less important than whether the number of new H.I.V. infections is rising or falling. Ideally, statisticians want to know that number each year. But because such data are not collected nationally for H.I.V. and no national study has encompassed all high-risk groups, extrapolations must be made from small studies and surveys.
Calculations from cases of full-fledged AIDS can also be helpful. A major problem in using AIDS cases, however, is that they then reflect the status of the epidemic in the year individuals became ill with AIDS and not when they became infected with the virus, which is generally a silent process that produces no symptoms.
The delay in progression from infection to AIDS in adults is, on average, about 10 years, though the number can vary significantly.
Dr. James Curran, who coordinates all AIDS activities at the Atlanta centers, said a major problem was lack of knowledge about who had become infected with the virus over the last five years. "We don't know whether the incidence of H.I.V. in the United States in 1993 was different than it was in 1991 or 1989, and we do not know yet whether the current figure exceeds or is less than the number of deaths from AIDS," he said.
Dr. Harold W. Jaffe, the centers' top AIDS scientist, said there was ample evidence that the newly infected were different, as a group, from those who were getting infected 10 years ago and that the driving force of the epidemic was changing.
Several studies strongly suggest that the AIDS epidemic may have peaked nationally among gay men. As of last September, the latest month for which data are available, gay men had accounted for 183,344 of the 334,344 cases reported in this country since the disease was first recognized in 1981.
But the transmission of H.I.V. has by no means stopped in gay men. Studies in Chicago and Denver showed that 2.5 percent of gay men in their teen-age years and early 20's were becoming infected each year. Another study showed that despite an overall decline in new infection rates, many young gay men were becoming infected with H.I.V. in San Francisco and Berkeley, Calif.; the highest rates are in black gay men.
The question is whether there is enough transmission among young gay men to create a second wave of AIDS that would rival the one of a decade ago when the figures for H.I.V. infection ranged from 10 to 20 percent a year.
A federally sponsored national survey of childbearing women shows that the number of H.I.V. infections is rising gradually among women in general, but has risen sharply among black women in the South.
Participants said the number of infected users of intravenous drugs was probably not increasing.
Statistical data about other diseases are often as imprecise as those for H.I.V. infection. Advocacy groups for a particular disease tend to cite the highest number of affected people to show the magnitude of the ailment's effects on society and to get a larger share of Federal health money. But figures for other diseases seem to get less scrutiny than do those for H.I.V.
Officials at the Federal health centers say their estimate will be based on the best available scientific data. But an estimate lower than a million is bound to be criticized.
"So many people have so much invested in the epidemic that anything that makes it look like it is going away, that there may not be as many infected people as some once had thought, causes panic among the investors," one conference participant said in an interview. Funds are often cut for diseases perceived as no longer being public health threats. Sometimes a resurgence follows. Tuberculosis is a striking recent example.
If the new estimate for H.I.V. infection were substantially lower than a million, some fear that the public and the Government would see less need for financing for education and prevention, the very tools that have been credited with stemming the rise in some areas, if not nationally.
"It is very scary what the fallout from low numbers could be," said Dr. Neil Schram, a member of the Federal centers' advisory committee on H.I.V. prevention and a representative of the American Association of Physicians for Human Rights. "My fear is that when people look at the numbers, everybody is going to feel the epidemic is over."
A new problem has arisen to increase the difficulty of revising the estimate. In 1993, the centers began using a revised definition of AIDS, leading to a significant increase in the number of cases. For the first nine months of 1993, 85,526 cases were reported, a rise of 148 percent over the 35,479 cases reported for the same period in 1992. Any statistical method based on AIDS cases used to arrive at a new estimate of H.I.V. infections must take account of the changed definition.
To overcome the problem for future estimates, researchers are trying to develop new ways to estimate the number of newly infected people from spot surveys that could eliminate the need to follow large groups for many years.
Even if the C.D.C. substantially lowers the estimate from one million this July, however, one point about the epidemic seems certain: AIDS is not going away. The disease that was unknown before 1981 will remain endemic in this country. In what numbers remains to be seen.
