HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Aqueduct Measures Snow by Days Lost

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
What is so rare as a day in June? How about one in January or February with actual racing at Aqueduct?
Those days were especially rare in this year of snow followed by sleet followed by snow. And from the highest track official to the lowliest railbird, cancellation of 14 of the first 51 racing days of the winter season, most recently last Wednesday , is anything but a joke. 
 "This has been absolutely the worst winter I've ever had the privilege to be involved with," Richard Migliore, a veteran New York jockey, said between races on a recent race day between snows.
Noting that cancellations had cost him many of his rides, Migliore pointed out that jockeys who don't ride don't get paid.
"We're not on salary," he said.
Bob, a clubhouse bartender who preferred to keep his last name to himself, echoed the point, saying his tips were down 20 percent. "I can't sell to people who aren't here," he said.
 
A Month Behind
 Robbie Davis, a leading New York jockey, noted that the series of snow days and freeze-outs had cost local riders more than an occasional payday. "It knocks you out of any chance of being in the top 10 in the nation," he said. "You're giving everybody else a whole month head start practically."
Even some people not involved in racing have been affected. Gertrude Arbona, for example, isn't a bettor, but she can tell when Aqueduct is closed. If it gets to be afternoon and her 81-year-old husband, Ray, is still underfoot, she knows something is amiss.
Like many inveterate horseplayers, Ray Arbona has a wintertime ritual, in his case, hopping the Q27 bus at his Bayside corner in Queens, transferring to the Q46 to Kew Gardens, then taking the Q37 to Aqueduct.
Ask him a familiar question as he comes away from an automatic betting machine after making his hour-long, three-bus trip and Arbona supplies a familiar answer: "I've lost a few dollars."
Those losses are the lifeblood of the New York thoroughbred industry, and according to Jerry McKeon, the president of the New York Racing Association, the not-for-profit corporation that runs the thoroughbred tracks in New York State, this year there have been far too few of them.
"Depressing," he said. "This game is one that is very much tied to momentum. If you get on a negative roll, it takes days to overcome that, and we've never been able to. We'll get going and then two or three days later, Whack! an ice storm or a snowstorm."
The season has been especially frustrating because the interruptions have kept officials from getting a reading on this winter's bold new experiment, supplementing a reduced card of seven live races with betting on five simulcast races from Gulfstream Park in Florida. (On weekends, the mix is now nine live races and five on simulcast.)
 
Live Races Preferred
 The mixed card was necessary, McKeon said, because recession and competition have cut the number of horses available for Aqueduct's winter season by some 40 percent, from more than 2,400 last year to fewer than 1,500 this year.
In theory, a card of 12 races, or 14, should be more profitable than the traditional nine-race format, especially since the track gets to keep an extra percentage point of the betting on the televised races.
In practice it doesn't work out that way, largely, McKeown said, because a live race draws about twice as much betting as a televised race, even one involving superior horses and bigger cards.
"People prefer to root for the home team," he said.
 
The Money Drain
 Even so, the experiment has shown promise, with the first six-day run of races this year generating a larger handle than the comparable week a year ago.
Over all, though, comparisons between 1993 and 1994 are disheartening. Attendance, now running more than 100,000 below last year, is off more than 35 percent, and even including this year's handle on Gulfstream simulcasts, total on-track betting is down some $30 million, or more than 30 percent.
Thanks in part to an unprecedented streak of good, or at least racing-possible, weather recently, the attendance and handle gaps have narrowed considerably since the last big snow, on Feb. 11.
Part of the catchup came over the three-day Presidents Day weekend, when the track, as a gesture of appreciation to its frustrated fans, waived admission and parking fees, drawing more than 10,000 fans on each of the three days.
The 1993-94 comparisons were especially satisfying on Sunday. A total of 10,989 fans bet $2.6 million. That was $2.6 million more than a year earlier, when racing was canceled because of snow.
Despite the recent catchups, the racing association expects losses to be bigger than usual this winter. The association holds a winter season to subsidize the industry, expecting to lose about $7 million (and to make it up in the spring, summer and fall seasons). This winter's losses are projected to increase to $11 million, more than can be made up later.
In addition to lost revenues, operating costs, which McKeon says generally run five to six times higher in winter than in other seasons, have been even higher this winter.
At Belmont, where Aqueduct horses are stabled, there are 60 barns, each with 6 doors, said McKeon. Factor in the single-digit temperatures of one memorable January night and the result was 360 doors frozen shut.
For safety reasons, crews on double shift receiving time-and-a-half pay cracked open two doors in each barn, then cracked ice on the horse paths so the horses could get to the training track. "Then we had to put chains on the trucks so we could get the horses to Aqueduct," McKeown said.
And after all that? "Racing was canceled," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Because of bad weather, Aqueduct has been forced to cancel 14 of the first 51 racing days of the winter season. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Our Tourists Can Save Russia

 BODY:
1To the Editor:
Not that I dispute your facts on crime in Moscow in "Riding Shotgun in Capitalist Russia" (Business Day, Feb. 16), but by overdramatizing events that have become commonplace in our own society, you do damage to one of the few areas of Russia's fledgling free market economy that work: tourism. 
 Tourism is one of the few ways Americans can help support economic transition in Russia without having to support massive United States aid. Tourism puts hard currency into the system quickly. A post-cold-war trading and tourism partner creates a safer world than a poverty-stricken closed nation with nuclear arms. Not to mention the mutual understanding that develops when people from different countries visit one another.
I am co-owner of an American-Russian company that arranges travel and business needs for people who visit Russia. As a result of your article, we received four cancellations, two from New York and two from Florida. Yes, only four, but how many Russian lives are affected?
The four guides and four drivers they would meet in their 12-day stay would continue to be employed by a private company (instead of a state-owned factory). In addition, the gratuities those Russians would likely receive from those four people would feed their families for a week! The two managers in Moscow and St. Petersburg would receive a profit-sharing bonus in dollars that are deposited in a United States bank for them to spend at the end of the season. (Are you listening, American retailers and bankers?) The Russian families where the tourists booked a "dinner party in a home" may not without them have meat this month.
Then, there are baggage handlers, taxi drivers, street artists, waiters, hotel maids and bartenders, who depend on tourists to provide security for their families in a chaotic system. As a side note, the female manager of our Moscow office was an engineer in a state-owned institute making $100 a month just four years ago. Last month she bought her family an apartment in Moscow with her profit sharing from last season. The manager of our St. Petersburg office, formerly a low-paid teacher, and his wife spent last November in the United States. They spent $2,000, an unheard-of sum two years ago. This is the free market working, folks!
Think about how the New York City Visitors and Convention Bureau would react if foreign newspapers started publishing articles about how dangerous New York City is. If you're not sure how much money and public relations effort would be spent to protect New York tourism, just ask Florida.
And, readers, if you've been considering visiting Russia, but The Times has convinced you it's too dangerous, think about this. Last year in New York nine innocent commuters were gunned down on a suburban train. How many gang-related assaults and murders did the New York area experience last month? How many foreigners were ripped off by unscrupulous taxi drivers last year? How many people get mugged every day?
People travel to understand one another's cultures, to see the world with new eyes, to walk in another's shoes. Russia needs America more than ever, not because of our aid, but because of our people. I know a lot of Russians (and Americans) who would be happy to tell you about what's beautiful, what's hopeful and why you shouldn't miss seeing Russia this year!
 
LINDA APPLETON
Redondo Beach, Calif., Feb. 21, 1994

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Recovery Room

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
We spent three weeks where it never snows and there lost touch with the news, which is often fatal to journalists. In journalism survival requires a zealot's belief in the importance of the present moment, and three weeks of refuge from present moments can leave that faith in tatters.
Three weeks without immersion in the millions of absolutely vital present moments that constitute journalism's definition of three weeks -- Ah reader, would you believe how little of consequence really happens in three weeks? 
 Would you believe maybe nothing?
"A cease-fire in the Balkans you call nothing?" someone will ask, someone fleetingly lifting eyes and ears from the cannonading of present moments pouring in from CNN, New York Times, Connie Chung, "Inside Edition," ESPN, "Oprah," Time, "Entertainment Tonight," the whole, in fact, madhouse of what is called "information," such is the parlous state of the language, Heaven having refused to help us.
"Information," indeed. Information's job is to enrich us, not to bury us in popcorn.
Information, as opposed to "information," would not shout of a cease-fire in the Balkans, but sigh quietly of "another cease-fire" in the Balkans, nudging us to reflect that in lands where firing has gone on eternally it would be foolish to hope for much from "another cease-fire."
As for the mass murder in Israel, it is notable for the great number of victims in a single incident, but matched against the number of Arabs and Israelis killed since their killings began years ago, it is a trifling number. Diplomacy will or won't be impeded, but only for the moment, and afterward it will succeed or fail in its own time, and probably, over the long run, do both.
You ask, "After three weeks of abstinence from present moments, how do you know of these things?"
A quick study, reader. That's how. The journalist who cannot fly from Washington tonight, land in Ulan Bator tomorrow afternoon and three hours later file a comprehensive report on the political, economic and moral crisis confronting Ulan Bator is not worth the cardboard it takes to make a press card. He must be a quick study.
Preparing to re-enter the world of present moments, I buried myself two hours ago in the newspapers of the past three weeks. They tell of the Balkans and Israel and of incessant blizzards coating the north in ice, abandoned cars and those sinister creations of the snow-removal artists, ancient blackened mountains of curbside snow that are urban America's winter wonderland.
These stories provide a shameful twinge of sadistic pleasure for one who has passed three weeks where the climate was perfect day and night and the only annoyance a woodpecker wearing his beak out on the house's clapboards.
Still, even the evil-weather stories show how fragile journalism's memory can be. They bring to mind an insupportable New York winter 10 or 12 years ago when a grotesque black tower of snow stood, apparently unmeltable, at Hudson and Jane Streets well into August, if I remember correctly, and if not, so what? "The artistic lie is always preferable to the inartistic truth, except in journalism," according to Henry James, who despised journalism.
And no wonder, I say to myself, as I wade through thousands of square yards of prose about young people engaged in ice-and-snow sports and dance in Norway.
This is intertwined with a tawdry tale about one Tonya Harding, whose fate in these frigid endeavors so fascinates all America that scarcely a couch potato can bear to turn off the television no matter how mercilessly CBS wields its brutal commercials.
So obsessed with Tonya Harding, America apparently lost all interest in President Clinton. The President, whoever he be, is America's superstar, for the obvious reason that Presidents lend themselves to the simple situation-comedy format which television, being an entertainment medium, needs to convey news. Imagine trying to get the TV audience interested in some 500 Congressmen and their families.
So for three weeks of breathtakingly vital present moments, President Superstar gave way to a sad waif in an ice rink. The thought begins to thrill me. Must be time to resume journalism.

HEADLINE: U.S. AND RUSSIANS BROKER NEW PACTS FOR A BOSNIA PEACE

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Working on parallel diplomatic fronts, the United States and Russia brokered separate agreements today that were meant to move Bosnia and Herzegovina closer to peace.
In Moscow, Russia succeeded in persuading the leader of the Bosnian Serbs to permit the reopening of the airfield near the Bosnian Muslim town of Tuzla for relief flights of food and medicine. In Washington, negotiators for the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Croats signed a framework agreement to unite the parts of the country that are under their control. 
 While the United States and Russia have a general agreement that Washington will pursue the Bosnian Muslims and Moscow will work on its Serbian friends, the separate diplomatic negotiations do not a represent a carefully orchestrated effort to end the 23-month war in Bosnia, which has cost more than 200,000 lives.
 
U.S. Was Not Informed
 Indeed, senior American officials acknowledged that the United States was not even aware of the details of the latest Russian plan that was accepted in Moscow today by the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, after Russia promised to send its own observers to the Tuzla airfield.
While the two initiatives reflect the common desire in both capitals to find a formula for peace, the Russians are also motivated by a determination to foreclose any use of military force against the Serbs, who share the Orthodox Christian religion with the Russians. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization has threatened air strikes against the Serbs if they refuse to allow the airport to open by next Monday.
 
Second Set of Concessions
 Dr. Karadzic announced the concession on Tuzla after meeting today with the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev. The decision came a day after NATO fighter jets shot down four Serbian airplanes that the Western alliance said had violated a United Nations-appointed no-flight zone.
It was the second time in less than a month that the Bosnian Serbs have made major concessions under the protective arm of Russia, in the face of Western threats of force. Last week, Russia persuaded them to remove their heavy guns from hills ringing Sarajevo before NATO carried out its threat to bomb them.
But senior Administration officials said that Russia would be allowed to send observers to the airport only under the auspices of the United Nations peacekeeping force.
In a last-minute, but elaborately choreographed, signing ceremony held by Secretary of State Warren Christopher in the State Department, Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic of Bosnia, Foreign Minister Mate Granic of Croatia and Kresimir Zubak, the political leader of the Bosnian Croats, signed an accord to create a Swiss-like federation of cantons or municipalities made up of areas where a majority of the population is either Muslim or Croat. The cantons will have authority over police, education, culture, housing, public services, tourism and radio and television.
Both populations would enjoy equal protection under the law, with a central government responsible for foreign affairs, national defense and commerce.
 
Economic Union
 In a separate signing, Mr. Silajdzic also accepted a preliminary accord with Mr. Granic to join the Muslim-Croatian entity in Bosnia in a financial and economic confederation with the Republic of Croatia.
"This agreement shows how much can be accomplished, even after bitter years of violence, when the two sides sit down together," Mr. Christopher said, adding, "It shows that peace is possible.
In a statement issued by the White House, President Clinton praised both agreements as "a major step in the search for peace in Bosnia," pledging that, "The United States will continue to work closely with the parties throughout this process."
Although Mr. Christopher and the negotiators heralded the accord as a breakthrough, its obvious deficiency is that it does not deal with the Serbian faction in Bosnia, which controls more territory than either of the other two factions. Senior Administration officials acknowledged that as the military victors in the Bosnian war, the Serbs will not have much reason to join the Muslim-Croat entity, even with substantial inducement.
The goal of today's Muslim-Croatian agreement is to create an economically and politically independent state that would avoid a three-way partition of Bosnia and Herzegovina along ethnic lines.
 
A Loose Confederation
 A likely scenario will now be for the United States and the Europeans to press for the newly created union to join with the Serb faction in a loose confederation with separate executive authority, as envisioned under current United Nations-European Union negotiations in Geneva, a senior Administration official said.
But other senior Administration officials hope that the Serbs will somehow prefer to be aligned with what is envisioned as a democratic, economically vibrant Muslim-Croat entity rather than to try to secede from Bosnia and be annexed to Serbia.
A senior administration official briefing reporters after the signing ceremony conceded that the agreement covers only 32 to 33 percent of the territory of Bosnia. The rest is controlled by the Serbs.
Brent Scowcroft, the former national security adviser and now a director of the Forum for International Policy, told reporters today that the agreement between the Bosnian Muslims and Croats would do little more than allow diplomats to claim a triumph.
"If anyone thinks this is going to put pressure on the Serbs," he said, "it's not going to work."
 
Details to Come
 Today's agreement grew out of informal discussions last year between President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, who will now be called upon to negotiate the details of their own confederation.
Talks between the two Governments are expected to begin in Vienna this Friday, and the two leaders have been given a deadline of March 15 for completing work on their confederation.
As an inducement to the Croatian Government in Zagreb, the initiative holds out the promise of substantial economic and political incentives. Croatia and the Croats in Bosnia would no longer be threatened by economic sanctions. And the confederation of the Sarajevo and Zagreb Governments would be given access to Western European economic structures and be invited to participate in NATO's "Partnership for Peace" plan that will extend some of the benefits of NATO, but not membership, to the former Warsaw Pact countries.
The accord creating the Muslim-Croat entity guarantees all refugees and displaced people the right to return to their homes and the right to "have restored to them any property of which they were deprived in the course of ethnic cleansing and to be compensated for any property which cannot be restored to them."
 
A Major Concession
 In today's accord, the Croats made a major concession in accepting the idea of creating ethnic-based municipalities. The Croats fear that they will be dominated by the Muslims, who outnumber them, and initially demanded a union of two discrete Muslim and Croatian pieces of territory, rather than a federated state.
In a suggestion of how ambitious the agreement's goals are, it envisions a common army after a transitional period, despite the fact that the Bosnian Government and the Croats have been locked in bitter fighting for nearly a year.
But it leaves some details to be resolved, including a precise map defining the borders of the cantons because so many of the borders depend on the Serbs. "There cannot be a final agreement without a map, and a map depends on the Serbs," one senior official said.
The White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said that Russia did not inform the United States in advance of its initiative on Tuzla, but added that this was not a matter of United States concern. "I think they're trying to be helpful," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic of Bosnia, left, congratulating Kresimir Zubak, the Bosnian Croat political leader, after they signed a pact yesterday to unite territories they control. Foreign Minister Mate Granic of Croatia was between them, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher was behind him. (Paul Hosefros/New York Times) (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Senate Turns Down Amendment On Balancing the Federal Budget

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The Senate tonight rejected a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget, killing the proposal for at least this year.
The vote was 63 to 37, leaving the measure four votes short of the two-thirds majority required for a constitutional amendment. 
 The measure, sponsored by Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, never stimulated the grass-roots support its backers had hoped for. It failed after intense, skilled opposition by Senators Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia and George J. Mitchell of Maine, who raised the specter of political, economic and constitutional perils.
 
Maneuvering by Opponents
 The two Senators also solidified wavering opponents by arranging for a vote on a much weaker version of a balanced budget amendment, a plan that was overwhelmingly defeated but still provided a political comfort zone for a few senators. Seven senators voted for the weaker version and rejected the Simon version.
Backers in the House insisted that they would still press for a vote there next month, but Mr. Mitchell, the majority leader, declared he would not bring it up again in the Senate.
"This is it," Mr. Mitchell said. "Under no circumstances over which I have any control will this be brought up again, this session, this Congress, this year."
But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said: "It's going to happen. If not this year, next year or the next year."
 
'Political Posturing'
 Mr. Mitchell delivered the closing speech against the proposal, saying, "The balanced budget amendment now before us is a bold example of political posturing." But he said he understood that some members felt a need "for political cover."
Forty-one Republicans and 22 Democrats voted for the amendment tonight, while 3 Republicans and 34 Democrats voted against it. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, voted in favor. The five Democratic Senators from the New York metropolitan area -- Bill Bradley and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York -- voted against it.
In an interview, Mr. Mitchell said many members of both parties had made it clear to him that they thought the amendment was a bad idea but feared for their re-elections. "If this was a secret ballot, this amendment would not get a majority," he said.
Mr. Dole, meanwhile, criticized the Clinton Administration's opposition to the amendment, saying, "The bottom line is this Administration is looking for every excuse in the book to spend more money than Americans are willing to pay for in tax dollars."
He said that without the amendment the nation would be like a family "that struggles year after year with a growing credit card debt because it can never quite tighten its belt enough to pay off the principal."
But at the White House this morning, President Clinton said the amendment would produce legislative paralysis.
"It amounts to turning the whole future of America over to 40 percent plus one of each house of the Congress," he said, referring to the provision that would allow deficit spending only if three-fifths of each house agreed, giving the two-fifths minority effective veto power. "In an intensely partisan atmosphere, that's a recipe for total paralysis."
Under the Simon amendment, which would have taken effect in 2001, Federal spending could not exceed income unless Congress agreed in sufficient numbers to allow a deficit. It would have required separate three-fifths votes to increase the national debt, the accumulated total of annual deficits.
Supporters contended that the measure was the only way to force Congress and the executive branch to halt years of deficit spending. "There is a day of reckoning," Mr. Simon said. "We ought to stop this before we get to the edge of the cliff."
Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, a reluctant supporter, called the measure "the worst method proposed for eliminating our persistent Federal deficit" -- except for all the failed alternatives that had already been tried. But he said it was "the only way to force Congress and the executive branch to face up to the problem."
Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, rejected that sentiment, saying, "The only thing that will stop this spending is courage, and courage cannot be legislated into the Constitution."
Mr. Byrd said the "amendment undermines a basic principle underlying our representative democracy: the principle of majority rule." He said its requirement of three-fifths majorities would be an invitation to "gridlock and blackmail."
He also denounced one change that had been made in the Simon amendment to secure votes, a provision that would bar courts from issuing any orders to increase taxes or cut spending. Mr. Byrd said that would either prove ineffective or enable the executive branch to ignore Congress and cut any spending it liked.
 
Lonely Battle
 Only last fall, the amendment seemed likely to pass. But Mr. Byrd, who attacked it almost alone for months and rallied opposition, and Mr. Mitchell, who went after Democrats one by one, worked tirelessly against it.
The substitute amendment, proposed by Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, was an important tactical step toward making opposition easier. It had several loopholes, including guaranteed protection for Social Security, and the Reid alternative made it easier for some senators to vote against the Simon proposal and still tell their constituents they had supported a balanced budget.
Rejected on a 78-to-22 vote, the substitute never had a chance of adoption. But that was not its purpose. As Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, Mr. Simon's chief Republican ally, called it, it was a "hastily contrived fig leaf."

HEADLINE: Japanese Premier May Soon Dismiss Key Adviser

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 1

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa was reported today to be ready to expel his chief Cabinet secretary from a crucial policy-making role, a step that is likely to encourage those who want faster changes in the economy and closer ties to the United States.
After seven months of unstable government and several policy zigzags, Mr. Hosokawa was described as being on the verge of ending a longstanding battle within his Government by casting his lot with the conservative. 
 He met today with the leaders of the seven parties and reportedly described the shuffling as an attempt to refocus on important economic issues -- resolving a trade dispute with the United States and jolting the economy out of recession. But few doubt that the real aim is to remove Masayoshi Takemura, the chief Cabinet secretary and once his closest ally.
A Cabinet shuffle would be a major victory for the most conservative thinker in the Government, Ichiro Ozawa, who holds no official post but has been Mr. Hosokawa's key strategist. But the shake-up could drive deeper the wedge that has split the right and left wings, and could complicate the already painful decision-making process.
Mr. Takemura and Mr. Ozawa share Mr. Hosokawa's commitment to cleaning up the electoral system and removing some of the layers of regulation that control the economy. But Mr. Takemura believes in consensus-building and gradual change. Mr. Ozawa, the strongman of the coalition's second-largest party, favors a faster pace and thus has long been seen as a closer ally of the United States.
Mr. Takemura has hinted that the small party he heads might quit the coalition if he is dropped; the Socialists, the coalition's largest party, also oppose a Cabinet shuffle.
Even if the disputed shuffle does not take place, it is clear that Mr. Takemura and his moderate policies have fallen out of favor.
Up to now, the split between Mr. Takemura and Mr. Ozawa has left the Government careering on key issues, leaving all sides fuming.
For instance, early this month Mr. Hosokawa announced a $140 billion stimulus package to lift the economy out of its recession. It included a three-year income-tax reduction and then a large increase in the sales tax to cover the loss in revenue.
The tax proposal, which had been pushed by Mr. Ozawa, brought down a storm of protest and Mr. Hosokawa withdrew it the next day.
Not long afterward, Mr. Hosokawa again took Mr. Ozawa's advice and backed a union of most of the parties in his coalition to create a counterweight to the Liberal Democratic Party, which the coalition ousted last summer after it had held power for 38 years.
But the idea of a two-party system -- a central tenet of Mr. Ozawa's philosophy -- contradicted Mr. Hosokawa's pledge to maintain a multi-party system, which Mr. Takemura supports.
If there has been a motif in Mr. Hosokawa's decisions, it has been to side with the conservative bureaucrats he had vowed to override. Whether the issue was taxes, trade negotiations or deregulation, Mr. Hosokawa has hewed to the demands of the ministries.
"Hosokawa has been relying completely on the bureaucrats," said Takashi Inoguchi, a political scientist at Tokyo University. "It is doubtful that will change."

HEADLINE: Administration Outlines Hopes for Health Savings

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
With its health care plan battered by critics on the left and the right, the Administration tried today to revive interest in the proposal by asserting that every state would save money if Congress approved the plan in precisely the form recommended by President Clinton.
The Administration's estimates are rosier than those by various governors, Republicans and independent researchers. In addition, lawmakers from both parties say Congress will make major changes in the President's plan. 
 The Administration said New York State would save $8.6 billion under the plan, or 9 percent of what it would otherwise spend on Medicaid and certain types of long-term care for disabled people from 1996 to 2000.
In addition, it said, New Jersey would save $3.7 billion, or 19 percent; Connecticut would save $1.2 billion, or 12 percent, and California $6.5 billion, or 11 percent.
 
Doubt About Savings
 Taken together, the Administration said, states would save at least $46 billion, or 8 percent of what they would otherwise spend on health care over the five years.
Richard M. Cook, a health policy adviser to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, disputed the estimates, saying, "We don't believe there will be an $8.6 billion saving for this state." At the most, Mr. Cook said, the President's proposal may save New York $1 billion over five years. But, he warned, such estimates are uncertain because the Clinton plan is "predicated on a model of competition that has not been tested."
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents 91 hospitals in the metropolitan New York City area, said: "The report is incomplete. It does not show the impact of the President's proposed Medicare cuts, which would be devastating to New York hospitals, especially teaching hospitals."
The study made public today was conducted by the Department of Health and Human Services to show the effects of the Clinton plan on state budgets. Administration officials said they would issue a separate study in several weeks to show the effects on hospitals, doctors and medical schools.
 
Support on One Side
 The Administration's estimates assume that Congress will approve all elements of the Clinton plan and that the cost controls proposed by the President, including Federal regulation of private health insurance premiums, will be 100 percent effective. But lawmakers are not only expecting major changes in the plan; they also say they doubt that the cost controls can slow health spending as much as the Administration says.
Nevertheless, Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the National Governors' Association, said: "The Administration's estimates, in the aggregate, are plausible. There would be potential savings for states under the plan as drafted."
Moreover, Mr. Scheppach said, the Administration tried to prevent big cost increases for the states.
Despite these efforts, he said, governors are split about the merits of the Clinton plan. They do not agree on the wisdom of Mr. Clinton's proposal to require employers to provide health insurance for their employees nor do they agree on his proposal for a national health budget, setting limits on spending for a standard package of benefits.
Kenneth E. Thorpe, a deputy assistant secretary of health and human services who supervised the study, said the savings would occur for three reasons.
First, Mr. Thorpe said, many people now enrolled in Medicaid, a Federal-state program for low-income people, would be shifted to private health insurance plans, relieving the states of a large financial burden.
Second, he said, the Federal Government would establish a new program of home care for severely disabled people, substituting Federal money for state financing in many places. And, third, the Clinton plan would reduce state spending on health care for active and retired state employees.
But Gail R. Wilensky, an economist who headed the Federal Health Care Financing Administration under President George Bush, and William Kristol, who was chief of staff for Vice President Dan Quayle, said the estimates were implausible.

HEADLINE: New Economic Data Send Stocks Down

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock and bond traders pounced on new economic data yesterday, furiously examining the numbers for symptoms of inflation. And when they found them they sold furiously, sending stock prices down and interest rates up sharply.
Both the stock and bond investors assume, with little clear and convincing evidence for now, that a strong economy necessarily carries with it a strong dose of inflation, which would hurt the investment value of bonds, raise the borrowing costs for corporations and thus hurt the price of stocks as well. 
 The markets are also assuming that disquieting inflation news in February, when the economy was chilled by record winter storms and hobbled in California by an earthquake, means even worse inflation news later as the skies clear, California rebuilds, and the economy begins to trot.
 
Signs of Renewed Inflation
 And so when both stock and bond traders saw signs of renewed inflation yesterday in the report from the nation's purchasing managers, they did not like it. The 30-year bond,, one benchmark for fixed-income securities, leaped to yields not seen since June 1993 and the Standard & Poor's 500 receded to a price level not seen since December 1993.
Interest rate-sensitive companies like Travelers Inc., the big insurance company, economically sensitive companies like Monsanto, the chemical processor, oil companies like Chevron, and utilities like Pacific Gas and Electric were all hurt.
On Monday, the bond market had rallied on what it saw as a sign of declining or stable prices in the Chicago purchasing managers' report, carrying most of the stock market, except for the Dow Jones industrial average.
But yesterday, the 30-year bond was down 115/32 at 93 5/16 , with a yield of 6.77 percent. The Dow dropped 22.79 points, to 3,809.23, while the broader S.& P. 500 dropped 2.70 points, to 464.44. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index, which has outperformed larger companies so far this year, fell 3.86 points, to 788.64.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index fell 1.42 points, to 257.81, on moderately heavy volume of 304.5 million shares. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks, 1,449 to 716. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 1.38 points, to 469.96.
The turning point in market psychology this year was the quarter-point rate increase by the Federal Reserve Board on Feb. 4, which bond traders seem to want the Fed to do again to assure them that the central bank will stamp out inflation. The hapless stock market, which mirrored the rise in interest rates with its own selling, is moving defensively so big portfolio managers will not be too embarrassed when they report quarterly performance figures.
"The bond market wants the Fed to move more aggressively, meaning a 25-basis-point rise is no more than a token," said Charles Lieberman, a managing director at Chemical Securities Inc., referring to the increase on Feb. 4. "But the stock market wishes Greenspan hadn't had the idea in the first place." Mr. Lieberman's reference was to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Bond prices only dipped yesterday after the early morning report of a revised gross domestic product -- 7.5 percent, instead of the expected high of 7.0 percent. The positive surprise in the data was that inflation was very low in the last quarter of 1993 despite the strongest growth in 10 years.
But it seemed that bond and stock investors ignored this positive price news to focus their anxieties on a big rise in the February price index from the National Association of Purchasing Management, a trade group of corporate buyers.
Bond traders put faith in the index, despite its flaws. The purchasing managers' index rose to 67 percent, the highest since October 1990. But historically, changes in the index have shown little predictive power for wholesale and consumer prices.
And the February index can be produced so quickly (the month ended on Monday) because it simply asks manufacturers whether prices rose, not by how much or whether the increases were in economically important products or services.
The stock market has still far to go to complete the widely expected "correction." Elaine Garzarelli, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, has said she expected a price drop of up to 7 percent following the Fed's Feb. 4 interest-rate rise. That would imply a Dow of about 3,690, an S.& P. 500 of about 447, and a Nasdaq index of about 742.

HEADLINE: Trying to Produce Doctors With a Sensitive Touch And a Grasp of Economics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Feb. 28

 BODY:
For their clinical education course at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, the five young doctors had just completed an eight-hour shift working as nurses and they still sounded a little shellshocked, sitting around a conference room table, discussing what they had learned.
"You see the effects of all these blood tests we doctors order," said Dr. Pierre Herard, who spent the day hunting clean bed pans, untangling patients snagged in intravenous tubes and waiting for countless blood test results from the hospital laboratory. "And I realize, sometimes we doctors order all these blood tests and we don't even check them." 
 "Sometimes?" said Ann Marie Sanna, a nurse.
"A lot of the times," Dr. Herard said.
"A lot of interns feel a drive to take blood every morning," said Dr. David Gamburg, an intern himself. "In fact, I have felt that drive."
Tagging along with nurses, the interns are forced to notice the work, time and expense that goes into the batteries of tests that they routinely order, often with little thought to cost. They noticed the patients' arms, black and blue from being pricked so often.
"When my grandmother was in the hospital," Dr. Gamburg said, "I confronted the intern: 'Why did you take so much blood?' Couldn't give me a reason. You get 7 tubes with 7 c.c.'s -- 50 c.c.'s a day. Finally they have a reason. The poor patient's anemic!"
The day with the nurses is part of a new academic program at Long Island Jewish, aimed at turning out a revolutionary new breed of doctors -- sensitive to patients and nurses and aggressive about holding down hospital costs.
 
Cost Cards for Doctors
 Dr. Steven Walerstein, the program director, frequently reminds his interns that a series of 20 blood tests, ordered daily for a patient by most doctors, costs $35, when often, all that is needed is a test for the blood's four electrolyte levels (sodium, potassium, chloride, bicarbonate) for $19. This year, for the first time, the 39 first-year doctors doing their residency in internal medicine all carry a small card in the pockets of their white coats that lists the comparative costs of the most common intravenous antibiotics.
Efforts to make young doctors more cost-conscious are hardly new, but as the debate over national medical costs intensifies, education programs like the one at the Long Island hospital are spreading and growing more formalized. For the last three years at the University of Minnesota, interns in the family practice program have been required to spend two weeks with the business manager of a clinic to learn about the costs of medical services and the economic pressures fostering a greater reliance on outpatient care.
This spring at Georgetown University, interns will compile their own list of cost-effective medications and then prescribe from that list. "Instead of just handing them a list, this forces them to balance the effectiveness of the medications with their cost," said Dr. Kevin Schulman, director of the school's clinical economics research unit.
At Long Beach Memorial Medical Center in California, family practice interns pose as patients and are checked into the hospital for a day, complete with fake diagnoses and fake casts. "They're poked and probed and they see the bill," said Ron Yukelson, a hospital spokesman. "Ninety-five percent of them have never been a hospital patient, and this is a chance to show them how to walk in the patients' slippers."
This year the hospital plans to conduct a mock malpractice trial to teach interns the importance of proper documentation on patients' charts.
"This is just beginning in a formal way in many places and will become much more prevalent," said Dr. Jordan Cohen, the incoming president of the Association of American Medical Colleges. "A lot more medical training programs will be doing these kinds of things very soon."
Dr. William Jacott, vice chairman of the American Medical Association's Board of Trustees, said many intern programs now put the daily cumulative bill on a patient's hospital chart to expose young doctors to treatment costs. "They see the impact of ordering blood gases every four hours instead of twice daily," he said.
Whether training medical students to be more cost-conscious will actually produce more cost-conscious doctors is another matter. Dr. John Eisenberg, chairman of medicine at Georgetown University, is skeptical. "You can teach them in medical school and then they go out on their own where cost-consciousness is not practiced, and that's the end of it," he said. "The question isn't how many medical programs; it's whether they make a difference."
Last fall, in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Eisenberg published a review of studies conducted in the last decade that had tried to change doctors' medical practices. "My conclusion is that education alone usually doesn't work," he said.
But the directors of the program at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center point out that this is not a matter of educational altruism; there are growing financial pressures. In the last decade most insurance companies have gone from compensating the hospital for each test to providing a flat fee according to the diagnosis.
"In a pneumonia case, we'll get a standard fee," Dr. Walerstein said. "If the person's in for four days and gets the minimal blood work and X-rays necessary, the hospital makes money; if it's two weeks, thousands of X-rays, thousands of blood tests, you lost money."
 
Pressure on the Interns
 A hospital has a limited ability to control the diagnostic practices of the veteran attending physicians who have offices in the community and visit the wards to see their patients on daily rounds; but a hospital has a good deal of sway over its medical interns and their practices, and that is where the push is coming.
"I think we're beginning to change the culture," said Dr. David Dantzker, acting president of Long Island Jewish. At his daily 7:30 A.M. meeting with senior interns to discuss the previous day's admissions, Dr. Dantzker constantly probes them on cost-effectiveness. At a meeting today, when an intern suggested a second battery of tests for a patient, a colleague commented, "Hillary's not going to like that."
Dr. Walerstein believes the Clinton health care plan and the spread of managed care make these young doctors more receptive than their predecessors. "As managed care penetrates the market, these companies will track their physicians," Dr. Walerstein said. "If Dr. A's cost for hypertension care is regularly 20 percent higher than Dr. B's, Dr. A may find himself out of the program. Our trainees understand it's in their interest to be cost-effective."
The hospital's revamped advanced clinical skills program for internal medicine offers cost-analysis classes in diagnosing respiratory problems, urinary infections and lower back pain. Dr. Walerstein has interns pull out their pocket price lists and explains that they can often treat a bacterial infection of the urinary track with gentamicin for $21.55 a day, instead of ticarcillin/clavulanate at $100 a day.
The course advocates using traditional diagnostic methods when possible, as opposed to performing high-tech tests. "We have produced a generaton of trained physicians that feels insecure without technology," Dr. Walerstein said. "Instead of listening to a lung and saying it sounds the same as yesterday, they need a test to confirm. It's become a practice to order blood tests every day just to see the stupid numbers that don't mean anything."
The program promotes the idea that the humanistic approach can pay financial dividends. "If they spend 15 extra minutes talking to a patient with lower back pain," Dr. Walerstein said, "they may learn he's going through several personal stresses in his life that explain the pain -- and save expensive diagnostic tests."
One reason for spending the day with a nurse -- a program originated at the University of Kentucky College of Medicine in 1989 -- is to show the intern how much more nurses talk to patients than doctors.
"I noticed the patients speak to the nurses differently; there's more closeness," Dr. Mani Ushyarov, one of the first-year interns, said at the end of his nurse shift. "It's like the doctor's not a part of the family."
Dr. Gamburg said: "We all know the tricks to avoid talking to a patient. You say to the patient, 'Don't talk right now; let me examine your lungs. Don't talk right now; let me take your pulse.' The nurses can't escape the way we do."
Nor could the young doctors during their day as nurses. Dr. Isidore Miah fed an elderly woman breakfast and lunch. Dr. Calvin Pan changed a woman's diaper twice in 10 minutes.
A half dozen times, Dr. Herard untangled the feet of the patient in room 430 from the intravenous tubes. As Dr. Herard crawled around the floor chatting with the patient, his nurse-partner for the day, Eileen Fitzgerald, listened from the hall. "He's good with the patients," Mrs. Fitzgerald said. "You don't always see that."

HEADLINE: Flake and His Church Agree to Repay Federal Money

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
In a settlement to a civil suit brought by the Justice Department, Representative Floyd H. Flake and the church he heads in Jamaica, Queens, have agreed to repay $530,000 in Federal money that the government had claimed was improperly used to help build a church school.
With interest dating to 1982, when construction on the school started, the repayment will add up to $925,000. 
 The settlement is the latest chapter of a case that began when the Department of Housing and Urban Development provided loans to help build a senior-citizen housing project sponsored by the Allen A.M.E. Church, which the congressman serves as pastor.
 
First Amendment at Issue
 The alleged misuse of the money to build a community center connected to the church school came to light at the time Mr. Flake and his wife, Margaret Elaine, were indicted on Federal tax-evasion and embezzlement charges. In April 1991, the tax case was dismissed for lack of evidence.
The settlement of the civil suit, first reported yesterday in New York Newsday, includes no admission of wrongdoing on the part of Mr. Flake or the church.
"We are a church that has been at the forefront of economic development, education and housing in the community," Mr. Flake, a Democrat, said yesterday, "and as we continue into our next phase it was incumbent upon us to get this matter behind us so that we can move forward."
The repayment, in 48 monthly installments, is to be made by Mr. Flake and the church to the Allen A.M.E. Housing Development Corporation, the church-sponsored organization that built the senior-citizens housing project.
Mr. Flake contended yesterday that it was proper to use the money to build a community center connected to the school because the center served the general public.
But Robert Begleiter, chief of the civil division in the Office of the United States Attorney for the Eastern District, said, "It was for the purposes of the church school, and there happens to be something called the First Amendment." The First Amendment, among other things, stipulates the separation of church and state.
 
Prosecution Was Defeated
 Mr. Flake's congressional chief of staff, Edwin Reed, said the money used to build the community center became available because "they brought the housing project in on time and under budget."
"When we set up the corporation for the multiservice community center, we set it up as the Allen Christian School," Mr. Reed said. "That was the mistake." The center provides space for community meetings and services, he said, but classes for the school are also held there.
When the use of the money for the center was discovered, Mr. Flake persuaded officials in the regional Housing and Urban Development office to forgive the misspending. That decision was later rescinded.
On April 3, 1991, at the request of prosecutors, all the criminal charges of tax evasion and embezzlement against Mr. Flake were dismissed in Federal court in Brooklyn. The case ended after three weeks of trial in a complete defeat for the prosecution.
The Flakes had been charged with not reporting $177,578 of income from two sources that they deposited in a ministerial expenses fund. The Government charged that the money was used to buy such "personal" items as jewelry, clothing, toys and a life insurance policy.
One source of those funds, prosecutors said, was a "parsonage allowance." The other was a program to transport elderly residents of the housing complex to shopping centers and elsewhere.
Jurors interviewed after the dismissal said that the Government's case was weak and was undermined by its own witnesses.

HEADLINE: Wall Street Helps Neediest Cases Rest on a High Note

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
With a push in the final days from several Wall Street firms, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended its annual appeal on Monday with the second-best campaign in its 82-year history.
The fund raised $4,590,568.69 from nearly 13,500 contributors during the three-month drive. The donations will help seven social-service agencies feed, house and provide medical care to tens of thousands of poor New Yorkers. 
 While the number of contributors declined from the previous year by about 500, those who did give reached deeper, allowing this year's drive to exceed the 1992-93 total.
 
Wall Street Comes Through
 "We are delighted that a surge of donations from readers in the last few days enabled our drive to finish on such a high note," said Arthur Gelb, the president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund. "And on behalf of the seven benefiting charities, we thank those who contributed so generously. There were fewer donors this year, but many of those who did contribute gave more than in previous years, and some gave two and three times to make sure that the campaign would not lag behind last year."
The appeal surpassed the 1992-93 drive, which raised $4,469,034.47, with the help of contributors at 13 Wall Street firms, who gave checks and cash last week worth more than $135,000, a 70 percent increase over their gift the year before. This year's appeal was second only to the 1991-92 campaign, which raised $5,083,550.81.
As in the past, The Times paid the campaign's overhead costs so that all the money was given directly to the social service agencies, which provide such services as emergency rent help for those in danger of eviction and vocational training for mentally ill former drug abusers.
The money has been used to find safe, clean shelters for homeless families, like Jerome Crawford and Melonie Owens, who lost their apartment last year and moved with their three children into Pelham Fritz Apartments, a residence operated by the Children's Aid Society in East Harlem. The center provides apartments for 33 homeless families and helps them find permanent housing.
In mid-December, after staying three months at the shelter, Mr. Crawford and Ms. Owens moved into their own four-bedroom apartment a few blocks away.
The money has also been used to buy furniture for families who previously slept on the floor, to provide medical exams for thousands of children, to give Thanksgiving and Christmas dinners to the hungry and to help immigrants and the newly unemployed negotiate the maze of the city's human resources system.
In addition to monetary support, the attention the appeal brought to the plight of some of the most indigent cases also had an effect. Three men who had been out of work for more than a year because of the economic downturn found jobs after their stories were told in articles and employers called.
 
Publisher Is Proved Right
 The appeal was started in 1912 by The Times's publisher, Adolph S. Ochs, who reasoned that if the newspaper's readers knew about the suffering around them, they would be eager to help. Contributors from New York and around the world have proved him right, collectively increasing their giving nearly every year. The initial appeal received 117 gifts totaling $3,630.88. In 1970-71, the fund passed the $1 million mark, in 1983-84 it passed the $2 million mark and in 1988-89 it raised more than $4 million for the first time.
All donations received after Monday will be credited toward next year's appeal, which will begin on Thanksgiving Day.

HEADLINE: Jean Gottman, 78, a Geographer Who Saw a Northeast Megalopolis

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS 

 BODY:
Dr. Jean Gottmann, the French geographer who scrutinized the Northeastern Corridor of the United States and defined it as a new social, economic and political entity he called Megalopolis, died on Monday at his home in Oxford, England. He was 78.
The cause was cancer said his wife, Bernice. 
 During the 1950's, Dr. Gottmann conducted a landmark four-year study of the Northeast under the auspices of the Twentieth Century Fund. His report became a model for examinations of smaller but similar regions.
His first view of the area's future was optimistic.
In the study, published in 1961 as "Megalopolis: The Urbanized Northeastern Seaboard of the United States," Dr. Gottmann concluded that the area "was the cradle of a new order in the organization of inhabited space." It was almost 600 miles long and at the time had 30 million inhabitants.
At the time, he said, Megalopolis stretched from just north of Boston to just south of Washington, had gained many characteristics of a single city and had become pre-eminent in the policies, arts, communications and economy of the United States.
In spite of fears for the future of Megalopolis expressed by city planners, Dr. Gottmann said the area's future was bright in part because it had an "extremely distinguished population" that was "the richest, best-educated, best-housed and best-serviced group of similar size in the world."
Dr. Gottmann used the term Megalopolis in defining the region, a word he credited to ancient Greeks who coined it for a newly founded city intended to be their largest. The city never fulfilled those aspirations, but Dr. Gottmann retrieved the long lost name for modern usage.
Dr. Gottmann's four-year examination was the fruit of 20 years of thought and study of human and economic geography, which led to his initial, generally optimistic, view of the region.
 
Optimism Wanes
 But in a retrospective in 1975, Dr. Gottmann was to take a more cautious view. He said that many large and growing American and foreign cities were faced with challenges that had not been foreseen. Among them were the unexpected demand for social services in the midst of shrinking employment prospects and increasing human stress.
"Local government powers and planning theory in general are not adapted to deal with the entanglements of the new situation," he wrote. "The city becomes a mosaic of diverse but poorly adjusted pieces, offering more contrasts than harmony. The present mutation of American cities reflects the dynamics of a society in search of new structures and a new ethic."
Dr. Gottmann began his academic career at the University of Paris, where he received a doctorate in geography. During World War II he taught at Johns Hopkins University, returning to France after the war to teach at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes, an affiliate of the Sorbonne.
In the 1950's he was also a member of the Institute of Advanced Study at Princeton.
Among his other books were "A Geography of Europe" (1951) and "Virginia at Mid-Century" (1955), the latter written under the auspices of the Mellon Foundation.
After leaving the University of Paris he became a professor of geography and the head of the department of geography at the University of Oxford. He retired in 1983.
He is survived by his wife.

HEADLINE: G.D.P. Up at 7.5% Pace In Last Quarter of '93

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
The Government reported today that the economy lunged ahead at a 7.5 percent annual pace in the final quarter of 1993, the strongest performance in nearly 10 years, but most economists stuck to the view that growth has already slowed in the new year and that the risk of revived inflation remains low.
In sharply raising its late January estimate of a 5.9 percent rate of expansion in gross domestic product -- the nation's total output of goods and services -- the Commerce Department said much of the revision resulted from a jump in exports. The Government, however, did not expect exports to continue at their fourth-quarter pace, given the weak economies of American trading partners. 
 The revision to a 7.5 percent growth rate, the fastest since a 7.9 percent burst in the first quarter of 1984 when the economy was emerging from the 1981-1982 recession, lifted the economy's growth for the full year to 3 percent, from the 2.9 percent that had been announced a month ago.
It compared with advances at a rate of 2.9 percent in the third quarter, 1.9 percent in the second quarter and a scant eight-tenths of 1 percent for the January-March period last year during which Bill Clinton was inaugurated as President.
While investors reacted calmly to the revised G.D.P. report, later in the day stocks tumbled and interest rates rose on a report from corporate purchasing managers that showed prices in the industrial sector were firming.
But neither report did much to alter the view of most analysts that the economy is settling back into a more sustainable growth rate of about 3 percent.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said one reason the economy was likely to slacken from its sizzling fourth-quarter pace was that trading partners who remained in recession would be unable to maintain their purchases of American exports, which jumped $2 billion in December and accounted for half the increase.
The Clinton Administration was restrained in its assessment of today's batch of economic data, which also included January declines of 3 percent in sales of previously owned homes and of 1.2 percent in spending on construction. Both were held back by weather.
At a seasonally adjusted rate of 4.22 million, home sales were still the second highest on record, while the fall in construction, to $505.5 billion, was the first since April.
"We believe the economy will continue to grow this year in the neighborhood of 3 percent," said a senior official who appeared in the White House briefing room under ground rules that she not be identified.
What traders seized on at a time of hypersensitivity to signs of possible higher inflation was the latest survey of the National Association of Purchasing Management, a group of corporate shoppers. The survey's price index climbed to 67 percent last month, the highest since 1990, from 59.8 percent in January.
Yet the market response, some suggested, may have been overdone, since the Federal Reserve seemed unlikely to be much swayed either by the G.D.P. report, which covers a quarter that ended two months ago and which provided reassuring inflation figures, or by the purchasing managers' survey, which the Fed may have already anticipated when it raised short-term term interest rates on Feb. 4.
Indeed, close scrutiny of the purchasing survey showed only 28 percent of respondents paying higher prices last month, the same proportion as in January. The only change was a shift of five percentage points from the "lower prices" category to the category of managers, now 66 percent, who said prices neither rose nor fell.
 
Weather Played a Role
 The survey is intended to reflect the breadth of inflation, not its intensity, observed Kevin Logan, an economist at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. Moreover, like various other indicators of late, the survey was no doubt affected by severe winter weather. The price of rock salt, for example, is said to have tripled or quadrupled in some places.
Besides the trade sector, which was revised upward by $11.5 billion at an annual rate, G.D.P. also benefited from an extra $4.7 billion in spending on personal consumption, the report showed.
Recovery from last summer's floods in the Midwest and drought in the Southeast added at least four-tenths of a percentage point to the fourth-quarter expansion, the department said.
Besides an expected slowdown this year in exports to Europe and Japan, which some analysts predict will be offset by increased sales to Latin America and elsewhere, the economy is seen as being held back this year by continued sluggish growth in incomes, by the effect of higher taxes on the free-spending wealthy and by monetary and fiscal policies that are at least modestly restrictive.
 
An Inflation Gauge
 Today's report also showed that the department's price index for gross domestic purchases rose at a 2.2 percent rate in the fourth quarter, one-tenth of a point higher than estimated last month.
G.D.P. expressed in current dollars, rather than in constant 1987 dollars, jumped at an 8.8 percent rate in last year's final quarter, up from an initial estimate of 7.4 percent. Based on the fourth-quarter data, the annualized G.D.P. was $6.532 trillion in current dollars, and $5.232 trillion in 1987 dollars.
The purchasing managers' report, based on a survey of executives at more than 300 industrial companies, showed that while the manufacturing sector expanded for the sixth straight month in February, growth of the overall economy slackened. The group's overall index was at 56.6 percent last month, down from 57.7 in January; anything over 44.5 percent indicates an economic expansion.
"The economy continued to grow in February although at a slightly lower rate than in January," said Robert J. Bretz, head of the association's business survey committee. While weather problems "clearly contributed" to the slowdown, he added, growth in new orders and order backlogs "definitely was less."
Data included in the gross domestic product for the fourth quarter of 1993 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Climb on Report Of Inflation Pressures

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates climbed to their highest level in almost a year yesterday as investors sold on economic data that bore evidence of inflationary pressures building in the economy.
The selloff came after the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its price index climbed in February to its highest point since 1990. The report rekindled speculation that the Federal Reserve would move again on short-term interest rates as it did on Feb. 4. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 115/32 , to 935/16 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 6.77 percent, from 6.65 percent on Monday, and was the highest since June 1993. For bondholders, that meant a loss of $12.31 for every $1,000 bond.
Short maturities also came under pressure yesterday. The three-month Treasury bill rate rose 9 basis points, to 3.49 percent, the highest since July 1992. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Although traders and analysts attributed the selloff to the purchasing management report, many thought the market's reaction was overdone.
"The N.A.P.M. index shows only the market's direction of prices, not how far they are going," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg Securities in New York. "But the market is reacting to them as if they are hugely higher."
 
Positions Examined
 Larry Daly, senior vice president and senior portfolio manager for the Global Investment Trust for Putnam Investments, said the market might be approaching an oversold position.
Mr. Daly who saw just as much weakness in the overseas markets for Treasury bonds yesterday, said people were re-evaluating their positions in the markets after having misinterpreted the amount of tightening needed to ease market concern about inflation.
"Not happy with the size of the Fed's last interest rate hike, the market is now wondering if instead the Fed shouldn't have made a larger move," he said. "Their concern is that small moves will only lag behind the market, instead of getting ahead of it."
Joseph V. Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisors, a division of Gruntal & Company, said low interest rates were more of a crutch than market watchers had believed. "So when the reasons for low rates are removed, it creates enormous volatility and each bit of news raises concern," he said.
 
Another Increase Seen
 Mr. Battipaglia said comments by Robert Parry, president of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank, left little doubt that there would be another increase in short-term rates. Mr. Parry said it was unlikely that one step was going to be enough, and "that added some fuel to the fire," Mr. Battipaglia said.
The next closely watched economic report, February unemployment, is scheduled to be released on Friday.
Analysts say that any tightening by the Fed will now be an admission that inflation is an immediate problem, and would prompt another selloff.
But Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, does not see inflation as a threat yet. "The Fed's job is to prevent any potential overheating of the economy that will produce inflationary pressures in 1995 and 1996," he said.
Mr. Fine said that if the central bank continued to move in increments of a quarter-point, it might not be enough to curb inflation. He expects the Fed will increase the Federal funds rate to 3.50 percent from 3.25 in the near future.
