HEADLINE: Mafia Defector Says He Lost His Faith

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Facing the twin perils of an underworld death threat and a 30-year prison sentence, Anthony Accetturo defected as the top Lucchese crime family leader in New Jersey to become a Government witness because, he says, the Mafia's current bosses have discarded the secret society's traditional principles.
"The new generation that is running things threw all the old rules out the window," said Mr. Accetturo in an interview Monday in a northern New Jersey prison where he is being held in a witness protection wing. "The key word is greed. All they care about is money, not honor." 
 After a lifetime of avoiding Federal convictions on major felonies, Mr. Accetturo, 55, was convicted in August on New Jersey charges that he was the leader of an organized-crime faction and on charges of racketeering and extortion. Two weeks later, while awaiting a minimum sentence of 30 years and a maximum of 60 years, he agreed to cooperate with the New Jersey Attorney General's office, where, not coincidentally, a boyhood friend works.
 
A Mafia History
 Law-enforcement experts on the Mafia say that Mr. Accetturo's 35-year voyage from a $75-a-week apprentice to the highest rungs of the Lucchese family and his ultimate downfall as a mob chief encapsulates the turbulent modern history of most of the nation's Mafia groups.
Although several higher-ranking Mafia members have defected and testified at criminal trials in the last decade, Mr. Accetturo is the first major turncoat from the New York area to be publicly interviewed.
The interview, in the presence of three members of the New Jersey Attorney General's office, was conducted on the condition imposed by prosecutors that The New York Times would not identify the prison in which Mr. Accetturo was being held.
 
The Path of Opportunity
 A portly, moon-faced man, 5 feet 9 inches tall and 220 pounds, Mr. Accetturo smiled frequently and responded freely during most of the 80-minute interview. He said that as a young man, growing up in Orange, N.J., and in Newark, he was was drawn to a life in the Mafia because he had few other economic opportunities. He asserted that in the blue-collar Sicilian-American neighborhoods of the 1950's and 1960's, acceptance into the Mafia was viewed by many of his contemporaries as "an honorable and respected thing, like a dream, like some people want to become a doctor."
Sicilian Mafia groups and their parallel organizations in America have long referred to themselves as the honorable or honored society and as Cosa Nostra, Sicilian for Our Thing.
Portraying his leadership role in the Lucchese family as that of a benevolent businessman, Mr. Accetturo claimed that he merely sought to enrich himself and his confederates and that he had avoided violence.
However, on the orders of Melaine B. Campbell, a New Jersey deputy attorney general who observed the interview, he refused to answer questions about murders he had participated in or sanctioned. Law-enforcement officials familiar with information gleaned from Mr. Accetturo said he has admitted knowledge of conspiracies that led to at least 13 slayings.
At his trial on racketeering charges this summer, Mr. Accetturo was acquitted of a charge that he authorized the 1984 murder of Vincent Craparotta, a Lucchese associate suspected of withholding payoffs to family leaders from an extortion plot. No other charge involving a killing has ever been brought against Mr. Accetturo.
Heeding an admonition from Ms. Campbell, Mr. Accetturo also declined to specify the payments he accumulated as a crime boss from secret holdings in companies, how much the Lucchese family made from illicit gambling, loan-sharking, extortion and labor racketeering, and how the money was laundered.
"Let's just say it was multimillion-dollar business," Mr. Accetturo said, his brown eyes twinkling. "In the best times, I had a six-figure income from legal businesses and I never had to apply for food stamps."
Born in 1938, Mr. Accetturo said he dropped out of school after completing the sixth grade. His father, a butcher in Orange, and his mother, a seamstress, placed little value in traditional education, he said.
At the age of 16, Mr. Accetturo began living with relatives in Newark, and he said he became the leader there of a West Side gang of 50 to 60 teen-agers. Because he was a ferocious street fighter, Mr. Accetturo said he acquired the nickname Tumac, based on the caveman hero of the 1940 movie "One Million B.C."
At the age of 17, Anthony (Ham) Dolasco, a Lucchese family soldier, or "made" member, aware of Mr. Accetturo's tough-guy reputation, recruited him to work in an illegal gambling and loan-sharking organization.
"I came up with the old mustaches," Mr. Accetturo said, referring to a Mafia term for guarded, unflamboyant gangsters. "They didn't talk, you had to use your mind and street sense to figure out things. Whatever they told you was only on a need to know basis."
Mr. Dolasco, according to Mr. Accetturo, ran the largest numbers racket in Newark in the 1960's. When he died in the late 1960's, Mr. Accetturo was put in charge of the operation.
According to Mr. Accetturo, the Lucchese family prohibited the induction of new soldiers from the early 1960's until the mid 1970's, trying to maintain secrecy and prevent law-enforcement infiltration. Although he ran several rackets for the family for almost a decade, Mr. Accetturo said it was 1976 when he formally took the Mafia oath of omerta, the swearing of loyalty and secrecy.
 
Saint's Picture Is Burned
 He said that Joseph Abate of Margate, N.J., who was the head of the Lucchese family in New Jersey in the 1960's and early 1970's, and Michael Pappadio, a Lucchese soldier, drove him to a house in New York City for a meeting with Anthony (Ducks) Corallo, then the boss of the family. At a simple ceremony, he said, a picture of a saint was burned and he intoned: "May I burn in hell like this saint if I betray my friends."
For Mr. Accetturo, the induction "was the greatest honor of my life."
Reflecting on his activities in the Lucchese family, Mr. Accetturo said that like most Mafia members and their associates, he flourished in the 1960's and 1970's. Many law-enforcement officials acknowledge that feeble law-enforcement efforts from the 1930's through the 1970's generally failed to check the growth of the nation's 20 or so crime families.
The nation's five largest organized-crime groups -- the Lucchese, Gambino, Genovese, Colombo and Bonanno families -- originated in New York City and operate throughout the metropolitan region. The Lucchese family is the only one, law-enforcement experts say, that had three semi-independent factions: Brooklyn-Queens and Long Island, Manhattan-Bronx and New Jersey.
Mr. Accetturo, who had a home in Livingston, N.J., moved to Hollywood, Fla., in 1970 to avoid testifying before the New Jersey State Investigation Commission.
He said that Mr. Corallo had effectively put him in charge of the New Jersey faction in the early 1970's even before his formal induction and that he was named a capo soon after taking the oath of omerta. At most, he said, the "made" members of the Lucchese group in New Jersey numbered 20, but more than 100 associates worked for him. He used a trusted aide, Michael Taccetta, as his street boss in New Jersey, communicating with him by telephone and at meetings in New York City.
 
Juror Was Bribed
 "In them days, we were disciplined and coordinated," he said. "The other guys weren't," he added, referring to law-enforcement agencies.
The equations began to change in the 1980's and the indictments came thick and fast, Mr. Accetturo said. In 1985 he and 19 other Lucchese members and associates were indicted in Newark on Federal racketeering and narcotics trafficking charges.
All 20 defendants were acquitted in 1988 but last September, Mr. Taccetta admitted bribing a juror in the trial. Mr. Accetturo, in the interview, declined to say if had known about the bribe and possible jury tampering.
After the 1988 acquittal, Mr. Accetturo was imprisoned for 20 months for refusing to testify before the New Jersey Investigation Commission.
Further trouble for Mr. Accetturo emerged when a life sentence was imposed on Mr. Corallo after his conviction in New York on Federal racketeering charges in 1987. In 1988, Vittorio Amuso replaced Mr. Corallo as boss of the Lucchese family and he named Anthony Casso as underboss.
Mr. Amuso and Mr. Casso, Mr. Accetturo said, began cutting into his independence and demanded larger shares of the loot than Mr. Corallo had taken. Mr. Corallo, he insisted, rarely asked for more than $10,000 a year while the new bosses wanted almost every penny raked in by the New Jersey faction.
He said that when he resisted, Mr. Amuso and Mr. Casso also put out a contract to kill him and his son, Anthony Jr., falsely claiming that he "was a rat."
"They had no training, no honor," Mr. Accetturo said of Mr. Amuso and Mr. Casso. "All they want to do is, kill, kill, get what you can, even if you didn't earn it."
Mr. Amuso, 58, was convicted in 1992 on Federal racketeering and murder charges and sentenced to life imprisonment. Mr. Casso, 52, will go on trial later this month in Brooklyn on Federal racketeering and murder charges.
Mr. Accetturo said state prosecutors had made no promises of a possible reduced sentence for his cooperation and possible testimony at criminal trials. But his sentencing has been postponed and prosecutors said that the extent of his cooperation would be made known to the sentencing judge. (New Jersey law-enforcement officials, who spoke when granted anonymity, said that Mr. Accetturo had given them a wealth of information, including details of secret Lucchese family holdings in construction companies and real-estate development projects in New Jersey, North Carolina and Florida.)
Switching sides, Mr. Accetturo said, was eased somewhat by the presence of Robert T. Buccino, deputy chief of a unit in the attorney general's office that has been on his trail for last eight years. Mr. Accetturo and Mr. Buccino were boyhood friends in Orange.
Claiming he was remorseful about his criminal activities, Mr. Accetturo said he wanted to warn potential Mafia recruits that the organization "is no longer an honorable secret society, there is no glamour like in the movies and most of the families are becoming street gangs."
"Either you wind up in the can, your life finished like me, or dead," he said.

HEADLINE: Banks May Pay Fees to Be Regulated

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen proposed today to pay for the consolidation of bank regulatory agencies by charging Federal examination fees to large state-chartered institutions like Chemical Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
The Administration plan, put forward by the Treasury Department today to the Senate Banking Committee, would collect $50 million a year from these banks, said Frank N. Newman, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance. 
 It would create a single Federal banking agency that would take over most of the bank-supervision responsibilities of the Federal Reserve, which now examines many of the big state-chartered banks, but does not charge them fees for doing so. The proposed agency would also replace the Treasury Department in regulating banks and savings and loans, and would take over most regulatory responsibilities of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, as well.
 
Origins of System
 The nation's dual banking system, with Federal and state charters, evolved in the 19th century. The two kinds of charters are quite similar now except for differences in examination fees. State and Federal charters have gone in and out of fashion in the past, depending on the toughness of regulation. Once a bank chooses a charter, it is difficult to change it.
The Treasury Department oversees Federal-chartered banks and charges them fees that would be reduced under the proposed agency to the extent that the consolidation of agencies saved money, Mr. Newman said. He estimated the savings at $150 million to $200 million a year, but the Federal Reserve and the Congressional Budget Office have questioned whether significant savings could be realized.
The description of fees was the only new element in Mr. Bentsen's plan, which he presented today to Banking Committee. Several Republican senators said that before legislation could pass, the Treasury Department would have to resolve its differences with the Federal Reserve, which is strenuously resisting the plan, saying it reduces its ability to keep watch on economic activity across the nation as it sets interest rates.
Banking lobbyists criticized the planned fees today, contending that Fed-regulated banks already pay indirectly for examination because they are required to deposit money at the Fed that earns no interest.
Mr. Newman told reporters after the hearing that banks that are members of the Federal Reserve System derive a variety of benefits from membership, so their zero-interest accounts at the Fed should not be considered an unofficial exam fee.
 
Republican Comment
 Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, suggested that the Administration's enthusiasm for trimming the Fed's powers might be partly motivated by a desire to help the largest bank company in Arkansas, the Worthen Banking Corporation, and its largest stockholders, the Stephens family. The bank and its ties to the Stephenses have been under investigation by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis for more than a year. Worthen lent more than $2 million to the Clinton Presidential campaign, and the Stephens empire led early fund-raising.
Part of the inquiry involves filings with the Fed by the Rose law firm, where Hillary Rodham Clinton used to be a partner.
The Treasury's consolidation of regulatory authority would take the Arkansas bank and hundreds of other banks out from under the Fed's oversight.
Mr. Bentsen responded that he was unaware of any link between Worthen and the Administration's proposal. He said the White House had played little role in developing bank regulatory policy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Clinton to Reinstate Power to Move Fast On Japan Sanctions

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to sign an executive order reinstating his broad legal authority to impose trade sanctions on Tokyo quickly, an action that the Japanese have warned would mark an escalation in the brewing trade conflict between the two countries.
Senior Administration officials said the President had accepted the recommendation from his economic advisers and had asked his National Economic Council to meet tonight to decide when the order should be signed and what elements it should contain. An official announcement is expected soon. 
 Since the United States broke off trade talks with Japan two weeks ago after Tokyo refused to accept American demands for numerical indicators to show whether or not it was opening its markets, the Clinton Administration has been considering measures to compel Japan to open markets for insurance, telecommunications, autos and medical equipment.
Administration and Congressional officials said that after considerable debate, a majority of the President's National Economic Council -- headed by Robert E. Rubin and including Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen; Secretary of State Warren Christopher; Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown; the trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich -- recommended to the President last week that he reinstate by executive order the "Super 301" trade retaliation mechanism.
This would be the trade equivalent of locking and loading a rifle, but without pulling the trigger. The hope among American officials would be that just that ominous sound would get the Japanese to agree to some market-opening initiatives before they are actually named under Super 301.
Some analysts argue that putting such a powerful weapon into place could mark a dangerous increase in United States-Japan trade tensions. But that view did not prevail with the President, who sided with those officials who believe that only credible threats will get Japan to lower its trade barriers. These officials said the President still intended to move cautiously and simply signing the executive order did not mean that he would use it against Japan immediately, although it sends an obvious signal to Tokyo.
Super 301 is a lapsed provision passed by Congress in 1988. It requires the United States trade representative to identify the countries that maintain the most egregious trade barriers and to initiate what are known as "Super 301 cases" to eliminate those barriers. Presidential authority lasts for only two years under the insistence of the Reagan Administration, which thought it interfered with free trade.
 
Authority to Retaliate
 If the United States asks the offending country to eliminate the specific barrier and it refuses to do so quickly, the President has the authority to retaliate by blocking an equivalent amount of that country's exports to the United States. So if Japan is deemed to be creating barriers that prevent the import of $100 million in American telecommunications equipment, the United States would impose punitive tariffs on an equivalent amount of Japanese products to prevent their coming into the United States. The President has 12 to 18 months to negotiate with the offending country before the retaliation takes effect.
The President already has the authority to impose trade sanctions under Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act. Super 301 is an amendment to that section that requires that any sanctions be imposed more quickly. Without Super 301, some trade cases have dragged on unresolved for nearly a decade.
President Clinton would be signing an executive order that would reinstate Super 301 by administrative fiat. That would give him the authority to both list the offending countries and initiate trade sanction cases against them. But he probably will not name Japan as a violator right away. He will simply reinstate his authority to do so.
The Super 301 law was initially written with Japan in mind, more than any other country. In 1989 Japan was identified under Super 301, focusing on three closed markets -- processed wood products, supercomputers and satellites. In each of the three cases the Japanese agreed to open the markets before retaliation. American officials since then have been generally satisfied with Japanese performance in these areas. Some countries are so eager not to be named under Super 301 that they will negotiate with the Administration beforehand, just to avoid it.
 
Moving at Their Own Pace
 In recent days the Japanese, who had a $59.3 billion trade surplus with the United States last year, have been discussing ways that they may on their own open some of the markets deemed to be closed by the United States, but they have made it clear to Washington that they will move at their own pace. Many American officials are dubious about what Japan will do.
Yoshihiro Sakamoto, a director general of Japan's trade ministry, told reporters in Tokyo on Monday that his country would file a grievance against the United States with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade if Washington imposed any sanctions. GATT is the Geneva-based body that governs world trade. The Japanese always threaten to take the United States before a GATT tribunal whenever trade sanctions seem likely.

HEADLINE: Sales of Stock Funds Remain Strong

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Despite the sharp drop in stock prices here and abroad last month, Americans still cannot get enough of equity funds, according to industry executives. But the specter of rising interest rates last month scared them into bailing out of some bond funds, even the ever-popular tax-exempt funds.
A sign of just how fond of stock funds Americans are is this: At Fidelity Investments, the country's largest fund complex and a popular one with trigger-happy investors, customers who took money out of long-term bond funds did not move it to the safety of money market funds. Instead, they put it into short-term bond funds and, most surprisingly, into stock funds, sales of which matched January's record, said Neal Litvack, executive vice president of marketing for Fidelity. 
 But although Fidelity and T. Rowe Price said they had experienced record stock-fund sales in February, inflows for the industry as a whole slowed last month, according to figures from AMG Data Services, which tracks most funds. And international funds continued to attract more than their share of the new investments. These funds, which account for only 20 percent of equity fund assets, attracted half the money going into stock funds.
While February inflows may have slowed some, it comes after a record-setting January. According to the Investment Company Institute, a trade group that released its monthly data yesterday, $18.3 billion was invested in stock funds in January, a record. According to the trade group, sales of foreign stock funds outpaced those that invested solely in the United States for the first time since September 1990 -- and that was a month when investors were pulling money out of domestic stock funds.
In a surge of speculative activity, aggressive growth funds also lured a record amount of money in January, $3.7 billion, and fund managers spent it as fast as it flowed in. The amount of cash in aggressive growth portfolios fell to 8 percent, from 8.3 percent, the reverse of what stock funds as a whole were doing (their cash level rose to 8.3 percent, from 8 percent). Equity funds bought $12 billion of stocks in January, compared with $9.6 billion in December, helping to drive the Dow Jones industrial average to a record high at the end of the month.
The love affair Americans have with stock funds may well continue, if a monthly survey for February that Fidelity commissions from the University of Michigan is to be believed. The survey found that a record 58 percent of mutual fund investors planned to buy stock funds in the next six months, up from 38 percent in January.
This enthusiasm comes even though the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 4 percent last month, including a 96-point plunge on Feb. 4, after the Federal Reserve raised a key short-term interest rate. Investors have been selling because they fear that more increases were on the way. The interest rate on long-term Treasury bonds shot up half a percentage point, ending the month at 6.65 percent (and yesterday got to 6.77 percent).
The investors who are holders of tax-exempt bond funds reacted the most. At Franklin Resources, one of the biggest purveyors of municipal-bond funds, tax-free sales fell by 25 percent in Feburary, a spokesman said. The decline came as a surprise to some fund executives because they had expected many people to buy anything that might keep them from paying higher taxes. "But people are much more worried about rate increases than taxes," said Stephen Gibson, director of retail marketing for Putnam Investments in Boston.
The trend was even more pronounced at fund companies that sell their wares directly to the public without the use of brokers. Both Vanguard Group and T. Rowe Price experienced what they described as modest outflows from long-term, tax-exempt funds last month, as investors switched into money markets. AMG, the data services company, reported that no-load fund companies saw $122 million a week move out of municipal funds in February.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Rates Surge, But Other Factors Curb Gain

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most other currencies yesterday as American interest rates surged.
Limiting the dollar's advances, however, were the Bundesbank's relatively tight policy stance and continued concerns that the Clinton Administration was seeking to push the dollar sharply lower against the Japanese yen. 
 Interest rates rose in the United States after a survey of corporate purchasing managers showed rising price pressures in February. That spurred talk of a further rise in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Higher interest rates are bullish for the dollar because they make dollar-denominated assets more attractive. Three-month Treasury bill rates soared yesterday to their highest levels since July 1992 on views that the Fed would soon tighten.
 The purchasing managers' report followed a Government report that the gross domestic product in the fourth quarter rose 7.5 percent, exceeding the Government's initial estimate of 5.9 percent.
 "The numbers helped the dollar along," said one New York foreign exchange dealer.
Buying was tempered, however, by news that the Bundesbank had allowed a key short-term money market rate to fall only three basis points versus expectations of a much more aggressive cut.
The dollar was also buffeted by concerns the Clinton Administration wanted an even stronger yen in order to trim the huge trade deficit.
 To counter these fears, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said he saw no risk of Japan pulling out of American money markets because of a potentially weaker dollar amid trade friction.
 Speaking before a Senate committee, Mr. Kantor said the Administration would act "on a reasonable basis" in tackling its trade dispute with Japan.
But Mr. Kantor's comment had little immediate impact on the dollar.
The dollar was quoted at 104.60 yen in late New York trading, up from 104.50 yen on Monday. It also rose to 1.7085 marks from 1.7037 marks.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery dropped $3.10, to $379.40 an ounce.
And the British pound rose to $1.4895 in late New York trading, from $1.4865 Monday.

HEADLINE: '91 Ports May Warm Shipper And Buyer

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
NOTHING warms fanciers of vintage port more than icy weather. And nothing warms port shippers more than declaring a vintage. New York's wretched winter was made in heaven for both.
And for consumers, too. The 1991 vintage ports, costing $20 to $30, are arriving in a buyer's market. Added to a glut of 1985 vintage ports in the same price range, the 91's offer immediate savings and future hedonistic value to canny shoppers. 
 Thirty-three of the 91's, tasted privately at the Portuguese Trade Commission two weeks ago, showed succulence, power and longevity.
The earliest Portugal's shippers are allowed to declare vintages is 18 months after their best harvests, but they can wait 34 months. Last year, 40 shippers announced they would release '91 vintage ports. The last major declaration was in 1987, when 31 shippers came out with the 85's.
"Only three or four times in a decade is there a near-unanimous consensus that a vintage port should be declared," said Pat Iocca, an American who is the commission's wine products manager.
In Britain and the United States, the market's acceptance of a vintage port, a house's most prestigious wine, can affect the reputations and prices of its ready-to-drink ruby, tawny and aged tawny ports, all wood-aged.
Vintage ports, which need years of bottle aging to evolve, represent a melange of a shipper's best casks of wine. "The art of port lies in the blending," Joaquim Manuel Calem, the owner of A. A. Calem & Filho, said at a recent seminar on his various ports given by Connaissance & Cie, a Manhattan wine school.
The English have used port, which is fortified with grape brandy and contains 20 percent alcohol, as a substitute for central heating since the 18th century. Because Britain has long been the principal market for vintage port (the United States is second), the early appraisal of the 91's in Decanter, an influential monthly, was awaited.
Its February issue, reporting on a judging by five specialists, said the panel was "very impressed by the overall standard," and thought that the 91's resembled the great 70's and 77's. It predicted that the best wines would last at least 15 to 20 years, if not longer.
At this stage, the high-octane 91's -- dark purple to opaque, with berrylike flavors, some tannic and some svelte -- stun the palate. These young vintage ports, like infants, offer only superficial clues to their adult personalities.
Still, when the long corks are pulled from the black bottles, which must carry the year and the phrase "Vintage Port" or "Vintage Porto," early favorites emerge.
The most appealing, in order of preference (with hairline distinctions), were: Quinta do Noval, Osborne, Burmester, Quinta do Infantado, Fonseca-Guimaraens, Cockburn's, Martinez, Quinta do Vesuvio, Niepoort, Rozes, Quinta do Castelhino, Barros, Gilbert, Graham's, Croft, Van Zeller's Quinta do Roriz, C. da Silva (Presidential), Feist, Sousa and Pocas.
Tasted another time, Gould Campbell, Smith Woodhouse, Quinta de Vargellas and Warre, all critically acclaimed, might ram their way to the top of the list.
Taylor Fladgate and Fonseca, two major exporters (under the same ownership), dampened the image of the 91's by not declaring 1991 vintage ports under the company names. Instead, they used second labels: Taylor's Quinta de Vargellas (a quinta is a farm or vineyard), and Fonseca Guimaraens. Nonetheless, both wines are outstanding. Sandeman also did not declare a vintage.
The recessions in Britain and the United States depressed both markets for vintage port, which is largely a collector's item and is traded as a commodity that usually appreciates in value as it ages. In the barometric British auctions, vintage port has been sold for less than the original prices in recent years.
Some New York-area merchants and importers say the 91's have fetched little interest. "I don't think they will do that great," said Carlo Russo, the owner of Wine and Spirit World in Fort Lee, N.J. "The only people who ask about 91's are people who had a kid in '91."
He added: "I have a lot of unsold 85's. But I am optimistic. Last fall, after two years of slack sales of vintage ports, things picked up."
With 91's and 85's equally priced, impatient economy-minded customers seeking vintage ports for near-term drinking, especially in the waning days of winter, might prefer the relatively more mature 85's.
Several shippers have produced fewer cases of 91's than 85's, perhaps to generate future scarcity, perhaps to avoid further dampening prices because they may want to declare a '92 vintage.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Sarah Lyall 

 BODY:

Good and Bad
At a whither-publishing panel sponsored by the PEN American Center on Monday night, the first speakers were having an elaborate discussion about Martin Midlist, a hypothetical author, and his discouraging prospects when Harold M. Evans all but floored the audience with some solid facts.
Making the point that commerce does not always correspond to culture, Mr. Evans, the publisher of the Random House adult trade division, said the 29 books he published that made it onto The New York Times's 1993 list of Notable Books lost $698,000 collectively. At the same time, he said, the eight books published by his division that recently won awards from the American Library Association lost a total of $370,000. 
 Adding that not all the books lost money individually, Mr. Evans then went on to name some of them, distinguished titles indeed: "Lenin's Tomb," by David Remnick; "Preparing for the 21st Century," by Paul Kennedy; "United States: Essays 1952-1992," by Gore Vidal, which also won a National Book Award. The books achieved generally glowing reviews and a great deal of attention, and received the benefits of much promotional money from the publisher. Mr. Evans revealed some of those figures, too, without matching the figures to the books: the company spent $78,000 to advertise and promote a book that lost $300,000, he said, $71,000 for a book that lost $60,000 and $87,000 for a book that lost $101,000.
Mr. Evans's remarks were refreshingly candid, particularly because publishers usually go to great lengths (even, shockingly, lying outright) in professing that their big-name titles turn a profit. But his revelations confirmed absolutely what publishers often say: that a few big titles a year can help subsidize the rest. That is why something like "Private Parts," by Howard Stern, might cushion the way for other Simon & Schuster books, and why Oprah Winfrey's postponed autobiography would have meant so much to the cash flow at the hyperliterary Alfred A. Knopf.
In Random House's case, Mr. Evans went on to say, all the award-winning books that lost money were paid for by two blockbuster best sellers that together made a profit of $1.4 million. He didn't say what these were, but others in the division speculated that he probably meant "Wouldn't Take Nothing for My Journey Now," by Maya Angelou, and "A Woman's Worth," by Marianne Williamson.
Mr. Evans said in an interview that he revealed the figures to point out that companies could publish good books, lose money on them and still have a profitable year when everything was added up. "Publishing has to be viewed as a whole," he said. "We have to balance what we can do over the entire range of books and authors," he said.
 
Best-Seller Lists
 Publishers and authors seem to enjoy few things more than being able to announce that a book is a best seller. But what that really means is surprisingly imprecise. For one thing, there are myriad best-seller lists, calculated by different methods and conveying different degrees of prestige. For another thing, being a best seller doesn't mean that a book will earn back its advance, sell all its copies or even sell a large number of copies, except in relation to the other books on the market.
But people are crazy for lists. And publishers love being on lists because, as Robert Miller, the publisher of Hyperion Books, said: "The more places that call attention to new books emerging as popular, the more there's a chance that people will go to a bookstore and buy them."
Which might be why The Wall Street Journal began publishing its own best-seller list last week. In doing so, The Journal joined a growing crowd of regional lists and the Publisher's Weekly list. USA Today started its list in the fall.
The lists in The Journal and USA Today are clearly attempts to compete with The New York Times's list, whose power often leaves publishers grumbling (particularly when their books don't make it) and which has a major effect on sales because bookstores typically use it to decide which books to discount and which books to display prominently.
Joe Urschel, the managing editor for special projects at USA Today, said that the newspaper began its list "for competitive reasons" and that USA Today made the radical decision to lump all the books together and rate them from 1 to 50 to more accurately reflect the marketplace. Of The New York Times's system of dividing the books into five categories (fiction hard covers; nonfiction hard covers; mass-market paperbacks; trade paperbacks, and how-to, advice and miscellaneous books), he said, "The Times creates five No. 1 best sellers every weekend, so five books can claim that title. With USA Today, there's only one king of the hill."
Under that construction, The Wall Street Journal has two kings of the hill. It separates fiction books from nonfiction, but ignores paperbacks. "We're looking at this as something that gives insight into the business of book publishing both for people in the industry and for interested consumers," said Richard J. Tofel, an assistant managing editor at The Journal. "We thought hard covers were where readers' greatest interest lay."
Mr. Urschel and Mr. Tofel boast that their lists are more timely than The Times's. The Times's best-seller list comes out in The Book Review on Sundays, which, because of the section's production schedule, is two weeks after the data have been been compiled. The Journal and USA Today publish their lists sooner: The Journal on Wednesdays and USA Today on Thursdays. (People who want the information from The Times may, however, pay the newspaper to send them the up-to-date list by fax on the Wednesday that it is compiled.)
Warren Hoge, an assistant managing editor at The Times, said the strength of The Times's list lay in the number and variety of outlets -- 3,050 chain bookstores, independent bookstores and wholesalers -- from which the paper draws its data each week. (By contrast, The Journal polls only chains; USA Today polls both chains and independents, but doesn't factor in sales at wholesalers.)
"This is an area with lots of opportunities for manipulation," Mr. Hoge said, "and I think that the fact that we go to so many more sources to compile our list gives us the best insurance against distortion."
 
Man vs. World Bank
 Bruce Rich is a senior lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington who has often been pointedly critical of the World Bank's environmental record. In his forthcoming book, "Mortgaging the Earth" (Beacon Press), he lets the development bank have it, saying, among other things, that it has been "a prime accomplice in a quiet war against the diversity of humankind's cultures and our planet's biological inheritance."
Management at the bank is clearly not happy about this, nor is it taking it lightly. In an internal memo that someone leaked to Mr. Rich and that he in turn made available, Alexander Shakow, the director of the bank's external-affairs department, asks 22 senior bank officials to help prepare written responses to many of Mr. Rich's criticisms, for use with journalists, legislators, book reviewers and the like.
"The President's office places a high priority on the speedy and effective preparation of the bank's views in a readable and easily used form," Mr. Shakow wrote.
To Mr. Rich, the memo was an example of just what he is criticizing. "One could not have a better example of the bank's misplaced priorities," he said. "The memo is notable, among other reasons, because it demands that more time of senior bank management be devoted to preparing responses to 'Mortgaging the Earth' than they often devote to environmental or social concerns in major bank loans."
Andrew D. Steer, deputy director of the environmental department at the World Bank, said the bank was not out to discredit Mr. Rich's book but rather to point out where its philosophy differed from the author's, in case anyone asked. He said that this was a new approach, adding, "We are not an institution that has worried enough, perhaps, about our image."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 4, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A brief report about best-seller lists in the Book Notes column on Wednesday misstated the number of categories in the lists published by The New York Times and their headings. There are six categories, three each in hard cover and in paperback. They are fiction; nonfiction; and advice, how-to and miscellaneous. The report also misstated the day on which faxes of the Times's lists become available; it is Thursday of the week in which they are compiled, not Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Mexico, Pledging Big Changes, Reaches an Accord With Rebels

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico, March 2

 BODY:
The Mexican Government and peasant rebels who rose up against it two months ago announced a tentative agreement today on reforms that could transform the political and economic landscape of Mexico's poorest state.
As part of the draft settlement, which still needs approval by the peasant communities that support the rebels, the Government promised new rights and protection for Indians, changes in the political and judicial systems of Chiapas state, land reforms and a deluge of new social programs. 
 The agreement did not include any binding Government commitments in response to the rebels' call for national democratic changes in the political system that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's party has dominated for 65 years.
 
New Election Laws
 But drawing a clear connection between the demands of the insurgents in the southern state and the growing prospect of further political reforms, the negotiator for the Government said it would support new laws to assure impartial control over elections and the convocation of a special session of Congress this month to approve them.
In a brief statement read by one of its Mayan Indian leaders, the rebel Zapatista National Liberation Army said the agreements reflected a "true interest" in peace by the Government negotiator, Manuel Camacho Solis.
The rebels said nothing about the specific content of the accords, however, and their silence resounded with the mistrust shown toward Government promises in the past.
"We now have the obligation to reflect well on what their words say," said a Zapatista leader known as Juan. "We must speak now to the collective heart that orders us. From our own, from the Indians of the mountains and the canyons, will come the signal to take the next step in this road, the destiny of which will either be peace with justice and dignity or it will not."
 
Admission of Shortcomings
 Over the rebels' caution, the 32-point draft accord spoke loudly for itself.
Item by item, it read as an extraordinary admission of shortcomings in the program of rapid economic transformation that only last fall had seemed to crown Mr. Salinas as the envy of modernizing leaders throughout Latin America.
Under one provision, the Government said it would carefully study the impact of the North American Free Trade Agreement on Chiapas and its Indian communities.
For those found to be hurt by the pact, which went into effect on Jan. 1 and which gradually reduces barriers to trade and investment among Mexico, Canada and the United States, the draft accords promised the sort of help that the Salinas administration tended to belittle in the past: job retraining, new industries, Government support for the sale of Mexican products that face tougher foreign competition.
Except for issues relating to the country's Indian peoples, the draft accords focus almost entirely on Chiapas, the impoverished agricultural state along Mexico's border with Guatemala to which the Zapatistas' Jan. 1 rebellion has generally been confined. Yet Mr. Camacho did not hesitate to speak of their possible effects on the rest of the country.
Should the agreements take effect, he said, "Chiapas will be converted into a very important laboratory where we will be able to evaluate new answers to the social problems and those of justice and freedom in the poorest zones of the country.
"To the extent that those changes show themselves to be valuable and effective, they will of course have an impact on the rest of the nation."
The 19 Zapatista representatives to the talks are expected to leave San Cristobal on Thursday and begin traveling through the highlands and the rain forest to seek approval for the agreement among the peasants.
That process could take several weeks and bring demands for modifications. But the mediator in the talks, Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia of San Cristobal, said he expected the two sides to meet again before the end of March.
As he sat flanked by Government negotiators and masked rebel delegates in the cavernous 16th-century cathedral where the two sides have been meeting for 10 days, Bishop Ruiz warned of "dark or cynical forces that oppose the path of history."
But the more immediate questions lay with the rebels, who have spoken constantly of Mexican Governments that promise changes they never make.
The insurgents' 34 formal demands, made public today for the first time, were striking in both their simplicity and their broad scope.
Point 9, for example, asked for hospitals and clinics, enough doctors and enough medicine. Point 15 called for an end to discrimination against Indians. Point 11 asked not only for the construction of housing in all rural communities, with electricity, roads, potable water and the like, but also for "the advantages of the city, like television, stoves, refrigerators, washing machines, etc."
 
Some Demands Ignored
 The Government virtually ignored some demands, like that for political trials of two past governors of Chiapas, Absalon Castellanos and Patrocinio Gonzalez Garrido. It responded to others essentially by promising to study them.
Still, the Government also seemed to have seized some of the political initiative with offers of change that implied a new willingness to admit that the impoverished south had fallen behind the industrial hubs of the northern and central regions.
In answer to the rebels' more narrow demands, the proposed agreements call for doubling the pace of rural electrification in Chiapas, licensing an Indian-controlled radio station, rehabilitating state hospitals, building clinics, increasing investments in housing and other basic services, financing scholarships for Indian children and improving schools.
Under new laws contemplated in the settlement, racial discrimination against Indians would be outlawed for the first time and special prosecutors would be assigned to such cases. Bilingual education programs would be developed in Indian languages, and the Government would move to stop the expulsion of Protestant Indians from communities dominated by Catholics.
As part of a state-level political reform plan, the accords promised early municipal elections, an overhaul of state election boards, the creation of new municipalities and changes in congressional districts to increase the weight of Indian communities in the Government.
The Government refused a demand that it overturn the constitutional changes it pushed through to eliminate the longstanding promise of land for all peasants who work it. But the Government said it would protect semi-communal farms called ejidos, restore lands taken from peasants and increase aid to poor farmers. Most important, perhaps, it also said it would allow for the expropriation of private lands to break up large holdings "in cases of public utility."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Welfare Advisers Urge Plan Stressing a Need to Work for Wages

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
The task force drafting President Clinton's welfare plan is urging him to abandon traditional work programs for a more stringent approach that denies any cash to welfare recipients who fail to work, officials said.
The endorsement of the plan, called work for wages, was reached at an unusual daylong meeting on Saturday, which for the first time spelled out many of the crucial details behind Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to "end welfare as we know it." 
 To keep families from coming onto welfare, for instance, the task force also wants to spend an extra $2 billion a year on child care for low-income workers. That would, in effect, double the Government's annual spending on such programs.
And to reduce the number of jobs needed, the task force wants to phase in the program over 10 years or longer. The work requirements would apply only to mothers born after 1972, a move that would initially exempt about three-fourths of the caseload.
 
Cost Put at $7 Billion
 While Saturday's meeting spelled out important new details on the emerging plan, several issues remain unresolved. Perhaps the most important is how to pay for the program, which is expected to cost up to $7 billion a year.
The work-for-wages plan would mark a sharp departure from previous work programs for welfare recipients. Those programs, sometimes called workfare, continue to send out welfare checks while requiring recipients to show up on a job site, often in a government office.
Studies indicate that those programs have done little to move people into private jobs. And critics say welfare rules make it too difficult to penalize recipients who do not show up for work.
The work-for-wages program, by contrast, would try to simulate a regular job better. States would pay private companies, government agencies or nonprofit groups to hire welfare recipients for a limited period. Those recipients who do not show up for work would get no cash at all.
 
Threat Seen to Some Families Seen
 Some advocates for the poor say the work-for-wages plan could harm vulnerable families by exposing them to the whims of employers without a welfare system to fall back on. They fear, for example, that a mother could be accused of poor work habits, dismissed from her job and left without any eligibility for cash assistance.
The task force is also uncertain about how to treat welfare recipients who complete a work program but still cannot find regular jobs on their own.
Allowing families to continually re-enroll in a work program could prove costly and dissuade people from seeking independent jobs. But barring re-enrollment could leave families with no support.
The recommendations were discussed today at a two-hour Cabinet meeting, as the Administration moves to fulfill one of Mr. Clinton's most popular campaign promises. He has vowed to expand training opportunities for welfare recipients and require those still unemployed after two years to join a work program. Under pressure from Congress, he has promised to deliver a bill this spring.
 
Secrecy Called Excessive
 The task force drafting the Clinton plan is made up of 32 officials from 10 Federal agencies. For the past several months, however, most of the work has been done by the group's three co-chairmen: David T. Ellwood and Mary Jo Bane, who are Assistant Secretaries of Health and Human Services, and Bruce Reed, a White House aide.
As they presented their findings on Saturday, they cloaked them in an unusual amount of secrecy. The task force members were given less than an hour to read a 45-page paper, which they were not allowed to keep. Each page was stamped with the member's name, to prevent anyone from removing a page.
Several people who attended the meeting, annoyed at what they called excessive secrecy, agreed to provide accounts of the discussion. "I mean, you're talking about very complicated stuff, and we have to read it all there," said one person at the meeting.
The group also endorsed a provision that would require welfare mothers under the age of 18 to remain in their parents' home rather than set up independent households. The move is intended to dissuade young women from becoming pregnant.
In addition, the group called for the Treasury Department to find a way of giving low-income workers advanced payments on the refundable tax credits they now collect at year's end. The idea is to make work more immediately rewarding.
The group also voted to allow states to let 10 percent of their caseloads remain in training for longer than two years -- to pursue higher educations, for instance.
 
Program for Wage Earners
 In backing the work-for-wages approach, the task force hopes to create a more effective and dignified set of work programs. "In principle, persons are wage earners, rather than recipients," the confidential paper said, according to the notes of one person who attended the meeting. Participants receive paychecks, not welfare checks.
But only as long as employers remain satisfied. Some advocates worry that employers may not be able to accommodate the often-chaotic lives of young, unskilled mothers. People on welfare often accept jobs, but lose them frequently as spirits flag or problems arise with child care or transportation.
Under a strict work-for-wages scheme, they might no longer have a cash welfare system to fall back on.

HEADLINE: Cavendish Journal;
Shielding Solzhenitsyn, Respectfully

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAVENDISH, Vt., March 2

 BODY:
Joe Allen, the affable proprietor of the Cavendish General Store, will chat about the weather, his homemade kielbasa ("the best in the country"), the town budget, even about his former wife. But when it comes to directions to Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's house, Mr. Allen isn't talking.
"I don't give directions," he told a visitor this morning. "I don't care what your story is. That's what Solzhenitsyn wants." 
 There are 1,323 people in this mountain town, and surely all of them know the way to Mr. Solzhenitsyn's house. But they have guarded his secret for nearly 18 years, and they were still guarding it this week, even after he announced he was going home to Russia, now free of the Soviet government that exiled him in 1974 over his book "The Gulag Archipelago."
Privacy is still honored here in New England, and in Cavendish the Nobel laureate was able to live and work as he wanted, in solitude. His neighbors understood the distance he needed. They greeted him at the Post Office but never asked for his autograph. And they say they never thought of him as particularly aloof.
"We respected him," said John Stearns, a former town selectman.
Over the years, Mr. Stearns said, he had wondered about the suffering Mr. Solzhenitsyn had endured in the gulag. "That prison business was terrible," he said. "We don't talk about it. You don't talk about these things."
The townspeople never tried to capitalize on their most famous resident, though the local economy could certainly have used a boost. They never referred to "Cavendish, home of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, Nobel laureate." In fact, the only sign that mentions him is the one outside the general store that reads: "No Directions to the Solzhenitsyn Home." Mr. Solzhenitsyn, for his part, thanked them on Monday night in an emotional farewell speech at the annual town meeting.
"You were very understanding; you forgave me my unusual way of life and even took it upon yourselves to protect my privacy," he said, speaking in Russian as his son Stephan translated.
He told his neighbors that they had helped make possible the most productive years of his life. "I have done all that I wanted to do," he told them. Here Mr. Solzhenitsyn, now 75, has completed "The Red Wheel," an epic history of the events that led to the Russian Revolution of 1917.
The 200 people who had gathered at the Cavendish Elementary School to approve the $659,015 budget (which includes the town's first fax machine) gave him a standing ovation.
At town hall today, Richard F. Svec, the town manager, said he had often thought of Mr. Solzhenitsyn writing in his farmhouse behind the fence. "While you and I are talking, a mile and a half away in the woods, he's in his office doing his work," Mr. Svec told a visitor. "That's pretty exciting. I know there's a person in this town who has devoted his entire life to the subject of that nation, its culture, its politics, its history. And even though he's half a world away, he's still right in it."
Still, for Mr. Solzhenitsyn, his wife, Natalya, and their three sons, Cavendish has been home. "Exile is always difficult, and yet I could not imagine a better place to live, and wait, and wait for my return home, than Cavendish, Vt.," he said in his speech. His two-story farmhouse, with pond and tennis courts, will remain a home for his sons Ignat, 21, a piano and conducting student at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, and Stephan, 20, a junior at Harvard University. The oldest, Yermolai, 23, lives in Taiwan.
The farewell speech was only Mr. Solzhenitsyn's third public appearance here since his arrival. The first was at the town meeting in March 1977, when he introduced himself and explained why he had come. "I chose this place," he said. "I dislike very much large cities with their empty and fussy lives. I like very much the simple way of life and the population here, the simplicity and the human relationships. I like the countryside, and I like the climate with the long winter and the snow, which reminds me of Russia."
He said that in Switzerland, where he had begun his exile, he had been besieged by strangers. "And so for hundreds of hours, I talked to hundreds of people, and my work was delayed, and I had no means to stop people from coming," he said.
Here, Mr. Solzhenitsyn had an entire town to keep strangers from his door. Mr. Stearns recalled that the Solzhenitsyns arrived in the spring -- mud season in Vermont. The mud, Mr. Stearns said with a chuckle, helped ward off visitors. "They'd come up here with their city tires and get stuck in the mud," he said. "My boys would tow them out, and charge them a helluva price for it."
Mr. Solzhenitsyn declined a request for an interview today through his son Stephan. Stephan, who said his parents planned to return to Russia at the end of May, didn't want to talk about Cavendish anymore than Cavendish wants to talk about his father.
"It's between us and the town," he said.

HEADLINE: Victor of Budget Battle, Byrd Invokes An Army of Kings, Poets and Patriots

SERIES: The Lawmakers: A periodic look at the titans of Capitol Hill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
"Once again the Senate has justified my faith in the institution, and the Constitution still lives."
Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia offered that heroic analysis on Tuesday night after the Senate rejected, with three votes to spare, a constitutional amendment to require the Federal budget to be balanced. 
 No one expects understatement from Mr. Byrd. But neither did anyone doubt that he believed what he was saying. After invoking the Greeks, the Romans, the barons who wrested Magna Carta from King John and finally the framers in Philadelphia, Mr. Byrd had prevailed against an amendment he regarded as a monstrosity.
For months Mr. Byrd had been the point man. "He was publicly visible, rallying opposition at a time when the amendment seemed to have great public support," said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, his successor as majority leader.
Mr. Byrd spurred the White House, unions and other groups to action, and they spread sometimes hyperbolic fears of the effects of any amendment. He worked with them, organized hearings, went to news conferences. Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, first a rival and then an ally over 31 years in the Senate, said, "He has been very effective in marshaling the economic arguments, the constitutional arguments and the political arguments."
That might not have been enough to get the 34 votes needed to block the measure. Every year there are more senators here who have promised voters to support a balanced budget amendment. Mr. Byrd's strategy at first was delay, dragging the fight out with a long list of amendments intended to upset the delicate coalition supporting the budget amendment. No one knew if that would work.
But he was working with Mr. Mitchell, and Mr. Mitchell was busy, talking to every Democrat, urging each one to oppose the plan and, last week, judging that they were close enough to victory to risk a vote.
Still, Mr. Byrd was out front, the symbol of the opposition.
But he is an odd symbol in Washington these days. A 76-year-old Democrat and the senior Senator from West Virginia, serving since 1959, Mr. Byrd is not only a self-taught historian; he is a piece of living history, a throwback to the days when two-hour speeches full of classical allusions drew crowds to the Capitol. He is uncomfortable with television, unskilled in what he scornfully dismisses as "the 20-second sound bite."
While most modern members of Congress try to juggle the political hazard of being seen as a big spender with the political advantage of getting good stuff for the home folks, Mr. Byrd's commitment to domestic spending is unabashed.
He reminds an interviewer that Henry Clay was committed to public works, which he broadens to include schools, and research and development and other "investments in the country's future." He is proud of the billion or so dollars he has steered to West Virginia since he abandoned the "grubby work" of being Senate majority leader in 1989.
 
Protector of Senate
 He intimidates on the floor. He counts favors carefully. At times he sounds like a one-man committee supervising conduct for this very special club. He voted against the confirmation of Clarence Thomas in part because he felt the judge had insulted the Senate by injecting racism into the hearings. Last fall he urged Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon to resign because, in fighting a subpoena for his diaries, he had "chosen to protect himself at the expense of the Senate."
His opponents on the balanced-budget amendment suggested that he opposed it because it would curb the spending he presides over as chairman of the Appropriations Committee, the spending he defends when it aids West Virginia or other states.
But he contends that the amendment's gravest flaw was that it would surrender the hard-won power of the purse to what he plainly regards as the lesser branches of Government, the executive and the judicial.
Listen to him explain his opposition to the amendment: "The basic reason why I think it is a bad idea is that it certainly carries within it the seeds for the destruction of this Government, its structure, as we know it, the constitutional system, checks and balances, and separation of powers."
"The basic power which is probably more fundamental than any other power in the Constitution is the power of the purse," he said recently.
The most recent proof of this power was a Congressional vote to withdraw American troops from Somalia, as a provision in an appropriations bill. Mr. Byrd said, "When we passed legislation here saying that the President has a deadline of March 31 to get them out of Somalia, after which there will be no more funds, that was the claw in the trap."
"When we say 'this amount of funds and no more,' we are getting to the marrow of the bone."
And why must Congress resist anything that diminishes its control of the purse?
"That power of the purse belongs to the people. And that is where it is vested. It is vested in the branch that represents the people, elected by the people. Judges are not elected by the people. The President is not directly elected by the people. He is elected by electors."
To many other senators who would not yield an inch to Mr. Byrd in their belief in themselves and their own respect for the Constitution, of course, this amendment was an imperative to get the nation's finances in order. Some senators who opposed it before voted for it this week, as their last hope.
But others, Mr. Mitchell said, simply never made the distinction between a vote on an ordinary bill and changing the Constitution itself. And many members who told him that the amendment was a bad idea voted for it anyway because their constituents liked it.
 
Fear and Pork
 But a few senators will hit back at Mr. Byrd. One Republican who harbors no fears, Senator John McCain of Arizona, said, "I see fear and intimidation on the part of some of my colleagues who fear losing their pork."
And as evidence of what he considers Mr. Byrd's basic purpose, he carries around the Congressional Record's account of the passage of a provision for $20 million for 500 more jobs in West Virginia, at a Federal Bureau of Investigation center that Mr. Byrd got moved there, in the words of the amendment, "without regard to any employment ceiling imposed by the President or by law."
"I'm fed up to here," Mr. McCain said, holding his hand just under his nose.
Mr. Byrd tore a strip off Mr. McCain not long before that, ridiculing his attack on highway demonstration projects by reading the Senate a letter asking for help on that very kind of spending in Arizona.
On another day he thwarted Senator Bob Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat who was later an ally on the constitutional amendment, by preventing a deep cut in an appropriations bill from coming up for a vote. Mr. Kerrey appealed to Mr. Byrd's "fairness" to waive his parliamentary advantage and allow an up-or-down vote.
Mr. Byrd refused. "I have no compunctions about fairness," he said. "I will go home with a clear conscience tonight. The Senator from Nebraska knows the rules." He concluded by comparing himself to the current heavyweight boxing champion, Riddick Bowe, saying: "There comes a time when a fellow who crawls into the ring with the champ, if it is Mr. Bowe or whoever it is, he has to take his chances with the same gloves Mr. Bowe uses. And that is where we are now. We are in the ring."
But sometimes hardball backfires. Senators do not like to be humbled.
Many Senators thought Mr. Byrd's tactics worked against him last spring when Republicans, enraged by Mr. Byrd's parliamentary devices, filibustered and killed President Clinton's economic stimulus bill.
Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, perhaps Mr. Byrd's closest friend in the Senate and the senior Republican on the Appropriations Committee, said his party colleagues' attitude was, "This is one time we can get even for all the past experiences we think we lost on."
Mr. Byrd takes pride, but not joy, in his legendary command of the rules. When he was leader, he read the rules and all the precedents before each session of Congress and knew them as well or better than the parliamentarians who help other senators. But he called that effort "boring," and the need to spend hours negotiating agreements for votes "a grubby piece of work."
 
An Escape Route
 So when the chairmanship of the Appropriations Committee became vacant at John Stennis's retirement, he saw an escape route. He is pleased with the change. "I have more time to devote to West Virginia," he said. "I have more time to devote to things that are fulfilling and meaningful to me: reading of history, the reading of great literature, Milton's Paradise Lost, Emerson's Essays, Dante's 'Divine Comedy,' Shakespeare. There is no comparison."
Some younger Democrats were pleased that he left the leadership. They thought he was archaic in an age of television, not a good spokesman for the party. And his image is not necessarily much better these days: he is attacked as the epitome of pork-barrel politics, thwarting popular will so he can spend more.
Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization in Washington, has no patience with that view. A leading Congressional scholar, Mr. Ornstein said that was "about as ridiculous a stereotype as you can imagine."
 
Defender of System
 "Robert Byrd," he said, "sees himself deep down as the defender of our constitutional system, of the Constitutional role of Congress, especially the Senate."
He is not unique in his concern for the institution. Mr. Hatfield, who like Mr. Byrd was a poor boy who rose through politics, shares some of his feeling for the history of the place. So do others, like Mr. Mitchell or Mr. Kennedy. But Mr. Byrd talks about it more, worries about it more.
"Clearly the Senate is not what it once was," Mr. Byrd said. "It isn't the institution, but those of us who make up the institution. We don't have the same inspiration, the same goals, the same motivation. Most important today is the 20-second sound bite, making of the headlines."
He said, "It is not as uplifting as it once was."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Some analysts see a spurt for Texas Instruments, finally.

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
AFTER a day spent hearing his Texas Instruments executives forecast the longest economic recovery in history, strong worldwide demand for chips and the screaming success of new products, even Jerry R. Junkins, the company's chief executive, saw the need for some balance.
"We've about worn you out with all these positive attitudes," he told a roomful of analysts and money managers at the company's headquarters here yesterday, with a broad grin. "I'd like to try to correct that." 
 He went on to say that about $1.5 billion of the company's operations, out of annual sales of $8.5 billion, were falling behind his profitability goals, and that the company probably would not keep financing all of the inventions his aides had boasted of just minutes earlier.
Texas Instruments predicts that the world's semiconductor demand will grow 17 percent this year. Mr. Junkins, while noting that his company's own sales growth has outpaced the semiconductor market's, warned that slower rises in personal computer purchases could reduce increases in chip demand to the single digits.
Mr. Junkins had good reason for remaining cautious. Last year's record sales and profits came after a long stretch of disappointments to analysts and customers alike. The analysts, however, sounded as enthusiastic this week as if they had been at a meeting for Motorola or Intel, two semiconductor companies that over the long run have had much hotter stocks.
Mr. Junkins had some reasons for boasting, also. He hardly had to remind anyone that five years ago his company looked like a doomed victim of military budget cuts and a crowded semiconductor market dominated by the Japanese.
Since then, it has invested heavily in the development of the specialized chips that go into cars, high-powered computer work stations, cellular telephones and computer components including hard drives and audio and video equipment. Texas Instruments still makes the familiar pocket calculators, but its other consumer products are now limited to a few high-end laptop computers.
To smooth out performance in the cyclical semiconductor industry and overcome investor seasickness, the company has improved efficiency and found joint venture partners abroad -- a point company executives illustrated with perhaps a few too many slides showing jagged fever charts becoming as gently rolling as the Dallas landscape.
After missing most of the stock market's advance during the late 1980's and early 1990's, Texas Instruments has recently been trading near its 52-week high of 84.25. But its closing price yesterday of 83, up 1.375, on the New York Stock Exchange still leaves it at about 13 times analysts' estimated 1994 earnings of $6.25 or so a share, compared with about 15 times earnings for the broader market.
Does Texas Instruments deserve better? While Motorola, which makes not just chips but also the cellular phones several of the analysts were toting, trades at about 20 times projected earnings, Intelcarries a multiple of about 11.
Some analysts suggest that Texas Instruments might now enjoy a delayed spurt. "If you look at those other companies, you had a doubling or tripling of value," said Mona E. Eraiba of Gruntal & Company. "This is the only major stock in the semiconductor group that didn't do well."
What's more, the current market cycle, with reviving inflation fears and rising interest rates, could well favor cyclical companies, especially those whose products offer the technology to improve corporate efficiency.
But don't ask Texas Instruments to become the next Intel, dominating a market as much as Intel does for the chips that are the brains of most personal computers. This week, Mr. Junkins sounded like a reformed addict, promising that a company once hooked on seeking market share was now religious about its profit margins.
But then, Texas Instruments could do quite well without ever taking off like Intel.

 BODY:

Markets
Wall Street is beginning to worry about a "creeping crash," the financial version of Chinese water torture, with stock prices gradually but persistently falling. Such a long-term decline bespeaks a return of bear markets. [Page D1.]
European stock and bond prices fell sharply on fear that inflation might be on the rise in the United States and that interest rate cuts in Germany would come more slowly than expected. [D1.] 
 The turmoil in Europe spread to Wall Street in early trading, but American stock and bond prices later rebounded from sharp losses. The Dow Jones industrials ended the day with a gain of 22.51 points. [D8.] Treasury prices closed slightly higher. [D16.]
The dollar dropped as fears of German inflation supported the mark and trade tensions with Japan pushed up the yen. [D15.]
Lumber futures prices soared on reports of a shortage of rail cars to move wood from mills to customers. [D15.]
 
The Economy
Consumers stepped up spending by five-tenths of 1 percent in January, despite bad weather and their low levels of savings.Personal income fell three-tenths of 1 percent, its first decline since July, reportedly because of business inactivity resulting from the Los Angeles earthquake and other special factors. HEADLINE: Hint of U.S. Trade Escalation Draws Warning From Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 2

 BODY:
The Japanese Government reacted warily and with a touch of anger today to the prospect that President Clinton might be preparing to reinstate a tough trade law that would allow him to impose sanctions on Japan if it refused to open its markets.
Some senior Administration officials said in Washington on Tuesday that Mr. Clinton had decided to sign an executive order reviving the measure, known in official shorthand as Super 301, which would significantly add to his arsenal of weapons in persuading Japan to remove barriers to the import of foreign goods and services. 
 A formal announcement is expected as early as Thursday morning, Administration officials say.
The Japanese are deeply concerned about Super 301 because it can be used on relatively short notice, involves unilateral administrative action by the President, and can result in stiff tariff increases on Japanese exports to the United States.
The provision had lapsed several years ago, to the relief of the Japanese. Although a revived measure could be applied to any country that maintains high trade barriers, Super 301 is widely regarded as aimed specifically at Japan, which had a $59 billion trade surplus with the United States last year.
Trade negotiations broke down at the time of Mr. Clinton's meeting last month with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. The United States and Japan have both said they wanted a cooling-off period before resuming discussions on removing Japanese barriers to imports and reducing the trade imbalance.
But Japanese officials regard the possibility of Super 301's reinstatement as an escalation of the simmering tensions. Masayoshi Takemura, the Chief Cabinet Secretary, described such a toughened American position as unproductive. "We strongly urge the U.S. Government to take sensible action," Mr. Takemura said.
Washington is gambling that the reverse is true, that the threat of sanctions will force the Japanese to make concessions.
Officials at the Japanese Foreign Ministry and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry here tried to calm the atmosphere, but said that they felt the use of the Super 301 clause would be a grave error.
Japanese officials had previously said they would consider filing charges against the United States at the principal forum for trade disputes, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, if Washington took action on its own. They have also hinted that they would consider their own sanctions in retaliation, the first shots in a possible trade war.
Today, a Foreign Ministry official said, "The Government of Japan strongly requests that the U.S. Government act in the spirit of self-restraint and good sense."
An official at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry added: "If, in fact, the U.S. Government decides to reinstate the so-called Super 301, it would be deeply regrettable. We should not start trade wars. We should not change the world trading system into a bunch of unilateral measures. Once we start doing this, we would start going down a slippery slope."
The officials repeated Mr. Hosokawa's statement that Japan is preparing to take a series of measures on its own to open markets to foreign-made goods, and that tough American sanctions are thus unnecessary. The Japanese Prime Minister has said that he will lift some barriers to imports, deregulate portions of Japan's economy and take stronger measures to jolt the economy out of recession, which would draw more imports.
"Especially after the summit," the International Trade and Industry official said, "people are talking about their concerns on the possibility of trade wars. What is important in both countries is not to overreact."
Super 301 was first passed by Congress in 1988. It requires the United States trade representative to identify countries that maintain the most egregious trade barriers and to initiate cases to eliminate those barriers. The measure lapsed because the Presidential authority lasts for only two years.

HEADLINE: State Power Authority Chief Opposes Contract With Quebec

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 2

 BODY:
The new president of the New York Power Authority told a legislative hearing today that New York State should reject a 20-year, $5 billion contract to buy electricity from Quebec because of possible environmental damage in Canada and because of a sharp decline in the demand and price for electricity in the state.
"From a straight business point of view, why would we want to buy more of this stuff when we've got enough?" said S. David Freeman, who took over as president and chief executive of the authority on Tuesday. 
 The contract was supposed to expand and extend an agreement that has been in place for almost 20 years. Under the current contract, Quebec, which has high winter demand but big surpluses of power in the summer, sells power to New York, where the pattern is the opposite.
The new agreement, which has already been signed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo but which has an escape clause, would have provided Consolidated Edison with 780 megawatts of capacity, almost as much as the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, every summer from 1999 to 2018.
 
Demand and Price Dropped
 Because of the recession and investments in energy efficiency, however, the demand for power and the price of power have dropped sharply in the last two years, and Con Edison and Hydro-Quebec had been renegotiating the contract.
Another factor is a growing internationalization of the environmental movement, with environmental advocates in New York arguing that cleaning up New York's air with hydroelectric power should not come at the expense of the aboriginal peoples of Quebec's far north, where hydroelectric dams would be built.
Environmentalists called Mr. Freeman's remarks today a stunning victory for their position.
Ashok Gupta, senior energy analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that only three years ago, Hydro-Quebec expected to sell New York $18 billion worth of electricity in the next two decades. A separate contract, $13 billion for a year-round supply of 1,000 megawatts, was canceled two years ago.
 
Like Sharing Vacation House
 Mr. Freeman praised the idea behind the contract, which is called a diversity contract because the physical diversity of the New York and Quebec systems can make seasonal exchanges useful. He likened it to two families sharing a single vacation house, one preferring to vacation in summer and the other in winter.
But the contract at issue would also have required New York to buy 3 billion kilowatt-hours a year from Quebec at a price that looked reasonable when the deal was cut in 1989 but is now over market. (A kilowatt-hour is the amount of electricity needed to run ten 100-watt bulbs for an hour; a typical suburban house uses about 6,000 kilowatt-hours a year.)
Hydro-Quebec has proposed revising the deal so that each side would benefit from the other's surplus.

GRAPHIC: Photo: S. David Freeman, new head of the New York Power Authority. (Matthew L. Wald/The New York Times)
