HEADLINE: Concern Is Voiced in Croatia's Capital On Serbs' Reaction to Bosnia Accord

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, March 2

 BODY:
The peace accords signed by Croatian leaders and the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government on Tuesday were hailed today by politicians and foreign diplomats here, but they warned that the accords signed in Washington cannot be fully successful unless Serbs are persuaded to accept them.
The only force able to persuade the Serbs to do so, they said, is Russia, and some diplomats said they were encouraged by Moscow's recent performance. 
 "What happened in Washington represents a real breakthrough, and there is hope for a comprehensive settlement because the whole climate here has changed in the last few weeks," said a European ambassador here.
"For the first time, the Serbs are on the defensive," he continued. "They've been forced to stop shelling Sarajevo, they've been slapped down by having four of their planes shot out of the sky, and their friends in Russia have told them they can't count on unconditional support from Moscow. If the Russians put the kind of pressure on them that the Americans are putting on the Muslims and Croats, then there's the prospect of an end to all this madness."
 
'If It Leads Us to Peace'
 The Bosnian Serbs' leader, Radovan Karadzic, speaking in Moscow today, said he welcomed the Washington agreement "if it leads us to peace and not to war."
Dr. Karadzic's bid for support in Moscow had evidently fallen far short of his expectations. Russian officials endorsed NATO's downing of four Serbian bombers that were violating the no-flight zone over Bosnia on Monday. They also persuaded Dr. Karadzic to allow the airport at Tuzla to reopen for humanitarian aid flights.
"Karadzic was expecting the Russians to line up behind him, and they didn't," said a diplomat involved in the Washington talks. "It's going to be very difficult to bring the Serbs on board, but that is the ultimate aim. This whole thing is intended to make it easier to reach a global peace settlement."
Under the accords signed in Washington, Muslims and Croats in Bosnia are to join in a federal state divided into autonomous regions like those that make up Switzerland and Belgium. The state will then join in a confederation with Croatia.
 
Target for Completing Talks
 Details of the union are to be drawn up at a new round of talks scheduled to begin on Friday in Vienna. Both sides aim to conclude the talks with a final agreement by March 15.
While Bosnia's Muslims and Croats are at the bargaining table in Vienna, diplomats said, strong efforts will be launched to persuade the Serbian nationalists in Bosnia and Croatia to join the new confederation. Serbs now control about 70 percent of Bosnia.
In Moscow, Russian officials expressed cautious interest in the Washington agreement. Vitaly Churkin, Russia's special envoy to the former Yugoslavia, told the Interfax news agency that the agreement was "a new twist" that could lead to peace in Bosnia "if things go right."
"The formation of the federation permits the resolution of some complicated questions which had blocked the talks," Mr. Churkin said. "For example, the need for territorial division between the Muslims and the Croats becomes obsolete. The Muslim demand to get access to the sea is also lifted."
 
Incentives From the U.S.
 The United States, which was the driving force behind Tuesday's agreement, is expected to offer various incentives to help stabilize the new Croatian-Muslim confederation. American officials are likely to offer direct aid and also encourage international financial institutions, which have stopped lending money to Croatia, to begin doing so again.
If the Bosnian Serbs agree to join the new confederation, they could be offered similar incentives. Their agreement might also lead to lifting the crippling economic sanctions that are in place against the Serbian Government in Belgrade.
Croatian politicians today expressed fear that the Washington accords, instead of tempting Bosnian Serbs to join a new confederation, might lead them to try to form a confederation of their own with Serbia proper.
 
'A Good Opportunity'
 "The agreement is a good opportunity for Croats and Muslims to solve their problems, but neither group would gain much if the Bosnian Serbs are left out of the confederation," said Ante Dapic, a member of Parliament. "Croats and Muslims cannot allow Bosnian Serbs to secede from Bosnia and unite with Serbia."
Another uncertainty in the agreement is the future role of Serbs in the self-proclaimed Krajina Republic, a section of Croatia that is controlled by local Serbian nationalists with backing from Belgrade. Efforts will be made to entice them to join the new confederation, but they are likely to resist if their sponsors in Belgrade encourage them to do so. The region they control includes nearly one-third of Croatian territory.
Before the Washington talks began, United States officials had warned the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, that his country faced increasing isolation and even the possibility of economic sanctions if it did not stop supporting anti-Muslim campaigns in Bosnia. Other friends of Croatia, including Germany and the Vatican, also urged Mr. Tudjman to change his policy.
The change is profound, because it means that Mr. Tudjman is effectively giving up his dream of creating a "greater Croatia" in which Croatia would absorb regions of Bosnia in which Croats live.
 
'A Big Shock'
 "It's a big shock for our political scene," said Slaven Letica, a commentator and former Tudjman adviser. "Only two weeks ago Muslims were supposed to be our worst enemy."
Mr. Tudjman has enough political power to crush any opposition to the accord from militant Croatian nationalists, but it is not certain that Muslim leaders will be so successful in assuring that Muslim militants support it.
"It is axiomatic that generals who are losing like to negotiate, while those who are winning often prefer to keep fighting," said one diplomat here. "In fighting between Muslims and Croats, Muslims have the upper hand, so Muslim generals may not be so interested in a peace plan at this point. Both sides will have to do a lot of explaining to their people, but the Muslim leaders will probably have the harder time."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Fighting Intensifies in Bosnia
 SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, March 2 (AP) -- As accords in principle were hailed abroad, Serbian nationalists intensified their attacks in scattered areas of Bosnia today, pounding some Muslim enclaves, blocking relief convoys and violating the cease-fire in Sarajevo.
Serbian artillery hammered the enclave of Maglaj in northern Bosnia and pressed an offensive against the northwestern area around Bihac.
A United Nations military spokesman, Lieut. Col. Bill Aikman, said that Serbian artillery also fired on the Muslim town of Breza, north of Sarajevo.
The spokesman said Serbs also fired three rocket-propelled grenades at positions of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government around the Jewish cemetery in downtown Sarajevo. United Nations officials quoted Serbs as saying that they had broken the truce because Government forces were reinforcing their trenches in violation of the cease-fire accord reached three weeks ago.

HEADLINE: Setback for Japan's Leader on Trade Issue

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 2

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's efforts to resolve a bitter trade dispute with the United States and to revive the faltering economy suffered a major setback today when he announced that he had been forced to abandon a campaign to remove a dissident from his fractious inner circle of advisers.
It was a startling display of political weakness, in which Mr. Hosokawa apparently succumbed to threats that several parties, including the Socialists, might quit the coalition Government if he forced out the official and pursued a more conservative course. 
 Mr. Hosokawa said he would focus on uniting his Government, which is so divided between its right and left wings that it is unlikely that Mr. Hosokawa's coalition will be able to pull together behind the bold economic and trade policies he has said are needed.
Mr. Hosokawa's long-expected Cabinet shuffle was to have included the removal of Masayoshi Takemura as the chief Cabinet secretary. Mr. Hosokawa and Mr. Takemura, both the heads of small parties, were once so close that they agreed to merge their parties to push an agenda for change.
But Mr. Takemura has proven more moderate than Mr. Hosokawa, particularly on critical economic issues.

HEADLINE: Harvey Leibenstein, Harvard Professor, 71

 BODY:
Harvey Leibenstein, an author and professor of economics at Harvard University for 20 years, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 71.
He died of cancer, his wife, Margaret, said. 
 Beginning in 1967, Dr. Leibenstein held the Harvard chair of Andelot Professor of Economics and Population. He retired in 1987.
He was the author of several books on economic theory, including "Economic Backwardness and Economic Growth" (1957), "Beyond Economic Man" (1977) and "Inside the Firm: Inefficiency of Hierarchy" (1987).
In his 1977 work, Dr. Leibenstein argued for a concept of "selective rationality" as the basic psychological assumption to explain human economic behavior. This, he said, is a compromise between the way people would like to see themselves behave and the way they would wish to behave in the absence of any constraints.
Dr. Leibenstein held degrees from Northwestern and Princeton universities and was a professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley from 1951 to 1967.
Besides his wife, he is survived by a brother, Rabbi Ben Dov Leibenstein of Chicago.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bankers Trust Denies Rumors of Europe Loss

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Amid rumors that Bankers Trust had sustained huge losses in European markets, the company's stock did not open for an hour and a half yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, until Bankers Trust denied that it had lost money.
Shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday, the bank issued a short statement that said that "its operations thus far for 1994 have been profitable." At 11:02, Bankers Trust's stock finally opened for trading at $79, down $1.75. Nearly one million Bankers Trust shares traded yesterday, triple the usual volume, mostly at prices below $78, although the stock closed at $78.50, off $2.25 for the day. 
 The market was reacting to rumors, mainly in Europe, that Bankers Trust had lost money in the recent sharp and unexpected rise in European interest rates and fall of the dollar against the yen. Bankers Trust takes very large, often aggressive, proprietary positions -- those positions taken for its own account rather than as part of serving customers.
 
Lower Profit Seen
 Indeed, a person familiar with the results of the bank said that its profit from such trading would be significantly lower in the first quarter than in recent quarters. "It's not going to be a great quarter, far from it, but their are not going to be losses," said the person, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Bankers Trust earned $590 million from trading for its own account last year. The bank is generally considered to be among the leaders in systems to control its trading risk.
Nonetheless, most analysts expect that trading results for Bankers Trust and other banks will be lower this year than last year's record levels. And it is not unusual for aggressive trading firms to have a bad quarter from time to time.
"One of the prices one pays with an average return on equity of 20 percent is a certain amount of short-term volatility," said Raphael Soifer, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman. As measured by its return on equity, Bankers Trust has been among the most profitable American banks.
Some rumors said that the bank had sustained losses in its dealings in derivatives, complex transactions that have values related to underlying markets, like options on currencies. The person familiar with the bank's results said that its derivatives business was not hurt in the same manner as its proprietary trading. Bankers Trust is a leading dealer in derivatives mainly on behalf of customers. Its proprietary trading is largely holdings of bonds and currencies.
 
Bond Prices Lowered
 In the last two months, many traders and investors have lost money because bond and currency markets have performed the opposite of expectations. Most traders started the year confident that interest rates in Europe would continue to fall and that the dollar would continue to rise.
When the Federal Reserve moved to raise short-term rates early last month, it caused an unexpected chain reaction around the world raising rates -- and lowering bond prices, which move in the opposite direction -- in other markets. Moreover, the dollar was weakened by fears of a trade war after negotiations between Japan and the United States broke down.
The market moves were exacerbated, traders said, precisely because so many people had bet in the other direction. Aggressive investors, like hedge funds, who had borrowed on margin to buy European bonds, were forced to sell them as the market declined, leading to a cascading wave of sales. And many institutional investors were moving to liquidate positions as well out of caution, leaving few buyers in the market.
"Some people are saying they lost a lot of money; others say they were able to duck and get out, but I haven't heard any rumors of people who made a ton of money," the head of trading at a large New York bank said.
 
Bid-Ask Spread Widens
 A portfolio manager at a large international bond mutual fund said that bond dealers were far more willing to sell bonds than buy them in recent weeks and that consequently the bid-asked spreads, or the difference between a price a dealer will buy and sell a security, had widened. "Traders at two firms told us that their managers had ordered them to reduce the size of their positions," the portfolio manager said.
The volatile markets have substantially increased trading volume with customers at many banks and brokerage firms. As a result, those that did not have large proprietary positions may actually have good quarters.
Because of the rumors, two credit agencies said yesterday that they were affirming their rating of Bankers Trust's debt.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Rises 0.5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2

 BODY:
Despite bad weather and low levels of savings, consumers stepped up their spending by five-tenths of 1 percent in January, matching December's satisfying gain, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the 10th consecutive increase in this indicator, which covers two-thirds of business activity.
"That's some kind of evidence that the household sector is maintaining its spending momentum," Paul W. Boltz, economist at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore, said. "That's an impressive number." 
 Personal incomes, meanwhile, eased three-tenths of 1 percent, the first decline since July. But incomes would have posted a sizable advance had it not been for the California earthquake and other special factors.
 
A Gain in Wages
 The wage and salary component surged 1 percent for the month, intensifying the nervousness of securities markets that have become highly sensitive of late to any hint of potential inflation.
Inflation fears were still troubling investors this morning as stock and bond prices, also affected by turmoil in European markets, dropped sharply. But both markets eventually rebounded to finish higher on the day. [Pages D8 and D16.]
In a separate set of economic statistics today, the Government reported that sales of new homes plunged 20.1 percent in January to an annual rate of 695,000. Economists and industry analysts generally dismissed this drop, which followed a 13 percent jump in December, as reflecting severe weather and a normal correction from what had been the strongest monthly pace since 1986.
The decline in new-home sales in the storm-battered Midwest was 35.2 percent but, in something of an anomaly, sales gained slightly -- though from a very low level -- in the Northeast.
 
Help-Wanted Index Off
 Bad weather was also cited today as the main reason for a four-point drop in January, to 106, in the index of help-wanted advertising published by the Conference Board.
Although the jump in wages and salaries roiled Wall Street, economists cautioned against what they called premature conclusions of revived inflation.
"The likelihood of any acceleration of significance is now exaggerated," John Lipsky, chief economist for Salomon Brothers, said. Economic data in the winter months are often subject to erratic swings because seasonal adjustment factors are very large, he noted.
Somewhat more concerned, however, was John E. Silvia of Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. He agreed that while the markets had probably been overreacting to recent price data, "wages and salaries are just very strong" and may even be understated, he said.
Mr. Silvia said he thought the Commerce Department report was not capturing all the income now earned by part-time workers and by a new group of self-employed consultants who were let go by corporations that reduced their numbers of workers.
The report said incomes were reduced by uninsured losses to homes and businesses from the California earthquake. The loss of rental income for residential property alone was $39.9 billion at an annual rate.
Also reducing January incomes were lower subsidy payments to farmers, higher taxes for social insurance and retroactive Social Security benefits payments that had inflated incomes in December.
Partly offsetting these factors were cost-of-living adjustments to several Federal transfer programs and pay raises for Federal personnel, both civilian and military.
With all special factors excluded, personal incomes advanced by seven-tenths of 1 percent, the report showed.
In continuing their rapid spending, consumers reduced their savings in January at an annual rate of $47.2 billion -- to $157.5 billion in January from $204.7 billion in December.

HEADLINE: Chancellor Presents Plan To Rebuild School System

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL 

 BODY:
Warning of the stresses of growing enrollment and educational failure, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines sketched out a broad plan yesterday to rebuild the school system, from cutting administrators in high schools to reorganizing the city's huge and costly special education program to experimenting with year-round schooling.
Mr. Cortines told the City Council that school enrollment has topped one million this year for the first time in 15 years, and that with even more students expected, the Giuliani administration has not made plans to provide seats for them. He predicted that 117,000 more seats would be needed over the next decade -- twice the total school enrollment in Boston. 
 "When I came to New York City I found a school system in crisis," he said at a hearing of the Council's Finance Committee, called to discuss Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget. "The only item on my agenda is strengthening teaching and learning."
 
Different Strategies
 He said he was working on many different strategies to accomplish this -- from cutting administrative waste to protecting the school system from deeper budget cuts proposed by Mr. Giuliani that he said could end up hurting students.
His proposals include these:
*Shifting special education programs from the central board to the 32 community school districts. Mr. Cortines said the current system has "nine layers of adminstration before you get to the student." He said that schools use current programs to get rid of difficult students who may not need special education and that minority boys continue to be disproportionately sent to special education.
*Setting up pilot projects to run schools year-round, to cope with overcrowded school buildings. Students would attend school for 30 days and then get 15 days off, throughout the year. He said the plan would require cooperation from parents and the school employee unions.
*Setting tighter requirements to make sure the money for textbooks and library books does not get diverted for other school supplies. He said he may also ask for a waiver from the state so that citywide reading tests could be administered every other year, rather than every year.
*Staggering the school day so that buses and full-time school bus drivers will be able to take several loads of children to school, a proposal that would require complicated discussions with drivers, teachers and parents.
In his testimony, Mr. Cortines reported for the first time that a student census conducted last October found that enrollment had reached 1,016,728. It was the highest enrollment since 1978. Last year 995,465 students were reported enrolled in the city schools
 
Cutbacks in Capital Spending
 Despite this enrollment challenge, he said, the Giuliani administration, looking to reduce debt-service costs and to enhance the confidence of investors, slashed the city's capital spending plan for schools. While the administration proposed spending $3.3 billion over the next five years, Mr. Cortines had proposed a $7.5 billion spending plan.
He said the administration had cut the Board of Education's capital spending plans so deeply that he would be forced to drop all plans to construct new schools and rebuild old ones. Instead, he said, the school system would have to spend all available funds replacing leaky roofs and failing boilers.
The construction freeze, he said, would block the building of 33 new schools, with 30,000 seats, and 17 modernizations and additions that would add 3,700 more seats.
"Unless the city rethinks its planning assumptions, it will be setting the stage for a capacity crisis in the near future," Mr. Cortines said at the hearing.
He said Mr. Giuliani's budget office wanted the school system to lease space and reschedule classes to deal with the problem. But he said the administration did not have "even the rudiments of a plan for dealing with the problem."
To lease enough space for the 117,000 students who need seats would require 12 million square feet of space -- the size of the entire World Trade Center complex -- over the next decade, he said.
 
Wave of New Immigrants
 Mr. Cortines attributed much of the enrollment increase to a wave of new immigrants settling in the city: 138,000 immigrant students have entered the schools in the last three years.
Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics at New York University, said the rising enrollment was also driven by a higher birthrate and a "reduced suburbanization," with fewer middle-class families with children moving to the suburbs.
As a result, the city's official count showed 1,016,728 students last Oct.31, up from 995,465 a year earlier. School enrollment had peaked at 1,149,068 in 1972, just before the onset of the city's fiscal crisis, and dropped to a low of 919,633 in 1982.
In his testimony, Mr. Cortines presented himself as a school reformer, deeply troubled by a pattern of failure in scores of city public schooos, who was focusing on paring the school bureaucracy and shifting resources into school districts, schools and ultimately into the classroom.
 
Exposition of Agenda
 It was in part an exposition of the agenda he brought with him to New York and in part an effort to seize the initiative from the Giuliani administation, which has called for much sharper cuts in the school bureaucracy, eliminating much of the school administration, but no cuts in teaching.
Mr. Cortines said that by the end of March he would distribute a deatailed budget request outlining how the budget cuts proposed by the administration would affect schoolchildren if it were carried out.
He said he was going to cut back in administrators at every level, reduce the cost of administration in high schools and order freezes for school disricts with too many administrators, as well as review the the central bureaucracy job by job.
And he said he was planning to rebuild the special education system, which he said "spends enormous sums of money to comply with mandates without necessarily providing a quality education."
He attributed the problem to a split in responsiblity between the central board and school principals. "No one is responsible for these children," he said.

HEADLINE: Brazilians Get Serious On Inflation and Deficit

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, March 2

 BODY:
Brazil is mounting yet another effort to reduce its 2,500 percent annual inflation rate and achieve economic stability, a step that is necessary to make Latin America's largest nation more attractive to foreign investors.
Television talk shows today featured Government officials introducing Brazil's seventh anti-inflation package in eight years and fifth new currency in a decade. 
 This hyperinflation has been a major obstacle to investment from the United States, Brazil's largest trading partner, creditor and investor. If Brazil joins other Latin American nations in radically reducing inflation, the country may become attractive to investors who lost interest over a decade widely seen abroad as a time of economic chaos.
To prepare Brazilians for living again with a hard currency, the Government started this week to carry out what some economists call "disguised dollarization."
Unlike Argentina, which has established a legal parity between the dollar and the peso, Brazil has opted for a unit of account, called the Real Value Unit, which is to indirectly track the dollar's value.
For several months, store prices are to be listed both in these constant units and in the steadily eroding currency, the cruzeiro real. Within a few months, planners say, the Real Value Unit will become Brazil's new currency.
 
Assault on Budget Deficit
 Behind the scenes, the planners say, measures are being taken to attack inflation's structural cause, a $12 billion budget deficit, compared with a gross domestic product of $450 billion and an $89 billion national budget.
"We are going to balance the budget this year," Finance Minister Fernando Henrique Cardoso promised in an interview here today. Mr. Cardoso, who is expected to run for President in October, is banking his political future on the plan. After he became Finance Minister last May, monthly inflation increased from 30 percent to 40 percent today. The surreal annual rate of 2,500 percent reflects the power of compounding, month after month.
Brazilians are uncertain whether this latest plan will work, but there are indications that the nation is indeed moving slowly in the direction of economic stability.
The trend, if continued, would be extremely important for a country with an economy roughly the size of Russia's and with 155 million people, making it Latin America's giant.
Though Brazilians are notorious for tax evasion, tax collection is now running at $5 billion a month -- up one-third over last year's levels. The economy is expected to grow 4 percent this year, which will further increase tax revenue, and beyond that, national revenue sharing with states and cities is to be cut by $9 billion this year. All these imply deficit cuts.
Moreover, a privatization program is gradually paring down state industries that grew unimpeded during the era of military rule, from 1964 to 1985.
 
Year of the Auction
 Starting this month with auctions of a state shipping company and a state petrochemical company, 30 companies are to be sold to private investors in 1994. The Government, taking advantage of billions of dollars already pouring into Brazilian stock markets from abroad, plans also to sell its minority holdings in private companies -- about $900 million worth of shares -- this year.
"I want to see more cutting of expenditures," said Alexandre Barros, a political-risk analyst here. "You can raise tax collection, balance the budget and finish off development."
In this inland capital, free-market ideas of small government are slowly penetrating the walls of the Brazilian Congress, too. Starting this week and running to March 31, Congress is to function as a sort of constitutional forum.
"The sense of Congress is to open the market," Mr. Cardoso, a Social Democrat, said. He predicted that Congress would sell some telecommunications to foreign companies and the oil sector to allow foreigners to enter into joint exploration and production ventures with Petrobras, the state oil company.
A survey published today of the 584-member Congress found that 83 percent of the members believe that foreign investment is very important for economic growth, that two-thirds want private-company participation in telecommunications, and that half call for erasing legal differences between foreign and local companies.
"I have changed, the left has changed, Congress has changed," said Augusto Carvalho, a Congressman from the Popular Socialist Party, which used to be called the Brazilian Communist Party.
"We're not against foreign capital that can create jobs and bring technology to the country," Mr. Carvalho said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We are going to balance the budget this year," said Fernando Henrique Cardoso, Finance Minister of Brazil. He is expected to run for President in October. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Up After Rate Rise Earlier

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rebounded to finish slightly higher in volatile trading yesterday, battling back from another sharp rise in interest rates, this one ignited by an overnight slump in world bond markets.
But according to market participants, the market's surprising turnaround yesterday does not mean that the recent selloff is over. Many analysts say nothing has changed since the bond market decline began in February because investors are still afraid of inflation and waiting for another rate increase by the Federal Reserve. The first rise in short-term rates, on Feb. 4, set off the selloff. 
 "The fact that we had such a selloff overseas didn't really bode well," said Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading specialist at CS First Boston. He said he does not think yesterday's rebound was an indication that the market had hit bottom because "we did not see the kind of end user purchases at the bottom that you would expect to see if that were the case." He was referring to investors who plan to hold on to securities for a long time.
"I think people were not ready to buy at these yields and say they really offered value," he said. "They are still waiting on the Fed to drop the other shoe."
 
No Changes in Fundamentals
 Peter Hirsch, the head of the government trading desk at Salomon Brothers, said he also didn't see any changes in market fundamentals. "If someone says the market has bottomed, they are the same people who said it was bottoming at 6.25, 6.50 and 6.75 percent," he said.
But he did say that after the overnight blowout in the world bond markets, "people came into the office today and saw that prices of Treasury securities were too cheap to pass up."
In European trading, the yield on the 30-year bond got as high as 6.92 percent after the German Bundesbank announced that its main guage of money supply growth rose 20.6 percent at an annual rate in January. That immediately raised the specter that the long anticipated decline in interest rates in Europe would slow down, which touched off selling in European bond and stock markets that spilled over into sale of United States Treasury securities.
In New York, the Treasury's 30-year bond gained 5/32 in price, to 93 15/32 in late trading, for a yield of 6.76 percent, down from 6.77 percent on Tuesday. In the shorter-maturity bill market, rates were down moderately, with a three-month bill down three basis points, to 3.46 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
One economic report yesterday may have served as the catalyst for some buyers and helped recoup the European losses. January new-home sales plunged 20.1 percent. But analysts at C. J. Lawrence said that the decline was related to the harsh winter weather and that sales are considerably higher than levels a year ago.
Other data released yesterday showed United States personal income down three-tenths of 1 percent and personal spending up five-tenths of 1 percent in January. The market was largely unaffected by the data, even though there were some signs of economic growth in the reports. The data reflected the impact of the Los Angeles earthquake, analysts said. Excluding the quake, income was up seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Imposing of Trade Sanctions
 Mr. Alexy said another factor which had cast a shadow over the bond and dollar yesterday were the reports that President Clinton had decided to sign an executive order reinstating his powers to impose trade sanctions, which could mark an escalation in the trade dispute between the United States and Japan.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue Inc., an Ashland, Mass., firm that provides research and analysis for retail and institutional investors, said that the Japanese were buyers of United States Government securities for years and still hold a lot of them in their portfolios. "There is concern that a trade war between the two countries could make the Japanese, if they chose to do so to get back at us, sell some of those U.S. Treasury bonds, and drive rates up here," Mr. Frank said.
"And though it will not happen, the threat is all that is needed with investors already nervous."
Mr. Frank, who thinks the bond market has overreacted to inflation fears, expects the economy to slow in the first quarter, but with enough carry-over momentum from the strong fourth quarter to maintain some solid growth through the first half of the year. "But forget the kind of growth you saw at the end of last year," he said, when the economy surged at a 7.5 percent annual rate.
"There is nothing else out there in the economy that you can say will continue to lift it," Mr. Frank said. "And we won't be revisited by a lot of the strength that we've already seen, such as autos and housing."
For that reason, he said the market could rally in the second half of the year as inflation fears ease. "Yields may not come down to the old lows in 1994 before inflation fears kicked in, but certainly they'll be close enough," Mr. Frank said.

HEADLINE: Annual Ritual Begins as Cuomo and Legislators Argue Over Forecasts of Tax Revenue

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 2

 BODY:
The backroom sparring over the state budget began in earnest this week as Democratic and Republican legislative leaders said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has underestimated tax revenues for the coming fiscal year, and they called on him to make deeper tax cuts and increase spending on schools, parks and social programs.
The economic forecasts released this week by the Democratic-controlled Assembly and the Republican-controlled State Senate are nominally based on the same general premise as projections released by Mr. Cuomo in January: that the state's economy is improving, but only sluggishly. 
 Yet in arriving at different estimates of tax revenues for the fiscal year beginning on April 1 -- both the Assembly and the Senate say Mr. Cuomo has underestimated those revenues by about $450 million -- the legislators and the Governor demonstrated that such forecasting can be bent to political aims, particularly in an election year.
 
A Middle Course
 For Mr. Cuomo, who is seeking his fourth term, that aim has been to steer a middle course between tax-cut advocates in the Senate and social spending advocates in the Assembly, all while trying to fashion himself the strong steward of an economy battered by two recessions.
Thus, in his proposed $33.4 billion budget, Mr. Cuomo has recommended only moderate tax cuts and moderate spending increases. And in issuing a more conservative economic forecast than both houses, Mr. Cuomo has positioned himself to chide the lawmakers for being spendthrifts.
"I've tried to get them to spend less, but they are going to say let's spend, spend, spend," Mr. Cuomo said of the Republicans this week. "That's what they've been doing for the last 12 years."
But legislators from both major parties -- whose political survival often depends on how much state aid they win for constituents -- say Mr. Cuomo has purposely low-balled his revenue estimates to parry their demands for cutting taxes or expanding programs.
"Again this year, the Governor would deny New Yorkers significant tax relief by underestimating revenues," said the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican. "It is critical that our priority be tax relief to help prime our economic resurgence."
 
Revenue Projections
 Though the differences between the legislative leaders and Mr. Cuomo are not small, they are not as large as in past years. For that reason, all three sides say that an agreement on revenue projections, traditionally the starting point for serious negotiations over spending, could be reached this week.
That would leave negotiators on schedule to pass an on-time budget by April 1, something they have not been able to do for nine years running. To do that, they will have to agree by March 24, before the Passover and Easter holidays, to avoid pushing negotiations into the second week of April.
Once they agree on a revenue figure, the legislators and Mr. Cuomo will have to decide how to allocate the additional money.
The Senate Republicans, who say they believe the state will collect $458 million more than Mr. Cuomo has projected, want the money used to increase aid to suburban schools and for sharp cuts in an array of business taxes.
 
Ending State Hotel Tax
 Though Mr. Cuomo has called for reducing the corporate surcharge and phasing out the state hotel tax on rooms costing more than $100 a night, the Senate has proposed making deeper cuts in the surcharge and eliminating the hotel tax this year. They have also proposed reducing the personal income tax.
The Senate's tax-cutting agenda would cost the state more than $1 billion in the fiscal year starting on April 1. That money could come not only from improving tax revenues but also from cuts in welfare programs, aides to Mr. Marino say.
The Assembly Democrats contend that the state will collect $448 million more than Mr. Cuomo predicts. They want that money used to restore cuts in Medicaid services proposed by Mr. Cuomo and for additional aid to urban schools. They are also preparing their own economic development package that would provide tax relief to poor families and to businesses that create new jobs.
"We would like to target money to create jobs," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat.
The three sides must also grapple with how to use an anticipated surplus in the current budget. Mr. Cuomo's aides estimate that this surplus will grow to about $700 million by March 31. The Senate estimates the surplus will be $760 million; the Assembly, about $815 million.
Mr. Cuomo has recommended using $110 million of the money to begin a state takeover of local Medicaid costs this year. New York City's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, has endorsed the plan, but the Senate and the Assembly have not agreed to it.
 
To Improve Credit Rating
 Mr. Cuomo has also called for using surplus money on several measures intended to improve the state's credit rating. Those include repaying in this fiscal year a $120 million Medicaid payment not due until the next fiscal year and adding $82 million to a special fund to cover state litigation costs. Legislative leaders have not yet endorsed those ideas.
The legislative leaders are also expected to reject some of Mr. Cuomo's revenue-raising ideas, including his proposals to collect unclaimed bottle deposits from beverage wholesalers and to create a new Keno game. If they do, they will have to plug a $124 million hole in the budget, probably using the surplus.
"Our theme is don't read the $448 million as real yet," said one Assembly leader. "Not until you've found the money to replace all the things the Governor wants that you aren't willing to do."

HEADLINE: Rise in German Money Supply Roils Markets in the U.S.

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
There were few American economic statistics to stampede the high-strung financial markets yesterday, so stock and bond traders looked all the way to Germany for their daily dose of excitement, and the stock market fell sharply, then surprisingly rebounded, in heavy trading.
The Dow, which plunged 50.65 points at one point, closed up 22.51 points, at 3,831.74. The Dow's gyrations of more than 76 points for the day set off the anti-program trading rules of the New York Stock Exchange for the second time in five sessions. 
 The violent price movements underscored how American anxiety about inflation has spread to world markets, where ambiguous data on the recovering American and European economies have prodded traders both here and overseas into looking for the smallest sign of resurgent inflation.
At the very least, the session also showed how reluctant American investors were to participate in the much-heralded correction in stock prices.
 
 
German Money Supply
 The proximate cause of yesterday's turmoil was clear. Europe, shocked by news that the German money supply had expanded sharply, shunned United States Treasury bonds, which the American stock market had been watching for inflation news of its own. The yield on the long bond soared to 6.93 percent in early morning trading overseas, a level not seen since late May 1993, then fell back to 6.76 percent, a decline of 1 basis point from the day earlier. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The few economic statistics that were reported yesterday were generally positive for fighting inflation, so the markets ignored them. January personal income decreased three-tenths of 1 percent, instead of the expected rise of three-tenths of 1 percent. New-home sales in January equaled an annual rate of 695,000, below the expected 750,000. On the other hand, January personal consumption rose five-tenths of 1 percent, more than the anticipated three-tenths of a percent.
"It's unbelievable what we pay attention to sometimes," said Frederic T. Leiner, bond market strategist for Continental Bank in Chicago, referring to the report by the Bundesbank that a measure of the Germany money supply jumped at an annual rate of 20.6 percent in January. But he expects the American stock and bond markets to stabilize soon, if the rise in long-term bond rates persists above 6.75 percent.
 
 
'Negative Effects'
 "Long-term rates are high enough that we'll begin to see negative effects on the economy" that will dampen whatever inflation exists, Mr. Leiner said.
For his part, Donald W. Kimsey, senior stock market analyst for Smith Barney Shearson, sees a decline in stock prices continuing for months, perhaps into the third quarter. Like a bus driver accelerating, then braking, the decline is "not going to be nice and neat," he said.
Today -- when February car and truck sales are due to be reported -- may be relatively tranquil compared with tomorrow's session, when the Government releases data on the February unemployment rate and the rise in nonfarm payrolls.
The Dow's gyrations yesterday set off "circuit breakers," which are designed to slow the lightning-fast reflexes of computer-guided trading programs and begin when the Dow moves 50 points or more from the previous day's close. A 250-point decline would lead to a one-hour trading halt; 400 points two hours.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index, meanwhile, rose 0.37 point, to 464.81. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 5.17 points, to 783.47.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.34 point, to 257.47, on volume of 361.1 million shares. But declining stocks led advancing stocks by 1,404 to 788. The American Stock Exchange market value index closed down 3.64 points at 466.32.
The stock market still has far to go to complete the widely expected correction. Elaine Garzarelli, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, has said she expects a price drop of up to 7 percent following the Fed's Feb. 4 interest rate increase. That would imply a Dow of about 3690, an S.& P. 500 of about 447 and a Nasdaq index of about 742.
In a report issued yesterday, Ms. Garzarelli was even less bullish than before. She said her statistical model of the market had declined to 57.5 percent from 63.5 percent; a reading below 30 percent is a sell signal.
Economically sensitive stocks continued to show strength yesterday, as they have recently. The highest price increases in the 30 Dow component stocks were for such companies. Caterpillar rose 3 1/8, to 112; General Motors gained 2 3/8, to 60 1/2; Chevron advanced 2 1/8, to 87 1/4, and Alcoa rose 2, to 76 1/2.

HEADLINE: 'Creeping Crash' Is New Investment Nightmare

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
When Americans worry about the stock market, they dread The Big One, a crash like the 1987 stock market meltdown. But after a three-year rally that carried the Dow Jones industrial average up almost 70 percent to a record high, the stock market seems to be edging down slowly but inexorably. And some investment veterans increasingly fear something worse than the crash.
Their nightmare is that stocks will suffer gradual but persistent declines, the financial version of Chinese water torture. Such a "creeping crash" would mark the return of traditional bear markets, the slow and painful sort that prevailed before the 1980's. 
 While changes in investing habits, regulations and technology can work to prevent a quick, sharp drop, Wall Street savants argue, no one has repealed the cycles that bring bear markets and falling prices.
For investors, especially the relative neophytes who have been pouring billions of dollars a month into equities through mutual funds, a creeping crash would be even more traumatic that a sharp plunge.
A slow-motion crash would come as a surprise. Since 1982, every time investors have lost money in stocks, the pain has been over quickly and the recovery has been swift. Indeed, people have profited by "buying the dips," which works only if stocks rebound; in a slow-moving decline, that would amount to throwing good money after bad.
Millions of Americans have found a comfortable home in the stock market, confident that they can ignore the market's day-to-day gyrations because in the long run stocks will go up. But in a prolonged slide, the long run could well turn out to be five years or more. Everyone who had to sell their stocks or mutual funds in the meantime -- to buy a house, send a child to college, or for retirement -- could end up with a lot less money than they had expected or needed.
Even if their losses were only on paper, people would feel poorer, which would make them reluctant to borrow or spend. A long and deep decline, some economists say, could slash corporate profits and retard economic growth.
But the worst effect of a creeping crash would be psychological: it would destroy the confidence and optimism of millions of people who have not lived through a prolonged bear market. For those who survived the last one, which began in 1973, it was an epic event, one they recall the way soldiers remember their worst campaigns. Hugo Quackenbush, senior vice president of Charles Schwab & Company, summed it up in one word: "Pain."
To be sure, the stock market could climb from here; yesterday, the Dow plunged more than 50 points before rebounding sharply, closing the day up 22.5 points. But the gurus on Wall Street generally agree that the bear market is coming closer. And when the rally ends, it will not go with a bang, but with a long, drawn-out whimper.
"I don't think it's true, but it's certainly possible that we're in a bear market," said David Shulman, an equity strategist at Salomon Brothers. "But when we do have one, and I can guarantee you we will, it will be a drip, drip, drip one."
The Dow has already tumbled almost 4 percent since the end of January, but the decline has not come in one fell swoop. The Dow plunged 96 points on Feb. 4, after the Federal Reserve raised a key interest rate, but stocks worked their way back up almost to their previous high. The Dow closed up on more than a third of the trading days in February.
Still, the trend over all has been down, and choppy, leaving the Dow up just 2 percent for the year, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index slightly in the red.
A creeping slide would be a big change from the market meltdowns of recent memory. In the "Saddam Hussein" stock drop of 1990, the market tumbled more than 20 percent in 90 days. But the carnage quickly ended, and it was only a matter of months before investors recouped their losses.
 
Similarities to 1987
 That is also what happened in the crash in 1987, when the Dow plunged 508 points in one day, a drop of more than 20 percent. But by December stocks had begun to rise again. The brave souls who started buying stocks soon scored big gains.
That is not the way earlier bear markets had worked. The downdraft that began in 1980 lasted 21 months and slowly cut stock prices by 27 percent. The bear market that started in 1968 took 18 months to knock down stock prices by 36 percent.
The grizzly of all bear markets, which began in 1973, lasted for 21 months and ground down stock prices by almost 50 percent. If such a market decline began today, the Dow would touch 2,000 by the fall of 1995.
But memories are short, and investment professionals who deal with the public are worried. "If we get a correction that lasts six months, you'll see people jumping out of windows," said Harold Evensky, a financial adviser in Coral Gables, Fla. Preparing his clients for a long, slow decline, he added, "is our major concern -- what we spend most of our time on."
 
A Rush to Equity Investing
 Many Americans have plunged into equity investing in the last five years, driven by falling interest rates that slashed the returns they could get in more conservative vehicles like bank certificates of deposit. More recently people have been shoveling money into stock funds because they are optimistic about the economy.
But the new investors have heard that they should use every drop in the stock market as a chance to go bargain hunting, and that advice has paid off. Indeed, the willingness of Americans to buy stocks whenever the market has suffered a setback has helped keep the market buoyant through the longest rally in history.
But there are signs that the stock market rally may have run out of steam, leaving it vulnerable to a downturn. Figures from AMG Data Services, a company in Arcata, Calif., that tracks funds, indicate that while huge sums continue to flow into mutual funds, the inflow is slowing. Half the money is going to funds that invest only overseas, which will not help United States markets.
 
'Anything Could go Wrong'
 Eventually, Americans will run out of money. "Households own more equities now than any time since the early 1970's," said Gail Dudack, a strategist for S. G. Warburg & Company. "It's not a record level, but anything could go wrong now -- say the U.S. market gets choppy -- and those money flows could grind to a halt." Ms. Dudack had predicted a decline of 10 percent in the Dow when the index neared 4,000. "And I feel that if I'm wrong, it's because it might be more," she said.
Without cash to push up stock prices, the market may become vulnerable to the problems that have been looming for some time. By traditional measures -- earnings, dividend yields, book value -- the stock market is radically overvalued, according to data from the Leuthold Group, a research company in Minneapolis. Indeed, only when compared with short-term Treasury bills do stocks look cheap. And short-term interest rates have hit bottom and are, in the words of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, more likely to rise than fall.
"Ratcheting downwards -- that's the way you should think of it," said Byron R. Wien, director of United States portfolio strategy for Morgan Stanley. "The market is vulnerable to the most serious correction it's had since the fall of 1990."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops as Mark Rises And Stocks and Bonds Fall

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most foreign currencies yesterday, as fears of German inflation supported the mark and trade tensions with Japan pushed up the yen.
Early steep losses in United States stock and bond markets also put pressure on the dollar, dealers said. 
 "Everything was chaotic this morning with the dollar weakening due to the horrific German money supply figures and weaker stocks and bonds markets," said William Arnold, chief foreign exchange dealer for the Chemical Banking Corporation.
A closely watched measure of German money supply used by the Bundesbank rose 20.6 percent in January. The report dashed hopes of any near-term cut in official German rates, and the dollar tumbled in early trading. Money supply growth is viewed by some economists as a sign of inflation.
The dollar settled at 1.7043 marks in late New York trading from 1.7085 on Tuesday.
While German central bank officials attributed much of the rise to special factors, many dealers said the news spurred prospects that interest rates would remain steady for now.
The dollar also tumbled on overnight reports that President Clinton was set to renew a unilateral trade tool known as Super 301 to put pressure on Japan to open its markets.
The news sparked fear of a United States-Japan trade war and sent the dollar to its lows. A late-morning statement by President Clinton that no final decision had been made on Super 301 lifted the dollar off its lows, dealers said.
Later in the day, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said he did not expect a trade war with Japan but that the two sides would work on the dispute "in good faith."
Nevertheless, traders remained skeptical about the dollar's outlook against the yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 104.25 Japanese yen, down from 104.60 on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery dropped to $378.90 an ounce, from $379.40 an ounce on Tuesday.
Also, the British pound rose to $1.4964 in late New York trading, from $1.4895 Monday.
Other late New York dollar rates, compared with Monday's quotes, included: 1.4318 Swiss francs, down from 1.4367, 5.8055 French francs, down from 5.8170; $1.3530 (Canadian), up from $1.3512 (Canadian), and 1,685 Italian lire, down from 1,692.

INDUSTRY: NAICS551111 OFFICES OF BANK HOLDING COMPANIES (83%); NAICS523999 MISCELLANEOUS FINANCIAL INVESTMENT ACTIVITIES (83%); NAICS522110 COMMERCIAL BANKING (83%); SIC6022 STATE COMMERCIAL BANKS (83%);

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Economists are keen to give the inflation-proof bond a try.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
HAVE interest rates on United States Treasury bonds soared because the demand for capital is blooming along with the American economy? Or are frightened lenders simply reacting to the first whispers of inflation in the air?
The question kept popping up at last Saturday's meeting in Germany of finance ministers and central bankers of the major industrial nations, in spite of the more pressing issue on the agenda of aid to Russia. And it obviously bothers the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who, while too much the old-school gentleman to say so, is vexed by talk that he might let inflation get out of hand. 
 By no coincidence, Mr. Greenspan last week again raised the notion of creating a different sort of Government security whose market price would provide a nearly definitive test of whether investors are indeed frightened by inflation: bonds with both the interest payments and redemption value indexed to the cost of living.
The idea has yet to catch the fancy of the Treasury, which, according to the Congressional Budget Office, has clear legal authority to issue an inflation-proof bond. Indexed bonds are already a marketing success in Britain, where one new Government bond in five is linked to consumer prices. And fresh talk of indexing is cheering up some academic specialists, who have long been enamored of the prospect. "Is there any economist who doesn't like indexed bonds?" asked Robert Hall of the Hoover Institution at Stanford University.
A garden-variety bond carries a fixed interest "coupon" and a set redemption payment -- say, interest of $35 every six months for 30 years and a payment of $1,000 at the end. But the market value of such a bond over its life is driven by a variety of forces. Part of the interest, after all, represents the expected real return on capital, while part is compensation for the expected fall in the purchasing power of the dollar. Mr. Greenspan would like to know which part is which, in order to assay expectations about price changes.
That is where indexed bonds fit in. Suppose Uncle Sam issued a bond where both the interest coupon and the redemption value rose with the general price level. Since the interest rate demanded by investors need not include a premium for expected inflation, the difference in market interest between the indexed bond and the rate on an ordinary bond of the same maturity ought to reflect expectations of inflation.
Suppose, for example, that regular 30-year bonds yield 7 percent and the comparable 30-year indexed bond yields 3 percent plus an annual cost-of-living adjustment. That would imply investors expected inflation to average the difference (4 percent) over the next three decades. Well, not quite: a piece of the four percentage point difference may represent the return that investors would willingly give up to know for certain what their investment would be worth in the future. But Benjamin Friedman, an economist at Harvard University, thinks it would be "close enough" to be informative.
Actually, the idea of creating a window on inflation expectations is not the first virtue of indexed bonds that comes to economists' minds. James Tobin, the Nobel laureate in economics at Yale University, sees it as a dandy way for investors, particularly "small, unsophisticated investors," to save for retirement.
As important, Mr. Tobin suggests, indexed Government bonds would make it possible for big financial institutions to hedge their own long-term inflation risks, allowing insurance companies, pension funds and banks to market inflation-proof retirement products.
Then, too, Mr. Hall argues, indexed bonds would reduce the Government's temptation to inflate its way out of debt. "No one should want the Government to write i.o.u.'s in ordinary dollars if the Government controls the future value of the dollar," he said.
Last but hardly least, issuing indexed bonds should save money -- especially in times when the public is irrationally skittish about inflation. Mr. Hall was a member of an advisory committee to the Reagan Administration that proposed an indexed bonds-only policy, a seemingly natural fit for a President committed to a low-inflation policy. "If they had taken our advice," he recalls wistfully, "they would have saved a half-trillion dollars in interest."
If indexed bonds are indeed the best idea since knee guards for skaters, why hasn't the Treasury already issued them? In fact, the Treasury has accumulated piles of studies favoring indexation, but has yet to act.
The Treasury's reluctance reflects the worry of getting stuck with the bill for an unanticipated burst of inflation -- hardly a sterling rationale if the alternative is to stick it to the public. But in part, too, it reflects skepticism that investors are ready for something new.
That skepticism frustrates policy makers who want to give indexed bonds a try. "Suppose we gave the party," one Government official suggested. "Nothing terrible would happen if nobody came."

HEADLINE: Inflation and Rate Worries Sink Stocks Across Europe

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 2

 BODY:
Investors drove down the price of stocks and bonds across Europe today on fears that inflation may be on the rise in the United States and that interest rate cuts in Germany may come more slowly than expected.
With markets in London, Frankfurt, Paris and other financial centers gripped by a doggedly negative psychology, prices fell precipitously early in the day, with the London stock market at one stage down by 75 points, or 2.3 percent. 
 Over the last month, the markets, which opened on a bullish note in 1994, have fallen 7.7 percent in London, nearly 9 percent in Paris and more than 7 percent in Frankfurt.
Prices recovered later in the day in most European markets today as investors again began focusing on the more positive long-term outlook, including the likelihood that European interest rate reductions would continue, albeit at a slightly slower pace, and that a gradual economic recovery would help corporate profits and share prices.
"It was an extremely volatile day driven by fear in the markets rather than by the economic fundamentals," said Keith Skeoch, chief economist at James Capel & Company, an investment firm in London. "The economic fundamentals still point to weak growth in Europe and therefore to further downward pressure on inflation and to further cuts in interest rates."
In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading issues closed at 3,248.1, down 22.5 points for the day. French shares lost 38.46 points, with the CAC-40 index closing in Paris at 2,144.66. Share prices in Germany fell to a three-month low as Frankfurt's DAX-30 index dropped 46.72 points, to 2,020.33.
Stock prices in Spain, Belgium and Sweden also fell sharply.
The selloffs continued a downward trend that began early last month when the Federal Reserve nudged up some short-term interest rates in the United States. Most European share prices had already fallen sharply on Tuesday on fear of renewed American inflationary pressure.
In the European bond markets, where many investors have suffered big losses over the last several weeks, prices swung wildly during the day and closed mostly lower. The prices of German bonds fell especially sharply, with the yield on the 6 percent coupon bond due in 2003 jumping to 6.39 percent, from 6.19 percent on Tuesday.
Selling of French Government bond futures was so intense early in the day in Paris that trading had to be halted temporarily, but prices later recovered after hitting a seven-month low. British Government bonds closed up slightly.
Many large institutional investors and hedge funds have suffered big losses in European bonds and in the currency markets in recent weeks, and analysts said some of today's selling may have reflected their need to raise cash to cover their positions.
 
 
German Inflation Indicator
 But the main trigger for the selloff today was the release of figures showing a much higher-than-anticipated rise in a key indicator of inflation in Germany. The indicator, a measure of money supply known as M-3, showed a 20.6 percent annualized rate of growth for January. Bundesbank officials had warned over the last month that the figure would be distorted by technical factors and that the markets should not read too much into it.
Even so, the rise was far higher than even the most negative forecasts, and suggested to many traders that the German central bank would feel restricted in its ability to stimulate the economy out of its torpor through further interest rate cuts out of fear of kindling a fierce level of inflation.
"The M-3 figure has confirmed a slowdown in the pace of rate reduction in Germany without eliminating it," Warren Oliver, an economist at S. G. Warburg Securities in London, said.
Without a continuation of the Bundesbank's general policy of small but steady rate reductions, other European nations, especially France, would have difficulty reducing their own rates without risking a sharp devaluation of their currencies. As a result, German economic and monetary policy ripples across Europe and through the European markets.
 
 
Following Frankfurt
 "The other European economies will find it difficult to move on their own," Robert Thomas, an economist at NatWest Capital Markets in London, said. "All of them are going to be forced to take their cue from Frankfurt."
The markets, analysts said, were particularly sensitive to the news from Germany because of the report on Tuesday that a widely followed economic indicator in the United States, the National Association of Purchasing Managers' price index, suggested that inflationary pressures could be increasing there.
A resurgence of inflation would lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again, a step that would decrease the value of bonds and make stocks relatively less attractive to investors.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wallboard Maker Picks Top Officer

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
The National Gypsum Company said yesterday that it had named Stephen M. Humphrey president and chief executive of the nation's No. 2 wallboard maker, effective March 21.
Mr. Humphrey's appointment is the second in as many months at National Gypsum, which has experienced a number of management changes that began during its Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization hearings. 
 The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., emerged from under Chapter 11 after nearly three years under court protection last July 1.
Mr. Humphrey, 49, is currently the president of highway products for the Rockwell International Corporation's automotive division. He succeeds Peter C. Browning, the previous chairman, president and chief executive, who left the company on Oct. 31 for a post as executive vice president of the Sunoco Products Company.
Last month, Mr. Browning was succeeded as chairman by C. D. Spangler Jr., whose family-owned Golden Eagle Industries of Charlotte controls about 10 percent of National Gypsum's stock.
Another high-ranking executive, J. Michael Conaway, previously National Gypsum's chief financial officer, left the company in December 1992 to join the Fluor Corporation. He has not been replaced.
 
 
'Well-Rounded Individual'
 Mr. Humphrey, whose background would not seem to make him an obvious choice for the job, "is a well- rounded individual who is the kind of person we're looking for to fill the C.E.O. job," said Allan V. Cecil, a company spokesman.
At Rockwell, Mr. Humphrey is responsible for a $1.3 billion truck component business. He previously had sales and marketing jobs with the General Electric Company.
The housing industry's collapse during the recession pushed debt-laden National Gypsum into chapter 11 in 1990. The company could not service its $2 billion debt, taken on in a management-led buyout in 1986.
While new owners of a once-bankrupt company might be expected to make management changes, Martin Bienenstock, a lawyer for National Gypsum's creditors, sees the departures in a different light.
The new owners' loyalty to old management apparently only lasted as long as they proved useful. "I'm sure it was all done in a polite way," he said. "But from looking at what happened you can see the sentiment."
The previous management proposed a pessimistic business plan that pulled down the company's expected revenue projections. Junior creditors opposed the plan. A section that was ultimately severed from the version approved by the court included management contracts that pushed up salaries, bonuses and severance for five officers, including Mr. Browning and Mr. Conaway. Their actual severance terms have not yet been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Bienenstock said.
Since National Gypsum issued new shares at $14 in July after emerging from bankruptcy, the company has raised prices and cut its work force. Last month, it reported fourth-quarter earnings of $14.1 million, compared with a loss of $33.5 million a year earlier. Yesterday, the company's shares closed at $40.75, down 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading.
Strong housing demand has helped buoy margins at National Gypsum, which has a 25 percent share of the wallboard market, second to USG Corporation's 35 percent. Single family housing starts last year reached their highest level since 1986.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 11, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on March 3 about a change in leadership at the National Gypsum Company referred incorrectly to the disclosure of severance terms for the previous chief executive and chief financial officer. Details of the executives' departures were indeed disclosed in Federal filings, in March and November 1993; the executives received no severance pay, as their departures were voluntary.
The article also referred incorrectly to a business plan submitted by the previous management. National Gypsum said the plan was not intentionally pessimistic.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
President Clinton signed an executive order restoring "Super 301," the heaviest weapon in America's trade arsenal, in an effort to intensify pressure on Japan to open its markets. The move angered Japanese officials, who said the Clinton Administration's actions violated the principles of free trade that the United States was trumpeting around the world. [Page A1.]
The U.S. and Japan are moving closer to a deal that might avert sanctions against Tokyo by giving American equipment makers more access to Japan's cellular telephone market. [D2.]
 
Markets
Some big bets on European and Asian markets have gone suddenly and unexpectedly bad, producing losses of billions of dollars for investment firms and banks that are used to losing just a few million dollars on risky investments. [D1.]
Why are investors shunning gold if it is such a good indicator of inflation? Stock prices dropped again on inflation concerns, yet the gold market was basically flat. The Dow Jones industrials lost 7.32 points. [D6.] Treasury bond prices also declined on those same worries, despite a return to stability in world bond markets. [D14.]
The grain markets were shaken by President Clinton's threat to impose trade sanctions against Japan, as prices fell to three-month lows. [D13.] The escalation in the trade dispute also sent the dollar lower against the Japanese yen. [D13.]
 
Companies
Chrysler is so bullish about its prospects after introducing several highly acclaimed new cars and trucks that it plans to spend $1.8 billion to increase its manufacturing capacity. [D1.] Automotive sales shot up 19.8 percent last month. [D5.]
Retailers reported surprisingly strong sales gains in February, a month marked by severe weather in several regions. [D1.]
Apple is rolling out an improved Newton computer, in a move comparable to Ford's seeking a second chance for the Edsel. [D1.]
Lawrence A. Kudlow abruptly quit as chief economist of Bear Stearns, and there were hints that he had been forced out. [D1.]
Tyson Foods is making a hostile takeover bid of $30 a share for WLR Foods, a large turkey processor. [D4.]
Internal documents show that United Airlines has begun a two-tier wage and benefit system for some nonunion employees. [D4.]
Intel will introduce two faster versions of its Pentium microprocessor in its drive to accelerate acceptance of its chips. [D4.]
The Proffitt's department store chain is buying the McRae's chain for $337 million in cash, debt and equity. [D4.]
Microsoft and Tele-Communications are planning a joint test of interactive cable television systems. [D5.]
A steelworkers' strike against Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel attracted little notice and ended after 48 hours. [A16.]
A jury awarded three women $27.9 million in damages in a suit against 3M and two other makers of silicone breast implants. [A16.]
G.M.'s lawyers may have known of the destruction of documents related to a fire-prone G.M. pickup truck, a judge said. [A20.]
Con Edison is testing an electric van built by Ford. [B4.]
 
The Economy
Factory orders rose 2.1 percent in January, their sixth consecutive rise, helped by strong demand for aircraft. But shipments fell, suggesting a leveling off in the manufacturing pace. [D14.]

HEADLINE: Union Chiefs Accept Plan On Severance

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
The leaders of New York City's municipal labor unions said yesterday that they would accept one of the essential components of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's preliminary budget plan: severance payments to cut at least 7,600 jobs from the government payroll.
Details of the severance package have not yet been negotiated, and the unions said they would seek the best possible deal for workers willing to leave city government. 
 But the willingness to accept the loss of so many city jobs appeared to reflect a realization by the unions that the Mayor was serious in his intent to reduce the size of city government and that a severance package was better than wholesale layoffs.
The Mayor still needs the approval of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation to use $200 million in a M.A.C. surplus fund to offer the severance package to workers.
Despite accepting the severance plan, the union leaders were sharply critical of the Mayor's plan to close a $2.3 billion gap in next year's budget by making deep reductions in spending and cutting 15,000 jobs.
 
Services at Issue
 In announcing the response by the Municipal Labor Committee, a coalition of the city's labor unions, Stanley Hill, the committee's chairman, said the plan was "top-heavy against workers" and would diminish services for New Yorkers.
But given the considerable concessions the Mayor has demanded from the unions in his budget plans, the committee's response appeared restrained when compared to the confrontational statements heard from the city's labor leaders in past showdowns with mayors over budget cuts.
Mr. Hill said the union leaders were willing to negotiate with the Mayor. And he pointedly would not reject any concessions Mr. Giuliani had demanded out of hand.
"We're not accepting anything right now," Mr. Hill, who is president of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said at a news conference at the council's headquarters on Barclay Street near City Hall. "But we're willing to deal with this problem, knowing there's a $2.3 billion deficit out there."
 
Linchpin in Mayor's Plan
 The severance package is a linchpin of Mr. Giuliani's plan to balance the city's $31.2 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. The Mayor has said he favors offering severance rather than resorting to layoffs, because it has less impact on city services.
The job cuts would fall heavily in the agencies that serve the city's poor, including a target of 3,600 jobs -- or almost half the total -- in the Department of Social Services, city officials say.
The details of the plan, including the amount of the severance packages and the number of workers to be offered them, will be determined after negotiations between the unions and the Mayor's office.
Mr. Hill said the unions would hold their first talks with Randy Levine, the Commissioner of Labor, who heads the Mayor's negotiations, on March 8. Mr. Hill said Mr. Levine outlined the administration's initial offer in a telephone call last weekend. Although the Mayor's office has declined to spell out publicly the details of its severance offer, an official said yesterday that it would include cash payments based on salary and the number of years of service, as well as health benefits for as long as a year after workers leave the payroll. Mr. Hill said the packages would still allow workers to receive unemployment compensation.
An important concession that the Mayor's aides say they need to make the severance plan work involves an agreement by the unions to allow the redeployment of workers between city agencies. The Mayor's budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, said this week that with an agreement on reassignments, the severance would be offered to about 70,000 workers to reach the total of 7,600.
Appearing with the leaders of many of the city's unions, Mr. Hill said that the unions would bargain for "a much more attractive package" of severance comparable to those offered by private companies.
Beyond the general agreement on severance, the response by the Municipal Labor Committee, whose 50 unions represent almost 300,000 public employees, included some pointed criticism of many of the Mayor's assumptions in his budget plan.
The report challenged Mr. Giuliani's contention that the municipal work force is too large, arguing that it is comparable to other major cities. And it said that the Mayor had underestimated revenues for the next fiscal year by as much as $200 million and could save hundreds of millions more by improvements in the way agencies spend money on supplies.
The unions' leaders also made it clear that another important element of the Mayor's plan -- the use of $200 million in savings from the pension funds for the city's unionized workers -- needed to have their agreement.
The committee also called on the Mayor to involve workers in the review of city agencies for waste and to share savings from productivity measures with the workers, something one administration official said yesterday was not out of the question.
The Mayor's office reacted cooly to the unions' criticisms of the preliminary budget plan. One administration official said the unions offered no real alternatives for closing the $2.3 billion gap. "There's not a single proposal in it," the official said.
While Mr. Hill said the unions would keep all their options open, noting that a strike or other job action "is always possible," the unions appeared unwilling to confront the new Mayor directly at this point.
Capt. Richard D. Brower of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association said the unions would give the Mayor a chance. "Nobody," he added, "is looking for a fight."
