HEADLINE: U.S.-Japan Cellular Pact Held Near

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 3

 BODY:
The United States and Japan are moving closer to an agreement that would avert pending sanctions against Japan by vastly accelerating access to Japan's cellular telephone market for American equipment.
The talks, in which a powerful Japanese politician is playing a behind-the-scenes role, could still veer off course. But people involved said an agreement could be reached as early as this weekend. 
 The accord is coming as Washington continues to weigh further retaliatory measures against Japan in the wake of the breakdown last month of broad trade negotiations under the new framework signed by the two nations last year.
 
 
Accord Could Cool Tensions
 An agreement on cellular phones could help cool trade tensions between the world's two largest economies and could influence the Clinton Administration to give Japan more time on other areas.
However, a cellular phone agreement by itself would not solve the bigger question of what to do about framework negotiations. There the main issue has been whether Japan would accept numerical goals for opening its markets to foreign goods and services.
President Clinton last month announced that the United States would impose sanctions on Japan for violation of a 1989 trade treaty aimed at providing access for cellular equipment made by Motorola Inc.
But the list of proposed Japanese products on which tariffs would be placed is not expected to be disclosed until the middle of this month. The sword hanging over its head had induced the Japanese side to make concessions, some officials said.
 
 
'Comparable Market Access'
 In the 1989 accord, Japan agreed to provide "comparable market access" for Motorola in the region from Tokyo to Nagoya. A cellular telephone company that was already operating in that region -- using different technology -- was persuaded by Japan's Government to build a second system using the Motorola technology.
But the company, Nippon Idou Tsushin Corporation, known as IDO, invested far more heavily in its first system, which used technology developed by the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. As a result, IDO now has about 310,000 subscribers using the N.T.T. technology compared with a little more than 10,000 subscribers using the Motorola technology.
A new agreement being forged by Motorola and IDO calls for IDO to vastly accelerate the construction of base stations using the Motorola equipment.
Those involved in the talks say the the two companies have pretty much agreed on a timetable for IDO to build the Motorola infrastructure. That schedule would be close to Motorola's demand that 159 new base stations be built within 18 months. Previously IDO had said it would build 130 new base stations over the next three years, and that it did not have the financial resources to do any more or go any faster.
 
 
Other Issues
 There are still other issues to be worked out. The United States wants IDO to actively promote the Motorola system while freezing further development of new base stations and new channels for the system using N.T.T. technology.
And the United States Government wants the Japanese Government to guarantee that IDO carries out its promises. A Japanese official said today that it would be difficult for the Government to guarantee a commitment by a private company.
One catalyst for the negotiations, which began in earnest last weekend, was the involvement of Ichiro Ozawa, a politician who is the chief strategist of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's coalition Government. Mr. Ozawa has been meeting privately with the United States Ambassador, Walter Mondale, about cellular phones and other issues.
Mr. Ozawa, a fixer whom the American Government has relied upon in the past to override Japan's bureaucracy, negotiated the 1989 cellular phone agreement.

HEADLINE: Indian Chief and Waterbury's Mayor Announce Plan for a Casino

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., March 3

 BODY:
The leaders of an embattled Indian tribe and a financially struggling Connecticut city joined today in an imaginative economic development project intended to solve all their problems and realize all their dreams: a gigantic casino that would generate more than a billion dollars a year.
The city, Waterbury, would give the tribe, the Golden Hill Paugussetts, land for a casino, resort hotel, museum, bingo hall and tribal village, relieving the nearly landless tribe of the need for a legal war it is waging in several towns and cities to win back ancestral territory. 
 The Paugussetts, in return, would not only withdraw their land-claim suits, which have made real-estate transactions difficult in some towns, but would also pay Waterbury almost a third of their casino profits. The city would distribute half of that revenue, projected at more than $100 million a year, among other communities, and keep the remaining half.
So far, however, the agreement is only between Aurelius H. Piper Jr., known among the Paugussetts as Chief Quiet Hawk, and Edward D. Bergin, known in Waterbury as Mayor.
Before any casino opens high on a hilltop overlooking the Naugatuck River, little more than a mile south of Waterbury's best-known landmark, Holy Land U.S.A., Quiet Hawk must not only win Federal recognition for his tiny tribe and negotiate a gaming pact with the state, but also establish his authority over the Paugussetts themselves.
Today other tribal officers, who aided the state's defense against the Paugussett land claims last year by challenging Quiet Hawk's authority over the tribe in court, said they had never heard of the Waterbury plan.
"This Waterbury thing would have to go before the tribal council, and nobody in the tribe has heard of it," Snow Owl, a member of the Tribal Government Committee, said in a telephone interview from the tribe's small reservation in Colchester. "It's totally bogus."
Quiet Hawk's motives have been questioned almost from the day in 1992 when the Paugussetts filed their first land suit, claiming most of downtown Bridgeport, where City Hall sits atop Golden Hill. The tribe wasn't really a tribe, its opponents said, and its goal wasn't a reservation and self-sufficiency, but a casino like the Mashantucket Pequots had recently opened in eastern Connecticut.
The real goal of the land claims, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said, was to hold property owners hostage until the state agreed to help the Paugussetts win the Federal recognition and sovereignty they need to operate a casino.
As more suits were filed in Trumbull, Southbury and other towns, Quiet Hawk acknowledged that they were financed by out-of-state investors interested in a casino in the Bridgeport area. The casino, he said, was necessary to attract investors who would help the poor tribe pursue its claims.
He suggested that attacks on the tribe, whose members are descendants of interracial marriages, were racially motivated.
Today, reaction in Hartford was quiet. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who fought unsuccessfully to block the Pequot casino, was out of state. Lieut. Gov. Eunice Groark said the realization of the Waterbury plan was so far in the future that it was not worth thinking about.
Mr. Blumenthal, who only last week argued against an Indian land claim before a Federal appeals court, said the Paugussetts still needed Federal recognition to resolve any of their claims. Quiet Hawk is appealing the decision of a state judge who had dismissed the suit on grounds that he did not represent the Paugussetts.
 
Praise From Bridgeport
 But the plan announced by Mr. Bergin, the Waterbury Mayor, was cautiously praised by the Mayor of Bridgeport, Joseph Ganim, whose office sits on contested land and whose city, like Mr. Bergin's, has long sought new revenue to relieve homeowners of high property taxes.
"It sounds like he's put together a good deal that would give revenue to not only Waterbury but 90 other municipalities," Mr. Ganim said. "At the same time he would be able to extinguish existing land claims."
The first hurdle under the agreement is Mr. Bergin's. He cannot pursue the project unless residents endorse the concept in a city referendum. If they do, he would then lobby on behalf of the tribe's efforts to win Federal recognition and a gaming pact with the state.
 
Something for Everyone
 If the tribe can overcome those obstacles, Waterbury would give it 200 hilly acres of city-owned land on its southern border with the town of Naugatuck for the casino, hotel, museum and bingo hall. The city would later buy the tribe 500 acres, not necessarily in Waterbury, for its village.
The financial arrangements, as envisioned by Mr. Bergin, offer something to nearly everyone. At a time when the state says it can't afford property-tax relief for homeowners, Waterbury would receive 30 percent of the casino's profits, keeping half of that for itself and distributing the remaining 15 percent among 90 communities, using a formula based on their tax rates and the amount of public housing within their borders.
One percent of the profits would go to neighboring Naugatuck, for its troubles, and 1 percent would go to the town where Waterbury buys land for the tribal village.
The aid plan would bypass the state government, which this fiscal year distributed $88 million from the Pequots (received in return for barring slot machines anywhere else in Connecticut) to towns and cities.
 
A Plan for the Money
 Mr. Bergin has already sketched a plan for spending Waterbury's $100 million or more a year, in a city that is stretching, as it does in most years, to meet its $208 million annual budget.
While other Waterbury officials are likely to have their own ideas, he proposes that the money not go toward financing the general budget, but be dedicated to special uses, from property-tax rebates to neighborhood sports groups. A 2 percent share would finance the 500 acres due the tribe.
The largest single share, 25 percent, would go not to improve the city's schools, but to finance a student-voucher plan to allow families to choose private schools.
Mr. Bergin, who approached Quiet Hawk with his plan, used understatement in summing up the possibilities. "Obviously," he said, "if we're successful, we'll be able to address a lot of our problems."

HEADLINE: Big Investors Suffer as Foreign Markets Sour

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Investment firms and banks that like to make big bets in the world's financial markets routinely lose millions of dollars here and millions of dollars there on the expectation that taking risks with investments can reap handsome rewards.
But in the last few weeks big bets on European and Asian markets have gone suddenly and unexpectedly bad, and the millions here or there have grown to be more like billions of dollars and more, Wall Street investment experts say. 
 The losers include financiers like George Soros, who acknowledged losing $600 million because of a bet on the Japanese yen by his hedge funds, which make aggressive investments for large private investors and institutions. Bankers Trust is believed to have lost perhaps as much as $100 million trading foreign bonds in recent weeks, some analysts said.
The bets by Steinhardt Partners in world bond markets have led to a loss of 15 percent to 20 percent in the firm's funds so far this year, which translates into about $650 million.
Madis Senner, global bond portfolio manager for Chase Manhattan Private Bank, said he thought it was obvious why a lot of the bets, especially those in the European bond market, went wrong. But he was still a loser.
Why? Competitive pressure, he said. "I was 50 percent to 70 percent in cash last summer, and I started to underperform, so I put half to work at the top of the market," Mr. Senner said. "I would have been on the cover of Business Week but I buckled like a moron. Why did it catch me by surprise? Because the market kept going up and I had relative performance to be concerned about."
Lesser firms have also been hit, like Eastbridge Capital, which also suffered losses on the gamble that European bonds would rise in price. Instead, they fell when interest rates rose in the United States and the interest rate decline slowed in Europe.
As a result some firms have reigned in their traders and taken a more cautious stance, at least for now, after heavy losses.
"There is a lot less leverage in the market place today than a week ago," said William Ferrell, the head of Ferrell Capital Management, which runs a fund that invests in proprietary trading. "A lot of people are getting out of the market and getting clear to shore after the turmoil."
While hedge funds can move quickly, their size is dwarfed by the vast pools of money from longer-term investors like insurance companies and mutual funds. But these players have also been selling bonds and getting more cautious after their bets went wrong.
"I saw a portfolio manager at a very large Swiss bank last week who converted 40 percent of his fixed-income investments to cash over three days," Mr. Ferrell said. "He was very anxious about the market and didn't want to take a risk."
But many Wall Street experts and traders at the affected firms said the losses would not stop them from making such big bets again because they know that some losses are the cost of making big profits. "If you could make the money they do without occasionally taking a good beating, everyone would want to do it," Paul DeRosa, managing director of Eastbridge Capital, said of the big trading firms.
And while acknowledging the losses on these bets, many firms still argue that they are ahead for the year so far. In response to speculation about losses on Wednesday, Bankers Trust said it had made a profit over all so far this year. People close to the firm said the trading operations were still in the black.
Firms are also apparently not blaming their losses on individual traders.
"Anyone lost their jobs? Not a single soul," said Peter Gonye, a principal of Egon Zehnder International, an executive search firm. "This is a systemic problem, and no one individual can be faulted for their judgment when it is psychological and not fundamental factors that have caused the market to trade down."
 
A Bank Undaunted
 At Bankers Trust, the traders are largely on the sidelines now, but the bank is undaunted and ready to jump back into the market, said Kelly Doherty, the head of the global trading group.
"Our level of activity is low because there don't seem to be as many obvious trends," Mr. Doherty said. "If we feel we will have a good idea next week, we will do what we always do -- we'll go after it."
Even if the bank had made some wrong bets on the markets, Mr. Doherty said, it had not changed its commitment to proprietary trading -- taking bets on markets for its own account.
"We believe our approach to risk management is solid and I certainly don't want to change it," he said. "Over time, that is what will distinguish us in the market."
"This is not an easy business," he added. "It isn't the leading contributor to earnings every month or every quarter, but we have tried to approach it consistently."
 
Some Windfall Profits
 It has been difficult to determine how much a firm has been hurt when particular trading bets have gone bad because traders in other parts of the firm who make different bets may be making money at the same time.
At some firms, traders of derivatives have had windfall profits because the markets have been more volatile than expected. Derivatives are transactions based on underlying markets, like an option on currency or interest rates.
In general, derivatives traders set up complex portfolios that are hedged so they are not sensitive to the up-and-down movements of the markets. Instead, they bet on whether markets will be volatile or calm. And at one big bank, the traders took a large position in January that the market would be volatile and it paid off handsomely.
The funds Mr. Soros manages lost $600 million on Feb. 14 by betting that the yen would continue to fall against the dollar. It did not. After trade talks between Japan and the United States broke down, the yen surged by 5 percent in one day. A stronger yen makes Japanese exports more expensive, which is why the Clinton Administration has tried to push up the yen.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bullish Chrysler Moves To Beef Up Auto Plants

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 3

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation, bullish about its long-term prospects after introducing several highly acclaimed new car and truck models, said today that it would spend $1.8 billion over three years to increase its manufacturing capacity by 17 percent.
Chrysler's move could be among the first of many in spirited jockeying among the Big Three auto makers to capitalize on rising vehicle sales -- particularly of sport-utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans -- over the next two to three years. The Ford Motor Company has been trying to squeeze extra capacity from its assembly lines, especially for its hot-selling utility vehicles and light trucks, and the General Motors Corporation recently announced actions to increase truck capacity.
 
Thousands of New Jobs
 Chrysler said it was undertaking a series of actions, including canceling its plans to shut down one of its two assembly plants near St. Louis. Over all, Chrysler will increase its worldwide vehicle-making capacity to 3.5 million units a year from about 3 million currently. The increase is expected to generate as many as 6,000 jobs in the United States and Canada, the auto maker said. Some jobs will go to laid-off union members but at least several thousand new workers will be hired. 
 Chrysler "wants to be a strong player, and in recent history they haven't been," said J. Michael Losh, G.M. vice president and group executive for car and truck divisions. The distinctively styled Dodge Ram pickup has been a hot seller since it was introduced last fall; Chrysler's decision to expand production assures much tougher competition for full-size pickups from Ford and G.M., which had the market mostly to themselves for many years.
"We realize that we have to strike while the iron is hot, and nowhere is the demand hotter than in Jeep and Dodge Ram pickup truck sales," said Robert J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive of the No. 3 auto maker. "If we don't move ahead now, we might miss opportunities for improved sales in North America, including exports to Mexico under Nafta. At the same time, we could lose jobs that new sales could bring."
Among its various moves, Chrysler said it would cancel plans to shut a plant in Fenton, Mo., known as the St. Louis North plant, and would retool the plant to add capacity for an additional 130,000 full-size Ram trucks, starting in the third quarter of 1995. Part of the plant's production will be devoted to extended-cab versions of the Ram, which Chrysler has not yet started to produce but for which there is strong consumer demand.
"These actions will touch virtually all of our facilities and many of our suppliers," Mr. Eaton said. "The involvement of the unions and state and local governments will be crucial to the successful implementation of these plans."
Chrysler did not specify what it was requesting from local units of the United Automobile Workers union or local governments; presumably the auto maker will seek tax abatements and changes in work rules.
 Another feature of Chrysler's expansion will be a third work shift at the auto maker's Jefferson North Assembly plant in Detroit, which builds the Jeep Grand Cherokee, a popular sport-utility vehicle that has been in short supply at dealers.
Employees at Jefferson North, on Detroit's east side, have been working overtime for nearly two years to meet demand for the Grand Cherokee. Many have said they like the extra pay but they are tired, and the union has been pressing Chrysler to hire more workers.
Mr. Eaton said one bottleneck to increased vehicle production had been the availability of engines and transmissions. Since September, the auto maker has committed to raising engine and transmission production by 400,000 units a year. Chrysler said today that it would spend $120 million at its Trenton, Mich., engine plant to build an additional 100,000 3.3-liter engines for mini-van production.
Chrysler also said it would spend $20 million on capital improvements at its Belvidere, Ill. assembly plant, which produces the new Neon subcompact, adding about 14,000 units of capacity.
 The auto maker will also consolidate production of its Dodge Dakota midsize pickup at its assembly plant in Warren, Mich. That will permit additional production of the Jeep Cherokee and Wrangler models at its Toledo, Ohio, assembly plant.
 Mike Aberlich, a Chrysler spokesman, said surveys showed that more and more younger buyers -- the group that marketers call "Generation X" -- reported that they want to buy a sport-utility or some other trucklike vehicle. "In 1989, 10 percent said their dream vehicle is a sport-utility," Mr. Aberlich said. "Now it's 20 percent."
Mr. Losh, the G.M. vice president, noted that with the exception of the recession of the early 1980's, light-truck sales as a proportion of total vehicle sales have been increasing for 25 years. Today, light trucks account for about 40 percent of total sales, up from 30 percent two decades ago. At Chrysler, the light-truck segment, including the company's popular mini-vans, accounts for almost 60 percent of total sales.
The Japanese auto makers have been notably weak in light trucks. One reason is a 25 percent tariff on many models. But Mr. Losh said he thought that Japanese auto makers had not developed many of the products, like full-size pickups, that American buyers want.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Surpassing Predictions, Vehicle Sales Jump 19.8%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 3

 BODY:
Automotive sales shot up 19.8 percent last month, compared with February of last year, exceeding even the optimistic expectations of industry executives, forecasters, retailers and Wall Street analysts.
Sales of light trucks were particularly strong as the Big Three auto makers capitalized on their advantages over Japanese competitors in mini-vans, pickups and sport-utility vehicles. But the strong sales, combined with recent price increases by the auto makers, could provoke further moves by the Federal Reserve to ward off inflation. 
 "That's a legitimate concern," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. "It's almost too good. This is above the top end of the range we thought possible."
 
Another Surprise
 Mr. Heinbach noted that February was the second consecutive month in which many analysts were surprised on the high side.
Sales in January had been surprisingly strong in light of bad weather and the California earthquake. So some analysts expected that sales might drop back a bit in February.
Nevertheless, sales of all vehicles reached 1,150,665 for the month, compared with 960,142 a year earlier. Light-truck sales were 446,811, up 23.3 percent; car sales rose 17.7 percent, to 703,854. The seasonally adjusted annual rate for sales of domestically produced cars was 7.3 million for the month, up from a 6 million annual rate last February.
The Big Three auto makers continued to win customers back from Japanese auto makers. The Big Three captured 74.4 percent of sales for the month, compared with 73 percent a year earlier. The market share of the Japanese dropped to 21.2 percent from 22.1 percent last year. All other imports, meanwhile, accounted for 4.4 percent of the market, down from 4.9 percent a year earlier.
The Big Three's trade organization, the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, was crowing about the rebound. "America's car companies are leading America's manufacturing resurgence and economic recovery," said Andrew H. Card Jr., president of the group.
 
 Car dealers were particularly effusive, having contended with weak new-car sales and slim new-car profit margins for several years. "Everything is selling," said Tony Lunt, the new-car sales manager at Simpson Buick-Oldsmobile in Downey, Calif. "Every Buick across the model line." Ben Arthur, new-car sales manager for Bob Maloney Ford-Mercury Inc. in Rogers, Ark., said: "We're looking for our best year ever. We're in a good situation."
 
 
 
Grasping for Superlatives
 Auto executives, so glum only a few years ago, were struggling to find new superlatives. "Sales of Jeep Grand Cherokees and Dodge Rams are so hot you could fry eggs on them, but with mini-vans you get bacon," said Theodor R. Cunningham, executive vice president of sales and marketing for the Chrysler Corporation.
For the month, Chrysler's total vehicle sales rose 22.9 percent, to 176,550. Chrysler's light-truck sales rose 34.9 percent, to 111,906, while sales of cars, virtually all of which are built in North America, rose 11.9 percent, to 62,007.
The Ford Motor Company's vehicle sales rose 12.9 percent, to 293,066. Car sales rose 6.4 percent, to 153,225, while light-truck sales rose 21.4 percent, to 136,569. (Ford's vehicle total includes 3,272 medium- and heavy-duty trucks.) Sales at Ford of domestically built cars were 153,225, up 6.4 percent.
 
 
 
G.M. Gains 26.6%
 The General Motors Corporation's vehicle sales rose 26.6 percent for the month, to 400,985. The total consisted of a 28.4 percent increase in car sales to 253,289 and a 23.5 percent increase in light trucks to 145,336. G.M.'s sales of domestically built cars were 250,183, a 29.8 percent increase. Sales of domestically built light trucks were 144,402, up 23 percent.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's total sales fell 8 percent in the month to 69,947 vehicles, but that total included a 7.7 increase in Corollas built in North America, to 12,539, and an 11.8 percent decrease in North American-built Camrys. Toyota's Lexus luxury-import division was down 15.9 percent for the month to 5,175.
The Honda Motor Company's sales rose 24.6 percent, to 56,476. Car sales were up 21 percent; the monthly total includes sales of 1,628 Passport sport-utility vehicles, Honda's first entry in the light-truck segment.
The Nissan Motor Company posted vehicle sales of 54,536, up 29.9 percent. Nissan's Infiniti luxury division reported a 7.7 percent gain to 3,491, led by strong sales of the J30 luxury sedan.
The Mazda Motor Corporation's monthly sales rose 23.1 percent, to 25,859. The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation's sales were 19,032, up 34 percent.

HEADLINE: BROOKLYN BRIDGE SHOOTING;
Indistinct Picture of Shooting Suspect

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
An emerging portrait of Rashid Baz, incomplete and often contradictory, seems notable mostly for its lack of distinction.
Several acquaintances describe Mr. Baz, the suspect charged with 15 counts of attempted murder in the shooting of a vanful of Hasidic students on the Brooklyn Bridge, as a man of mixed religious background with no particularly strong or sophisticated political beliefs. He was an unremarkable student, an often unemployed worker. One acquaintance said he admitted using drugs to relieve his boredom, but the police could not confirm that and said he had no previous police record. 
 The 28-year-old Mr. Baz, according to the accounts offered by people who had come in contact with him in his Brooklyn neighborhood, is the son of a Druse -- an offshoot of Islam -- father and a Muslim-Palestinian mother.
Mr. Baz came to the United States a decade ago to escape the violence of Lebanon. "His mother pushed him to go more than anything, he told me," said an employee of a Sunset Park pizza store who declined to give his name but described himself as Mr. Baz's "one friend."
 
Talk of the Massacre
 The worker, who said he last saw Mr. Baz three or four days ago, said there had been a conversation about the massacre of Muslims by a Jewish settler in Hebron on the West Bank last week. The two men expressed horror but not surprise over what had happened to their fellow Arabs in the Israeli-occupied territory.
"We both agreed it was crazy -- an inhuman thing to have happened," he said. "But we asked what was to be done -- that it was a Jewish state." But while the store employee said he himself would be eager to "make jihad" or "a holy war" against the Israelis, but he said Mr. Baz had not expressed any such militancy.
After emigrating from Lebanon in 1984, Mr. Baz appears to have made only modest efforts at meeting the requirements of his student visa. He married, but separated, and held what a relative called "odd jobs," until being hired in the last year as a driver for the Pioneer Car Service in Brooklyn.
The police add their own touches to the picture of Mr. Baz. Mr. Baz appeared to be a man who harbored grudges, owned weapons and was perhaps capable of violent eruptions of emotions, say senior law-enforcement officials.
"For the moment, it seems he was riding around with a chip on his shoulder and a lot of guns, waiting to have the chip knocked off," said a law-enforcement official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
 
Seen as Ordinary Student
 Mr. Baz, known as Ray to his friends, began his odyssey in the United States by living with his uncle, Jamel Akel, in Park Slope, Brooklyn. He soon enrolled as a commuter student at Rockland Community College.
But Mr. Baz, taking only single courses a semester, left after his term in the summer of 1985. According to school records, he never provoked any disciplinary action from the school, nor was he a member of any campus organization.
"We have students from nearly 30 countries," said Dr. Neal A. Raisman, president of Rockland Community College. "Juding from his records, he was not one of our stellar students."
Mr. Baz seems not to have left his mark on many other endeavors or people. Those who crossed his path in Sunset Park described him as quiet and as a man capable of becoming upset that his aunt spanked her children. One neighbor on 45th Street said he could be less than gracious, once failing to help someone on the block whose car was stuck in the snow. One woman who would meet him in the local pizza store said he would sit and drink his coffee -- "no sugar," she said -- and talk without great passion about the day's topics.
"The one time I felt I got a look into his brain," said the man who runs the store, and who describes himself as a Palestinian from the West Bank, "was when he said the one thing he wished for politically was for there to be an Arab United States. He said he didn't care what kind of government it was, just that all the Arabs could live together."
 
'Didn't Know How to Pray'
 The store worker said that Mr. Baz had come to call him his "Palestinian uncle" and that his embarrassment at his lack of religious observance once became so great that he agreed to attend prayers at a Bay Ridge mosque.
"But he didn't even know how to pray," the worker said.
Two officials with the Bay Ridge place of worship, the Musab Bin Omair, said they had never seen Mr. Baz at prayers, although 600 to 700 people might worship on a Friday.
"But of course what he did goes against all of our beliefs," said Marwan Khaled, secretary for the Islamic Society of Bay Ridge. "What happened was an act of terrorism by an individual. To kill any innocent people is an act of terrorism."
Mr. Baz's world took a different spin when he was hired by Bassam Reyati to drive for the Pioneer Car Service last year.
Mr. Reyati, a Jordanian who bought the enterprise four years ago, ran a car service that employed seven drivers, said his wife, Amalia. The establishment, hit with summonses for unlicensed drivers since 1992, is facing "padlock hearings," said officials with the Taxi and Limousine Commission. Mr. Reyati was arrested along with a third man, Hlal Mohammad, on Wednesday and both were charged with hindering prosecution and weapons possession.
"They could have fights, argue," Mrs. Reyati said of her husband and his drivers. "But they were like brothers, also."
Hazin Abuhakmeh, a dispatcher at the car service who Mr. Baz picked up every morning, said Mr. Baz was a solid employee.
Two months ago, Mr. Abuhakmeh said, Mr. Baz was held up by several black youths from the neighboring Red Hook Houses. "Then, I saw him mad," he said.
An employee at Fourth Avenue Pizza said Mr. Baz showed up recently under the influence of drugs. When asked why he was engaged in drug use, Mr. Baz said he did it because he was bored or to relax, the employee said.

HEADLINE: Gold Is Ignoring Wall St.'s Inflation Fears

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Why, if gold is such a good indicator of inflation, as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, recently told Congress, have traders around the world shunned gold?
The price of gold should be rising because of inflation fears. Stock and bond markets dropped again yesterday over just such concerns, with the Dow Jones industrial average declining 7.32 points, to 3,824.42. And today's session could be another nervous one if the January employment data defy expectations. 
 Traders will examine today whether the data, known as nonfarm payrolls, almost doubles, and the unemployment rate remains the same, as expected. If job creation expands even more or unemployment drops, or both, the markets will probably interpret the numbers as inflationary, analysts say.
 
Gold Is Oasis of Calm
 But the gold market is likely to be largely unmoved. It has been an oasis of calm lately. Gold closed down slightly yesterday for the fourth consecutive session. Why?
"The gold market is saying that there is no evidence of inflation in the system," said Daniel S. Weissman, vice president for precious metals trading at MTB Bank.
Moreover, Mr. Weissman said, the customers that have been driving up the price of the precious metal in recent months, like the Chinese and Koreans, are scaling back and big portfolio managers are selling gold to raise cash -- often to cover their losses in the stock and bond markets.
Yesterday, the Standard & Poor's 500 index declined 1.80 points, to 463.01. But the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 1.11 points, to 784.58.
 
30-Year Treasury Bond
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 24/32 to 9222/32 , at a yield of 6.83 percent, up 7 basis points from the day before. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
By contrast, gold for April delivery fell 60 cents, to $378.30 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Gold has lost about 3 percent of its value since since Feb. 4, when the Fed nudged short-term interest rates higher. Gold traders have mostly ignored inflation-related news that plunged the stock and bond markets into turmoil.
Dinsa Mehta, chief bullion trader for the Chase Manhattan Bank, said: "As long as the gold market believes inflation is being neutralized by higher interest rates, the gold market stabilizes. It's the fear of un-neutralized inflation that raises gold prices."
For its part, the Dow plunged in the first half-hour of trading, attempted to recover for most of the session but closed down, the fifth declining session out of the last six.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index closed off 0.79 point, to 256.68, on volume of 292 million shares. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing ones by 1,190 to 950. The American Stock Exchange market value index closed down 0.67 point, to 465.65.
Eighteen of the 30 Dow component stocks dropped in price, including several economically sensitive stocks. Aluminum Company of America dropped 1 5/8, to 74 7/8, and General Electric dropped 5/8, to 105 1/4. Disney dropped 1, to 45 3/4, despite a London debt trader's description of Euro Disney's debt as attractively priced.
The biggest percentage decliner on the New York Stock Exchange was First Union Real Estate, once a leading real estate investment trust. Its lofty stock price had defied industry analysts' longstanding criticism of the company's high debt and questionable real estate projects.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Drop On More Inflation Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday, despite a return to relative stability in world bond markets. On Wednesday, a plunge in world bond markets set off selling of American Treasury securities.
Weakness in yesterday's session was traced to those bond investors still concerned with inflation ahead of today's scheduled employment report for February. Also weighing on the market was fear of a potential trade confrontation between the United States and Japan, which some analysts termed overblown. But other analysts say the threat is just as real for a market where nerves have frayed more each day over the last month. 
 In late trading, the price of a 30-year Treasury bond was down 24/32 to trade at 9222/32 as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.83 percent, from 6.76 percent on Wednesday.
Shorter-maturity Treasury bills were mixed with a three-month bill rate unchanged at 3.46 percent and a six-month bill at 3.67 percent, up a basis point. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
An Inflationary Move?
 President Clinton's decision to reinstate tough trade powers weighed on the market because some saw trade sanctions as protectionist and potentially inflationary, traders said. It could set the stage for United States producers to raise prices on manufactured goods as prices of imported products are forced up because of tariffs.
Leon C. Brand, global market specialist at NatWest Securities, said that with the overseas markets somewhat stabilized, investors turned their attention to today's unemployment data, which will be delivered to a market still in the dark over how much of the surge in fourth-quarter economic growth has has carried over into 1994.
Because of the market's concern about inflationary pressures building in the economy, analysts said the jobs data would be scrutinized for signs of growth.
Guaranteed to attract particular attention in the report, the analysts said, will be the average hourly earnings figure, which will be following an increase of eight-tenths of a percent in January. A flat hourly earnings number would provide the market some reassurance that wage inflation is not a near-term threat, analysts added.
Some market watchers, however, are not expecting the data to be illuminating because of weather-related distortions.
Mr. Brand of NatWest said the consensus forecast was for an increase in nonfarm payroll jobs of 138,000. But the range of forecasts runs from 50,000 to 275,000.
 
Other Data Reported
 Treasuries were not influenced by data showing United States factory orders rose 2.1 percent in January. Prices had dipped earlier after a report that showed a surprisingly large plunge in jobless claims. The claims in the week ended Feb. 26 fell by 57,000, to 318,000, from a revised 375,000. Analysts had expected a drop of 21,000. But while the drop was large, analysts said it might reflect distortions from weather rather than any significant change in the labor market.
Mark Grant, managing director and head of fixed-income investing in Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the market needed a period of stability to regroup. "But right now," he said, "there is a lot of volatility in the market, being fueled by large investors repositioning themselves after going out on the yield curve for better yields. Perhaps much further out than was probably prudent."
At the Treasury's one-year bill auction yesterday, the average rate was 4.03 percent, up from the 3.59 percent at the last auction on Feb. 3 and the highest yield since May 28, 1992, when it was 4.07 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Yen As Japan Dispute Intensifies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
An escalation in the trade dispute between Washington and Tokyo sent the dollar lower against the Japanese yen yesterday.
But the dollar strengthened slightly against the German mark and some other European currencies. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices eased in American trading after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for April delivery slipped 60 cents, to $378.30 an ounce.
Currency traders said the dollar fell on official word that President Clinton had resurrected a punitive provision of American trade law that could result in sharply higher tariffs for Japanese imports. Although the dollar partly recovered, it ended in New York at 103.88 yen, down from 104.25 yen on Wednesday.
"There was a knee-jerk reaction to sell the dollar," said Curtis Perkins, a trader on the foreign exchange desk at the Chemical Bank in New York.
Mr. Clinton's move had been expected but was still seen as an inflammatory step in the prolonged dispute over Japan's large trade surpluses with the United States. Talks over ways to reduce the surplus collapsed last month.
 
Some Pressure to Sell
 There is an underlying assumption in the currency markets that the dollar must decline in value against the yen to help resolve the dispute. A cheaper dollar makes American goods more affordable in Japan and Japanese goods more expensive in the United States, which could help narrow the trade imbalance.
"It wasn't a real surprise to anybody," Jack Griffin, vice president on the corporate foreign exchange desk at the New York branch of Japan's Fuji Bank, said of the Clinton move. "There was some selling pressure when the news came out but that abated."
The dollar did rise to 1.7100 marks in New York, from 1.7043 on Wednesday. The gain came after Germany's central bank took no action on interest-rate policy after a regular meeting.
There had been some speculation that the Germans might nudge up interest rates after money-supply figures released on Wednesday suggested a possible rise in inflation. The dollar had plunged in value against the mark in response because higher German rates would make mark-denominated investments worth more.

HEADLINE: January Factory Orders Up For Sixth Gain in a Row

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
Factory orders increased in January for the sixth consecutive month, helped by strong demand for aircraft, the Commerce Department said today. But the report also suggested a leveling off in the manufacturing pace as shipments fell.
Separately, the Labor Department reported a sharp drop in new claims for unemployment benefits last week. 
 The 2.1 percent rise in January factory orders, to a seasonally adjusted $272 billion, extended the best string of pickups in six years. The last time there was a longer series of monthly increases was during the nine months from September 1987 through June 1988.
Analysts said the report was further evidence of an expanding economy, but noted that factory business was strongly pumped up in January by booming aircraft orders.
Total transportation orders, which includes cars as well as airplanes, shot up 14 percent after a 3.7 percent gain in December.
But excluding transportation, total factory orders rose only a scant three-tenths of 1 percent, after an increase of 1 percent in December.
"The report is pretty consistent with current economic conditions showing the economy doing nicely after adjustments for weather and the California earthquake," Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis, said.
Possibly because of harsh weather, shipments dipped in January for the first time since mid-1993. They fell only one-tenth of 1 percent but the slackening was evident in virtually every product category except cars and planes.
Order backlogs grew six-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $444.6 billion, the first bump upward in unfilled orders since February 1993. That suggests factories have enough business in hand to keep busy.
In the report on first-time claims for unemployment benefits, the Labor Department said claims dropped 57,000 in the week that ended Feb. 26, to 318,000 -- the lowest since the week of Christmas.
The weekly number of first-time claims has whipsawed this year, making it hard to construct an accurate picture of the employment situation. Bitter cold and winter storms caused temporary layoffs, but the weather also kept some people from filing for claims.
The four-week moving average for new claims, which smoothes out weekly fluctuations, stood at 352,500 in the week that ended Feb. 26. The average remains well above the 324,250 level seen at the beginning of the year.
"We had to be worried about whether increased claims were caused by layoffs or weather," Brian Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers, said. "It will take time before we thaw out and find out for sure if it's the weather."

HEADLINE: As Farrakhan Groups Land Jobs From Government, Debate Grows

SERIES: Ministry of Hope, Message of Hate -- Second of three articles on the Nation of Islam.

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
The four security guards sit serenely behind the plexiglass barrier in the barren lobby of the Flaghouse Courts housing project. They tell visitors to pass through a metal detector, show identification and name the residents they want to visit. Occasionally, one of the four -- all young blacks whose contract says they earn $11 an hour -- picks up a walkie talkie, zips up his blue jacket and leaves the booth to patrol the building's hallways and staircases.
For the most part, the guards look and act like any other guards keeping watch over a public housing project. Only a patch on the left sleeve -- a white crescent and star and "N.O.I. Security" stitched on a red background -- indicates they represent something different.
 
For Some, a Ray of Hope
 To many residents at Flaghouse Courts, near downtown Baltimore, the presence of the guards from a company affiliated with the Nation of Islam provides a ray of hope for halting the drug dealing and violence that infest the project. 
 But some Jewish groups and legislators like Representative Peter T. King, Republican of Long Island, have complained that employing a company affiliated with the Nation of Islam to protect public housing means taxpayer money is subsidizing a hate group whose leader, Louis Farrakhan, calls whites "devils" and has described Judaism as a "gutter religion."
For the Nation of Islam and its followers, however, the government contracts represent a fundamental shift in financial policy. The organization's leaders are now aggressively seeking work from governments and white-owned businesses. In Baltimore, for example, the N.O.I. Security Agency has, since June, signed contracts with the Baltimore Housing Authority to provide security at 10 high-rise public apartment houses. The contracts will eventually bring in $2.8 million.
It was not always this way. For years the Nation of Islam preached a doctrine that called for economic development, primarily by selling goods to other blacks.
"The businesses were never supported by anyone other than Nation of Islam members," said Iman W. D. Mohammed, who followed his father, Elijah Muhammad, as leader of the group until he moved toward mainstream Islam 15 years ago. "There was no government funding at all during the Honorable Elijah Muhammad's lifetime. That was his policy. He feared government involvement would take away from his control and plans for the businesses."
 
Move to Moderation
 The flow of public money does more than bolster the financial base of the organization. Some former members and other outsiders in academia or community groups who study it see a parallel: as the group's acquisition of government contracts expanded, Mr. Farrakhan's speeches grew more moderate. The contracts have also drawn many public agencies into the national debate over religious freedom and racial bias that has shadowed the Nation of Islam.
The group first ventured into providing private security guards in 1988, when it began patrolling two apartment complexes in Northeast Washington, near the Anacostia River. In 1990, members of the Nation formed the N.O.I. Security Agency, with headquarters in Washington.
The company won contracts to guard federally subsidized apartment complexes in Pittsburgh in 1991, in Philadelphia and Los Angeles in 1992, and in Chicago and Baltimore in 1993. Though several of those contracts have not been renewed, and the one in Los Angeles was canceled, N.O.I. Security has continued to bring in more business.
As privately held businesses, the Nation of Islam affiliates are not required to publish details of their finances, and officials declined to provide them. But based on figures gathered from public records and private estimates, companies associated with the organization have taken in more than $1 million from public agencies since June 1991. And the businesses are ever seeking to increase that amount.
Another security company, New Life Inc., run by Mr. Farrakhan's son-in-law Leonard Farrakhan Muhammad, gets about $60,000 a month from the State of Illinois and Chicago for guarding public housing projects. It is also part of a joint venture negotiating a $5 million contract with the Chicago Housing Authority to manage and guard another project on Chicago's West Side.
 
Treating AIDS Patients
 A chain of health clinics run by a top Nation of Islam official received $213,000 last April in Federal money for a one-year contract to treat AIDS patients in Washington; the chain, Abundant Life Foundation, is also seeking a share of $2 million in AIDS treatment contracts that the District of Columbia government will soon hand out.
N.O.I. Security has also provided security for private companies in Washington, including Federal Express, which employs it to guard its sorting center, and for the Ramada Renaissance Hotel.
These contracts have caught the attention of critics of the Nation of Islam, especially Jewish groups, who say that public money should not go to individuals or companies affiliated with such groups.
"Giving money to hatemongers only empowers and legitimizes them," Alfred H. Moses, president of the American Jewish Committee, wrote in February to Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
Similarly, Abraham H. Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, complained: "Any group seeking federally funded contracts cannot discriminate on the basis of race or religion and government funds cannot be used to proselytize. All these concerns come into play with Nation of Islam contracts."
But Leonard Muhammad bristles at such suggestions, saying, "What we resent, what I resent, having had relatives who fought and died for this country, is for anyone to suggest that because of our religious affiliation we don't have the right to be in business."
Officials at the Department of Health and Human Services say the decision to provide money to the Washington AIDS clinic was made by the District of Columbia government, not by Federal officials. Housing Department officials did not respond to requests for comment on Federal money going to pay the security company.
 
The Reviews
Earning Praise, But Not Invincible
 The security companies affiliated with the National of Islam have chalked up some striking successes and suffered some stunning failures. Nation of Islam security guards generally do not carry weapons but have nonetheless been accused of violence in a few instances. And in some cities they have failed to halt lawlessness at apartment complexes they were guarding.
But in Washington and Baltimore there have been accolades, and more contracts.
"They didn't try to indoctrinate anyone," said Gregory E. Harraka, director of operations for Coakley Williams, a Maryland construction company that hired N.O.I. Security to guard a construction site in Washington. "They put a picture of Elijah Muhammad on a wall of their trailer, but that didn't bother us at all. We don't endorse their philosophy. But, in terms of security, they did a fine job."
That has not been a universal sentiment, and poor evaluations led housing managers in Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Los Angeles to cancel or decide against renewing contracts.
Last year, for example, the managers of a HUD-subsidized housing developmentin Los Angeles dismissed N.O.I. Security after its guards were unable to stop gang violence and drug trafficking. N.O.I. won a $644,000-a-year contract in November 1992 to guard the project, Holiday Venice.
Los Angeles police officials showed the managers photographs and videotapes of N.O.I. guards watching drug sales at Holiday Venice. The police said the guards appeared to have been intimidated by a gang, the Shoreline Crips.
"They went head to head with these guys, and even if the Nation of Islam had been armed, that may not have made the difference, though they certainly would have had more of an impact," said Sgt. Kirk Albanese, who headed a police antidrug unit at the time. "This was not your typical security job at a supermarket. This was as dangerous as it gets."
In Pittsburgh, police officials and some tenants said that there had been no noticeable decrease in crime in the two HUD-subsidized housing complexes guarded by N.O.I. Security. When the contracts expired, management hired armed guards from another company.
The Nation has also not enjoyed spotless records as guards: two members of a Nation of Islam security detail were convicted in 1992 of second-degree murder in the death of an unarmed patron at the Inglewood, Calif., nightclub they were guarding.
 
The Businesses
Taking Money From 'Devils'
 In aggressively seeking public and private contracts, Mr. Farrakhan and his aides have revived an emphasis on entrepreneurship begun under Elijah Muhammad that had flagged when his son W. D., or Wallace, succeeded him in 1975.
"Economic nationalism wasn't as important to Wallace as it was to Elijah," said Salim Muwakkill, who is a former managing editor of Muhammad Speaks, at the time the group's newspaper, and who is no longer a Nation member. "He wanted to transform the Nation of Islam into a community of religious people who might be or might not be entrepreneurial. Economic and political matters would be ancillary."
When Elijah Muhammad died, the group's assets were $46 million, say lawyers familiar with the battle over estate. Poor financial management and a reduction in contributions whittled this down quickly. Mr. Muwakkill said that Mr. Farrakhan's break with Mr. Mohammad (Elijah Muhammad's son changed the spelling of his name) in 1978 had almost as much to do with his anger over the group's sagging financial fortunes as it did with Wallace Mohammad's declaration that whites were no longer to be considered devils and would be allowed to join the organization.
Once on his own, Mr. Farrakhan rebuilt the Nation of Islam's financial base, reinstituting mandatory tithes and expanding the circulation of the group's newspapers.
 
Economic Blueprint
 In addition, Mr. Farrakhan developed what he called an economic blueprint for the Nation of Islam, buying farms and setting up banks and insurance companies and other businesses. The group now sells a line of hair and skin care products started up with a $5 million loan from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi the Libyan leader.
In February, Mr. Farrakhan announced that the group would spend $1.5 million for a printing operation in Chicago to produce the Nation of Islam's newspaper and, he hopes, other newspapers for black readers. He has also joined leaders of other black religious groups in starting a company to buy broadcast and other entertainment companies. The first purchase of the group, the African-American Religious Connection, was WLGO-AM in Columbia, S.C.
But in courting white companies and government agencies for contracts, Mr. Farrakhan has moved his group beyond just selling goods to blacks. Some analysts suggest that the move is connected to efforts by Mr. Farrakhan to moderate some of his views.
These analysts theorize that the need to keep government contracts was a factor in the demotion of his chief spokesman, Khallid Abdul Muhammad, for the language he used in an anti-white, anti-Jewish, anti-homosexual speech in November.
"It was important to rebuke Khallid; otherwise it would have been hard to reach out to mainstream people," Mr. Muwakkill said. "The playing field in which he is now working is contracts and the kind of things that people must be credible to receive and need some sort of mainstream acceptance, even if it's grudging."
 
The Project
In Baltimore, Relief From Crime
 Crime had been rampant at a number of Baltimore's 16 high-rise apartment buildings for low-income tenants. The situation was the bleakest at Flaghouse Court, a stone's throw from the Inner Harbor and the National Aquarium, two of the city's leading tourist attractions. Drug dealers peddled their wares in the open-air hallways, and sniper fire occasionally rained down on the parking lot of the city's main post office next door.
Last spring, at the suggestion of an acquaintance, Daniel P. Henson 3d, executive director of the Baltimore Housing Authority, began to consider hiring N.O.I. Security. In May, housing authority officials visited the two Washington apartment complexes that use N.O.I. Security guards, and Mr. Henson spoke with company officials.
"In listening to them describe their philosophy the thing that stuck with me was their view that they give respect to get respect," Mr. Henson said in an interview.
Relying on a provision in HUD regulations that allowed him emergency powers to enter into contracts without putting them out for bid, Mr. Henson hired the company to patrol 10 of the authority's buildings at an annual cost of $288,000 for each building, the biggest paycheck yet for N.O.I. The contracts, which have been phased in since June, give the housing authority the right to cancel with 30 days' notice.
 
Crime Cut in Half
 Figures compiled by the Baltimore Police Department show a 50 percent decrease in serious crime at Flaghouse Court in the last half of 1993, compared with the same period in 1992. Housing authority officials say it is too early to evaluate the impact of N.O.I. at some of the other high-rise apartment buildings that N.O.I. Security patrols.
N.O.I. Security is not the only force at work. Before the buildings were turned over to the company, the Baltimore police conducted an apartment-to-apartment sweep, evicting people who could not prove they were legal tenants. The housing authority also installed metal detectors, alarms on all doors leading to the outside, and either wire mesh or plexiglass barriers on the open-air hallways on the bottom floors.
But tenants at Flaghouse Court give plenty of credit to the group they call "the Muslims."
Lawrence Manuel, who has lived in Flaghouse Courts for five years, said that last summer, with the new security guards around, he felt safe enough to sleep with his apartment door open to provide some relief from the oppressive heat.
"It's not Tombstone Territory around here right now," Mr. Manuel said. "It was before, and if somebody else comes back here it will be again."
 
The Series So Far
 YESTERDAY Louis Farrakhan, man of contrasts, preaches love but says there is no shame in hatred.
TOMORROW In New York his base is a nondescript building on 125th Street; his influence reaches much farther.

HEADLINE: Property Tax Changes Are Urged To Help Preserve Northeast Forest

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

 BODY:
A regional commission examining ways to preserve the 26-million-acre forest of northern New York and New England called yesterday for changes in the way the property is taxed to help individual owners keep control of their land. But despite the urging of some conservationists, it did not recommend specific changes in forestry practices or major programs to set up natural preserves.
About 85 percent of the forest, which runs almost interrupted from upstate New York through New Hampshire and Vermont to northern Maine, is privately owned, much of it by paper and timber companies. 
 The panel, the Northern Forest Lands Council, urged the governments of the four states to protect the land from excessive development by acquiring tracts that are especially valuable, if possible. It also called on the states to find ways to protect the many species living in the forest.
The council said its recommendations should be part of a broad strategy to prevent the "breakup of large undeveloped tracts of land and continuing pressure on finite natural resources."
 
Hearings Planned on Ideas
 The council was established by Congress in 1990 amid concern about the future of one of the biggest expanses of forest land in the country. The panel, whose members are appointed by the governors of the four states, has no legally binding authority. Its recommendations, issued in Concord, N.H., serve mainly as a guide for the Federal, state and local governments. A series of public hearings will be held on the panel's suggestions in the next two months.
The council said that the way forest land is taxed poses one of the biggest threats to the forest by encouraging owners to sell their holdings. It called for local governments to tax the land based on how it is currently used, not on what it might be worth if broken up and sold to developers.
"Rising property taxes have severe impacts on the ability of landowners to own and manage forest land," the panel said. "The council has identified this as one of the most significant problems facing forest land across the region because of its effect on private landowners' ability to hold onto their land. In most areas of the northern forest, making sure that property taxes reflect the productivity of the forest will have the most immediate effect."
The state and Federal governments, the panel said, should change estate-tax policies to reduce the pressures on heirs to sell forest land that they inherit, the council said. It also recommended that the governments change the way capital gains are calculated for timber that takes years to grow to maturity by adjusting the capital gains to take account of inflation.
The report was praised by the spokesman for a coalition of environmental groups for its "middle-of-the-road" approach. "Respecting the rights of property owners will be helpful in the long run," said John Sheehan of the Northern Forest Alliance.
But the council received mixed reviews from an Adirondack landowners' group, which chided it for recommending more public land purchases.

GRAPHIC: Map of the Northeast shows the region designated as the Northern Forest Lands area.

HEADLINE: Notice the Steel Strike? 48 Hours Sum Up a Slide

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MARTINS FERRY, Ohio, March 3

 BODY:
A steelworkers' strike used to be feared as a catastrophic event, with the President sometimes preparing the nation for an economic jolt. But on Tuesday, steelworkers staged a strike against a major manufacturer here in the Rust Belt, and hardly anyone outside this region noticed. By this morning, the strike was over and workers were returning to the mills.
The 48-hour job action, which mainly concerned health care and pension benefits, began after talks broke down between the United Steelworkers of America and the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation. The company, one of the nation's 10 largest steel manufacturers, is notable for almost making a profit last year, just three years after it emerged from bankruptcy. 
 So when 4,700 workers closed the company's eight plants in Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia, the action might reasonably have been expected to command some attention, especially since labor historians say it was only the eighth or ninth major job action in the industry since 1946.
But from the outset, there was a startling lack of interest. That alone suggests the far-reaching changes in the steel industry, which had $60 billion in revenue in 1965 and only $40 billion last year, after accounting for inflation.
 
Shrinking of Industry
 Once a monolithic giant, the industry began shriveling in the early 1980's as a result of global competition and technological improvements, slashing jobs, wages and benefits and closing scores of mills as it consolidated.
Even today, profitable companies are rare. Wheeling-Pittsburgh, for example, posted a $7 million loss on $1 billion in revenue last year. Company officials say they have no estimate of how the strike and its settlement will affect this year's revenues.
The power of the steel union has followed the fortunes of the mills. The industrywide labor contract, which gave the union power to close down the entire industry every time it was renegotiated, disappeared in the mid-1980's when survival superseded all other issues. It was replaced by company contracts, usually packed with worker concessions, that were individually negotiated. The industry has subsequently become a model of worker-management cooperation. Workers' representatives even hold seats on the major company boards.
Against this backdrop, labor experts say, the Wheeling-Pittsburgh strike was just a bump in contract negotiations between a union willing to compromise and a steel company that had pioneered worker participation in management. "Strikes are a thing of the past, and this strike is just a glitch," said Ben Fischer, a professor of labor studies at the John Heinz School of Public Policy at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh.
"We're in a new era, a period of unprecedented cooperation in decision making and planning at every stage," Mr. Fischer said.
That may explain why this strike seemed half-hearted: a dozen strikers took shelter from Wednesday's sleet and snow in a heated trailer equipped with a coffee maker, television set and refrigerator. Outside, a single placard, declaring "No Contract, No Work," leaned against the trailer.
John Saunders, president of Local 1238 here, said the intransigence of the company on some aspects of the contract, and the need for the union to take action, surprised everybody.
The strike began on the first day in office of a new president of the United Steelworkers of America, George Becker. "We didn't plan that," Mr. Becker, a 65-year-old former safety inspector, said of the walkout at a news conference in Pittsburgh.
 
Talks Break Down
 Union officials said talks broke off at 3:30 A.M. Tuesday, and by 6 A.M. the strike was on.
Despite the walkout, union officials leavened complaints about the company with compliments. "It's a progressive steel company, no question about it," Mr. Saunders, the local union leader, said on Wednesday. "We probably had the best union-management relationship in the industry prior to the work stoppage Tuesday."
Although workers said they were doing more work for pay that has not yet exceeded 1982 levels, many pointed proudly to their income, which these workers said ranged from $30,000 to $40,000 last year.
Today, union and company officials said they were pleased with the settlement. "It's one of the best contracts in the industry," said Carmen DeStefano, a union negotiator. "Our people are ecstatic, and they're glad to be going back to work today."
Mr. DeStefano said the company had addressed, if not fully satisfied, all union demands regarding wages, benefits, job security and other workplace issues. He would not release details of the settlement until after the workers voted on it next week. But there seems to be little question that they will approve it, since all workers are returning to the mills today.
Mr. Saunders said the new contract would improve hourly wages and benefits, although it would not fully repay workers for the concessions they made in 1986, when Wheeling-Pittsburgh was being restructured under the protection of bankruptcy laws. The average worker, union leaders say, now earns $12 to $16 an hour, down about 20 percent from the hourly pay levels of the mid-1980's; the company says average compensation, including benefits, is closer to $28 an hour.
Gregg Warren, a spokesman for Wheeling-Pittsburgh, which is based in Wheeling, W. Va., and owned by the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Corporation, a holding company, said management was satisfied with the contract. While Mr. Warren also declined to discuss the contract's details, he said it would run two and a half years, instead of the usual five years, to give the company flexibility in future negotiations.
 
Not Like Old Days
 "It's not like it used to be," said Don Dellget, a 63-year-old welder, as he sat inside the strikers' trailer on Wednesday. "In the old days, we had power and the union held the upper hand."
In the 1950's, this plant alone employed 1,400 steelworkers; today it has only 425. The union had 1.3 million members in 1979; today it has 600,000, and the number is falling as new technology replaces workers by the hundreds. The most telling industry statistic, however, is that it took 12.8 manhours to produce a ton of steel in 1965, but only 4.7 manhours in 1993 as a result of technological improvements.
In these circumstances, pensions have become a crucial bargaining issue, partly because the steelworkers tend to be older and partly because the bankrupt company was forced to sharply reduce pension payments in 1986.
Carl D. Yoho, a 60-year-old truck driver who earned $40,000 last year, said that if he had been able to retire in 1985 he would have received about $1,200 a month in pension benefits. But if he were eligible to retire now, Mr. Yoho said, he would receive only about $550 a month, minus $100 a month for health insurance. "I've got to stay on the job as long as my health stays good," he said.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
G.O.P. on Health Care: Seeking a Second Opinion

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
The health care issue should be rich with opportunity for the Republicans these days, with President Clinton's plan sagging in the polls and the Democrats still struggling for consensus in the relevant committees on Capitol Hill.
After all their campaign promises and all their photo opportunities on "health care that's always there," the Democrats are in an embarrassing stall, divided among several health care plans and ideological camps. They have created a perfect moment for an opposition party to step boldly into the void with an alternative. But the Republicans have deep and abiding problems of their own. 
 They are divided philosophically over just how much the health care system needs to be overhauled, and they are divided just as starkly over the means by which any such restructuring should take place.
In the Senate there are clear tensions between conservatives like Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who argues that the public is rejecting the idea that any overhaul of the system is necessary, and centrists like Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, who has offered a plan of his own aimed at providing universal coverage. Indeed, Administration strategists consider Senator Chafee an important potential ally in any ultimate grand compromise.
Away from Capitol Hill there is similar friction, as befits a party still struggling to redefine itself after losing the White House in 1992. Among the theoreticians focused on returning the party to Presidential power, a debate has played out over whether Republicans should even agree that there is a "crisis" in health care.
 
A Pragmatic Outlook
 Meanwhile, party strategists with clients in the midterm elections take a more pragmatic outlook, trying to protect them from being perceived as obstructionists who are insensitive to the nation's health care problems.
Democratic strategists, after all, have already signaled their willingness to reprise the campaign they ran in 1992, asserting that a party that refused to see the recession now refuses to see the crisis in health care -- a strategic box the Republicans have no desire to enter.
As Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, declared in an interview: "It is important that people know three things about the Republicans and health care: No. 1, we're for health care reform; the issue is not whether but how. No. 2, we can't afford a government-run health care system financed by a massive payroll tax that will end up hurting the quality of care. And No. 3, we don't have to have a government-run health care program to do health care reform."
The problem is how to get beyond those broad points. As Mr. Barbour suggests, it is fairly clear what most Republicans are against in the Clinton plan: a new government requirement that employers pay for insurance for their workers; a new quasi-governmental structure of regional insurance purchasing alliances that most Americans would be required to join, and a new system of price controls for insurance premiums.
 
Conference in Annapolis
 But what are the Republicans for?
This is the question hovering over the two-day gathering of Republican senators that began in Annapolis, Md., this afternoon. It is the third such retreat devoted to health care issues for Senate Republicans in the past few years, but it comes at a particularly sensitive moment. Underscoring the stakes for the party on the health care issue, the organizers have called in several House Republican leaders, a few Republican governors, Mr. Barbour and assorted strategists.
At a news conference today before the Republicans left town, there was bold talk of stepping in where the Clinton Administration had faltered. "What I'm seeing from the polls is that the American people want a second opinion," asserted Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader.
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, said expansively, "Clinton has now failed, and you see on the House side, at least, no Democratic structure that can clearly command a majority." Given that, he added, "It becomes imperative for us to go to Annapolis and try to begin to sort out how we can put together a bipartisan effort that we would feel very comfortable with."
Still, Mr. Chafee, who heads the Senate Republicans' task force on health and organized this retreat, was just as busily trying to play down expectations. "I just hope nobody writes up on Friday night, 'Annapolis conference failure; Republicans fail to reach agreement,' " he said. "That's not the purpose of this; you can write that right now."
Presenting the session as largely the beginning of a process of reaching consensus and an exercise in education, he added, "I'm a realist."
 
Two2 Senators Poles Apart
 Senate Republicans, by virtue of Senate rules and the power they give to the minority, will play a critical role in any health care restructuring, and are thus more closely watched than their counterparts in the House. The poles of the debate among them are represented most visibly by Senator Chafee and Senator Gramm.
Mr. Gramm, who has 10 co-sponsors, backs a modest measure that does not promise universal coverage but tries to expand access to health insurance through such measures as tax credits for the working poor and the creation of tax-free savings accounts for medical expenses. There are no major new governmental structures created, along the lines of the health alliance, and there are no requirements that individuals buy insurance or that employers pay for it.
"I believe that we have won the intellectual debate," the Texas Senator said in an interview this week. "People have rejected the idea of the Government remaking the health care system; they've rejected alliances and the collectivization of health care purchasing, and they've rejected the employer mandate."
Mr. Chafee's bill, which has 19 co-sponsors in the Senate, does seek to guarantee universal coverage, hoping to require all individuals to obtain health insurance by the year 2005. Low-income people would receive government vouchers to help them purchase it. It also includes a version of the health insurance purchasing cooperative, although not as large and powerful as the Clinton plan's.
In a sense, the argument among Republicans is one of the very oldest for their party: Just what is the role of government on issues like health?
 
Chafee Bill Criticized
 William Kristol, the conservative strategist who advanced the "no-crisis" argument last fall, faults the Chafee bill. "Its premise is that government has to step in and fundamentally reorganize the health care system of the United States," he said. This, he argues, is in opposition to the Republican philosophy that the role of government should be a carefully limited one.
The man who must deal with all these tensions in the coming weeks is Senator Dole. And the irony is that, despite all the problems of the Clinton plan, the President is poised to get credit for whatever passes, many analysts argue. Voters, they say, simply give Democrats the advantage in dealing with health care, as they gave the Republicans the advantage on military issues throughout the 1980's.
