HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
In Proposal, Vincent Memoir Airs Criticisms

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
In a proposal for a memoir about his three years as baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent snipes at high-profile owners such as George M. Steinbrenner 3d, Peter O'Malley, Jerry Reinsdorf and Bud Selig, describes Bart Giamatti's unhappiness as National League president before becoming commissioner and says unequivocally that Pete Rose gambled on baseball.
The 40-page proposal is for a book called "And The Horse They Rode In On: My Tumultuous Years as Baseball Commissioner," which would be written with David Kaplan of Newsweek. The title refers to a favorite phrase of Giamatti's. 
According to the proposal, circulated among publishing houses by the William Morris Agency, bidding will start at $300,000 in a coming auction.
Proposals are come-ons to publishers, part of the process of selling the rights to a book, the hard sell to get the most money for an author. It is in the author's best interest to present as many of the best, juiciest and perhaps hyperbolic opinions in the proposal to gain maximum attention. Sometimes, elements contained in a proposal don't survive publication.
The proposal consists of Vincent's snapshot impressions of his stormy tenure in baseball, which began in September 1989 after the death of Giamatti, and a long narrative about the Rose case. Vincent resigned in September 1992, under pressure from owners who often bitterly disagreed with him over such issues as labor relations, divisional realignment and division of expansion fees. Major league baseball has not yet elected his successor.
Reached yesterday at his Greenwich, Conn., home, Vincent said he had approved the proposal, but distanced himself from its glib, often unpleasant tenor.
"I wouldn't put much stock in the tone," he said. "It's not my style. We have a lot of work to do before we write the book. I'm sure the book will be different." He added: "It's not my intention to be revengeful."
But upon learning that excerpts from the proposal would be made public, he abruptly said that he would not pursue writing the book.
 
Candid Assessments
 "Just say I'm not writing it," he said. "You did not get the proposal legitimately. I'm upset that you would do this and I don't want to be part of it. This tells me the publishing industry is filled with bad people."
Even if he does not write the book, the proposal provides the most candid assessments of baseball's hierarchy from Vincent ever to become public.
According to the proposal, Vincent writes that Reinsdorf, the owner of the Chicago White Sox, is "dangerous" and blames him more for "the poor state of baseball than anyone else."
Reinsdorf refuted the characterizations and said: "Fay is apparently bitter. I don't harbor any personal animosity to him. My problem with him was job performance. If he chooses to write a book, I don't think it will enhance his reputation. He'd be better off putting it all behind him."
The proposal has Vincent calling Bud Selig, the owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and the interim commissioner, a "small-town schlepper" who, along with Reinsdorf, is "the emblem of baseball's decline."
"I have no comment other than that I find all this very sad," Selig said from Chandler, Ariz., where the Brewers are training.
 
Steinbrenner Mentioned
 In describing the principal owner of the Yankees, the proposal quotes Vincent as calling Steinbrenner "the most hated man in baseball."
"How bad can a Williams graduate be?" Vincent asks rhetorically about his fellow college alumnus. "Are you kidding?"
During negotiations that led to Vincent banning Steinbrenner from baseball in 1990, Steinbrenner was asked if he was being "Machiavellian." He responded, Vincent says in the proposal, by saying: "Who's he--a famous ballplayer?"
A spokesman for Steinbrenner said he could not be reached for comment.
The proposal has Vincent lashing out at O'Malley, the Los Angeles Dodgers owner, as a "nitwit" and a "bigot."
Through a spokesman, O'Malley declined to comment on Vincent's remarks.
During the 1989 earthquake in San Francisco that interrupted the World Series, the proposal says Vincent's suggestion that each team contribute $50,000 to disaster relief was met with anger by O'Malley.
According to the proposal, Vincent says that Marge Schott, owner of the Cincinnati Reds, was the owner who "does the dumbest things," and that Jackie Autry, executive vice president of the California Angels and the wife of Gene Autry, the Angels owner, is "mean-spirited and not bright."
The proposal has Vincent taking aim at Bill White, the just-retired National League president, by saying in the proposal that White "is a good man" but "incompetent."
"I don't want to get into it," White said when reached at his home in New York. "I suggest you talk to people where he's worked before, if you want to talk about incompetent."
According to the proposal, Giamatti, who succeeded Peter V. Ueberroth as commissioner in April 1989, had been frustrated in his previous position as National League president and tried to leave within weeks of taking over in 1987.
Several weeks into Giamatti's tenure, the proposal says, Giamatti called Vincent, shouting about how he hated the job and that he was bored. Giamatti applied to be head of the Rockefeller Foundation, the proposal says, but lost the bid and then grew to enjoy the National League presidency because of his dealings with umpires.
According to the proposal, Vincent says most owners believe they must destroy the players union as the "final salvation" of baseball's economic future.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Fine Line

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico, March 3

 BODY:
As peasant rebels roamed the highlands outside this city in early January, bombs exploded in the capital and investors began to sell off their Mexican stocks, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari shelved plans for a crackdown on rebel supporters, dismissed his hard-line Interior Minister and declared a unilateral cease-fire.
What did not work, Mr. Salinas said, had to be changed. 
 In the tentative peace agreement presented to the rebels here on Wednesday, the Government essentially offered more change of the same sort. To Latin America's first guerrilla movement of the post-cold-war age, an insurgency that has won wide sympathy with demands for reform rather than revolution, Mr. Salinas proposed a strikingly post-cold-war response: he agreed to many of the reforms.
By their tacit admission of profound social and political ills, the accords mark a sobering retreat for a Government that was celebrating Mexico's formal rise toward the developed world with the North American Free Trade Agreement just as the rebel Zapatista National Liberation Army rose up against it.
 
'Deep Changes' Proposed
 Yet by moving quickly to meet many rebel demands, Mr. Salinas also came within reach of a settlement that would compromise neither his program of market-oriented economic transformation nor his party's place in the political system it has dominated for six decades.
"Deep changes have been proposed to make the yearnings of Indian communities for justice and dignity compatible with the modernization of the country," said Manuel Camacho Solis, Mr. Salinas's commissioner for peace in the southeastern state of Chiapas.
There are still reasons to question whether the proposals are enough.
In the highlands where the rebel movement has been strong, official promises of a better life have gone mostly unfulfilled since the 1910 Mexican revolution. And the Zapatistas say they will lay down their arms only when the conditions they rebelled against begin to change.
To the north, thousands of urban Mexicans have rallied in support of the insurgents. Thousands more -- peasant farmers, out-of-work laborers and others -- have turned to the Government demanding the same considerations given the Mayan Indians of Chiapas.
 
'Extraordinary' Achievement
 But Mr. Salinas's return to the political offensive, at least momentarily, also suggests that the rebels may be more vulnerable than they initially appeared to the pragmatism for which he and his Institutional Revolutionary Party are known.
"A guerrilla war in 1994, after the fall of the Berlin wall and everything else that has happened in the world, is such an extremely difficult proposition that what they have achieved already is extraordinary," Enrique Krause, a Mexican historian, said in a telephone interview today. "There is a difference between the agreement and their demands, but it is also an entirely reasonable difference."
In effect, the Government has bet that the Mexicans' fascination with the insurgency and their sense of shame at the poverty and political violence that have become almost synonymous with Chiapas do not necessarily mean full support for the Zapatista platform.
The rebels' complaints of discrimination, for example, have echoed powerfully in a society that pays ritual tribute to its pre-Hispanic past but little heed to its contemporary Indians. Rather than cede Indians the political autonomy sought by the insurgents, however, the Government offered measures that could affect local practices and national attitudes without sacrificing state authority.
New laws would outlaw discrimination against Indians for the first time, establish a special prosecutor's office to deal with such cases and formally recognize Indian customs for dealing with family relations, commerce, land use and minor crimes. Sensitivity to indigenous cultures would be taught in the schools and bilingual education programs would be expanded.
 
An Exceptional Case
 Similarly, Mr. Salinas refused to restore the Constitution's longstanding and often unfulfilled promise of land for all peasants who work it.
But without backing away from the land-tenure reforms that have been a pillar of his economic policy, the draft accords would recognize Chiapas as an exceptional case in order to restore lands taken from peasants and allow for the expropriation of private lands to break up large holdings "in cases of public utility."
If the agreement is put into effect, its promise of new roads, schools, housing and health clinics could at least raise Chiapas within a relatively short time from the bottom rank of Mexican states in some categories.
If the commitment in such areas appears large, though, it also fits clearly within the scheme Mr. Salinas has used to ease the impact of steps like the elimination of subsidies and the privatization of state industries. And while the accords make no mention of the National Solidarity Program, the President's huge antipoverty initiative, they constantly emphasize the responsibility of Government institutions to solve Chiapas's problems.
The Salinas administration's line against radical changes under the proposed settlement may be weakest on the issue of democratic reforms.
The accords include no binding commitment on the issue except at the state level. In Mr. Camacho's name, they express confidence that reforms will be approved by the Congress. But they speak only of the "inclusion" and "participation" of nonpartisan citizens in supervision of elections; the rebels and some opposition parties have demanded the Government cede control over electoral agencies entirely.
"Whatever they say, the Government is going to have to do many things quickly in order to make the elections credible," said Mr. Krause, the historian. "We are not going to achieve real democracy in minutes. But we have passed the point of no return."

HEADLINE: U.S. Ready to Help Ukraine and Georgia, if They Help Themselves

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 3

 BODY:
With Ukraine having tentatively agreed to destroy its nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today that President Clinton would double aid to Ukraine, to about $700 million a year.
The announcement is to be made when Mr. Clinton meets here Friday with Ukraine's President, Leonid M. Kravchuk. Administration officials said they were seeking to reward Mr. Kravchuk for agreeing to eliminate Ukraine's nuclear arms and encourage him to press for economic reforms. 
 The Administration hopes Mr. Kravchuk's visit, and a visit Monday by President Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia, will help rebuff criticisms that its policy toward the former Soviet Union favors Russia over the other 14 republics.
Mr. Shevardnadze, whose nation is ravaged by civil war, is to urge Mr. Clinton to back international peacekeepers in Georgia, a proposal the Administration is ambivalent about.
The new aid total for Ukraine is to include economic aid of $350 million and $350 million to help disassemble the atomic weapons. Each figure is about double previous commitments.
 
More Pressure on Ukraine
 Administration officials said that to further help reform Ukraine's teetering economy, President Clinton would urge the International Monetary Fund to withhold $1.1 billion in loans for Ukraine unless it takes bolder steps to privatize industry and lower inflation, which is about 90 percent a month.
The White House is disappointed that Mr. Kravchuk will not be delivering Ukraine's formal accession to the accord to eliminate nuclear arms. Despite repeated efforts, he has failed to persuade Parliament to ratify the agreement he signed in January to eliminate 176 long-range missiles and more than 1,600 nuclear warheads.
Administration officials voiced confidence that Parliament would soon agree, though some officials fear that Mr. Kravchuk's declaration that he would not seek another term may complicate matters.
This raises the prospect that the Administration might have identified itself too closely with Mr. Kravchuk, just as many critics have asserted it has done with Russia's embattled President, Boris N. Yeltsin.
 
Position Seems Shaky
 But, as one White House official said, "Kravchuk is the President of Ukraine and therefore he's the one we deal with."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher told a Congressional committee on Tuesday that he was not convinced that Mr. Kravchuk was a lame duck.
Bowing to demands made by striking miners, Mr. Kravchuk has agreed to hold elections this June; they were originally scheduled for 1996. But Mr. Kravchuk has suggested that he might cancel the elections on the ground that it was wrong to yield to such coercion.
Before leaving Kiev, Mr. Kravchuk told journalists that his message would be that helping create an economically strong Ukraine is critical. In seeking billions in aid, he said, "I'm convinced that if a democratic and independent Ukraine exists and is given the necessary support, then imperial policies of any European country, not only Russia, will fail."
 
Looking Toward Georgia, Too
 Mr. Kravchuk, 60, was once the chief ideologist of the Ukrainian Communist Party. He resigned from the Politburo only after the failed Moscow coup in August 1991, and became a national hero soon after when he brokered a deal with Ukraine's nationalists to pursue independence from Moscow while keeping Ukraine's Communist establishment in power.
Administration officials said countries other than Russia would receive more than half the $2.5 billion in aid authorized last fall for former Soviet republics.
Over the past two years, Washington has committed $233 million to Georgia, most of it to help victims of the civil war. United States officials expect to contribute at least $100 million this year.
Washington sympathizes with Mr. Shevardnadze's request for peacekeepers. Concerned that Russia is flexing its muscles in Georgia, United States officials say they would rather see peacekeepers there than Russian troops. But Washington hesitates to back such a plan because of the cost, and fears that such a commitment would be open-ended, officials said.
One subject Mr. Kravchuk and Mr. Clinton are certain to discuss is the Crimea, a Black Sea peninsula that is part of Ukraine but dominated by ethnic Russians. On Jan. 30, the Crimeans chose a regional president who supports seceding and joining Russia.
Administration officials said they back Mr. Kravchuk's position that Crimea should remain part of Ukraine -- a stance vigorously opposed by Russia's restive nationalists.
"Crimea could blow up into a major problem," said one official.

HEADLINE: An Ancient Ritual and a Mother's Asylum Plea

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
In trying to deport Lydia Oluloro, the Federal Government has presented a simple case. A native of a tiny Nigerian village, Mrs. Oluloro came to Oregon in 1986 and lied when she said she would stay no longer than her one-year tourist visa allowed.
Mrs. Oluloro, who works as a janitor for $6.25 an hour and says she loves the Oregon rain, concedes the Government its basic point. But she has raised a defense that seizes on a growing international human rights issue and, if successful, could set a precedent for other asylum seekers. 
 A mother of two American-born girls, ages 5 and 6, Mrs. Oluloro says they face the certainty of genital mutilation by her relatives in Nigeria if she is deported.
The ancient ritual, frequently referred to as female circumcision and widely practiced in many African countries and parts of the Middle East, has been condemned by human rights advocates and health professionals in the West as barbaric and unsafe. It entails cutting away some part of a girl's genitalia before the onset of puberty to thwart sexual appetite and so maintain her virginity and enhance her appeal as a marital partner.
 
'These Are American Girls'
 Federal immigration officials say this is the first time that the prospect of genital mutilation has been raised as a ground for asylum, which by law is generally granted only if the applicant can prove "a well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership in a particular social club."
"I don't want them to get cut," Mrs. Oluloro said of her daughters, Shade, 6, and Lara, 5, "because these girls are American girls. They are not like African girls. It would be a horrible thing for them."
Mrs. Oluloro's unusual argument in support of her bid for asylum has been advanced against a backdrop of an ever increasing number of asylum requests -- 150,000 in the last year alone. There is now a backlog of 330,000 people trying to win American asylum, and advocates of a tight immigration policy in particular fear that creating precedents like the one sought by Mrs. Oluloro would add many thousands to the list.
 
Lifetime of Pain
 Mrs. Oluloro, who is now 32 and lives in Portland, says she herself was required by her relatives in Ilobu, the little Nigerian village where she lived as a girl, to submit to the ritual when she was about 4 years old. The result, she says, has been a lifetime of intermittent pain, particularly during birth of her two daughters.
She says her relatives in Nigeria have already told her that if her girls are to avoid being shunned, they too must undergo the ritual, which in most cases entails removal of the clitoris and the labia minora with a knife or a razor blade, generally without anesthetic. The procedure is often performed by female elders, who in the most extreme cases also stitch together the external labia, leaving only a tiny opening for urination and menstrual discharge. Before a woman's wedding night, the stitching is removed.
Many women who endure the procedure later experience not only an absence of sexual sensation but also infections, recurring pain, particularly during intercouse, and painful, dangerous childbirth.
 
Report by State Department
 Nigerian Government officials, who have expressed opposition to the practice, say their country's culture is not such that Mrs. Oluloro should fear her daughters' being required to submit to the ritual if she returns with them. A report issued last month by the State Department, however, suggests otherwise.
The report, on human rights abuses against women around the world, said that in predominantly Christian southern Nigeria, Mrs. Oluloro's native region, virtually all young girls were still subjected to genital mutilation, as were about half the girls in the Muslim-majority north. In all, the report estimated, there are now as many as 110 million women in the world whose genitalia have been mutilated.
Mrs. Oluloro has won support from feminists and human rights advocates across the the United States, but none from her former husband, Emanuel Oluloro. They divorced last year.
Mrs. Oluloro arrived from Nigeria eight years ago to join him here. But Mr. Oluloro, in the United States on an extended work visa, or green card, never completed the paperwork that would have made her residency legal.
In court papers filed before their divorce, she said her life with him in Portland had been torment, accusing him of spousal rape and of frequently abusing her in other ways. She has been awarded custody of the children, although he has said he would still like to have them.
Mr. Oluloro did not respond to requests for an interview. But he has denied abusing his wife. And during a hearing in February before the immigration judge who is considering the deportation case against her, he said that she had previously supported ritualized mutilation and that her change of heart had coincided with the Government's move to deport her. She denies that.
 
Excruciating Alternatives
 By Mrs. Oluloro's account, a deportation order would pose an anguishing choice: either take her children with her to Nigeria, where she says they face mutiliation, or leave them with her former husband, who she says is abusive.
"I will take my kids if I am forced to go," she said. "They are my life, my best friends."
But it is clearly a prospect she would not relish even if her daughters did not face the danger that she says she fears. "Here in Oregon, I am an independent woman," she said. "If I go back to Nigeria, I am not independent. No job. No husband. I would be returned to my father's house. And I would have no say."
The immigration judge, Kendall Warren, has said he will announce his decision on March 23. Mrs. Oluloro's lawyer, Tilman Hasche, says the odds are against her gaining asylum, given the narrow criteria of the law. Further, the fear of mutilation that Mrs. Oluloro cites is not for herself but for her daughters, who as American citizens are free to remain.
But the judge could simply dismiss the deportation case and allow Mrs. Oluloro to stay in the country on an extended work visa. For him to do so,she must meet three tests, the first of which she has already passed, having been in America at least seven years. The two others: that she would experience hardship if forced to leave, and that she has shown good moral character.
Paul Stultz, an immigration lawyer who is handling the Government's case against Mrs. Oluloru, declined to comment on the matter, citing rules of the Immigration and Naturalization Service that bar public discussion of unresolved cases.
 
Retort to the Criticism
 No matter which way the judge rules, his decision is certain to bring added attention to genital mutilation as an issue. Already African immigrants' use of the ritual has led to a bill, introduced by Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, that would prohibit administering it on anyone in this country under the age of 18.
Genital mutilation has also received heightened attention of late because it is the subject of condemnation in a widely recognized book, "Warrior Marks." A co-author was the novelist Alice Walker, who has also produced a film of the same title.
Denunciation of the ritual has not been free of criticism in kind. Quite apart from the accusation that Western critics are cultural imperialists meddling in a custom of foreign lands where they have no business, there is the argument that those efforts could have a backlash effect, hurting attempts under way in those countries to end the practice.
"Superior Western attitudes do not enhance dialogue or the equal exchange of ideas," Seble Dawit, a human rights lawyer, and Salem Mekuria, a film maker, wrote in a recent article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. The two women, Africans living in the United States who oppose genital mutilation, say American critics, including Ms. Walker, take too blunt an approach. The practice should be viewed not in isolation, they say, but in the context of broader efforts to lift the poor educational, economic and social status of women throughout much of Africa.
Mr. Hasche, the lawyer for Mrs. Oluloro, has heard all the arguments. "Frankly," he said, "I don't give a damn if opposing this is a violation of someone's culture. To me, female genital mutilation is a violation of the physical and spiritual integrity of a person."
In any case, he said, the Oluloro children "are American girls" and as such "have more in common with all the other kids in Portland than they do with anyone in Africa."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lydia Oluloro says that she was forced to submit to genital mutilation as a child in Nigeria and that she fears the same for her daughters, Lara, left, and Shade, if the United States deports her. The family posed at the Portland, Ore., office of Mrs. Oluloro's lawyer, in front of a map of Nigeria. (Don Ryan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Proffitt's Department Stores To Buy McRae's Retail Chain

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Proffitt's Inc., a regional department store chain based in Knoxville, Tenn., announced yesterday that it was purchasing privately held McRae's Inc. with a combination of $337 million in cash, debt and equity.
The combined companies operate 53 stores in small and midsized towns in the Southeast and are expected to have sales exceeding $700 million this year. 
 The story is a familiar one in the consolidating department store business, where survival, particularly for small regional chains, depends on gaining operating efficiencies and buying power. The same pressures pushing Federated Department Stores, with more than $7 billion in sales, to seek a merger with $6 billion R. H. Macy & Company are driving the alliance between Proffitt's and McRae's, whose combined sales will be roughly one-tenth of Federated's.
"The combined business will be of a size to enjoy substantial benefits associated with increased economies of scale," R. Brad Martin, chairman and chief executive of Proffitt's, said in a statement.
 
Eliminating Redundant Costs
 The companies will eliminate redundant costs by merging functions like accounting, distribution and other operational aspects of their business. Analysts expect Proffitt's, which struggled last year to open 11 new stores, to benefit from McRae's strong operational skills and inventory management systems. Conversely, McRae's, which is based in Jackson, Miss., should gain from Proffitt's merchandising expertise.
But Mr. Martin said that the merger would add to Proffitt's earnings, although he did not specify by how much.
McRae's will become a subsidiary of Proffitt's. Mr. Martin will retain his position in the combined company, and Richard D. McRae, scion of McRae's founder, will become president and chief operating officer.
But contrary to other retail mergers, this was a case of a little fish swallowing a bigger one. With 25 stores, Proffitt's had sales of $201 million in the year that ended Jan. 29, while the 28 McRae's stores had sales of $419 million in the same period.
For the fiscal year that ended Jan. 29, McRae's profits were $19.6 million, compared with $14.8 million in the 1992 fiscal year. Proffitt's earnings increased 2.8 percent, to $6.9 million, in the same period.
 
A Well-Capitalized Company
 The combination of $180 million in cash, $30 million in subordinated debt and $127 million in equity is about 7.8 times McRae's earnings before interest and taxes, a common measure of cash flow. The price is somewhat high for a retailer, but McRae's financial statement portrays a well-capitalized company that has managed to achieve a strong return on its assets despite the weak retail environment.
The McRae's stores will retain their name and operate as a separate subsidiary. Mr. Branham said McRae's has a strong home-related business, while Proffitt's strongest sales come from women's apparel.
Shares of Proffitt's, which have been depressed by the company's weak showing during the critical holiday season, jumped $1.75 yesterday, to $19.75 in Nasdaq trading, although the merger was not announced until after the market closed.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 5, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the merger of Proffitt's Inc. and McRae's Inc. omitted the full name and title of the person who discussed the strengths of the two retailing companies and misspelled his last name. He is Jeff Branman, a managing director of Financo Inc., which advised McRae's.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Ways for investors to hitch their stars to suppliers for electric cars.

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
SHOULD investors grab a ride aboard the embryonic electric vehicle industry?
There are already half a dozen publicly traded companies that are developing components, like Valence Technology Inc.'s rechargeable lithium battery, Electrosource Inc.'s lead-acid battery, and Unique Mobility's electric motors, which could be used in emission-free cars.
These tiny, cash-hungry companies are attempting a breakthrough that American auto makers say is impossible: design the components of an electric car that would have the range, speed, refueling convenience and cost of a gasoline-powered rival. 
 The nascent industry got a kick-start last month when 11 Eastern states and the District of Columbia asked the Federal Government to impose California's stringent anti-smog rules on them. Among the states' demands is that zero-emission vehicles, presumably electric vehicles, be offered in 1998.
Despite the market's considerable new size, industry analysts raise caution flags for many reasons.
"It's hard to convince someone to buy on market projections for '98 in '94," said Martin A. Sankey, an electrical equipment analyst at CS First Boston, who follows Johnson Controls, a battery maker.
As with most emerging industries, investors often make bets on companies with no profits, unproved technology and untried production capability. There is also the threat that lobbying could undermine the Federal mandate and delay by several years the demand for electric vehicles, known as E.V.'s.
"Any investor who believes there is going to be a landslide transition in the next five years to E.V. ought to have their head examined," said Erik N. Jansen, a semiconductor analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons. Even so, he recommends shares in Valence, of San Jose, Calif., but says the growth potential for electric vehicles is a side issue. He sees opportunities for Valence's battery -- which may be capable of providing considerable energy from a battery smaller than conventional versions -- in cellular phones, camcorders and portable computers.
The company, which went public in May 1992, had a loss of $5.1 million in its third fiscal quarter, which ended on Dec. 31. It is not expected to be profitable until its 1995 fiscal year. Its stock closed yesterday at $17.50, unchanged, on Nasdaq.
A battery considered suitable for electric cars is a nickel-hydride version made by Energy Conversion Devices Inc. that is said to recharge quickly, use environmentally safe materials and have a long life. Yet Arthur P. Thomas, a broker for A. G. Edwards & Company in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., who follows the industry, does not recommend Energy Conversion as an investment. Nasdaq has delisted its shares because the company has fallen below the trading system's minimum financial standards.
"Their wealth is in the patents," Mr. Thomas said. "Their balance sheet looks like they'll be bankrupt in 90 days."
Mr. Thomas said the scientist who is the company's founding chief executive, Stanford R. Ovshinsky, is reluctant to share control. But the addition of a new director, Robert C. Stempel, the former chairman of General Motors, may presage a change. "He knows how to run a business," Mr. Thomas said, arguing that Mr. Stempel's track record at General Motors was better than generally thought.
Lawrence C. Oakley, editor of Conservative Speculator, an investment newsletter, recommends Unique Mobility Inc., based in Golden, Colo.
He likes Unique's strategy of accelerating development and commercialization of its electric motor by forming alliances with companies like Alcan Aluminum and BMW. "They are one of the better companies I've ever looked at," Mr. Oakley said, predicting that Unique, which closed at $7 yesterday, down 12.5 cents, could hit $100 in 10 years.
Environmentally conscious investors should not let their convictions be their only guide. A complication is whether these companies' technologies will actually cut pollution or just displace it from urban highways to the electric generating plants in less populated areas that will have to supply power to charge the batteries, said Alice Tepper Marlin, executive director of the Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research group.

HEADLINE: President Condemns Beijing; Christopher Visit Questioned

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
President Clinton condemned the detention by China of Wei Jingsheng, its most prominent dissident, and several others, and Administration officials said the detentions could change Secretary of State Warren Christopher's plans to visit China next week.
[An associate of Mr. Wei reported early Saturday that he had been released. Some other dissidents who had been detained by the Government were also freed, but the status of others was uncertain.] 
 Reacting to the arrests today, Mr. Clinton said at a news conference that the United States had "sent a very stern statement" to Beijing and added, "We strongly disapprove of what was done, and it obviously is not helpful to our relations."
State Department officials said that at least for now, Mr. Christopher was not canceling his visit because of the arrests, but they said it would also be wrong to assume that the visit would occur.
Mr. Christopher left this afternoon on a 10-day trip in which he is scheduled to visit Australia, Japan, China and Russia.
 
Christopher Deplores Arrests
 Speaking to reporters en route to Honolulu, Mr. Christopher said, "We deplore the detentions," adding that the United States believed it was essential that those arrested be released.
But he said the Chinese actions only served to underscore the importance of raising the issue of China's human rights record at the highest levels and making human rights "a major focus" of his trip.
State Department officials said the purpose of his three-day visit to China, scheduled to begin next Friday, was to caution Beijing that the United States wanted to see more progress on human rights if it was to renew China's favorable trading status.
"We view the situation with utmost gravity," Joan Spero, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said to reporters in commenting about the arrests. "I would simply state that it certainly will cast a pall over the planned visit."
The arrests came on the very day that John Shattuck, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, left Beijing after talking with Chinese officials about the hundreds of dissidents in jail, violations of religious freedom and other human rights matters.
At a White House news conference with President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine, Mr. Clinton said, "I have done what I could to make it clear that the United States does not seek to isolate China economically or politically and that we want a constructive and strong relationship with them, but that the observance of basic human rights is an important thing to us, along with nonproliferation, along with fair trade rules, and that was certainly not a helpful action."
Several American officials said the arrest would hurt China's chances of persuading President Clinton to extend China's low-tariff trading status, which comes up for renewal in June.
Ms. Spero said the arrests set back the human rights progress that Mr. Clinton had repeatedly said was required for most-favored-nation trading status and set back "our interest in putting U.S.-China relations on a much healthier and longer-term footing."
She also suggested that the arrests would make it harder for the Administration to have the needed Congressional support to renew the favorable trading status.
One State Department official said that during his 11-hour flight to Hawaii, Mr. Christopher would no doubt ask his team of Asia experts about the pros and cons of canceling the China trip.
Christine Shelly, a State Department spokeswoman, said Secretary Christopher was keeping abreast of the developments in China and would certainly be interested in hearing the response that the American Ambassador in Beijing received about the arrests.
On Thursday, Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia, warned China that it had not done enough to warrant renewal of its preferred trading status. "It's very important we make more progress," he told reporters.
Mr. Lord said, for instance, that it was a positive sign that China had agreed to let the Red Cross visit Chinese prisoners, but said Beijing still had to do more in this regard.
Human Rights Watch, a New York-based group, called on Mr. Christopher to postpone his trip to China. It criticized Beijing, saying that the dissidents had been "arbitrarily detained, apparently in an effort either to silence them in the week before Christopher's arrival or to punish them for comments made earlier."

HEADLINE: Clinton Vows to Improve Relations With Ukraine

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
President Clinton pledged a new era of warm relations with Ukraine today and told its President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, that the United States would double its aid to Ukraine to $700 million this year.
Mr. Clinton made clear that the key to the improved relations was Ukraine's making good on its promise to eliminate its 176 long-range missiles and 1,800 nuclear warheads, most of which are aimed at the United States. 
 At a joint news conference at the White House, Mr. Clinton also said he wanted vastly improved economic ties with Ukraine, which American officials say could someday become an economic powerhouse, with its 52 million people and a wealth of natural resources.
"The United States believes that the potential of Ukraine is enormous, and that we have to have a long-term view of our partnership," he said.
 
Concern Over Inflation
 American officials are eager to help stabilize Ukraine's desperate economic situation, concerned that it could create political chaos and fuel ethnic tensions. Ukraine's inflation rate is running at 90 percent a month, and its industrial output has fallen by more than 40 percent over the last two years.
One of Mr. Clinton's messages to Mr. Kravchuk was that Ukraine should move vigorously in slashing its inflation rate and privatizing industry.
In return, Mr. Clinton said, Washington would increase its economic aid to Kiev to $350 million next year, from the $155 million announced in January. In addition, the United States signed an investment treaty with Ukraine, announced plans to lower tariffs on some Ukrainian goods, and set up a joint trade and investment commission. The United States will also double to $350 million its aid to help Ukraine dismantle its missiles and warheads.
"The United States recognizes that it is very important to be supportive as Ukraine tries to reform and get through this period of economic transition," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Kravchuk told American officials that a strong and stable Ukraine could an be an important buffer against any expansionist tendencies in Russia. "Ukraine can play a great stabilizing role in the future," he said.
At times today, Mr. Kravchuk was outshone by a 16-year-old girl whom he asked to accompany him to Washington: Oksana Baiul, the ebullient Ukrainian orphan who bested Nancy Kerrigan to win the Olympic gold medal in women's figure skating.
"I think it's kind of neat that he asked her to come," Mr. Clinton said.
White House officials acknowledged that it was a bit awkward for the President to meet with the skater before he meets with the American Olympic team.
According to American officials, Mr. Clinton urged Mr. Kravchuk to redouble his efforts to persuade the Ukrainian Parliament to approve accession to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
Under that treaty, as well as other agreements, Ukraine has committed itself to becoming a non-nuclear state. Its Parliament may not vote on the treaty until after elections scheduled for March 27, and some American officials fear that the new Parliament may be less inclined to approve it, especially since Mr. Kravchuk appears to be a lame duck. He has indicated that he does not plan to run for re-election in June.
Nonetheless, Mr. Clinton voiced confidence that Mr. Kravchuk would win approval for the treaty.
 
Agreement With Russia
 To pave the way for Ukraine's denuclearization, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kravchuk signed a three-way agreement in January with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia in which Washington and Moscow provided some security assurances to Ukraine and pledged to reimburse it for the highly enriched uranium in its warheads.
Mr. Clinton showed his gratitude for Mr. Kravchuk's denuclearization pledge in several ways, including the aid increase for dismantling the weapons. In addition, in a demonstration of the way he often personalizes diplomacy, Mr. Clinton hailed the Ukrainian leader for his "statesmanship and leadership."
American officials also said they would work with Ukraine to deal with Russia's decision to cut off natural gas shipments as a result of Ukraine's failure to pay more than $1 billion it owes Russia.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The U.S. unemployment rate dipped an unexpected two-tenths of a percentage point, to 6.5 percent, in February. Unusually severe winter weather and statistical quirks again muddied the results, which also included the greatest shrinkage in the workweek in 10 years, a second consecutive drop of 20,000 jobs in the construction industry and a reduction of 10 percent in the ranks of the partly unemployed. [Page 39.] Bad weather pushed up the unemployment rates for both New York and New Jersey, while the jobless rate fell for New York City. [47.] 
 The video game industry promised to label the sex and violence content of its games by the holiday season, but lawmakers said they would press ahead with legislation requiring the ratings. [48.]
 
Companies
Continental Airlines and USAir have lowered fares on some East Coast routes in what could prove to be a far-reaching change in airline pricing. The carriers say the low prices will be permanent. [39.] The country's big airlines will match fare discounts by Northwest Airlines through March 11 for spring travel. [48.]
FHP International agreed to pay nearly $1.1 billion in stock and cash to acquire Takecare in a deal the companies said was the highest-priced acquisition in the H.M.O. industry. [41.]
A unit of Mars Inc. got preliminary approval to build three factories south of Moscow to make Mars and Snickers candy bars, Uncle Ben's sauces and converted rice and pet foods. [41.]
The billionaire financier Warren E. Buffett has bought more stock in Salomon Brothers, and now controls 19 percent of the company's voting power. [41.]
GFC Financial agreed to acquire Tricon Capital, a unit of Bell Atlantic. Terms of the all-cash deal were not disclosed. [41.]
 
International
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa conceded that he had not enacted the economic reforms Japan needed but vowed to insure that the Japanese market was open to the world. There was little evidence that United States trade threats against Japan were spurring Tokyo to make concessions. [39.]
The maker of Swatch watches and Mercedes-Benz will make a micro-compact car, nicknamed the Swatchmobile, that will have its debut in 1997 and cost less than $10,000. [39.]
 
Markets
Stock traders concluded that the unemployment numbers meant modest growth and subdued inflation, which would be good for stocks. The Dow rose 7.88 points, to 3,832.30. [40.]
Prices of short and intermediate Treasury securities fell, but the price of the long bond rose, for a yield of 6.83 percent, unchanged from Thursday. [48.]
Copper prices rallied to eight-month highs as new signs of a resurgent economy pointed to rising demand for the metal. [50.]
The U.S. dollar rose against most leading currencies after the Government reported that employment increased solidly in February. It picked up additional strength against the Japanese yen after the Bank of Japan bought dollars in Tokyo. [50.]
 
Your Money
Homemakers and small-business owners are taking advantage of an explosion in on-line financial information and inexpensive trading services to play the stock market using their PC's. [37.]
Credit cards bearing goodies like frequent-flier miles or discounts on cars may carry higher interest rates than cards that do not offer perks. Now there is a way to cut that interest. [37.]
Some car insurers offer discounts to owners who use antitheft devices. [38.]

HEADLINE: Croatian Leader Backs Pact by Bosnia's Muslims and Croats

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, March 4

 BODY:
Breaking with the hard-line nationalists who have backed him in the past, President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia has endorsed a peace accord signed this week by Bosnia's Muslims and Croats and asserted that only people who hold "narrow-minded" or "extreme" views could oppose them.
In a nationally televised address Thursday evening, Mr. Tudjman formally approved the pacts, under which Croats and Muslims in Bosnia are to form a federated state that will then join in a loose union with Croatia, and said they had "a far-reaching and even crucial historical meaning" that would protect the interests of Croats whether they were in Bosnia or in Croatia. 
 Mr. Tudjman said the accords "can be opposed only by those who uphold narrow-minded nationalist and extreme fundamentalist views."
"Croats should realize that this solution is historically necessary in order to maintain the Croatian presence in Bosnia and to protect the strategic interests of the Croatian state," Mr. Tudjman said.
"We are nearing the end of the war and the beginning of a new period in the development of the sovereign and democratic Croatian state," he said. "In these circumstances, we will be able to devote all of our strength to the economic revival and cultural development of our homeland."
Mr. Tudjman said that in exchange for signing the Washington accords, Croatia had been "explicitly promised" help in regaining Croatian control over Serbian-occupied regions, as well as reconstruction aid, renewed access to international loans, and membership in NATO's new "Partnership for Peace" program for former Communist nations in East Europe.
President Tudjman's endorsement of the Washington accords represented a sharp reversal in his Government's policy of recent months. Until recently, allies of Mr. Tudjman had been portraying Bosnia's Muslims as fanatics dedicated to establishing a fundamentalist Islamic state.
 
Hard-Liners May Go
 Some Croats expect that as part of his new policy, Mr. Tudjman will dismiss hard-liners in his Government, among them Defense Minister Gojko Susak. But a senior foreign diplomat here said that while the Croatian President may reduce the power of nationalists like Mr. Susak, he will probably not remove them.
"Tudjman knows that if he fires these people, they are likely to become leaders of some radical opposition to the new policy," the diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "He'll prefer to keep them inside the regime, where he can watch them and control them."
Mr. Susak has made no public statements since the accords were signed, but a Bosnian branch of Croatia's governing party issued a statement questioning the accords.
"The Croatian people in Bosnia-Herzegovina are willing to accept only a state which will insure Croat sovereignty in their territory," the statement said.
Before the Muslim-Croatian talks in Washington began last week, Mr. Tudjman forced the ouster of Mate Boban as leader of the militant Bosnian Croats. He was replaced by Kresimir Zubak, an ally of Mr. Tudjman's who signed the Washington accords on behalf of the Bosnian Croats.
The chief weakness of the Croatian-Bosnian Muslim accords is that they do not include the Bosnian Serbs, who hold most of the territory in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
"I deem it necessary to emphasize that the Croat-Muslim alliance is not directed against the Serbs, nor is it intended to prolong the war," Mr. Tudjman said. "It is focused on the immediate achievement of peace."
Diplomats and other analysts in Zagreb said it would probably be difficult to persuade the Bosnian Serbs to join the new federation, but expressed hope that Russia would help push them in that direction.
Arriving in Belgrade after high-level meetings in Moscow, the political leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, did not rule out accepting the Washington accords. He suggested that Croatia's Foreign Minister, Mate Granic, travel to Belgrade for talks.
Mr. Granic has no immediate plans to visit Belgrade but is scheduled to fly to Moscow next week for meetings with Russian officials. Arriving today in Trieste, Italy, Mr. Granic said talks would begin soon aimed at bringing Bosnian Serbs into the new federation "on the terms that were accepted by the two other parties."
The accords call for Bosnia's division into semi-autonomous cantons that would have broad authority over local affairs.

HEADLINE: Airlines Rediscover Short Trips

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Air fare wars come and go these days as predictably as a flight delay out of Chicago on a Friday evening. And with such a steady stream of cut-rate deals -- two rounds of cuts were announced this week alone -- many travelers refuse to buy anything but a sharply discounted ticket.
But for short flights between dozens of cities in the Eastern United States, some large airlines like Continental and USAir have in recent weeks responded to growing competitive pressures by offering lower fares that the carriers say are permanent. And while few things remain the same for long in the volatile airline industry, there are many indications that these changes will be a lasting boon to millions of travelers. 
 Delta Air Lines executives said they would announce their plan for a new low-fare service in the East and possibly elsewhere in coming months. United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, has also said that it wants to start a high-frequency service to compete more effectively against Southwest Airlines and other carriers on short flights.
In what could prove to be the most far-reaching attempt to revamp the airline business since the failed effort by American Airlines two years ago to introduce its simplified "value pricing" fare structure, Continental and USAir have lowered fares on many short flights to double-digit levels, eliminated many restrictions and put additional nonstop flights on routes that previously had mostly connecting flights.
 
Many More Flights
 "Six months ago, we would either be in a fare war or out of a fare war, but now fares are staying down," said Bob Wood, a manager at Garris Travel in Norfolk, Va. In Norfolk, Continental has increased the number of nonstop flights to other East Coast cities to 28 beginning next Wednesday, from 5 in September, and has cut its unrestricted one-way fare to Newark, for example, from $229 to $69.
"It is opening up a whole new world for our customers," Mr. Wood said.
Travelers elsewhere are seeing even greater increases in service. In Greensboro, N.C., passengers were offered only three nonstop flights a day on Continental last fall. Next week, the airline plans to start offering 57 nonstop flights a day. Unrestricted one-way fares from Greensboro that used to range from $220 to $341 have been cut to $69 to $139.
"It is not a fare exercise," Don Valentine, Continental's senior vice president of marketing and sales, said. "It is a new way of doing business."
That new way is spreading in the industry, with many airlines unabashedly modeling themselves after Southwest Airlines, the nation's eighth-largest airline and the only consistently profitable major carrier over the last 20 years.
Southwest's strategy is deceptively simple. The carrier has shown time and again that by offering low fares and providing frequent service, it can draw people that otherwise might not fly.
More frequent service, however, does not come easily. Continental and USAir, following Southwest's lead, have had to cut the time their planes are on the ground between flights to 20 minutes, from 45.
To do that, USAir has speeded check-in procedures, reduced the number of crew changes during the day and loaded its planes with enough food and drinks for several trips, rather than restocking at every stop. USAir said the quick turnaround of 22 planes that serve 18 cities enabled it to free 3,500 more seats simply by using its planes and employees more productively.
Other major airlines are expected to follow suit because they are feeling pressure from not only an expanding Southwest and from Continental's spreading "Peanuts Fares" service, but also from fledgling airlines like Private Jet, Valujet, and Kiwi International Air Lines. Although these carriers lack the marketing heft of more established airlines, travelers are rewarding their low-fare policies by flocking to their planes.
So, even though the new fare structure represents only roughly 5 to 10 percent of the flying that is done on the East Coast, industry analysts said the new type of short-route service might quickly sweep the country. This trend, with new point-to-point flying between many cities, also underscores how airlines are rethinking the hub-and-spoke system they developed during the 1980's.
"It's like the Olympic skating," said Robert Harrell, vice president of American Express's air fare management division. "We're all on the edge of our seats to see how this comes out."
Travelers who appreciate the new low fares are undoubtedly cheering on this trend. After all, air fares on short routes -- especially in Eastern states -- have long seemed to bear little relation to the distance traveled.
That is because airlines have used short trips to subsidize long trips, where fares have fallen the most quickly since deregulation because of the development of the hub-and-spoke networks. The hub system allowed many airlines to offer competing service between far-flung cities, although often with out-of-the-way connections through hub airports.
As fares rose on short flights, particularly in cities served by few competing airlines, more and more travelers decided not to fly. Many companies also cut travel spending during the recession and imposed tightfisted policies that they vow are not going to change. These factors have affected all but the most popular business flights, like the shuttle operations that link Boston, New York and Washington.
"There's this attitude of conservatism, where spending is not as good a thing as it was in the 80's," said Ralph Brown, a travel management consultant in Hoffman Estates, Ill., whose clients include large companies like Nike, Texas Instruments and Intel. "It will never go back to the way it was."
Whether these latest changes will last depends largely on whether airlines with lower costs continue to prosper and set low prices that competitors have no choice but to match.
But airline executives, who have too often seen their industry turned on its wing tip in a short period, shy away from making predictions on such matters.
"When you talk about permanency in the pricing world," said Gary Harig, assistant vice president of pricing at USAir, "it's pretty dangerous ground."

HEADLINE: 'Manhood Training' at the Mosque: Hope, Discipline, Defiance

SERIES: Ministry of Hope, Message of Hate: Last of three articles on the Nation of Islam.

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
More than two dozen black men, many dressed in work boots and baggy slacks and a few in business suits with briefcases at their sides, recently climbed the steep concrete stairs to Muhammad's Mosque No. 7 in Harlem in search of two things the Nation of Islam promised they could find inside: brotherhood and proper direction.
The men dutifully trudged through a fresh coat of snow to the unadorned blond-brick building that houses the mosque as well as a supermarket, a combination barber shop and beauty salon, a boxing gym and a black theater company, all stacked in three stories near the northeast corner of 125th Street and Fifth Avenue. 
 There are no onion domes or gilded Islamic iconography here -- only a modest, hand-lettered sign outside a third-floor window indicates that this is a place of Islamic work and worship, the latest incarnation of a flagship Nation of Islam mosque that was largely built by Malcolm X and has been led for more than a decade by Louis Farrakhan.
Yet, while much of Harlem stirred to a sluggish start on this Saturday, the men, many of them non-Muslims and some visiting the mosque for the first time, had little difficulty finding their way to the building and to their seats for what mosque officials are describing as "manhood training."
 
Old-Fashioned Values
 The Nation of Islam has built its mostly urban black membership in large part by retrofitting generations of men with values of old-fashioned manners and behavior. Mixed in with heavy doses of religious mysticism, separatist ideology and hate-charged rhetoric aimed at anyone -- white, Jewish or black -- thought to impede black progress, are equally heavy doses of self-respect, self-love and self-reliance.
Although sermons, the group's newspaper and books promoted by the organization are often laced with the stinging language of bigotry, there was no evidence of such views at the three-hour training session.
Manhood training, a pilot program aimed at nonmembers, was started a month ago to answer the often-heard criticism that Mr. Farrakhan's brand of Islam was little more than a movement of oratory, not deeds. In Manhattan, Queens, the Bronx and Brooklyn and in Westchester County and Long Island, the once-a-week course is offered free, Conrad Muhammad, leader of the Harlem mosque, said in an interview.
"In order to be a well-rounded man, you have to know things like how to manage a household economy, how to write a check and balance a checkbook," he said. "And these are things that many of our men come to this training without."
Mr. Muhammad said that a typical session attracted 200 men and that the program enabled the mosque to reach people who were not already believers, people in the broader black and Hispanic community, "to help our people in these communities to organize themselves."
He noted that America took centuries to build and said Mr. Farrakhan's group would not be built overnight. But he added that "we should be credited" for what the group had done so far, "because if a man is paralyzed, if you get him to move a finger, that's a cause for celebration."
The training program is one reason that in expanding black circles the Harlem mosque -- the nerve center of Nation of Islam activities in New York -- is becoming a landmark of hope and defiance. Many blacks in Harlem and throughout the New York metropolitan region say they see it as a factory in which men and women, whether troubled by drugs or criminality or simply uncertainty, can be retooled into community assets.
A young woman who said she is not a Muslim suggested how influential that view was, saying there was a growing chic in which clean-shaven young men with close-cropped hair in suits and bow ties were now regarded in her circle as cute.
Certainly there are many black voices in Harlem and elsewhere that speak of worry and concern whenever Mr. Farrakhan's name arises. One longtime neighborhood resident, Albert Murray, the writer, said the popularity of the Nation of Islam was a troubling indication of the extent of confusion racking much of black America.
"It's a bunch of ignorance," he said. "What concerns me most is that this promotion or stimulation of a feeling of alienation, separatism and hostility, would put down legitimate ambitions of American citizens that the civil rights movement made realizable."
But it is just as easy to find supporters, people like Tekima Berlack, a Harlem hat store owner, a non-Muslim who stood outside the 369th Armory in Harlem, where Mr. Farrakhan spoke recently, shouting encouragement to the blocks-long columns of men inching past on the way to hear him. "Glad to see you, brother!" Ms. Berlack and several other middle-aged cheerleaders shouted. "Good to see you come out tonight!"
And in more than a month of frequent visits to Muhammad's Mosque No. 7, with its narrow hallways, exposed wiring and closed window blinds radiating a scrubbed-bare austerity, it was not unusual to see people enter with wide-eyed expectations and a touch of awe.
"Today, most black people accept the Nation of Islam the same way they accept any other church," said C. Eric Lincoln, professor emeritus of religion at Duke University and author of "The Black Muslims in America." "The Nation of Islam is not exotic anymore."
 
The Training
Part Therapy, Part Preaching
 On this recent snowy Saturday, the glass door at the foot of the mosque's stairs was flung open to black men, any black men, who cared to participate in manhood training. It is part lecture, part paramilitary drilling and part group therapy and catharsis for inner-city blues.
It is also a seamless dissemination of the basic tenets of Nation of Islam philosophy, including handouts detailing the 26 "restricted laws of Islam," which was underscored by a lecture on the perils of pork, gambling, lying and adultery. There was also a guide given to each man on proper diet, and a glossary of terms that included the words "reliance" and "adversity."
A tall, honey-voiced man later introduced as Brother Kenneth 6X glanced at his watch and decided that the first lesson of the day would be about punctuality.
"Be on time, brothers," he said, admonishing nearly half the men who took their seats 15 minutes after the scheduled 10 A.M. start. "Don't think that because the weather is bad that we are not going to start on time; we are going to begin on time."
The men, whose ages appeared to range from the mid-20's to the mid-50's, sat shoulder to shoulder in straight-backed plastic chairs and nodded their agreement.
Like most free events sponsored by the Nation of Islam, people were encouraged to make donations. Few left the manhood class without dropping some cash in a plastic tub on a table at the back of the room. The Muslims also asked participants to fill out detailed background forms, a request reminiscent of Mr. Farrakhan's speech at the armory when he asked his audience of more than 10,000 men to fill out index cards with their names, addresses and Social Security numbers.
Many of the men attending the manhood training classes, like other blacks attracted to the teachings of the Nation of Islam, say they carefully pick and choose from the group's smorgasbord of race remedies and try not to get swept up in the sheer power of Muslim persuasion.
"I'm not interested in being a Muslim," said a 33-year-old publishing executive who works in midtown Manhattan and has attended several manhood training sessions at the Harlem mosque. "I'm a thinking individual who takes and uses anything I want from anyone who offers a good idea."
The executive, a Harlem homeowner, asked that his name not be used because he feared that his white and Jewish co-workers might misunderstand his relationship with the Muslims. "I like their commitment to empowerment and to doing for self," he said. "I want to stand with them for that. I don't hate anyone."
Nonetheless, Jews and whites are frequent targets of much of the Muslim leadership's superheated oratory. And such speech seldom fails to whip the 400 or so people who regularly attend Sunday afternoon services at the Harlem mosque into a frenzy of approving shouts of "um-huh!" and "yes!"
 
Emphasis on Cooperation
 For the most part, however, the manhood class concentrated on what black men could do to improve themselves and their neighborhoods. Much of the time, Brother Kenneth lectured about the importance of "economic unity" and "pooling resources."
"To build a nation, you can't do it individually," he told the men, who nodded in agreement. "We have to work cooperatively."
Almost as if to demonstrate his point, the class was turned over to another man, a stout former marine with a rumbling voice and seemingly infinite patience. For almost 30 minutes he taught the men the basics of military marching -- Nation of Islam style.
For example, as the men marched in place -- arms swinging and knees pumping -- and yelled in cadence -- "One! Two! Three! Four! -- he would help keep time by shouting out the names of Islamic holy men. "This is not like in the white man's army," he told the marchers. "We want you to think."
 
The Origins
From Malcolm X To Farrakhan
 Malcolm X, who became a Muslim while serving a prison sentence, was an early minister of the Nation of Islam's mosque in New York. Alex Haley's 1964 book, "The Autobiography of Malcolm X," says that in the summer of 1954 the temple was hardly more than a "little storefront."
But by raiding the congregations of some of the city's black churches, Malcolm X began to build a large following in Harlem. A few months after he left the Nation in 1964 for a more orthodox brand of Islam and was assassinated by Nation of Islam followers, Louis Farrakhan was named minister.
In 1975 Elijah Muhammad, the longtime leader of the Nation of Islam, died, and was succeeded by his son, Warith Deen Mohammad, who changed his spelling of his last name. He recalled Mr. Farrakhan to Chicago, but a short time later the two split, with Mr. Mohammad establishing a new branch of more orthodox Islam and Mr. Farrakhan leading the Nation of Islam.
The mosque led by Malcolm X, on the southwest corner of 116 Street and what is now Malcolm X Boulevard, is the site of the Malcolm Shabazz Masjid and Sister Clara Muhammad Elementary and Secondary School. It belongs to Mr. Mohammad's more orthodox Islamic order.
The Nation of Islam moved its mosque many times, settling on the present site in 1986. Conrad Muhammad, 29, became the minister there in 1991.
 
Clashes With the Police
 With the exception of occasional clashes with the police over the years -- one resulting in the death of a police officer in 1972, when he was shot in a scuffle with mosque members while investigating a false 911 call to the mosque -- the Nation of Islam in Harlem has had few problems with the city authorities.
But on Jan. 9, the Fruit of Islam, the organization's security force, "rolled out," as one mosque member put it, eight New York police officers when they entered the building during a Sunday service to investigate what turned out to be a false report that someone was robbing the mosque.
The incident, in which the officers suffered minor injuries, led to the arrest of a 29-year-old mosque member. The confrontation, coupled with the shooting two days later of a black, unarmed 17-year-old orthodox Muslim in what the police said was an East New York crack house, touched off a wave of tension between blacks and the newly installed Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
The tensions also raised the profile of black Muslims in New York City, particularly those in the Harlem mosque. An increased fascination, mosque members say, has already translated into new support for Mr. Farrahkan and his teachings.
"I think what happens is that a lot of people decide to forgive him for this negative side of him because they see the 'positive side' as being somewhat redemptive," said Ellis Cose, the author of a 1993 book, "The Rage of a Privileged Class." Ultimately, Mr. Cose said, such moral reductions are a trap. "If you take part of it," he said of the Muslim world view, "you take all of it."
 
The Critics
Anger Directed At Wrong Targets
 Albert Murray, the Harlem writer, was referring to this melting pot of contrasting views when he said that at its root Mr. Farrakhan's movement was anti-intellectual. He lamented that while Mr. Farrakhan could draw thousands of blacks to Harlem, fewer than a couple of hundred would probably appear to hear another prominent black man, Ronald H. Brown, the Secretary of Commerce.
Representative Major R. Owens, a Brooklyn Democrat who is a member of the Congressional Black Caucus, has been outspoken about his concerns that elected black officials may become too closely allied with Mr. Farrakhan. But, he said in a recent interview, he understands why the Muslim minister attracts a great deal of attention in black communities.
"People respond to any strong leader who is clear about what he stands for and has a following of people with a great deal of fervor," Mr. Owens asserted.
"There are a lot of frustrated, angry, bitter people who are looking for a leader," he said later. "In some cases they are looking for something to hate."
The tragedy of the Farrakhan phenomenon is that it directs black anger and frustration at the wrong targets, Mr. Owens said, adding that the political alliance between blacks and Jews "is vital to our survival."
Besides, he asked, what has the Nation if Islam really accomplished? "The Nation has not produced any jobs yet," Mr. Owens said. "It has not solved the crime problem."
 
The Supporters
Nods of Assent For Muslim Power
 Tekima Berlack is one of many who see things differently. "Minister Farrakhan represents power in the community," she said recently as she sat in her hat store on 125th Street.
The shop is one of many small businesses that operate in the shopping center Mart 125. Mart 125, one of many crossroads where the people of Harlem gather and discuss the events of the day, has been full of debate about Mr. Farrakhan and the tremors of racial politics surrounding him and his former spokesman, Khallid Abdul Muhammad.
Many in Harlem speak glowingly of Mr. Farrakhan and the Muslims he commands. His likeness is frequently found in shops and at vendors' stands in posters and velvet paintings alongside those of Malcolm X and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Recordings of Mr. Farrakhan's speeches are hawked on Harlem streets with almost the same urgency as the latest releases of popular hip hop and R&B artists.
And while many are quick to dismiss the anti-Semitism that surges through some of Mr. Farrakhan's oratory as simply a "white media" exaggeration of his message, the mere question of whether the Muslim minister and his followers are promoting hate is most often met in Harlem with questioning looks and incredulous expressions.
 
Gaining Status Through Demotion
 Even Mr. Farrakhan's recent demotion of Khallid Muhammad, for his racist and anti-Semitic remarks to a group of students at Kean College in Union City, N.J., seems to have only bolstered Mr. Farrakhan's standing in Harlem.
"I believe in the words of Elijah Muhammad that the white men are devils," said 18-year-old Nathaniel (Duce) Powell.
Other supporters were more reticent. For example, the owner of a black art gallery said he feared "an audit or worse" if he identified himself as someone who attended the Farrakhan speech with his son in Harlem last month.
But for thousands of others, including Tekima Berlack, a tall woman who favors blunt talk and a regal carriage, Mr. Farrakhan remains a heroic spokesman.
"I'm tired," she said, thinking back about her life, which she contended had been dogged at almost every turn by white racism. "I wasn't able to save my children from it, but I'm hoping to save my grandchildren."
Even as a Christian, Ms. Berlack confessed, she is still trying to persuade her son to embrace the Muslims, or at least their example.
Why?
"Because I have to leave my son where he's going to get protection," she replied. "Before I close my eyes in this world, he's going to be Farrakhan's."
 
THURSDAY Louis Farrakhan, man of contrasts, preaches love but says there is no shame in hatred.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mars Gains In Its Plans For Russia

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 4

 BODY:
Master Foods Russia, a subsidiary of Mars Inc., has received preliminary approval from Moscow's regional administration to build three food-product factories for the Russian market.
The company expects to make Mars and Snickers bars, Uncle Ben's sauces and converted rice, and Whiskas and Pedigree Pal pet foods. 
 Master Foods said in a news release Thursday that the three factories, which it hopes to complete by the end of 1995, could employ up to 1,000 people in food production. A company executive said total employment, including jobs in warehousing, distribution and other support services, could reach 5,000.
The company's investment in the factories would exceed $50 million, the executive said.
The factories would be built in Stupino, an industrial city of 125,000 about 60 miles southeast of Moscow. It used to be closed to foreigners because military components were produced there. Like other towns long dependent on the military, Stupino has had rising unemployment.
 
Approvals Needed
 Moscow's municipal and regional governments must approve a feasibility study by Master Foods before construction can begin. A team of Western engineers visited Stupino this week to begin the study.
The project is one of the most significant foreign investment proposals to be put forward in Russia since the strong showing of nationalists and Communists in the December parliamentary elections. Western investors have grown skittish here since the Government announced it would pursue a more moderate reform course and a less-stringent monetary policy.
Master Foods products, among the most popular Western imports, are widely available and heavily advertised. In addition to its candy bars, introduced in 1991, Master Foods has pioneered the marketing of pet foods, which were virtually nonexistent during the Soviet era and have become status symbols among Russians.
Unlike other Western companies, which have raised the ruble price of their products rapidly as the nation's currency has devalued and prices have increased, Master Foods has tried to keep the cost of its candy bars more stable. A Snickers bar costs about 600 rubles (about 35 cents).
 
51 Plants in 30 Countries
 Given the popularity in Russia of its products, which are now imported from the United States, Western Europe and Australia, the company executive said building the factories was a logical step. Mars currently has 51 plants in 30 countries.
A second phase, to produce Mars ice cream products, should be finished by 1998. The Moscow regional government has agreed to supply land on terms of a 49-year lease.
Anatoly C. Tyazhlov, chief administrator of the Moscow region, signed a decree on Jan. 27 accepting the initial Master Foods proposal to build the factories. The plants would "assure a more expedient use of labor resources freed from military industrial plants," the decree said.
The factories would have the capacity to produce 150,000 tons of food products a year.

HEADLINE: Weather Lifts Joblessness In New York and New Jersey

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
Dampened by winter storms, the overall unemployment rate for New York and New Jersey took a turn for the worse last month, while the rate for New York City improved, reflecting the growing strength of the city's economy.
In New York State, the unemployment rate, adjusted for normal seasonal fluctuations, increased to 7.8 percent last month from 7.1 percent in January, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. It was the first big increase since October. 
 The change represented a loss of about 58,000 jobs in the state, which has 672,000 people out of work.
New Jersey's unemployment rate also edged up last month, to 7.3 percent from 6.8 percent in January. The increase represented about 17,000 people who lost jobs, bringing the total number of unemployed in New Jersey to 295,000.
 
The Weather Factor
 The United States Department of Labor does not provide monthly unemployment figures for Connecticut.
The higher unemployment rates in New York and New Jersey ran counter to a decline in the national rate, which dropped to 6.5 percent last month from 6.7 percent in January. The drop, described by economists as a heartening sign of the continuing recovery, represented the addition of 217,000 new jobs.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the mid-Atlantic regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which is part of the Labor Department, said a main reason for the higher unemployment rate in New York and New Jersey was the severity of storms this winter. A series of 15 storms has shut down construction and made job hunting difficult, he said.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said the bureau's monthly unemployment survey was taken during a particularly stormy week, which probably further increased the figure.
"Over all, these figures don't show some new deterioration in the regional economy," he said. "Fundamentally, the regional economy is showing some strength. On the whole, we came through the month pretty well."
 
 
New York City Rate Is 10%
 A bright spot in the regional economy was New York City, where the unemployment rate dropped to 10 percent last month from 10.8 percent in January.
A total of 320,000 people were out of work in the city, while 2.9 million people had jobs, the bureau said.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said the improvement in the city's unemployment figures, which are not adjusted for normal seasonal fluctuations, stemmed from additional hiring in the service and financial sectors, which include hotels, restaurants, hospitals, advertising and securities companies.
"We're not in a boom, but we are seeing a slow improvement in the economy," he said. "Given that the number could have gone up because of the storms, it really shows the strength in the economy."
Mr. Ehrenhalt said the encouraging drop in the city's unemployment rate was also helped by stability in the construction, manufacturing and trade sectors, which had been particularly hard hit through the recession.
"If we can get March to go out like a lamb, we can look forward to an economic spring," he said.
