HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Electronics District Hits Hard Times

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 4

 BODY:
In a nation where it is considered impolite to call attention to oneself, the Akihabara district stands out, with its neon lights, its signs painted hot pink and emerald green and its hundreds of garish discount stores and back-alley stalls bursting with gadgetry, from televisions the size of postage stamps to remote-control toilets that provide a spray of water in lieu of paper. 
 "If you can't find something you like here, you can't find it anywhere," boasted Tsuyoshi Sato, president of the district merchants' association.
 
Japanese Pay More
 But if Akihabara is a showcase of Japan's ingenuity, it is now also a symbol of its troubles. Sales here have slumped in Japan's stubborn recession. And Sony, Matsushita and the other electronics giants have been unable to devise new products to follow such blockbuster items as the videocassette recorder, the Walkman, the compact disk, the camcorder, the microwave oven, the compact camera, the fax, the cordless phone, the calculator and the digital watch.
At the same time, retailing in Japan is undergoing a major change, with discount shops springing up everywhere. "In the past people came to Akihabara for a good price," said Bunzo Miyazawa, manager of a tiny store called Yamaichi Denki, or Yamaichi Electric. "Now people can find good prices in the suburbs too."
The rise of the yen has made Japanese products more expensive for foreigners, driving away some of the tourists from the district's shops. Japanese products are often cheaper in New York and Hong Kong than in Tokyo anyway because of the inefficient distribution system here.
All these factors have combined to produce what some merchants call the hardest times in memory. Two leading retailers went out of business last fall. One of them, Hirose Musen, closed abruptly, leaving its stunned employees to picket outside the shuttered store, demanding their jobs back.
The vast electronics bazaar got its start after World War II, when the area was home to a diverse and thriving black market. Soldiers would steal vacuum tubes, wires and other components from military bases and bring them to students at a nearby technical college, who would fashion the parts into radios and sell them.
 
Ever-Changing Prices
 Today, in an area that covers only a few blocks, 207 companies operate 348 shops, with total annual sales of about $3.8 billion, according to an analysis by Weekly Diamond, a business magazine. An estimated 5 percent of the electronic appliances sold in Japan pass through Akihabara.
Competition is intense. "It's quite often that the price in the afternoon is different from the price in the morning," said Akiko Inoue, a manager at Tsukumo Denki, a computer store. "One shop cuts prices and the others follow." As if to confirm her words, workers nearby were painting a sign listing newly lowered prices.
Mrs. Inoue, a rarity in Akihabara's predominantly male culture, won a contest as the best salesperson in the entire ward a couple of years ago, once selling 30 computers in a day.
Akihabara has three subcultures. The best-known is that of the appliance stores, with their television sets, vacuum cleaners and refrigerators spilling out onto the sidewalks.
Unlike sprawling superstores in the United States, shops here are narrow and vertical, with signs painted on the fronts of the steps to direct customers to the right floor. Many companies operate several stores within a block or two of one another.
 
Catering to 'Maniacs'
 The second segment of Akihabara society is made up of parts suppliers, who occupy tiny stalls in alleys and basements. They cater to small electronics manufacturers and to avid hobbyists, known here as "maniacs."
Suzuki Denki, one such supplier, has a counter crammed with diodes, clips, wires, chips, fuses, switches and integrated circuit extractors. Standing on the counter, at eye level, is another loaded shelf, making it virtually impossible for the clerk and customer to see each other.
"I just do business by voice," said Tetsuyuki Komami, the salesman there. Customers hand their money and receive their merchandise through the space between the counter and the shelf.
The third group is the computer, video game and software stores. Teen-agers play video games on the street and line up outside the stores when a hot new program goes on sale.
 
Evolution of Electronics
 This segment is growing. Computer hardware and software stores are opening one after another, often in locations vacated by consumer electronics stores. Some merchants say that far from being in decline, Akihabara is merely evolving from home appliances to computers.
There are other positive signs as well. Recently, there have been some signs of an upturn in sales of consumer electronics products. And efforts are under way to install nicer pavement and street lights. A new railroad line will connect Akihabara to Tsukuba, a scientific research center.
There are also grandiose plans, now highly uncertain because of the real estate slump, for an office and retail complex. It would include restaurants and parking lots that would make Akihabara more attractive for family outings.
"We want to renew the image of Akihabara," said Mr. Sato of the merchants' association.
But not everyone is hopeful about the district's future. "I can't see the end of the recession," said Mr. Komami, 61, who has been a salesman for 40 years at the Suzuki Denki parts shop. "I just want to hang on."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Akihabara electronics retail district in Tokyo is feeling the bite of Japan's recession and increased competition. But the shops, like Bunzo Miyazaki's tiny Yamaichi Denki store, are still packed with goods. (Fujifotos for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Broad Front After Report on Job Growth

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday after the Government reported that employment increased solidly in February. It picked up additional strength against the Japanese yen after the Bank of Japan bought dollars in Tokyo.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the economy had added 217,000 jobs in February. Few traders had expected such a strong employment report, with several analysts having predicted a rise of 140,000 jobs. 
 The dollar failed to rise more because January's gain of 62,000 jobs was revised to show a loss of 2,000 jobs.
"It was a good number, except for the revision," said Lynn Tierney, vice president at Shawmut Bank of Boston.
Investors often buy dollars after positive economic reports, betting that stronger growth will give the Federal Reserve the incentive to raise rates. Higher rates make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.65 yen, up sharply from 103.88 on Thursday. It also rose to 1.7186 German marks, from 1.7110.
The monthly employment report is considered one of the broadest assessments of the economy's strength. Without strong growth in employment, the Fed is considered less likely to raise interest rates to control inflation.
"I don't think they will tighten rates after this report," said Albert Soria, foreign-exchange manager at Kansallis Osake Pankki, a Finnish bank in New York.
The dollar rallied on Feb. 4, after the Fed pushed up the Federal funds rate to 3.25 percent from 3 percent. The rate is what banks charge one another on overnight loans.
Traders said the Bank of Japan had aggressively bought dollars to keep the yen from surging after the Clinton Administration threatened to impose trade sanctions. On Thursday, President Clinton signed an executive order reinstating a lapsed section of the 1988 Trade Act known as Super 301, giving him the authority to impose trade sanctions quickly against Japan if it fails to open its markets.
With trade relations worsening, many currency traders expect the Administration to resume calls for a strong yen, which would make Japan's exports to the United States more expensive.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Hits 8-Month High On Stronger Economic Data

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Copper prices rallied to eight-month highs yesterday as new signs of a resurgent economy pointed to increased demand for the metal. There were also signs of a potential supply shortage in copper .
May copper rose 2 cents, to 89.55 cents a pound, at the Commodity Exchange in New York, the highest closing price since July 8 and a 21 percent gain from a low of 73 cents in late October. 
 "A recent string of positive economic releases helped engineer a strong price rise, as U.S. industrial demand continues to expand," Jim Steel, an analyst at Refco Inc., said. "The market seems poised to go over 90 cents."
The copper market picked up considerable support from yesterday's report by the Labor Department on February employment, which showed the economy added 217,000 nonfarm jobs last month.
And the Commerce Department said the index of leading economic indicators rose three-tenths of 1 percent in January, the sixth consecutive month of gains in the forecasting gauge.
Copper is heavily used by many industries from manufacturers to telecommunications companies.
Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential Securities said a drop in copper inventories at London Metal Exchange warehouses might point to a potential supply shortage, which is reflected in the slim price spread between copper futures contracts.
"There's a bit of tightness in the spreads, suggesting potential supply tightness," Ms. Raptopoulos said.
Platinum also showed strength yesterday, with the April futures contract gaining $2.50, to $395.30 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
But there was little movement in gold and silver. On the Comex, April gold gained 30 cents, to $378.80 an ounce, while May silver slipped 0.2 cent, to $5.27 an ounce.
On other commodity markets, oil prices closed slightly lower in light trading as traders continued to mark time before today's meeting of the Gulf Cooperation Council.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, April crude declined 18 cents, to $14.57 a barrel, unchanged from its close on the previous Friday and still in a $14-to-$15 range. Traders expect that range to hold until Saudi Arabia makes its opinion known on an OPEC output cut.
"It's unclear where the market is going until we know what OPEC will do," said Shannon Burchett, vice president at Chase Manhattan. "There is nothing for people to hang their hats on."

HEADLINE: U.S. Jobless Rate Eased Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 4

 BODY:
The job market improved further in February as payrolls expanded and the unemployment rate eased to 6.5 percent, the Government reported today.
Unusually severe winter weather and statistical quirks again muddied the results, which also included the greatest shrinkage in the workweek in 10 years, a second consecutive drop of 20,000 jobs in the construction industry and a reduction of 10 percent in the ranks of the "partially unemployed." 
 But emerging rather clearly was a broad pattern of moderate improvement in employment and at the same time some settling down of an economy that had raced ahead at an unsustainable pace of 7.5 percent in the last three months of 1993.
 
 
Message to Federal Reserve
 "We now have a good, strong, steady economy," said the President's top economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson. Mindful of the Federal Reserve's watchfulness about upward pressure on prices, she added that the improved labor market conditions should not be seen "as signs that the economy is booming, or as a threat of impending inflation."
In a separate report, the Commerce Department index that forecasts business conditions climbed three-tenths of a percent in January. It was the sixth consecutive increase in the index of leading economic indicators, but it was less than half the jump of seven-tenths of 1 percent in December.
The employment report, the first comprehensive data on the performance of the economy in February, showed a gain of 217,000 jobs. The increase was somewhat more than most analysts had expected but it was less robust than it appeared because the gain initially reported for January, 62,000 jobs, was revised into a loss of 2,000 jobs. At the same time, an extra 40,000 jobs were added to the total for December.
 
 
Crucial Differences
 While job growth so far this year has been only half as fast as in the last four months of 1993, the February gain reassured analysts that the economy's vigor in the fourth quarter did not dissolve in the new year, as had occurred in early 1993.
"We're avoiding a replay of last year's riches-to-rags slowdown," said Robert D. Barr, deputy chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Factory jobs were up a modest 12,000 last month, but the gain was the fifth consecutive increase, totaling 78,000, since September. But bad weather cut heavily into the factory workweek, which shrank by 42 minutes from exceptionally high recent levels.
Employment in the retail trade sector rebounded by 58,000 jobs after a small loss in January. Gains in general merchandise and food stores combined with gains at automobile dealerships and service stations to more than offset a weather-related drop of 30,000 jobs at restaurants and bars. The finance industry added another 14,000 jobs, bringing the total gain to about 130,000 for the last 18 months.
The Labor Department's survey of households, on which the unemployment rate is based, showed a gain in jobs of 287,000, more than twice the growth in the size of the labor force. That pushed the jobless rate down two-tenths of a point from the January rate of 6.7 percent. But the Labor Department said that even this minimally significant change might have been exaggerated, because seasonal adjustment factors based on its old survey had to be used with the newly overhauled survey introduced in January, helping to push the jobless rate down a half-point since December.
Under the old method, the jobless rate actually ticked up a tenth of a point in February, to 6.4 percent, the same rate as in December.
The report today also showed that the number of the partly unemployed -- people who wanted more work than they had -- dropped by 524,000. This was another result of applying old seasonal formulas to new data, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
Still another aberration was a drop of 775,000, or 23 percent, in the number of people listed as out of work for five weeks or less. Ms. Abraham said this was a one-time adjustment resulting from refined questioning in the new survey that shifted many of the jobless people into the 5-to-14-weeks category. The average and median duration of jobless spells also rose.
 
 
Geographic Disparity
 While adult women seemed to have had more success than men in finding jobs -- the women's unemployment rate eased three-tenths of a point, to 5.7 percent, while the men's rate edged up to 6 percent -- there were no particularly large changes last month among the big demographic groups.
But the new survey showed considerable geographic disparity, with jobless rates up by 1.2 points in North Carolina, 0.9 point in Texas and 0.7 point in New York. The rate dropped by 1.8 points in Florida, 1.1 points in California, 0.9 point in Pennsylvania and Ohio and 0.8 point in Massachusetts.
These were sizable changes, even allowing for the fact that the rates for individual states swing by much larger amounts than the national figures, because of the smaller samples.
Regionally, the changes were less pronounced. The jobless rates were unchanged in the Northeast and South, at 6.7 percent and 6.3 percent, respectively, while the rate in the Midwest fell to 5.5 percent, from 6 percent, and the rate in the West fell to 7.6 percent, from 8 percent.

HEADLINE: New U.S. Pressure on Trade Doesn't Seem to Spur Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 4

 BODY:
With the Clinton Administration turning up the heat against Japan, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa conceded today that he had not yet begun to enact the sweeping economic reforms his country needs but vowed "to insure that the Japanese market is open to the rest of the world."
Nonetheless, there was little evidence that President Clinton's strategy -- to threaten action by the United States against a broad range of Japanese products unless progress is made -- was spurring Mr. Hosokawa's Government to make concessions or even generate new ideas about how to close the $59.3 billion trade gap. 
 In fact, senior Japanese and American officials say they think that whatever momentum Mr. Hosokawa once had to push through new market openings is quickly fading. Today, the Tokyo stock market Nikkei index even rose 360.14 points, or 1.84 percent, to 19,966, as investors concluded that Mr. Clinton's trade declaration sounded tougher than it really was. Some seemed confident that the declaration actually worked to Japan's interest, because it could defuse far worse proposals on Capitol Hill.
It now appears highly unlikely, Japanese officials say, that Mr. Hosokawa will be ready with any new proposals on improving access to Japanese markets by the time Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives here next Wednesday. Mr. Christopher's visit will mark the first high-level talks since President Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa deadlocked on trade issues last month in Washington.
"If anything, I'm afraid we are slipping backwards," a senior American official here said today. "However we frame the message in Washington, it still does not look like it is getting through."
Indeed the most striking aspect of Mr. Hosokawa's hourlong policy speech to Parliament today, a Japanese equivalent of the State of the Union address, is how little he had to say about the specifics of handling the new tension with Japan's biggest ally. He never once mentioned Mr. Clinton's action to revive the section of the 1988 Trade Act, called Super 301, which empowers the Administration to act quickly in drawing up a hit list of countries that erect barriers to American exports. He said that "the thing that the people most ardently desire now is an escape from this grim recession."
Rather than address market openings, Mr. Hosokawa returned to one of his favorite themes: deregulating an economy choking on bureaucracy and restrictive rules.
"We intend to move toward making nonregulation the norm and regulation the exception," he said, urging broader choices for consumers and sharp reductions in "the disparity between Japanese and overseas prices." He talked of the need for "comprehensive consumer protection." But he described no specifics.
"Japan is currently running a massive current account surplus," Mr. Hosokawa told the Parliament today, "and there are still insistent voices claiming that the Japanese market is closed. While some of this criticism stems from misunderstanding, I would rather see this as evidence of the high hopes people have for Japan and I believe we should take the initiative in implementing necessary reforms in our own interest."
Picking his wording carefully from the text of the "framework accord" on trade signed last summer, he committed himself only to "to achieve a highly significant reduction in our current account surplus over the medium term." However, just hours before Mr. Hosokowa spoke, the Finance Ministry reported that Japan's current account surplus with the world rose 30.9 percent in January to $6.83 billion, a record high for the month.
With his coalition Government veering from crisis to crisis, Mr. Hosokawa seems in a weaker position than ever to execute his goals. This week he was unable to gather enough support within his fragile coalition to dismiss his chief Cabinet secretary, Masayoshi Takemura, who has differed with him on a number of economic policy issues. He was left with the worst of all alternatives: He angered many members of his Government in a paralyzing debate about ousting Mr. Takemura, but in the end was left with the same team in place.
Indeed, the trade issue has become simply another of the many issues being manipulated by politicians jockeying for position around Mr. Hosokawa. The opposition Liberal Democratic Party, which was ousted from power last summer after dominating the country's politics for 38 years, is using the dispute with the United States to portray Mr. Hosokawa as an incompetent caretaker of the American relationship.
 
Criticism From Rivals
 The Prime Minister "is trying to make the trade dispute with the United States seem insignificant," Yohei Kono, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, said today. Meanwhile, members of Mr. Hosokawa's own coalition have attempted to slow some of the reforms that threaten economic interests in their own districts.
Mr. Hosokawa's supporters were clearly intent on playing down the Super 301 trade issue today, shrugging it off when the topic came up. "Some say Japan has been targeted, but I don't think so," Tsutomu Hata, the Foreign Minister, said tonight on the state-run television network, NHK. "Any country can be subject to it."
Mr. Hata, like other prominent Japanese officials, spoke at length today about the need to make sure that the trade dispute did not "infect" other elements of the relationship between the two countries. "I believe both sides can come to a compromise," he said. "There have been issues like this before."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Credit Card Goodies, With Lower Interest

BYLINE: By Saul Hansell 

 BODY:
MANY credit cards now offer goodies, from frequent-flier miles to discounts on cars and candy bars. Tempting as they may be, these cards are not always great deals.
That's because the cards with the perks often carry higher interest rates than those without. Some people, of course, pay their bills every month and lap up the bonuses. But most people -- even those who say they pay their bills -- occasionally borrow money on their cards. 
 For them, the Chase Manhattan Bank is offering an alternative. A card holder can charge all he wants on his favorite card, earning miles or points or whatever. Then if he doesn't have the cash to pay the entire balance, he writes a check from Chase's Reward Consolidator account, a credit line with a variable interest rate, now at 10.9 percent.
Since Chase's credit line carries no fee, and the rate is significantly less than the 15 to 17 percent on most cards with giveaways, the product could be a real money saver.
"This is a way for someone to have their cake and eat it too," said Robert McKinley, president of RAM research, a Frederick, Md., newsletter publisher. "If you are a consumer who has the commitment to charge groceries, gas, taxis and pizza to your airline card or General Motors card and pay it off using a credit line like Chase's, you will get the benefits without paying through the nose."
Moreover, by paying the card bill in full each month, the card holder won't pay any interest until the check clears at Chase. This means an average of 45 days without interest. While most credit cards offer a grace period if the bill is paid in full, they charge interest from the date of purchase for a partial payment.
By having two accounts, one for spending and one for borrowing, consumers may get a better view of their finances. The down side is that juggling two accounts will be more complex. And for borrowers who lack financial discipline, more credit could be a temptation to get too deeply in debt.
Of course, the two-account strategy does not have to include Chase. Many banks offer credit lines with access by checks, and many credit card accounts offer checks. (Watch out for fees here: Some credit cards charge fees of up to 2 percent on these checks, while others waive the fee for transferring balances from other cards.)
One credit card without a fee for check use is the Bank of New York Mastercard for members of unions in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The interest is the prime rate, now 6 percent, plus five percentage points, and there is no annual fee. (This account is less useful as a credit card because it does not have a grace period on purchases before interest begins accruing.)
Another option is the Preferred Credit Line offered by the Republic National Bank of New York, with access by checks at no fee and has an interest rate of prime plus 7.9 percentage points, or 13.9 percent.
Shopping for the best borrowing deal is easier than finding the best reward program. After the early success of the General Motors credit card, virtually every large retailer and manufacturer is at least considering a credit card program with a bank.
The ground rule is to pick a card affiliated with something you plan to use. It doesn't help to get a discount on a General Motors car if you buy a BMW. But for people who want their cars, General Motors and Ford probably have the best credit card deals around, offering auto rebates of 5 percent on card purchases.
The cards linked with the airline frequent-flier programs are also a good deal, if you spend more than $5,000 or so on your card each year. An airline mile is probably worth about 2 cents, so the airline programs offer roughly a 2 percent rebate. Pick the program of the airline you fly most.
For more moderate spenders, the Shell Oil card from Chemical Bank offers a 2 percent rebate on all purchases and 3 percent on Shell gas. Another choice would be the GE Rewards card, which offers a 2 percent rebate good at several stores, including Kmart and Toys "R" Us.
Even the corner store is getting into the credit card game. Harvest Foods, based in Little Rock, Ark., offers a card with rebates of up to 2 percent on purchases at its 54 grocery stores. So for the modern coupon clipper, a wallet full of cards from different merchants may make sense. Just be sure to shop for the best loan deal separately.

LENGTH: 522 words

HEADLINE: Risking a Trade War

 BODY:
President Clinton's decision to invoke a trade law provision that would enable him to impose tough sanctions against Japan if the Japanese fail to open their markets to American goods is unnecessary, dangerous and misguided.
The political logic behind the President's move is understandable. Polls show that a significant majority of Americans favor a tough stance toward the Japanese, and protectionists in Congress are pushing hard for retaliation against Tokyo. But any crackdown by the U.S. could undermine the elaborately constructed international apparatus for resolving trade disputes. 
 The provision invoked by Mr. Clinton, known as Super 301, triggers a timetable for the U.S. to decide unilaterally whether Japan (or any other country) is violating fair trade rules and, if so, what sanctions to impose. The key word is unilateral: under Super 301, the U.S. belittles its commitment to resolve disputes in multilateral settings.
The provision is unnecessary because U.S. law already permits the Government to retaliate unilaterally against unfair trade practices. That's risky enough, but Super 301 hastens the process.
Super 301 is dangerous because the added threat moves the U.S. one step closer to a trade war with an important ally and could undermine the fragile coalition of Prime Minister Hosokawa, who is pushing a deregulatory agenda that would eventually break down protectionist barriers around Japanese markets.
And the provision is misguided because it belies a profound misunderstanding about the economic impact of trade deficits. Even if the U.S. were to compel Japan to buy more U.S. autos and computers, the overall U.S. trade deficit would not fall. Trade deficits are caused by Americans buying more goods and services than they produce. The extra goods must come from trade partners -- if not from Japan, then somewhere else.
The Administration portrays the $60 billion trade deficit with Japan as an assault on U.S. jobs. But U.S. employment would not rise if Japan were to buy more goods from the U.S. Chairman Alan Greenspan of the Federal Reserve Board recently announced that the Fed would raise interest rates to ward off inflation. In other words, the economy was picking up enough speed that the Fed decided to dampen domestic spending. If the Japanese would spend more for American goods, Mr. Greenspan would tighten further. The important point is that U.S. employment rates are set by decisions in the U.S., not Japan, and Mr. Clinton's alarms are false.
True, specific U.S. industries -- some of which are highly profitable, like computer software, insurance and medical equipment -- are hurt by Japanese barriers. But opening up every Japanese market in sight would not add much to the $6 trillion U.S. economy.
If invoking a strategy that could trigger tit-for-tat sanctions pushes the Japanese to make further concessions or heads off even worse legislation in Congress, the strategy could be judged a political success. But if Mr. Clinton actually triggers a trade war or destabilizes the Hosokawa Government, the price could turn out to be very steep indeed.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
JUDY HENDREN MELLO has been named the president and chief executive of World Learning, formerly known as the Experiment in International Living.
The organization sponsors exchange programs for students and conducts higher education courses in international studies, management training and languages, as well as international development programs. 
 For Ms. Mello, who is 50, the appointment marks a change in career from finance and banking to the promotion of international citizen exchanges and cooperation.
Now a managing director of Cambridge International Partners, an investment banking firm, she is a former president of the First Women's Bank in New York and has held executive positions with Lehman Brothers, American Express, Marine Midland Bank and Citibank.
"I have been a banker in many different forms," she said yesterday. "Now, my challenge is to take those skills and think about the responsibility this organization has to help bring people and cultures together."
Based in Brattleboro, Vt., World Learning has an operating budget of $60 million and administers more than 260 programs in 70 countries. NADINE BROZAN

HEADLINE: Russia's Far East: Rainbown and Bears

BYLINE: By Celestine Bohlen; Celestine Bohlen is chief of the Moscow bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
WE NEVER DID SEE A bear in the wilds of central Kamchatka, although Zhenya Vlasov did his best to find us one.
During a bright spell in the brief, sub-Arctic fall on Russia's easternmost peninsula, as the birch trees were turning yellow and the blueberry bushes a burnished red, Zhenya, a small, bowlegged hunter and guide at our wilderness hunting camp, took us down to the river where bears come in the evenings to fish for salmon and showed us where they had trampled the brush underfoot. The weather was mild and sunny, not unusual for September, which is considered Kamchatka's best month since the air is free of the summer's mosquitoes and the winter's frosts. Taking the lead with a walking stick that was almost as big as he was, Zhenya marched us briskly -- as briskly as thigh-high rubber boots would allow -- through a field of man-sized grasses, poking at bear footprints and droppings, and pointing out their paw marks on several giant anthills. 
 He even told us what to do if a 10-foot bear should happen to rise up before us. "Never look a bear in the eyes," said Zhenya, who wears glasses. "And don't move. Just yell Russian swearwords at it."
In the far northeast region of Russia, between the Sea of Okhotsk and the Bering Sea, Kamchatka was for many decades closed to foreigners because of its strategic position as a border region and its secret military installations. But after it was opened up in 1991, foreigners arrived in droves -- hunters, fishermen, trekkers and adventure-seekers -- to discover a vast region of volcanoes, geysers and unpopulated wilderness, roughly the size of Colorado and with a population of about half a million people. Scores of small businesses opened, offering guides and helicopters to take visitors to the remote fishing and hunting camps scattered around the peninsula, from the treeless tundra of the far north to the more bucolic forests of the area around Milkovo, a town and a regional center about 125 miles northwest of Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky, the peninsula's main city. Our camp was about 93 miles -- 45 minutes by helicopter -- out of Milkovo, beneath the snow-capped Tumroki volcano, but we, two peaceful interlopers who were there just to look, saw neither bear, nor mountain sheep, nor moose -- although the region was obviously teeming with them. Our fellow campers, a German father and son, had better luck: after a week of hunting, they had bagged three bears, two snow rams and two moose -- a phenomenal catch by both local and world standards.
"I have been hunting for 30 years, all over the world -- Africa, Alaska, Europe," said Fredy Lemke, who owns a trucking firm in Ottersberg, Germany, outside Bremen, during an emotional toast over a dinner table laden with local fare -- smoked salmon, pickled ferns, fresh salmon roe, blueberry jam and moose patties, "but this year, this Kamchatka, this is the best."
FOR THE adventurous few who come as tourists rather than as sportsmen, Kamchatka offers different attractions. At the hunting camp near the Tumroki camp, we went berry picking, filling a large bucket with local blueberries and a variety known as zhimalost -- similar to blueberries and, as every Kamchatka native will tell you, so jampacked with vitamins that jars were regularly shipped to Soviet cosmonauts to keep them going in outer space.
With luck, hikers -- traveling by foot, by horse and, in the winter, by dog sled or skis -- can catch a glimpse of Kamchatka's wildlife, particularly in the Kronotsky Nature Reserve, a 2.5-million-acre expanse northeast of Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky, a region of craters and volcanoes that was first protected from encroachment by humans in 1802, when it was declared off limits to sable hunters. During spawning season, salmon of several varieties can be seen clearly in its rivers, twisting ever more slowly as they die a slow death by decomposition.
The centerpiece of the Kronotsky Reserve is the Valley of the Geysers, a bubbling, burbling cauldron of hot springs that, in terms of world-class geysers, ranks second only to Yellowstone Park. The valley is particularly beautiful in the fall, when the trees on the hillside are turning colors and the geysers merrily spout steam and jets of water into the crisp air, each one following its own secret rhythm.
These geysers, along with Kamchatka's formidable array of volcanoes -- many of them still active -- are what anchor this peninsula at the end of the Pacific Ocean's Ring of Fire and cast a silent and somehow primordial threat over its vast, empty spaces.
Mindful of the damage caused by eager backpacking tourists tromping across the valley's delicate growth of moss, grasses and ferns (not to mention the danger of scorching by boiling water), the managers at Kronotsky recently had wooden walkways and stairs built. A few benches have been positioned in key places, but otherwise the site remains much as it was when it was first discovered in 1941, free of the kind of commercialization that Russian conservationists abhor.
Still, tourism to the Valley of the Geysers has increased in the last two years, now that both foreigners and Russians are free to travel there. Last summer, there were about 2,000 visitors. Most of them came by helicopter, leaving from the Kronotsky Reserve's heliport at Yelizovo, outside of Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky.
The six-hour trip includes an aerial tour of neighboring volcanoes and water-filled craters, and lunch in a hunters' cabin by a river. The cost of the helicopter trip for a group of 20 people is between $2,000 and $2,500.
Not that all the wrinkles of Kamchatka's infant tourist industry have been ironed out. Far from it. The biggest problem remains getting there -- a journey that, except for charter flights from Alaska, is dependent on Aeroflot, the old Soviet airline that becomes increasingly less reliable and more uncomfortable. The direct nine-hour flight from Moscow (roughly the equivalent of a Moscow-New York flight), with a nine-hour time difference, means you arrive at the same time you leave. But when fuel supplies run low, or bad weather kicks in, flights can back up for days on end, creating havoc with finely tuned schedules.
Given its selection of poor hotels and indifferent restaurants, Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky has little to offer the passer-through besides one sorry street of prerevolutionary wooden houses and a view of the Koriaksky and Avachinsky volcanoes (11,338 and 9,025 feet high, respectively) that loom like guardians at the city's back. There is also a view over the bay -- taking in a steep hill to the left and a row of trees along the waterfront -- that hints at a scene from a Chinese scroll painting. In the distance, off in another direction, are the Three Brothers rocks that have become the city's symbol. But the square facing the water is dominated by a giant statue of Lenin, with ugly modern office buildings behind him.
In these conditions, any little glimmer of originality goes a long way. By the side of the new road leading out of the city to the airport, there is an open-air restaurant run by a family from the southern Caucasian republic of Azerbaijan. Fresh fruits and vegetables, chicken pieces roasted on a spit, cold beer served at tables next to a running brook -- for the traveler grown weary of dark restaurants reverberating to the sounds of bad rock-and-roll, this is more than relief, it is a victory.
Getting around Kamchatka is also difficult. The few roads are generally terrible, ground up by heavy trucks and a grueling climate. Helicopters, small airplanes and, along the sparsely populated coast, boats are the main means of transportation; at $500 an hour, helicopter travel has virtually reached world prices -- a factor that has dampened the travel business here somewhat. Rented cars are also available through local firms; it cost us $200 to get a driver to take us from Petropavlovsk to Milkovo, an exorbitant rate by local standards, but it beat spending extra hours at the local airport waiting for helicopters that are trying to do several jobs -- ferry fish, cart food and taxi local residents -- at once.
As always in Russia, logistics here are a problem, made worse by the fact that fuel and other supplies have to be shipped to the peninsula either by sea or by air (there are no road or rail links to the mainland). We met a German hunter, stranded at the Milkovo airport, who had been taken on a 22-mile trek from one hunting camp to another for reasons he never did understand since he and his guide had no common language. "In Alaska, all this would have worked perfectly," he said, putting a brave face on his predicament. "But then it would not have been so adventurous."
Still, visitors keep coming, even as local residents -- many of whom were first lured here by the high wages and generous benefits offered by the Soviet regime -- leave, driven from this distant outpost by a formidable climate and a foundering economy. But for true patriots, the loss is not great. "Less people, more oxygen," was the cheery analysis of Olya, the cook at the Tumroki hunting camp and a descendant of a local hunting dynasty.
The camp and the area around it belong to the Milkovo Gospromkhoz, a Soviet-era state company that manages a 104,200-square-mile swath of territory in central Kamchatka and all that takes place on it, from berry picking to sable trapping, from hunting and fishing to wildlife management. Hunting season comes twice a year, in the spring from mid-April through May (bears only) and in the fall, from the end of August to the end of October. The hunting is controlled, although there are different rules and prices for locals and for foreigners. Generally, the going rate is between $4,000 and $6,000 for a large trophy (bear, moose or mountain sheep), which covers all expenses, including the helicopter, guide, license, room and board. Tatiana N. Girenko, the Gospromkhoz's fierce, old-style Communist manager, said that last year hunters were issued licenses to kill 40 bears on the Milkovo Gospromkhoz territory, of which only six went to foreigners.
With a local bear population of about 350, these figures are considered well within reason, but they do not reflect the rise in poaching, brought about by the hard economic times and general lawlessness that are principal features of post-Communist Russia -- and certainly the main subjects of conversation. Mrs. Girenko said that 10 bear carcasses were found on the Milkovo territory last year, the work of poachers who kill bears not only for their skins but also for their gall bladders, which sell for $3 a gram in markets in China and Korea where they are highly valued for their medicinal properties. Local fishermen describe how poachers move in on spawning salmon at night, with flashlights, and scoop up fresh roe -- or red caviar -- by the bucketful. Visitors interested in fishing now have to go deep into the wilderness since the rivers around Petropavlovsk have been heavily depleted. According to local guides, a fisherman can catch about 30 salmon a day, or 15 to 20 rainbow: the size of king salmon averages 22 to 44 pounds, although one local fisherman described seeing one that weighed 132 pounds.
Most of Kamchatka's residents are hunters, full time or part time. In the winter -- a season that everyone admits lasts almost eight months a year -- there is little else to do in places like Milkovo, a small town of 16,000 people first settled by Russians 250 years ago. Zhenya Vlasov is a member of one of Milkovo's most notable families, descendants of a Massachusetts fur trader who came there in the late 19th century. Yet for all his local connections, he is still waiting for a coveted "ugodyia," a six-square-mile lot on which he would have exclusive hunting and trapping rights.
For several years now, Zhenya's extended family, together with the Milkovo Gospromkhoz, has been trying to make a go of the cooperatively held hunting camp, on the site of a famous hot springs beneath Tumroki, a perfect triangle of a volcano that by mid-fall already has a band of snow at its neck. On a windy days, the snow drifts into a fine, feathery mist.
A few years ago, before the economic changes that brought inflation to Russia, the hot springs were a popular attraction for local residents who came to cure a whole list of ailments, starting with aching bones and ending with eczema. But today, with the cost of helicopter flights skyrocketing, local cure-seekers have been displaced by rich tourists, mostly foreigners who come for the hunting, not for their health. "Foreign tourists don't have ailments," Zhenya noted dryly.
WITH ITS half-dozen, two-story wood cabins fitted out with fireplaces and bunk beds, its outhouses and a full-fledged kitchen, the camp at Tumroki was dubbed the Hilton of Kamchatka by Fredy Lemke's son, Manfred, who, on earlier trips to the area, had weathered far more primitive facilities.
But the hot springs provide the camp's most luxurious touch, with three pools set into the hillside offering water temperatures that range from warm to too hot to bear for more than five minutes at a time. In the bathing hut, weary trekkers and hunters can hang up their clothes, and, in the morning, sit and watch a thick mist of steam roll off the trickling stream into the surrounding forest.
There is a kind of traveler who will go around the world to find spots like this, and Charlotte Mitchell, a 50-year-old Hong Kong resident, is one. To the delight of her numerous Russian hosts, she made her way across eastern Siberia to Kamchatka, traveling by foot, train, ferry and boat through regions that most people consider impassable.
Having reached the Tumroki camp after a long hike through the fields and valleys of Kamchatka's wilderness, she sat in the hot springs to give her feet a well-deserved treat. "This," she said, beaming through the steam, "is excellent."
 
EXPLORING A WILDERNESS
Two companies, based in the United States, that offer both customized and group tours of the Kamchatka Peninsula are:
EAST-WEST DISCOVERY, Post Office Box 69P, Volcano, Hawaii 96785 (800-985-8552), specializes in travel to the Russian Far East. Organized tours include a two-week Kamchatka Adventure Expedition, with hiking, rafting, berry gathering, volcano exploration, wildlife observation and fishing for salmon and trout in some of the least visited regions of the peninsula (more than 600 miles are covered by helicopter). Sites visited include Petropavlovsk and the Kronotsky Nature Reserve, with about 10 days in field camps in wilderness areas. Groups are limited to 12 people; the cost is $2,795 a person and includes local transportation, meals, guides and lodging. Among the scheduled departure dates are July 19 and July 27, with other dates to be announced. The company can arrange discounted air transportation between North America and Kamchatka via Anchorage.
East-West Discovery also offers a two-week birding trip, led by American and Russian ornithologists, that visits the Othotsk coastal region, the Kamchatka River Valley and the island of Starichkov. Most nights will be spent camping in large expedition tents. The group size is limited to 10; the cost is $4,995 a person, and includes all land expenses and local transportation. The scheduled departure date is May 24, with a second date to be arranged.
KAMCHATKA FISHING ADVENTURES, 2825 90th Street Southeast, Everett, Wash. 98208 (206-337-0326), has more than a dozen nine-day fishing trips scheduled for this spring, summer and fall. Groups, which average about 15 people, are housed in the Cedar Lodge on the Zhupanova River, north of Petropavlovsk; all rooms have private bathrooms with flush toilets and showers. The price, $5,000 a person, includes meals, lodging and local transportation. The company can help arrange trans-Pacific fares.
Kamchatka Fishing Adventures also arranges hunting packages in the spring and fall. The groups -- usually four to eight people -- are based in the lodge on the Zhupanova and taken by helicopter to field camps near the hunt sites. These trips can be combined with the fishing packages; the price varies with number of people and length of trip.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY, MARCH 6, 1994;
Cold War Spending

 BODY:
When the cold war was in full swing, it made Americans spend as though there were no tomorrow -- precisely because they believed there wouldn't be one.
At least that's the theory of Joel Slemrod, an economics professor at the University of Michigan who has been following the relationship between Americans' fears of nuclear war and the saving rate. Slemrod compared private savings to the "Doomsday Clock" in the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, a measure of the editors' sense of the likelihood of nuclear war. 
 His comparison suggests that the greater the fear, the lower the savings. Moreover, throughout the cold war, Slemrod says, polls showed that more than half of Americans believed that nuclear conflict was likely within 10 years. "How could it not affect their planning?" Slemrod asks. In the same period, only about a quarter of Japanese thought nuclear war was likely in the next 10 years. Their saving rate was (and is) far higher.
Savings have not quite boomed since the end of the cold war, however. The rate bottomed at 4 percent in 1989 and inched up to 4.8 percent in 1992. But these were recessionary years, when savings usually decline. Proof is yet to come.
If Slemrod is right, the Reagan economic revolution -- cutting taxes so that the rich would have more to save and (theoretically) invest -- was irrelevant. Instead, according to this reasoning, Reagan's military build-up and Evil Empire rhetoric worked against his economic program by discouraging saving. Star Wars, meanwhile, by lessening the perceived danger of nuclear holocaust, acted as a clever ploy -- not to save Americans but to get Americans to save.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Denver's New Airport: A Boon or a Bane?

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
WHATEVER else can be said of the behind-schedule, over-budget, far-flung new Denver International Airport, it will surely make life easier for some travelers: those coming to Colorado to inspect cattle on the scrubgrass Plains, for example. For travelers headed west to the ski slopes, on the other hand, the $3.2 billion airport will not be so convenient.
DIA, the first major airport to be built from scratch in the United States since Dallas-Fort Worth 20 years ago, is set to open May 15, eight months late and more than $1 billion over initial cost estimates.
The new facility is situated 23 miles northeast of downtown Denver, about 20 miles farther northeast of the city than Stapleton Airport. It will mean perhaps an extra 30 to 40 minutes for the drive to Vail and Aspen. The cab fare to downtown Denver will more than double, to at least $30. 
 But officials here say the 53-square-mile airport, about six times bigger than Stapleton, will sharply reduce delays. The new airport can safely handle three simultaneous landings, or 99 arrivals an hour, in bad weather, compared with a maximum of 25 an hour at Stapleton. And a high-tech luggage conveyor is said to be able to get bags to the claim area before passengers get there.
The main terminal is topped by white Fiberglas spires, meant to look like snow-capped Rocky Mountain peaks. Its interior is adorned with $7.5 million in art work. And its vast windows permit so much natural light that architects say artificial lighting will be unnecessary during the day. There are 15,000 covered parking spots for vehicles and computer-operated subway trains that deliver passengers near the gates.
The project was approved in 1987 under the leadership of Federico F. Pena, who was then the Mayor of Denver and is now the United States Secretary of Transportation. The cost overruns have been ascribed to inflation and demands by the two airline hubs, United and Continental.
Mr. Pena and other backers of the airport say the gleaming facility will promote business and tourism in Colorado. But some travel experts, like Bill Siegel, the president of a tourism research organization based in Toronto, have expressed doubts. Among factors that motivate travelers to choose a destination, he said, "I've never heard of airport facilities even being mentioned." Mr. Siegel said that nearly 20 million tourists came to Colorado in 1992, and about 37 percent were air travelers, "an extraordinarily high percentage."
He said he expected the new airport's greater distance from the slopes to provoke some grumbling. "Skiers are paying a lot of money for one thing -- to get up to the mountains as fast as they can."
Shuttle services to ski resorts recently increased prices to reflect the longer distances. A ride to Vail now costs $44, compared with $35. And the shuttle, which departed from Stapleton every half-hour, now leaves every hour.
City officials say Stapleton, hemmed in by residential development, had no room to expand. The 64-year-old facility, which is up for sale or rent, will not function as an airport.
The most recent delay in the opening of the airport, announced Feb. 28, was required to fix the high-tech baggage system, security doors and TV screens showing flight information.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 6, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Travel Advisory column on page 3 of the Travel sec tion today, about the new Denver International Airport, misstates its opening date in some copies. After the section went to press, the opening was rescheduled to May 15, from March 9.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Short Films Have Their (Brief) Moment in the Sun

BYLINE: By ANN HORNADAY 

 BODY:
THOSE WHO participate in office Oscar pools will find themselves stumped once again when it comes to the short categories. Let's see, for best short feature will it be "Black Rider," about an elderly Jewish woman and a young black man on a bus in Berlin? Or maybe "Down on the Waterfront," a send-up of "On the Waterfront," with Ed Asner. And for best short documentary, how about "Chicks in White Satin," about a lesbian wedding? Or maybe "Defending Our Lives," about battered women who kill their attackers.
But for the first time this year, Oscar kibitzers will have a chance to improve their odds by actually seeing some of the short films. A two-week series called "Oscar Shorts 1993," which includes most of this year's nominees for short live-action movies and documentary films, opened on Friday at Cinema Village. Short films can range in length from 3 to 30 minutes and cost as little as $1,500 to make. 
 Although animated shorts, another Academy Award category, already have a dedicated following, live-action shorts have had trouble finding audiences, who tend to think of them as intimidating -- or worse, boring -- technical exercises. In fact, they can be as sophisticated and satisfying as their feature-length siblings, though their demanding and economical form makes them comparable to haiku. Often they provide first glimpses of promising talent.
"Short films are how people learn to make movies," says the critic Roger Ebert, who will be the host of a program of short films on the Bravo cable channel. "It was Martin Scorsese's first film" -- a short called "Who's That Knocking at My Door?" -- "that announced unmistakably that he was a director."
"Oscar Shorts 1993," with six films, may be part of what many are calling a rejuvenation of interest in the form. Shorts were recently given a boost when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences voted to reinstate the embattled category, which it had announced in 1992 it would eliminate. After the original announcement, letters poured in from Mr. Scorsese, George Lucas, Francis Ford Coppola, Steven Spielberg and other important directors who got their starts making short films.
There are other signs of a renewal. This year, the Sundance Film Festival gave its first special recognition award for a short film. The movie, "Family Remains," directed by Tamara Jenkins, will be shown at the New Directors/New Films series in New York on April 1 and 2 along with 12 other short films. This spring for the first time Andalusian Pictures is negotiating to bring a festival of 20 short films to New York.
Miramax has bought theatrical distribution rights to "The Perfect Woman," a nine-minute parody of male-female relations by the actress Illeana Douglas, and will pair it with "Camilla," a feature film with Bridget Fonda to be released this summer. Indeed, actors who want to make their first foray into directing (and which actors do not?) increasingly turn to short films. Recent converts include Daryl Hannah, Rob Morrow, Ethan Hawke, Matthew Modine and Peter Weller.
On Oscar night, March 21, the Bravo cable network will have commentary by Mr. Ebert during the ceremony's commercial breaks and in between will air 15 shorts, including "The Perfect Woman" and works by the English directors Mike Leigh and Kenneth Branagh, Mr. Morrow and the actor Steve Buscemi.
THE SHOWING OF SHORT films in movie theaters has been in slow decline since the late 1940's, when theaters became interested in a faster turnover of audiences. Although short films are still sometimes shown at art houses, most begin and end their lives on the small screen. Cable networks have been particularly fond of short movies. Showtime uses them on its "Directed By" and "30 Minute Movie" series, and "Saturday Night Live" often uses short films.
While such visibility is a blessing for film makers, it is also a curse. "Exhibitors are resistant to short films because they've been on TV already," says Bingham Ray, the co-executive manager of October Films, which released a package of three short films called "Two Mikes Don't Make a Wright." "The result is that they're only seen as calling cards at studios, or at festivals."
Some purists at the motion picture academy think that short films' dalliance with television places them outside Oscar contention. "In the days when I was an assistant director at MGM, the academy was the academy," says Howard Koch, who was the organization's president for three years and has produced eight Oscar telecasts. In the past, Mr. Koch advocated the elimination of shorts. "The people who made short subjects were the studios; they were part of us. They were some of the greatest directors-to-be. We worked together, we talked together, we had lunch together."
Of the new short-subject film makers, Mr. Koch says: "We don't know them. We never saw them before. We never see them after. They just make long speeches on the Academy Awards."
But Mr. Koch joined the unanimous vote by the academy's board of governors in January to restore the awards for short films. "I guess as time went on I was brainwashed more and more," he explains. "When the vote came, I was reluctant. But I figured: what the heck. If a lot of the members felt it was important to give these people life, even though they're strangers, I must have been wrong."
The controversy suggests that the stakes are high for Oscar winners in the short-form category. A quick glance at past winners fails to reveal many famous directors' names. But even if being nominated doesn't guarantee fame, Dean Parisot, a winner in 1988 for "The Appointments of Dennis Jennings," says the Oscar "throws you into a temporary limelight, and makes you meet of the week." Mr. Parisot has since worked primarily in television, most recently directing episodes of "Northern Exposure."
Jana Sue Memel, whose production company, Chanticleer Films, produces short films for Showtime, has won two Oscars (for "Ray's Male Heterosexual Dance Hall" and "Session Man"). Chanticleer also produced one of this year's nominees, "Partners," directed by Mr. Weller. (The other nominees for live-action short -- in addition to "Black Rider" and "Down on the Waterfront" -- are Susan Seidelman's "Dutch Master" and a French film called, in English, "The Screw." Short documentary nominations -- there are only three -- include "Blood Ties: The Life and Work of Sally Mann.")
"It's still Christmas," Ms. Memel says of the recognition a nomination gives. "It allows us to secure future funding for short films, which is next to impossible."
According to a report commissioned by the academy, short films reach a significant audience at giant-screen IMAX theaters, theme parks and other venues. "They account for literally hundreds of millions of dollars for thousands of film makers, production companies and distributors," says Saul Bass, an academy governor who won an Oscar in 1968 for his short documentary "Why Man Creates." "The budgets on some of these IMAX films are up to $7 million or $8 million or more, so we're not dealing with penny-ante stuff."
Most makers of short films, however, are not in it for the money. Usually, short films are intended as calling cards to drop at major studios. Andrew Fleming had three short student films under his belt when he graduated from New York University's film school in 1985. It turned out that the cheapest one, the three-minute "Prisoner," got the most attention.
"It was the most visually dynamic," says the director, whose second feature-length film, "Threesome," will be released next month. "And it was short. It's a truism, but people in this business have short attention spans. They don't want to sit through a 25-minute, serious, dramatic film."
When Gale Anne Hurd, who produced "Aliens" and "The Terminator," saw "Prisoner," Mr. Fleming says, "she said, 'Let's do a film.' Less than a year later I was shooting a horror film called 'Bad Dreams' for Fox."
Relegating short films to the status of springboard rankles those directors who are dedicated to the form for its artistic and technical demands. "There's a whole world of film makers who are living out their lives in the short film area out of choice, not necessity," says Mr. Bass. "They love the form, they're challenged by it, and they're content to wrestle with it for the rest of their lives."
Now, if only there were an audience for them.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Summer Glories Passed Quickly, But Oh, the Fall

BYLINE: By WILL CRUTCHFIELD 

 BODY:
TO HEAR HER IS TO LOVE her: if anyone feels otherwise about Victoria de los Angeles, I don't want to know. It has to be counted among life's startling and unexpected consolations that each of the last 20 or so years, which might have done so, has not brought the retirement of this most inexhaustibly illustrative of singers. Now she is back again to celebrate her 70th birthday (it took place on Nov. 1) and the 50th anniversary of her professional debut. Neither is a milestone customarily celebrated in public by vocalists, least of all sopranos.
The debut was in Barcelona as Mozart's Countess. At the end of the 1940's, the operatic world -- discovering in two or three seasons a decade's worth of great singers queued up during the war years -- responded rapidly to this generous voice of cream and port, and Miss de los Angeles had debuts in rapid succession at the Metropolitan, Covent Garden, La Scala, Rome, Vienna. Even then she had the confidence to insist that she first be presented in recital in each city; this guaranteed a friendly core audience in the opera house, because the recitals were at such a level of expertise, novelty, spontaneous communication and indefinable stylistic savoir-faire that the singer could initiate a houseful of devoted admirers at each one. 
 In fact the glory days of the Spanish soprano's operatic career were rather short: the strong high notes did not last, and by 1960 she was having uncomfortable moments in many scores. She continued as a beloved concert artist, with ever more economical use of reduced vocal means. For a while it seemed that her last great New York evenings might have been the Hunter College recitals with Alicia de Larrocha in 1973.
But early in the 80's a kind of Indian summer began. And went on. The valedictory feel of her Spanish program at Avery Fisher Hall in 1985 allowed most in the delirious audience to assume it was her farewell. A couple of seasons later, however, she was back at the 92d Street Y with her beloved Schubert and Faure, and a couple of years later still she visited the old City Center for an improbable weeklong stint in a song-and-dance zarzuela revue. Two years after that she gave a song recital at the Manhattan School of Music that was practically the highlight of the New York season, and now she is still manifestly going strong. Reviews of her 70th-birthday tour to date -- from Europe, Australia and New Zealand, Chicago -- speak of enchanting expression, delightful timbre, ovations and flowers.
One might as well ask the obvious question: If her voice faltered so long ago (and to tell the truth, hints of difficulty could be heard even earlier), what is she doing making tours and new records and garnering accolades?
This voice, like the artist, is a special case. It bears the relation to its youthful self of an expertly pressed flower to a dewy bloom. If her tone was a juicy orange (it always had a citron tang to it), it is now an exquisitely aromatic confection of the preserved rind. Or if it was a bold Goya full of contrasts and rich textures, it is now the precise and economical sketch that shows intent, drama, direction, essence. If it was marjoram, now it's pepper.
A friend of one of her accompanists watched her rehearse a few years ago and described the way she conserved her voice. Only before the public did she let it out at all; the pianist was guided in preparation by the click and sibilance of her consonants -- the percussion section, so to speak. If the voice used to be a lush Romantic symphony orchestra, perhaps now it is the crackling ensemble of Stravinsky's "Histoire du Soldat": tangy winds, percussion, a single wiry violin, rhythmic speech.
What it is not is a failed effort to be something else. She does not essay the soaring phrases of her old Puccini heroines; does not struggle with herself or subject us to agonies of disappointment or grim insistence as so many singers have done. If certain notes -- or many notes -- falter or run dry, they never throw her off her expressive course. And if it isn't going to bother her, why should it bother us?
Let me not give the wrong impression: if I have a vivid impression myself of Miss de los Angeles's early triumphs, it is not because I was around to hear them. The world's most venerable and judicious record company -- its name became EMI at around this time -- saw her worth from the start and documented her progress lavishly.
Miss de los Angeles's recording career falls into three periods, with a delicious series of 78-r.p.m. songs and arias in the late 40's as a prelude. The 50's were dominated by opera: Gounod's Marguerite, Rossini's Rosina and Puccini's Cio-Cio-San twice each; roles of Falla, Debussy, Verdi, Massenet and Bizet; a luxurious recital of Italian arias.
The recital is a knockout, with full-throated, spirited renditions of "Ernani, involami," "Ebben, ne andro lontana" and the final rondo of Cenerentola among others. But in the complete operas, often enough a little phrase from here or there will stand out in memory just as prominently as the great solos. When Mimi sings about Rodolfo's having bought her the little bonnet, and a moment later (to the same music) says that being in love is sweeter than honey, Miss de los Angeles tastes the honey, as Mimi does, in the ordinary exchanges that love makes so sweet. Or when Antonia asks Hoffmann to come with her to the piano -- "Viens-la, comme autrefois" -- the two lines say everything about nostalgia, loss, poignant unawareness of loss, music as lovers' language.
New roles were added in the next decade (Antonia, Charlotte, Suor Angelica, Lauretta), but the great legacy of the 60's and early 70's was a series of 14 solo albums for EMI/Angel, covering the heart of Miss de los Angeles's concert repertory in French, Spanish and German, with excursions to early music, zarzuela arias and Canteloube's "Songs of the Auvergne."
It is faintly maddening that EMI has just reissued so many of these scrambled and remixed into a four-CD set, "The Fabulous Victoria de los Angeles" -- not because there is anything unsatisfying about it but because so many items from the original albums are now on the cutting-room floor. Eventually we'll need a deluxe de los Angeles "Edition" that gives them all in their original sequences. But the new set, along with the two "Great Recordings of the Century" CD's of her early records and a sampling of her late ones, will give the collector a rounded portrait.
THE "INDIAN SUMMER" period has found Miss de los Angeles a free agent after a quarter-century with EMI. There was an LP of songs, over-reverberantly recorded but containing some beauties, on CBS, then another on Polydor. Hunt for this in the second-hand shops: it has a Japanese song like a tart cherry, enchanting folk songs from Portugal and Italy, and a haunting, uninhibitedly Hispanic rendition of "Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child."
On CD there have been Catalan folk songs on Collins and two kaleidoscopic live recitals: an evening at London's Wigmore Hall from 1990 on Collins and a Tokyo concert from 1986 on Camerata. In Tokyo she sang Schumann's late song cycle on Mary Stuart with piercing directness and simplicity, followed by Chopin songs in Polish with all the verve and stomp of the mazurka. At Wigmore there were brilliantly pointed, neat limnings of old Italian airs one has heard a thousand times since last listening, as Miss de los Angeles makes one do.
And perhaps best of all is the 1989 jubilee recital in Barcelona on Video Arts International, for adding visual presence to the succession of grace, gravity, flirtatiousness, sorrow, reflection, enigma and abandon that make up a de los Angeles evening. The gradual realization as one song follows another -- as one world of mood is created, inhabited and bid farewell -- is that in its present unusual form, this voice may well last as long as the singer has health and energy. That is a real consolation: not just that we can celebrate her 50th anniversary, but that we can reasonably suppose it might not be a farewell.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Does 'Germinal' Speak Across a Century?

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
IT WAS A MEASURE OF EMILE Zola's political influence that coal miners from northern France joined his funeral procession in Paris on Oct. 5, 1902, shouting "Germinal! Germinal!" in tribute to his support for their fight against exploitation. They didn't seem to mind that in his novel "Germinal" the miners went down to defeat when their strike was crushed by gendarmes. What mattered was that Zola sympathized with their struggle. For the France of the day, that alone was an act of subversion.
Almost a century later, the director Claude Berri has brought his movie version of Zola's classic to a very different France. All but a handful of coal mines are now closed, factories are automated, a welfare state is in place and the labor movement, having come full circle, is again weak. In fact, when the movie was released in France last fall, the cries of "Germinal! Germinal!" came from businessmen in Lille, complaining that Mr. Berri had muddied the image of the "new" high-tech northern France of today. 
 The 59-year-old director refused to apologize. He insisted that the film, which opens in New York on Friday after achieving great popularity in France, was not intended as a political statement. But he said he hoped it would at least give cause for reflection, not only about the grim working conditions that still exist in much of the third world but also about the social crisis that has brought a surge of unemployment, homelessness and strikes to France today.
"I set out to make a film about a great work of literature," Mr. Berri explained, "but when I now see French fishermen protesting angrily, they are like the movement in 'Germinal.' "
His reasons for making the film, though, were far more personal. Looking for a new subject after completing his last movie, "Uranus," in 1990, he picked up "Germinal" almost by accident. "Like many people, I thought I had read it, but I had not," he recalled in an interview in his production office here.
"I found it was the book I was waiting for at this stage of my life. The story touched my childhood, my roots, because I am the son of a worker who voted Communist and was fully conscious of the injustices that he suffered." He dedicated the movie not to the workers of the world but to his late father.
In adapting the 1885 novel to the screen, Mr. Berri and his sister, Arlette Langmann, have remained faithful to Zola. "If Zola were alive today, he would be a great screenplay writer," Mr. Berri said. So, like the author, the director traveled to northern France to make his "Germinal." And while Zola witnessed a strike at the Anzin mine in 1884, Mr. Berri shot his film in old mining villages in the same area, adding authenticity by using retired coal miners among his 500 extras. The director even aped the novel's epic dimension -- the movie took seven months to shoot, it runs 2 hours 38 minutes and, costing $30 million, it is the most expensive film ever made in France.
The story tells of an outsider, Etienne Lantier (played by the French protest singer Renaud), who arrives in the mining town of Montsou in the 1860's. Hired to replace a miner who has died, Lantier is given a bed in the overcrowded cottage of Maheu (Gerard Depardieu) and his wife, Maheude (Miou-Miou). Soon indignant over the poverty of the miners, the dangers of the pit face and the good life of the mine owners, Lantier begins stirring the protest movement that eventually leads to the strike. Simultaneously, Lantier tries to win over Maheu's daughter, Catherine (Judith Henry), who "belongs" to another miner. Eventually, the two plots come together in tragedy.
FOR ALL THE HUNGER, CHILD labor, accidents and violence documented in the film, however, Mr. Berri said he was eager to show the dignity of the miners. And while he had his furrier father in mind, several cast members were similarly motivated: Renaud comes from a family of miners, Mr. Depardieu sought the role of Maheu because his father was a metalworker, and Miou-Miou's mother sold vegetables in a market. "We all had reasons that went back to our childhood," the director said. "I identify with Etienne Lantier," he said. "I could have been a revolutionary, but my life decided otherwise."
Best known abroad for his 1986 films, "Jean de Florette" and "Manon of the Spring," Mr. Berri has lived, by his own admission, in "a world of money and success." He is not only an established film director and producer, he is also the owner of an impressive modern art collection. Did his "Germinal" make him feel guilty that he was not poor, not a worker? "Perhaps," he said softly. "Perhaps I would have preferred the life of my father. He had an awareness of injustice that I understand but have not lived."
His nostalgic evocation of a true working class, though, was not uniformly appreciated in France. Released at the same time as Steven Spielberg's "Jurassic Park," Mr. Berri's film was promptly nicknamed "Germinal Park" by Le Figaro's movie critic, Claude Baigneres, who said Zola's work could only appeal to "intellectuals of the Jurassic era." Le Monde's Jacques Siclier was kinder, calling the film "topical, courageous and necessary." But Gerard Lefort of Liberation said Mr. Berri's screenplay "would not have gone beyond the desk of a secretary at Warner Brothers."
The director shrugged off his critics, noting that, with about six million tickets sold so far in France, "Germinal" is already among the top 10 box-office hits in French movie history. "For these critics, if a film draws the public, it's commercial, but if it interests no one, it's a work of art," he said dismissively. "They're stuck in the 1960's. For them, anyone who makes a first film or a boring film is the heir to Truffaut or Godard."
