SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1240 words

HEADLINE: Breathing Easier

BYLINE: By DAN SHAW 

 BODY:
THOUGH the tickets cost $1,000 and the invitation read "black tie," many men at the awards dinner of the Council of Fashion Designers of America at Lincoln Center last month interpreted the dress code liberally, not literally. Tommy Hilfiger wore a cashmere turtleneck under his tuxedo; James Truman, the editor in chief of Details, wore an iridescent shirt without a tie; Stephan Weiss wore a band-collared shirt by his wife, Donna Karan; Andre Balazs, the hotelier, wore a mandarin-collared jacket buttoned up to the neck. James Simpson, the theater director and husband of the actress Sigourney Weaver, wore a vest and open-collared shirt with his dinner jacket.
Calvin Klein didn't wear a tie -- or a shirt. He wore an insouciant white silk scarf under his tuxedo, showing off a lot of skin. 
 Black tie used to mean a dinner jacket and a tie, but no more. These days, ties don't invariably connote sophistication or seriousness, and suits don't necessarily require ties.
Designers like Ms. Karan, Mr. Klein, Giorgio Armani and Dolce & Gabbana are experimenting with four-, five- and six-button suits, which often look more elegant and sophisticated without a tie. The suits are shown on the runway and in stores with band- or mandarin-collar shirts, high-button vests, knitted Henleys and cashmere polos and turtlenecks.
Many fashion-conscious men are choosing these alternatives. "Our tie business has dwindled," said Jon Weiser, the president of the five Charivari boutiques in Manhattan. "We're selling 50 percent fewer ties than three years ago. I guess we are making progress. It's not an oddity to wear a band-collared shirt. With men's wear, there were so many limitations for so long."
Some men are suffering from necktie en nui. "There aren't any ties that interest me now," Mr. Balazs said. "More and more, I'm wearing ties less."
Indeed, the Suit and Tie paradigm is coming into question as corporations restructure and downsize, as the information superhighway alters the concept of the workplace and as men of a younger, more fashion-conscious generation insist on working in comfortable clothes that allow them to express their individuality.
"In a society where a tie is a sign of work, taking off a tie signals that one has control over one's life," said Dr. Stuart Ewen, a sociologist and author of "All Consuming Images: The Politics of Style in Contemporary Culture" (Basic Books, 1988). "What was once a symbol of being a gentleman has become a symbol of being a drone. The term 'suit' has become a euphemism for being boring and noncreative and stuck in a 9-to-5 life."
Nevertheless, the Neckwear Association of America, a trade group based in Manhattan, reports that 132 million ties were sold in this country in 1992, a 10 percent increase from 1991. The association said women buy 65 percent of the ties sold in America, which is one of the reasons Joe Silverberg, co-chairman of the Knot Shop Stores, a 35-store chain, isn't worried about his business. "Women don't send men flowers, and fragrance can be tricky," he said. "A tie is a good gift."
Tie sales are up 22 percent in the last year at Paul Stuart, the Madison Avenue haberdashery. "Men are paying more attention to accessories," said Julie Oddy, the store's spokeswoman. "They are more conservative in the number of suits they buy, so accessories are a way to update their wardrobe."
The Neckwear Association estimates that 20 to 25 percent of the ties bought are "conversational," or novelty, ties, featuring comic-strip characters, pop-culture iconography, scenes from famous paintings. These ties are frequently more vibrant and interesting than the men wearing them. They are often worn on "dress-down days" at major corporations, one day a week, usually Friday, on which employees are permitted to wear casual clothes. These are ties that look better with chambray shirts than with pin stripes.
Marshall Blonsky, who teaches semiotics at New York University and is the author of "American Mythologies" (Oxford University Press, 1992), believes that the deconstruction of the classic postwar business uniform reflects a changing global economy based on telecommunications. "When you start tampering with the suit, it says the whole world is up for grabs and the old ways of doing business are in question," Dr. Blonsky said.
Businessmen are now being offered the same fashion options that the women they work with have. "It's not about wearing ties or not wearing ties," said Ms. Karan, whose first men's collection, in 1991, included a banded-collar tuxedo shirt that was designed not to accommodate a bowtie. "It's all about giving men alternatives."
Some men don't want to make choices about what to wear to the office. Steven Yee, director of development for Children's Television Workshop, contemplated not wearing a tie to work and thought better of it. "I'd have to construct a whole new look, and I don't have the right shirts," he said. "All my shirts go with ties. It's easier for me to wear a traditional shirt and tie. Besides, it's the code here. It's the line of demarcation between the business and creative people."
Tampering with the concept of black tie doesn't interest Alan Levenstein, vice chairman of Bozell Worldwide, the advertising agency. "I think a tuxedo is formal wear and it requires a necktie," he said. "I don't understand why someone wouldn't wear one."
But even a traditionalist like the designer Alan Flusser, who has a custom-order shop at Saks Fifth Avenue, is expanding his notion of appropriateness. The way you can tell "whether a suit has legs," he said, "is if you can wear a T-shirt under it."
Though Mr. Flusser says he doesn't think his Wall Street clients, who pay $1,200 to $2,200 for a bespoke suit, will abandon neckties at the office, he recently made a black silk, fly-front, band-collared tuxedo shirt that is popular with them. Paul Stuart is also making a mandarin-collar formal shirt that doesn't take a tie.
John Bartlett, the up-and-coming men's wear designer, said men shouldn't wear ties with his suits. "If you have a gorgeous white shirt, there's no reason," he said. "A plain white shirt is more formal in a way."
The type of shirt that is worn with a suit but without a tie is not the classic button-down Oxford. "The shirts are not as structured and the collars are not as hard," said Skip Cuddy, a wardrobe consultant at Louis, Boston, where suits sell for $700 to $2,000. "They accept a necktie during the day and can be worn without one at night."
Traditions, of course, die hard. Men who work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, for instance, are, according to its floor manual, "expected to wear: A Dress Shirt, buttoned at the collar, with a tie knotted at the customary place, i.e., snug to the collar." Exchange members are fined $250 for noncompliance; clerks are suspended for three days.
Michael R. Solomon, a professor of marketing at the Rutgers University School of Business, thinks he understands why many professions and organizations still enforce the wearing of ties. "It's a leash," Dr. Solomon said. "It makes you more rigid, circumspect and aware of your behavior.
Even a modernist like Calvin Klein (who designs ties, too) isn't an abolitionist. "I want my accountant, my lawyer and my banker to wear suits and ties at all my business meetings with them," the designer said. "It makes me feel much more secure."

At the Council of Fashion Designers black-tie dinner, Calvin Klein, center, with Sigourney Weaver, wore only a scarf with his tuxedo; Tommy Hilfiger, far left, and James Truman also echewed ties. HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

DANCING THE BAROQUE
 Some of the dances once performed in the courts of Louis XIV and Louis XV will be recreated in the more modest precincts of the United Church-on-the-Green in New Haven on Friday at 8 P.M.
In a presentation by Old Post Road Historic Concerts, Edith Lalonger, a Baroque specialist from France, is the solitary dancer, dressed in the panniered gowns and satin slippers of the period, accompanied by Suzanne Stumpf, playing the traverso; Stephen Marvin on violin; Daniel Ryan on the harpsichord, and David Sinclair on the viola da gamba. 
 Ms. Lalonger will dance a passacaglia to Lully's "Armide," and other courtly dances to the music of Couperin, Hotteterre and Rebel.
The company, formed in 1987, takes its name from the venues in which it usually performs, along Route 1 from New York to Boston. Its programs are always based on historical themes.
Tickets are available at the door for $12, or $6 for students and the elderly. For more information, 617-648-4824.
 
AMERICAN MORES
 The differences between the good old days and the present will be highlighted in a series of discussions about three seminal, turn-of-the-century American literary works, to be presented at the Howard Whittemore Memorial Library in Naugatuck as a Library Centennial Program.
Charlotte Scully, an independent scholar with a special interest in the perceived decline in American moral values, has chosen the three books as a basis for comparing mores at the beginning of the 20th century to those at the end of it.
Today at 2 P.M. the series will open with Edith Wharton's novel "Ethan Frome," exploring the options available then and now to the poverty-stricken, the sick, the dependent and women on their own. That discussion will conclude next Sunday at the same time, and a study of Thornton Wilder's play, "Our Town" will begin, carrying the saga of Grover's Corners, N.H., into the third session on March 20. The final discussion on March 27 at 2 P.M. will be based on a selection of poems from Edgar Lee Masters's "Spoon River" anthology.
The library is located at 243 Church Street and admission is free. For more information, 729-4591.
 
GUIDE TO GARDENING
 The annual Garden Symposium held by the Bartlett Arboretum, a unit of the University of Connecticut in Stamford, is set for Saturday from 9:15 to 3:45 at the university's branch on Scofieldtown Road. Admission is $55 and lunch will be available for $7.
Designed to show home gardeners how to create a garden with its own distinctive style, the day will be filled with workshops led by Elsa Bakalar, David Smith, Maggie Daly and Mary Jo Palmer, experts on assembling complementary plant combinations, putting unusual plants together successfully, garden ornaments and propogating plants for fun and economy. They will demonstrate why herbaceous or woody perennials are best in certain locations, what combinations of plants may be impractical, and offer guidelines on where to place what garden ornaments for maximum effect.
Subsequent programs include a three-session series on redoing a garden with landscaping problems, scheduled for March 16, 23 and 30 from 10 A.M. to noon, at a cost of $50. On March 25 from 10 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. the subject will be French intensive raised-bed vegetable gardening at $20. To register, or for information, 322-6971.
 
WOMEN'S CHOICES
 "Eighteenth Century Women: Wives, Midwives & Spinsters" is the title of a two-part lecture and slide program taking place on Monday at the Fairfield and New Canaan Historical Societies. It focuses on the limited choices open to most women at that time.
Laurel Thatcher Ulrich, an assistant professor of history at the University of New Hampshire, will deliver the lecture from 9:30 to 11:30 A.M. at the Fairfield Society's headquarters, 636 Post Road. Her talk is based on diaries, letters, court records and poetry of women who lived more than 200 years ago.
Dr. Ulrich won a Pulitzer Prize for her 1991 book "A Midwife's Tale," and she received a MacArthur Foundation fellowship, which is awarded to creative people who enhance the human condition.
From 1:15 to 2:15 P.M. the second portion of the program will be held at the New Canaan Historical Society, 13 Oenoke Ridge Road, titled "The Age of Homespun." Slides of the fabrics and domestic items produced by women demonstrate not only their utility but the fact that they provided one of the few outlets for creativity and artistry.
Tours of the Ogden House and Hanford Silliman House in New Canaan on Wednesday and Thursday from 2 to 4 P.M. are included in the fee of $25. A box lunch is available for an extra $10. For reservations and information, 259-1598.
 
KINSOLVING READING
 William Kinsolving will read from some of his books at the Oliver Wolcott Library in Litchfield on Wednesday at 7:30 P.M. Among the selections are excerpts from "The Diplomat's Daughter," published by Doubleday in 1993, and a new novel that is described as a sequel to "Mutiny on the Bounty."
Mr. Kinsolving has acted and directed in the legitimate theater on and off Broadway and served a playwright for the Stratford, Ontario, Shakespeare Company. His other novels include "Born With the Century' and "Bred to Win," both Literary Guild main selections. He has also written a number of television scripts, among them were a four-hour mini-series called "The Brownsville Raid" and "The Gentle Tasaday," a three-hour special.
Admission to the reading is free. The library address is 160 South Street. For more information, 567-8030.
 
ON ARTHUR MILLER'S CONTEXT
 Long Wharf Theater in New Haven has arranged three discussion programs under the heading "Arthur Miller in Context: American Jewish Culture in the 1930's," to be held today and next Sunday following the matinees, and on Friday after the evening performance.
The programs are being presented as an adjunct to the current run through April 3 of Mr. Miller's new play, "Broken Glass," which examines the reactions of a Jewish couple in Brooklyn to the Holocaust unfolding in Germany in 1938.
Today's speaker is Leon Botstein, president of Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, music director of the American Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall, a commentator on National Public Radio and author of "Jews and Modernity," to be pubished soon.
Friday's program will be conducted by Joyce Antler, professor of American Studies at Brandeis University and author of several books on Judaism and women. The final program will unite Ms. Antler, Tom F. Driver and Gerald Weales in a public forum.
Mr. Driver is a professor of theology at Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan, and the author of "Romantic Quest & Modern Query: A History of Modern Theater." Mr. Weales, a professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania, has written several essays and critical tracts on American theater and Arthur Miller. The forum will be moderated by Cyrus Hamlin, professor of comparative literature at Yale.
Long Wharf is located just off I-95 at Exit 46. For information, 787-4282. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Rudin Magic;
Doing Big Business With a 'Mom-and-Pop' Warmth

BYLINE: CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
DAN GRONICH had long known that his Irish Government clients planned to consolidate, and he looked forward to finding them the space they needed. Still, he hadn't guessed how restricted the space search would be.
"The Consul General of Ireland insisted on being in a Rudin building," said Mr. Gronich, the new head of Grubb & Ellis New York. He put the agencies into Rudin Management's 345 Park Avenue, at 52d Street. 
 Robert L. Freedman had more leeway when he was looking for space for Publicis, an advertising agency. In fact, he found them some pretty good bargains. Publicis eschewed them all and moved to Rudin's 1675 Broadway, also on 52d Street. "They paid nearly 8 percent more to be in a Rudin building," said Mr. Freedman, a vice chairman of Williams Real Estate.
What is it about the Rudins?
In a city where brokers, tenants and landlords routinely castigate one another not a soul says a word -- even an off-the-record one -- against Lew, Jack or Bill Rudin. Yes, their 14 office buildings -- and, for that matter, their 22 apartment buildings -- are well-maintained and well-serviced. But so are myriad first-class buildings. Yet getting a tenant to leave a Rudin building is a Herculean task.
William C. Rudin, Lew's son who, at age 38 was just named the company's president, takes this stab at an explanation: "We treat a 1,500-foot tenant the same as we treat a 50,000-foot tenant." Mr. Freedman offers a different size-irrelevancy explanation: "They run Rudin Management like a mom-and-pop business, and that is their genius."
They're clearly doing something smart. Rudin Management's 7.5 million square feet of Manhattan office space is consistently occupied. RElocate, which tracks building vacancies, says that Rudin's eight midtown buildings are about 5 percent vacant; most brokers peg the percentage of empty midtown space at three times that amount.
Even the 35-story 1675 Broadway, which was completed in 1989 -- just in time for the real estate crash -- is almost fully occupied. Apparently, the Rudins were able to lease much of the building before it was half built.
"We wrote a 20-year lease for 200,000 square feet for a building that wasn't built yet," said David W. Levinson, executive managing director at the Edward S. Gordon Company brokerage, who put the law firm Lord Day & Lord in the building. "I could not have made the deal with anyone but the Rudins. They were tough, but they are credible."
The Rudins have not come through the recession unscathed. They have held onto their buildings -- indeed, the family prides itself on never selling anything it builds -- but the value of those buildings and their revenue streams has dropped precipitously.
In October 1990, Forbes Magazine placed the Rudin family wealth at more than $1.5 billion. Two years later, the estimate was $500 million. Last year the Rudins didn't even make it onto the magazine's annual list of the country's 400 richest folks.
MANY Rudin buildings, particularly downtown, are sopping up cash. Rudin Management recently redid the lobby at One Whitehall Street -- and, in fact, just landed The Topps Company, a children's entertainment company, as a tenant in the newly-refurbished building -- and plans a similar overhaul at 110 Wall Street. And 55 Broad Street, the empty 30-story building that lost its anchor tenant when Drexel Burnham Lambert filed for bankruptcy, will probably need millions before it's rentable.
But while occupancy is no more synonymous with profit for the Rudins than for other landlords, they hold onto tenants like pit bulls. Last year, the Discovery Channel, which had outgrown its space at 415 Madison Avenue, a Rudin building on 48th Street, seemed on the verge of moving to 300 Park Avenue, a non-Rudin building on 50th Street.
"The landlord was sure we had reached a deal, but I wasn't," said Mr. Freedman, who negotiated for 300 Park Avenue. "With the Rudins, it's not over till it's over." Indeed, the Rudins came through with a better deal at 641 Lexington Avenue, at 54th Street.
But the Rudins, brokers say, don't always immediately benefit from their deals.
"They keep their buildings full, even if it means they won't make money in the first three years or so of the lease," said Joseph G. Genovesi, managing director of the brokerage D.G. Hart, who just put Emmerling Post Advertising into 415 Madison.
John G. Martinez, head of New York State's newly merged housing finance and mortgage agencies, recently negotiated for 100,000 square feet at 641 Lexington Avenue.
"They understood that a public benefit corporation is motivated by the need to save money," said Mr. Martinez, who says he got a fairly low rent and a fairly high landlord contribution to building the space.
The Rudins have also had to contend with their share of deals gone sour. Numerous Rudin tenants -- Lord Day, for one -- have hit recessionary troubles. And the Rudins rarely hold troubled tenants' feet to the fire.
"If they can live with $24 a foot a year, they won't insist on $26," said Steven Spinola, head of the Real Estate Board of New York.
Some say it's compassion; others say it's long-term thinking. Today's troubled tenant can be tomorrow's high flyer.
Twenty years ago Kenneth G. Langone was president of R. W. Pressprich, a financial firm with five years left on a five-floor lease at 80 Pine Street, the Rudin building near Water Street. The firm was in trouble and needed only half its space.
"I expected Lew to say, 'Go bankrupt if you have to, but pay your rent,' " Mr. Langone said. "Instead he said, 'clean up space you don't need, and just pay for what you keep.' " Today Mr. Langone is a major stockholder in Home Depot and several other companies. "If any of my companies need space, I'll just ask Lew what he's got," he said.
That need had best be in New York for Mr. Rudin to help. Rudin Management has never ventured beyond city borders. Nor is it in ancillary businesses like hotels. Indeed, the last time the Rudins ventured onto unfamiliar professional turf was in 1953 when Jack and Lewis's father, Samuel, who'd been exclusively in housing, bought 415 Madison Avenue, which he tore down and replaced two years later.
"His brothers thought he was crazy, his partners wanted out, but the Tishmans and the Urises had office buildings, and he wanted them too," Lew Rudin recalled.
The company hired a leasing agent to rent that first building. Since then, Rudin Management has handled its own leasing.
TO hear Lew Rudin tell it, his philosophy -- do a few things, but do them well -- is not a lot different from Samuel's.
"My father always said, 'Shoemaker, stick to your last,' and, 'You are a favorite in your hometown,' " Lew Rudin said. "Well, what we know is how to build and manage buildings, and New York City is our hometown."
They have done well by that home. Jack Rudin was a prime mover behind the New York Marathon. Lew Rudin founded the Association for a Better New York.
"There's always a standing offer from the Rudins to City Hall to help, no matter who the mayor is," said Mr. Spinola.
Bill Rudin, although also a New York activist, is more of a national presence, serving as chairman of the Washington-based National Realty Committee's tax group.
"Other developers send delegates, but the Rudins get involved themselves," said Steven A. Wechsler, the committee's president.
Still, neither knowledge nor political activism has kept the Rudins from making mistakes. In the early 1980's they bought 310 Madison Avenue, at 42d Street, with the idea of demolishing the building and redeveloping the site. But someone else had space on the site that the Rudins couldn't get.
"We had no choice but to sell the entire site," Bill Rudin recalled.
They also felt compelled to turn 2 Fifth Avenue, a rental building they owned at Eighth Street, into a co-op when tenants sued them over rents and conditions. Later they co-oped 65 Central Park West, near 66th Street, and would have co-oped more buildings, had the co-op market not fallen apart.
"Office buildings are easier," Bill Rudin said. "You are dealing with a corporate mentality, and with 24 tenants, not 240."
Indeed, the Rudins seem to be steering more and more toward the office market, if not as builders, as consultants. Rudin Management served as a for-fee consultant to J. P. Morgan, which is developing 23 Wall Street. "It is my civic duty to keep them in New York," Lew insists. Bill is more candid about the business implications.
"Consulting is a good way to use our expertise without risking capital," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lew and William C. Rudin, father and son, in the Rudin offices on Park Avenue. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Staying the Course in Europe

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IT would be easy to conclude, based on the behavior of investors in European stocks and bonds over the past several weeks, that Europe is in for increasing inflation and higher interest rates and that the markets are headed for a downward spiral.
The markets have been extremely volatile, and on several days have endured sharp selloffs as pessimism about inflation and interest rates in the United States infected investors in Europe. The situation was not helped by the Bundesbank's announcement last week that the German money supply, a predictor of inflation, had increased at a far higher level than expected, although the central bank explained the jump away as a result of one-time technical factors. 
 But economists are nearly unanimous in their assessment that rates will continue to decline in Germany, Europe's biggest and most influential economy, and eventually throughout the major western European nations. Inflation, they said, remains quiescent. In other words, the same economic assumptions that underpinned a strong rally in most markets over the previous several months remain in place.
The most immediate question facing investors seems to be how quickly the European markets will shrug off what is happening in the United States, where stronger-than-expected growth and signs of incipient inflation are almost certain to bring further interest rate increases from the Federal Reserve.
Investors, particularly in the European bond markets, appear to have been operating in recent weeks as if the rising rates in the United States would inevitably bring the same in Europe, and as if falling share prices in New York would mean the onset of a bear market on this side of the Atlantic. The selloff was reportedly exacerbated by heavy selling among large hedge funds seeking to cover losses both on bond and currency trading. After enduring some violent swings during the week, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares closed on Friday in London at 3,278, down just 3.2 points on the week. In Frankfurt, the DAX-30 index ended the week down 14.83 points, at 2,060.09. The CAC-40 index in Paris closed down 20.23 points on the week, at 2,178.69.
"We maintain our view that the real economies of Europe and the United States are on very different cycles," said Joe Rooney, the European equity strategist at Lehman Brothers in London.
"The question is whether, when things settle down, the European bond markets will be able to decouple themselves from those in the U.S.," Mr. Rooney said. "We're increasingly of the belief that that will be the case."
Mr. Rooney said Lehman Brothers had studied the 11 periods since the 1950's when rising short-term rates led to a sharp fall in American stock markets. The study then looked at the extent to which the market declines in the United States were accompanied by falls in European markets, and concluded that there was not necessarily a direct relationship between the two.
The average market decline in the 11 corrections in the United States was 13.8 percent, excluding the 1987 market crash, Mr. Rooney said. Yet in Germany, for example, the market rose or was unchanged during 8 of those 11 periods.
Some analysts said the selloffs in Europe over the past several weeks were actually positive for the markets by ending an almost mindless rush into both stocks and bonds.
"In general we view the falling markets over the past couple of weeks as healthy signs," said Kenneth Anderson, the investment manager for Scottish Widows, a large pension fund in Edinburgh. "The liquidity flow into equities was indiscriminate and valuations had been pushed up too high."
There is some danger that rising rates in the United States will dry up or even reverse the heavy flow of funds from American investors into the European markets, analysts said. That flow has driven much of the upward surge in prices in the markets, especially in smaller markets like Madrid.
Richard Davidson, the European investment strategist at Morgan Stanley in London, said that the liquidity-driven phase of the European bull market is more or less over. Although European equities have generally held up better over recent weeks than European bonds, he said, economic fundamentals and market valuations suggest the opposite should be true. As a result, Morgan Stanley is advising a very cautious approach to picking European stocks, he said.
"We really can't say that the European equity markets deserve to be on the valuations they're on," Mr. Davidson said.
He said the best opportunities are in three categories: consumer stocks such as Nestle, Sandoz and Unilever that are likely to deliver solid earnings growth and are still priced relatively cheaply; restructuring and recovery stocks such as Philips, the Dutch electronics company, which showed a strong earnings turnaround last week; and stocks that benefit from high levels of dollar earnings, like Hanson, the British-American conglomerate.
Mr. Anderson of Scottish Widows said the markets, having put historically high valuations on so many companies, would harshly punish those stocks that failed to live up to expectations. "There's no scope for any earnings disappointment," he said.
But he said careful investors can still find good buys.
"Stock selection is going to be much more important than last year, when you could buy anything and everything," Mr. Anderson said.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 6, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3350 words

HEADLINE: The Humbling of the Harvard Man

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
WHEN Erich Segal wrote "The Class," a 1983 novel based on the lives of his Harvard classmates from their school days until their 25th reunion, the people he portrayed had experienced many of the problems common to his generation. They had endured divorces, loneliness, alienated children, thwarted ambition. Several had committed suicide. But nowhere in the 592 pages of "The Class" is anyone out of work, or pressed for cash. A Harvard degree seemed an immunization against unemployment.
Mr. Segal saw the 25th reunion of the class of 1958 as a gathering of the privileged. "It was not merely that you were going to make your way, but as a Harvard man the way was prepared for you," Mr. Segal said last week. "This is not arrogance. Unemployment was not part of our emotional baggage, not part of the range of things that we thought we would ever have to face."
How times have changed. In the nearly 11 years since that reunion in June 1983, at least 10 percent of the 1,040 surviving members of the all-male class, and perhaps as many as 20 percent, have lost jobs, according to those in the class who organize the reunions and track their mates. 
 Some, like Richard V. Wing, a manager at Honeywell, were laid off and, after looking unsuccessfully for new jobs, took premature retirement. Others, like A. Donald Slotkin and Thomas O. Bernheim, lost their jobs and became consultants while they looked for new work, sometimes successfully and sometimes not. Others forced from their careers, like Edward Gray, have retrained themselves and are now self-employed, often at a far lower income than before. And a few, like Thomas A. Stalker, who lost the family business, are surviving with welfare payments and food stamps.
Food stamps are a dizzying turn of events for people who came out of Harvard expecting an inside track to the most interesting and lucrative careers, and to a comfortable retirement. The class of 1958, whose members are 56 or 57 years old today, was far more homogeneous than the class of 1994. Almost all the 1,174 men who earned bachelor's degrees in 1958 were white and upper-middle or upper class. Many had prepared at top-notch secondary schools or private academies.
The class of 1958 included John D. Rockefeller 4th, now a Democratic Senator from West Virginia, along with other sons of wealthy families. Some in the class were talented scholars, like William French Anderson, who went on to pioneer in gene transfers. And there were those who were not so studious, earning, with minimum grades, their privileged lives as Harvard graduates.
Some from the class of 1958 became prominent business leaders, like James R. Houghton, now chairman of Corning Inc. Academia, medicine, finance and law drew many class members, and most have had successful careers. Their incomes reflect it; the average annual income of the 402 class members who responded to a questionnaire last year was $170,000.
 
An Unexpected Intruder
 But job troubles are increasingly intruding on this cheerful picture. "The members of the class of 1958 are either reaching the senior level of their career paths or they have been tumbled out into doing their own thing," said William F. Manley, who compiled the autobiographical sketches published for the 25th reunion in 1983 and the 35th reunion last June. "I would say that about 25 percent have been tumbled out."
The Harvard class of 1958 is not alone in this experience. Alumni groups at other Ivy League schools and at colleges and universities outside the Ivy League report that their members, in growing numbers, are suffering from the upheavals in Corporate America. That is particularly the case for men who received their bachelor's degrees in the 1950's and 1960's and are now over 45.
If there is a lesson in all this, it is that a degree from a college like Harvard is no longer the lifetime guarantee of success in careers that it once seemed to be. "The layoffs of managers and skilled technical people at I.B.M. or Xerox or A.T.& T. do not discriminate between graduates of Harvard" and of some lesser school, Senator Rockefeller said. "And when they come we are not prepared for this nonsuccess. We don't know how to deal with it, economically or psychologically."
In fact, fewer than 10 members of the class of 1958 owned up to their troubles in the autobiographical updates submitted for the 35th reunion report. One was Michael J. Stone, of Orinda, Calif. He left his job in 1991 as a vice president of Dolby Laboratories. He joined a new company formed to recycle waste wood, but it failed, and he was out of the work world. "I am now in a position of calling myself either unemployed, retired or a job-seeker," Mr. Stone wrote. "I haven't yet decided which." Last month, he finally got a job, doing the accounting for a real estate investment operation, at a salary of $100,000, which is less than his Dolby income.
Lynn D. Sprankle, angry and eloquent, has not found work. He lost his job as a corporate vice president, then hunted incessantly for another job, sending out 13,000 resumes, some to his classmates. "The response from these people was also zero -- no phone calls, no leads, no interviews and of course no offers," he wrote for the 35th reunion report. "So much for the 'camaraderie of the 10,000 men of Harvard.' "
Inevitably, Mr. Sprankle, who is 57, questions the value of a Harvard education. "I no longer look upon it with the pride I once did, and I have come to view my graduate degree" -- an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania -- "the same way," he wrote. "In fact, they may even have been detrimental -- in that they caused me to set higher personal expectation levels than I was ever able to attain."
Mr. Segal, who is most famous for his first novel, "Love Story," and is teaching this year at Oxford, was struck by how much things have changed for many classmates. In contrast with the autobiographical sketches compiled for the 25th anniversary, those written for the 35th "did not radiate with expressions of success and optimism," he said. "Quite the contrary, they seemed like a litany of loss and disillusion."
Responding to such frustrations, the class of 1958 has emerged as the first among Harvard's alumni groups to publicly recognize the jobs problem. Just before the 35th reunion, Thomas Stalker, who was out of work, mailed a letter to his classmates announcing the formation of a network to help the unemployed find jobs. The letter invited people to a breakfast during the reunion at which people without work could meet classmates who might help.
One hundred people showed up, among them Robert Waggoner, owner of Burrelle's Information Services, a successful press-clipping and data-processing service, that has his classmates on the payroll. "There was a feeling at that breakfast that some of these cases were very sad, and it was the tip of the iceberg and there must be more out there," Mr. Waggoner said. "And these people had courage and came forward."
The Harvard administration is only now acknowledging publicly that unemployment is an issue among the alumni. "There are a lot of capable people out there, who are Harvard graduates, who are losing their jobs through no fault of their own," Jack Reardon, an associate vice president at Harvard who heads the alumni association, said last week.
The solution? Mr. Reardon said that several regional alumni clubs would compile lists of members who had agreed to offer advice to other members seeking jobs. Harvard, he said, might try to measure statistically the extent of the unemployment among alumni holding Harvard bachelor's degrees, but has not considered setting up an employment office. "I am not so sure that Harvard would be particularly good at getting people jobs," Mr. Reardon said.
 
Thomas Stalker
From Corner Suite To Food Stamps
 Perhaps no one in the class of 1958 has fallen farther in the job world than Thomas Stalker, a 57-year-old Bostonian who once owned his own business. He is reduced today to selling powdered diet formula to friends and acquaintances. Yet he spends as much time on the phone helping classmates, as the self-appointed chief of the job network, as he does selling diet formula.
The hardwood-flooring business that Mr. Stalker owned went under in 1989. Five years later, he has still not adjusted to the shock and to the loss of the stature that he enjoyed as a well-to-do businessman. But the job network he has set up to help classmates, and himself, has lifted his spirits. At the 35th reunion, he says, "I was sought out by classmates, many of whom I did not know, all giving encouragement, advice and thanks."
He came to the reunion with food stamps in his pocket. His church has given him money. He gets a $339 welfare check each month. He is behind on the rent for the room he lives in. And when he needs medical treatment, he goes to Massachusetts General Hospital, where he is treated under a state law that provides free health care for people with incomes below the poverty level.
Like many in the class of 1958, Mr. Stalker had entered a prosperous family business right out of college -- in his case a lumber supply company. Through his own ingenuity, he concentrated the company's marketing effort on selling hardwood flooring, while eliminating other, low-margin products. A newly developed adhesive had made hardwood flooring easier to lay, popular and profitable.
"Dad paid me the highest business compliment he could when he came into my office one day, closed the door and said, 'Son, I never thought I would see the day when we would be making so much money,' " Mr. Stalker said. "Fortunately for him, he died several years later and was not around for the Gotterdammerung."
The Gotterdammerung came in the form of a much bigger, out-of-state competitor that pushed into the Boston area with low prices, winning away Mr. Stalker's customers, who were wholesale distributors of hardwood flooring. That blow, along with a weak New England economy and the distractions of a costly divorce, forced Mr. Stalker into bankruptcy.
In the search for work that followed, Mr. Stalker found that a Harvard B.A. sometimes worked against him. He was viewed as overqualified. So once, when he sought a job selling magazine subscriptions by phone for $6.20 an hour, he suppressed Harvard. "I put down on the application the University of Massachusetts at Amherst," he said. "I got the job."
 
Thomas Bernheim
Once on the Inside, Now an Outsider
 Thomas O. Bernheim also returned from Harvard to the family business, in his case a leather business in Hoboken, N.J. His father had sent him to Exeter, and Exeter regularly sent half its graduating classes to Harvard, Yale or Princeton. At Harvard, Mr. Bernheim majored in history and became interested in teaching, a goal that made him restless in his business. So in 1971, at 35, he left and prepared for a form of teaching -- training people to be managers.
By 1979, Mr. Bernheim had joined Wang Laboratories, the big computer company near Boston, and he rose to senior member of a 20-person training department. "It was a beautiful time," Mr. Bernheim said. "Wang was booming, and we hired a lot of people. They were engineers, and they had to learn management quickly, and we taught them."
By 1989, however, Wang was on the skids and Mr. Bernheim's department was abolished. He switched to teaching marketing people. "I put in a new course on how to use power and influence, and how to be assertive," Mr. Bernheim said. "I taught people how to get things through the company and how to build a common ground with others, and a common vision. It was an exciting time, and I enjoyed this work all the way up to 1991, when I got laid off."
He had been making $55,000 a year, and he got half that as severance. "We knew we were living under the ax," he said, "and we had already started sending out resumes."
Mr. Bernheim is still sending out resumes, and answering ads. He is working out of a basement office now, getting by on consulting fees. (His wife does not work, and his three children are on their own.) Mostly, he says, he is concentrating "on finding that wonderful, full-time job and wondering, 'Why can't I get one.' "
Mr. Bernheim, who is 57, has concluded that his main obstacle is age. His Harvard degree also sometimes works against him. "I am asked, how come I wasn't making more money, and how come I wasn't a vice president," Mr. Bernheim said. "How come? Because I chose to be a coach and contributor, to help others. I chose to do what I enjoyed doing."
 
Edward Gray
A Company Man Left on His Own
 Edward Gray, who is 56, sat in on the job network breakfast at the 35th reunion. "There was talk that a lot of people would have traveled to Cambridge for the reunion if they could have afforded to do so," he said.
Mr. Gray, who lives near Los Angeles, could afford the trip, but from savings, not from his current income as a self-employed patent expert without enough clients. He is not in this business by choice. After Harvard, Mr. Gray went on to earn a doctorate in physics, and for 23 years, until 1990, he worked in the military industry, on rockets and aircraft, for big contractors like TRW.
The cuts in military spending, and the job shedding they generated, finally forced him out of the industry in 1989. He has never regained the $75,000 salary he earned at the end, not to mention the generous expense accounts. To survive, Mr. Gray took an 18-week course in patent law, passed a Federal exam and went to work in 1991 for a law firm as a patent agent. His task was to prepare detailed patent applications for inventors.
But the law firm abolished Mr. Gray's job, in late 1992. So he set up his own one-man shop. "It has been extremely hard," Mr. Gray said. "Basically, I am constantly marketing. And if I am working on a case" -- each one takes up to 50 hours and pays $4,000 to $5,000 -- "then I am aware that this job will finish and I have to find clients."
If he could get a job, "something useful and productive, that would make a contribution to the national security, I would think about it," Mr. Gray says. He has submitted his resume to the job network, circling the category "underemployed." (His annual income is $40,000, but his wife has an income as a freelance writer, and his children are on their own.) At least, he says, "what I am doing is intellectually honest and rewarding."
 
Richard Wing
Going to School Instead of Work
 In many ways, Richard Wing of Newton, Mass., finds his early retirement more rewarding than the job he lost. Even before Honeywell Inc. laid him off more than three years ago, he had begun to study for a master's degree in classical civilization at the Harvard Extension School. And now that he is retired, he spends his days at a Harvard museum, cataloging ancient Greek coins -- the subject of his master's thesis.
Mr. Wing's entry in the 35th reunion book reflects this satisfaction in retirement. But it stands in contrast to what he wrote for the 25th book.
Then, he had presented himself as a successful engineer and manager for Honeywell, the computer company whose Boston office he had joined right out of Harvard. "I've had the satisfaction of having some of my designs manufactured," he wrote in 1983, "and I was the first person to transmit computer data by use of a space satellite."
The layoffs came after Honeywell was acquired by a French company. The new organization cut back on computer design operations that involved Mr. Wing, and the department of two dozen people that he once headed. "I saw this coming because I had responsibility for laying off people myself," he said. "I laid off two or three, and I found that very difficult. And when my boss called me in, I realized what was happening and tried to make it easy for him. I walked out with $10,000, and they paid my salary for almost a year. And I have health insurance from them."
Mr. Wing, who is 57 now, searched for more than a year for another computer industry job, finally concluding that he would have to leave Massachusetts to get one that matched the Honeywell job, which paid $63,000. "My wife works as a teacher here, and I would have had to give up school, and I did not want to do that. So when I turned 55 and became eligible for a Honeywell pension, I gave up looking for a job," Mr. Wing said. "We live now on my pension ($25,000) and my wife's salary ($44,000)."
 
Donald Slotkin
Between Jobs? Try Consulting
 Each time he has lost a job, Donald Slotkin has fallen back on self-employment, mainly consulting, as his avenue to the next job. "Harvard always opens doors," he says. "It does not mean that you will get a job, but having a Harvard degree opens doors, particularly when I am doing consulting work."
Mr. Slotkin, who lives in Detroit, is in meatpacking. Coming out of Harvard, he joined the family firm, Hygrade Food Products, remaining there until it was sold in the late 1960's. That was when he first tried consulting. "It was a good vehicle to stay in touch with the meat business," he said.
Consulting put Mr. Slotkin in touch with the Crown Packing Company in Yonkers, which hired him as president, a job he held for six years. In 1977, after another stint in consulting, he became president of John Morell & Company, a meatpacker based in Detroit, where he lasted 10 years. Morell fell into the hands of Carl Lindner, a corporate raider, and Mr. Lindner put his son in charge. "I basically had to work for a man half my age, who did not know the business," Mr. Slotkin said.
There was a parting, without a golden parachute but with "fair severance," and Mr. Slotkin spent a year writing a musical, drawing on a skill he had cultivated earlier in life. It wasn't produced, and Mr. Slotkin returned to consulting in 1988, for his longest stint. Consulting finally led last May to his third presidency, at Monfort Pork in Greeley, Colo.
Mr. Slotkin, who is 57, says that his income is in six figures and that consulting has never paid as well as the presidencies. He commutes from Detroit to the Colorado job. "I won't go to 65 doing this," he said, anticipating the early retirement that has overtaken so many of his classmates.
 
 
 
THE NORM IS STILL SUCCESS
 FOR every member of the class of 1958 who lost a job or retired unwillingly, there are two or three or more who are still enjoying successful careers or have gone happily into retirement. One is Edward L. Peirson, who retired as senior vice president of Corning Lab Services, a subsidiary of Corning Inc.
"I am having fun, smelling roses," he says. He has homes on Marco Island in Florida and on Cape Cod, and a "fairly large boat" he sails in the Caribbean. And he has enough money.
Mr. Peirson's career resembled those of executives in his father's generation. After a stint as an officer in the Marines, he joined Corning in 1961, where his father had also worked. He moved up through a series of jobs, reaching senior vice president of the Corning Lab division, with a salary and bonuses above $300,000 a year.
Corning gives full retirement pensions at 55, with 30 years of service, but Mr. Peirson, who is 57 now, was held over a year to complete some unfinished business. "There is a lot of emphasis at Corning on succession planning, and if you are successful at this, you are not needed," he said. "I will bet that in the last few years, there were not any officers who worked to 65. On the other hand, very few were told they had to leave."
Mr. Peirson had gone to Harvard because his father, who had also gone to Harvard, said he would not pay to send his son anywhere else. And like his father, Mr. Peirson retired from Corning as soon as he was eligible. For the father, who was director of public relations, that was age 62, since lowered to 55.
Mr. Peirson said that most of the people he dealt with at the 35th reunion did not have a job problem. "But I suspect," he said, "that there was more concern about jobs at the 35th reunion than the 25th."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 6, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1485 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: February 27 - March 4

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Nation's Unemployment Rate Falls Two More Notches
Slowly and steadily, America keeps going back to work. The unemployment rate fell to 6.5 percent in February from 6.7 percent in January -- which was the first month of the Government's new tallying method -- and payrolls expanded by a solid 217,000. And if a price for these gains is a brush with inflation, there are at least 217,000 people who don't mind a bit. Things slowed down somewhat on the factory floor, though: the average workweek had hit exceptionally high levels recently, but with much of the nation battling ice and snow, it fell by 42 minutes, the biggest shrinkage in 10 years. There was a hopeful note, too, in a 10 percent reduction -- a drop of 524,000 -- in the ranks of the "partially unemployed," those who want more work than they have. But this may be less than it seems: the Labor Department said January's statistical gear-switching skewed this figure. 

Ending '93 on a Mighty Note
Last year's fourth quarter takes on ever-more-mythic proportions. Everyone knew it was strong, but last week it became clear just how strong: the economy grew at a 7.5 percent annual rate, the mightiest in a decade. So, do the numbers add up to renewed inflation? Other data last week gave a mixed picture. A purchasing managers' index showed fast-rising prices, a bad sign, and retail sales took a big jump. But home sales and construction were off (blame the weather), and January's leading indicators showed an 0.3 percent rise, signaling slow, steady growth.
 
COMPANIES
 
Interactive TV: Not Just Yet
To hear some people tell it, we're bounding toward a dazzling video future -- movies on demand, vast libraries at our electronic whim. But occasionally there's a reminder that technology can't leap as fast as the human mind. Just recently Bell Atlantic and T.C.I. abandoned their dream of interfacing in that high-tech sunrise. And last week Time Warner Cable delayed until later this year -- it had been set for April 1 -- a field trial of its interactive television system in Orlando, Fla. "It's simply a matter of wanting to take more time," a Time Warner spokesman said. But there are skeptics. "They're trying to put a round peg in a square hole," one analyst said. . . . But wait: Now T.C.I. and Microsoft are teaming up to test interactive cable systems.
 
Coke Kicks Up Its Heels
Giant Coca-Cola is clearly miffed when its customers start drinking odd concoctions like Snapple or Clearly Canadian -- drinks neither fish nor fowl, sort of soda, sort of juice, and a downright random attitude to carbonation. Colas are losing some hold on the market, though, while such "new age" drinks are exploding. So last week, unable to lick 'em, Coke joined 'em -- with a vengeance. It pulled out all the new-age stops in introducing a line of non-fizzy drinks called Fruitopia, complete with flowery labels and names like Strawberry Passion Awareness. Remember when a bit of tinkering with the Coke recipe was front-page news?
 
At the New Paramount: No Jaffe
Now that Viacom has won the epic battle for Paramount, one uncertainty has been resolved. Stanley Jaffe, Paramount's president, will have no place in the final cut, Viacom executives said last week. The reason is simple: many movies made on his watch were flops. And not only do the new owners want better films, they want more. Mr. Jaffe promised 25 a year, but did not come close; Viacom wants up to 40. And Mr. Jaffe? He's said recently that he might want to buy the New York Rangers hockey team, and with perhaps $60 million in a Paramount nest egg, he can afford a spending spree.
 
Chrysler Gears Up
America's automotive rebound took on an even more solid shape last week when Chrysler, jubilant that its cars and trucks are so popular, said it will spend $1.8 billion to increase its manufacturing capacity. As a starter, it canceled plans to shut a plant near St. Louis. The changes could create as many as 6,000 jobs. "We have to strike while the iron is hot," the chairman, Robert Eaton, said. Irons don't stay hot forever, as Detroit would be wise to remember this time around. But now things are definitely jumping: auto sales soared by 20 percent in February.
 
A.T. & T., Beyond the Telegraph
Imagine if operators had to say, "Thank you for using the American Telephone and Telegraph Company." That mouthful of a name is clearly out of place in this 90's world of sleek, lean and quick. So last week the company said it would slim down to fit the age, and it came up with a short, catchy new name. But it's not one the public will have much trouble getting used to: it's "AT & T." Anyone listening over at the International . . . Business . . . Machines (take a breath here) . . . Corporation?
 
Newton: Apple Tries Again
Is a hand-held computer, one that can do parlor tricks like turning handwriting into print, what this troubled world really needs? Several years ago, Apple Computer decided it was -- and the company put a lot of effort into creating the Newton Messagepad. John Sculley, the chairman, promised great things for the Newton, but it fell far short of his dreams -- its flaws even became the butt of jokes -- and he has since departed, not exactly in triumph. But last week Apple tried again, introducing an updated Newton -- and hopes it's on the right track. It's cheaper ($599 vs. $799), slimmer, can do more tricks, and has more software. It's what Apple "should have introduced to begin with," one consultant said. But, still, the world will be a less spicy place if epic deals are not scrawled on napkins.
 
Balanced Budgets: Catchy Idea
A balanced budget: it's something Americans understand. Those idiots in Washington, they reason, shouldn't spend money they don't have. Lawmakers, of course, know it's a lot more complicated. George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, said many lawmakers in both parties told him that a balanced-budget amendment was a bad idea and they backed it only to get re-elected. On a secret ballot, he said, backers of such "political posturing" wouldn't even get a majority. Last week, the amendment fell short of the necessary two-thirds Senate vote -- 63 to 37 -- and Mr. Mitchell pronounced it dead for this year. Bob Dole still vowed, "It's going to happen." But wasn't it his party's Presidents who ran up a lot of those bills in the first place?
 
Keeping a Campaign Promise
It's a time-honored rule of politics: Promise them a tax cut; do the math later. Christine Todd Whitman made such a promise her rallying cry, and voters believed her. Last week New Jersey's new Governor started to make good on that pledge, as the state Senate approved her plan to cut the income tax 5 percent. The cut sends a "powerful message," Mrs. Whitman said. It's half a message, though, until she decides how she'll pay the bills. And it's a decidedly muted message: for those who make less than $40,000, the windfall is about $24 a year. They can replace those well-used snow shovels.
 
In Denver, Waiting for Baggage
Airport luggage. Even in the best of times, it can make grown travelers cry. But imagine the uproar if a snazzy, high-tech system were to go haywire at a huge airport, leaving thousands without toothbrushes and teddy bears. That kind of nightmare the new Denver International Airport does not need, so after its computerized baggage system misfired in a test, officials delayed the opening until May 15. The airport, the nation's largest, had been due to open this week. But it was also supposed to open in October. And in December.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Waving a Fist at Japan
President Clinton has this thing about Japan. Even with the domestic economy humming along, he's not going to rest till that stubborn nation welcomes American goods with open arms. Last week he really rattled his saber, signing an order reviving the dreaded "Super 301," giving him power to slap 100 percent tariffs on Japanese goods on a moment's notice. Never mind that the head of a world trade group called the move "misguided and dangerous." Never mind that he's raised the specter of a trade war. Mr. Clinton seems willing to risk a lot.
 
U.S. Gives Europe the Jitters
When the United States rubs its temples, the whole world starts popping Tylenol. With the recent whiffs of American inflation, European stock markets have proven very jittery, for any rise in interest rates will make stocks less attractive, especially in riskier markets. So at the latest inflation alert last week the markets in London, Paris and Frankfurt were hit hard, continuing a recent slide.
 
The Lighter Side of Mercedes
A "Swatchmobile"? Built by Mercedes? It's true: Mercedes and the trendy Swiss watchmaker announced an odd alliance last week to build a tiny, cheap two-seater. A sort of dinghy on wheels to sit by the serious machines.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Selling Is Hard When There Are No Buyers

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE world's economies are hardly in synch, and government economic policies vary widely. But you wouldn't know that from looking at the markets around the world. They have been sinking in remarkable unison for a month.
The slide has caused more pain in bonds than in stocks, and has been worst in the so-called emerging markets -- already being dubbed "submerging markets" by Wall Street wags. It has been deeper in Europe than in America, so you might say that this nation has been the winner. You would have lost less with your money here than almost anywhere except Japan. There, now, don't you feel better already? 
 What all these markets have in common are not valuation levels, or inflation outlooks, or monetary policy changes, or any of the other things that analysts tend to point to when trying to explain why markets went up and down. Increasingly, the common element is players, many of them American firms.
It is not clear what set off the slide, which began after markets around the world peaked in the first week of February. But after it got going, one firm after another decided that perhaps it was wise to get a little more conservative. Hedge funds, most of which had great years last year, had bet heavily on lower interest rates in most major countries. They had borrowed heavily to buy bonds, and when prices began to fall they rushed to sell. The market makers, many of them American banks and brokerage houses, soon had bought all they wanted. As they tried to sell, they found no buyers. Liquidity dried up and prices fell.
The worst may be over. Certainly the dramatic reversal in the American stock market Wednesday looked like a bottom. With luck, there will have been no fatalities, only a lot of bruised egos stemming from the discovery that markets, which had mysteriously created wealth for players the world over, can withdraw it just as rapidly.
It will probably be some time before liquidity returns to smaller and newer markets, and even now it is not clear whether some player or other still has big, unrecognized losses, perhaps from some imperfect hedge that went awry.
There is a search on in Europe for the villain that caused the sudden rise in interest rates. The central banks seem to be out to nail the hedge funds, notwithstanding their large losses, as the culprit. In 1992 and 1993, the hedge funds got rich selling overvalued currencies to the central banks, which had to buy to support a foolish European exchange rate mechanism. That fact may have something to do with their current vilification.
The real villain is overconfidence. All the money that banks made in proprietary trading the last couple of years left them expecting to earn 100 percent or more on the capital invested in the business. So they invested more capital, and had bigger positions to lose when markets turned. Japan was one country where relatively little American capital had been bet on a bull market, and that is probably one reason why it fell the least.

HEADLINE: Profile;
In Quest for Electric Cars, He Adds the Power of Faith

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Mass.

 BODY:
James Worden built his first electric car in the seventh grade -- if you don't count his earlier attempts, made with Legos, an Erector set or whatever was handy. This had a sturdy wooden frame, "something you could ride on, that wouldn't fall apart under you," he said.
By the 10th grade, Mr. Worden had built several cars "that only went in the road for short periods, between when police cars passed by." Eventually he built one he could take on the streets legally. It absorbed enough energy through solar cells on its roof and hood to take him to high school and back, in Arlington, Mass. 
 Not that the point was to get to school. "School was my distraction," he said. "This is my work."
Now he's 26, and electric cars are his life. He is chief executive of a company called Solectria, which has sold about 70 electric cars since late 1991, and has orders for 50 more.
Solectria's strong points include 18 employees with a variety of mechanical and electronic skills and a back room where an engineer is planning an electric car from scratch. But its main strength is simply a belief that electric cars are not a possibility for the future, but a reality now.
They are not perfect, but they run cleanly and in many cases with considerable pep. And wherever they go, they attract curious crowds. Mr. Worden calls them "magic."
The giants of the auto industry say electric cars don't go far enough, or fast enough, and are too expensive to build. But the growth of Mr. Worden's company seems to tell a different story. It is privately held and does not disclose precise numbers, but grossed about $2 million last year, double the figure from the year before, and hopes to do $4 million in business this year. And it has already outgrown the 20,000-square-foot shop and office suite here in Wilmington that it moved into just two years ago, and is looking for someplace three or four times as large.
True, his company is small, but it is one of the few car companies in North America that are hiring. There were 10 employees last fall; soon, the number will hit 20.
On a recent drive through this outer suburb of Boston, Mr. Worden drove a Force, a converted Geo Metro that is soon to be part of a demonstration project run by Massachusetts to lease electric cars by the month to commuters.
As he drove, Mr. Worden reeled off some objections to electric cars -- and answered them.
Batteries perform badly when cold, so electric cars won't run in cold weather, skeptics say. But the Force draws current from a wall outlet overnight, keeping the batteries at optimum temperature.
They may work in California, critics say, but in New England passengers will freeze. But the Force's heat keeps the passenger compartment toasty, and the heat comes on immediately, while in a conventional car there is no heat until the engine warms up. True, turning on the heat cuts down the driving range, but Mr. Worden says the penalty is small and will not affect a typical commute.
The car can't keep up in traffic or accelerate down a highway on-ramp, they say. But the Force performs fine in suburban driving and on Boston-area highways, where the speed limit, by local tradition, is as close to Mach 1 as the driver can manage without colliding with the fool ahead.
AND then there is price; a car that can be outperformed by a Geo Metro but costs twice as much can be a hard sell. But that, too, can be overcome, Mr. Worden says, when various manufacturing horrors are eliminated.
One of these is buying Geo Metros whole, then stripping out useless, but costly, parts -- like the transmission, fuel tank and muffler. But the cars, when converted, run quite well for 60 or 70 miles between charges.
When Mr. Worden graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1989, he founded Solectria with Anita V. Rajan, who was still an undergraduate. She is now president of the company, which is largely staffed with M.I.T. graduates.
The company is probably not the largest producer, especially now that U.S. Electricar, of Sebastopol, Calif., has acquired some smaller makers. But it has a strong reputation in a close-knit industry, and a table in the lobby is jammed with trophies for endurance and speed.
At the Northeast Alternative Vehicle Consortium, a Boston-based organization largely financed by the Federal Government to promote electric cars, Sheila Lynch, the executive director, said that when engineers enter a race, their goal is usually to break one of Mr. Worden's records.
Mr. Worden tries to keep visitors from getting a glimpse of his office, because every surface, including the floor, is strewn with electrical components. His hands sometimes look out of place unless they are tinkering with the guts of an electric car.
"He's the one who has the real faith," said Gill A. Pratt, an assistant professor of electrical engineering at M.I.T. and a consultant at Solectria.
Lots of companies in the past have had faith and a great deal of optimism, hardly ever justified. But now electric cars are at a critical moment. The Clean Air Act of 1990 requires companies that operate fleets of vehicles to buy some that run on alternative fuels, and puts the stiffest requirements on energy companies.
Many of those will use compressed natural gas, but the electric utilities will not -- if they can help it. So they are buying electric cars, and many are turning to Solectria.
Companies that make batteries and related equipment, eager for a test bed for their products, are also buying either cars or drivetrains, which Solectria also sells. Various large corporations that are quietly pursuing electric vehicle research have also bought cars or drivetrains for testing, Solectria says.
So far, hardly any buyers have bought the cars for personal use, although there are many inquiries. "We don't not sell to the general public," said Mark A. Kopec, vice president for marketing and sales. But Solectria prefers buyers who run fleets over predictable routes, he said, and have some in-house engineering support. And the price -- $26,050 for the basic model -- is hardly attractive except for field testing.
But California has approved a program of ever-tightening regulations on car emissions, and beginning with the 1998 model year, 2 percent of each car maker's sales must be electric vehicles. Massachusetts and New York have adopted the same rules.
Because of heavy lobbying by oil companies and domestic car makers, there is some doubt, even at Solectria, that California will hold to this requirement. But if it does, a leading car company might buy Solectria's technology, or ask Solectria to produce cars for sale under the larger company's nameplate.
Or, said Mr. Kopec, one big manufacturer might enter the market directly, with or without the California rules. If that happens, the optimistic prediction is that Solectria, far more nimble than larger companies, would be able to find a new niche, perhaps a specific kind of electric car. The less optimistic view is that it would resemble a scene from the film "Godzilla Meets Bambi," with Solectria getting second billing.
Solectria is not waiting for the regulations to take effect, though, and does not expect any magic bullets that will suddenly make its product indispensable.
Indeed, some factors are making electric cars look less attractive. Mr. Worden recently returned from Atlanta, where a Chevy pickup he converted to electric power set a record for most miles traveled in 24 hours. But on the trip he was dismayed to see gasoline selling for 89.9 cents a gallon -- less, he said, than he used to pay for a gallon of distilled water to top off lead-acid batteries. New batteries are sealed, with no water inside, but it will take more improvements than that to make electric cars competitive strictly on price.
INSTEAD, the company is designing a car from the ground up. The project, in a back room that visitors are allowed only to glimpse, has a $1.13 million budget, provided by the Pentagon and Boston Edison.
The idea is to build something designed for electricity. The Geo Metro, for example, is fairly lightweight, but, for lack of space, batteries must be mounted in two different locations, requiring cabling between them.
And in a gasoline car, heat is a waste product, so heating passengers is a trivial task. In an electric car, heat is precious. So the new design will have a well-insulated passenger compartment, which engineers say is not too hard to build in as long as they are rethinking the whole car.
All that is needed to see the electric car as practical is an independent mind, say engineers here.
"If I can sell you a gasoline car or an electric car," Dr. Pratt said, "it will bias my thinking on the question 'Is there anybody out there who will buy a battery-powered car?' " Companies that make conventional cars, he said, play a "zero-sum game," because selling one electric car means selling one less gasoline car. There is no change in total sales.
Solectria, meanwhile, badly needs a sales increase to achieve economies of scale that will bring down the price. Its parts would be cheap, Dr. Pratt said, if they could be mass-produced, but every part that must be built by hand can add hundreds of dollars to the car's cost.
Solectria wants to get away from that as a company, but Mr. Worden still likes to get his hands in the cars. Trying to get a company running, he now limits himself to two races a year, but at the annual Tour de Sol, a multiday road rally for solar and electric cars, he is often found working night after night on his own cars. He also works on those of his rivals, because he has sold components to most of them and he wants to see everyone make it across the finish line -- behind him, of course.
Racing, he said, could easily take up more time than it should. But "it's in my blood," he said.
 
 
 
A GEO, PLEASE (HOLD THE ENGINE)
 PRODUCING specialized parts by hand is hard, but Solectria has also done the opposite, turning some highly sophisticated parts into cheap commodities, notably engines from Geo Metros. Because Solectria has to buy the whole car, it must remove parts worth thousands of dollars. Mechanics drain the fluids and carefully box each set; stacked five high, they reach nearly to the shop ceiling.
There is not much secondary market, Solectria says, because the engines on Geo Metros don't often require replacement. The company has sold a few to dealers for parts.
But the biggest disposal method is to give them away with purchases, as if they were trading stamps or Ginsu knives. Schools and colleges that buy a Force or buy a drivetrain, intending to convert a car on their own, get an engine free, for teaching purposes.
Such are the hurdles of producing a product the Big Three say cannot be reasonably built. But Solectria is now in negotiations to buy the cars without engines; it hopes to have a deal with G.M. by June.
 
James D. Worden
 
 Born: April 24, 1967.
 
 Family: Single.
 
 Drives: The Force, Solectria's basic electric model.
 
 Education: B.S., mechanical engineering, M.I.T.. "Barely started" a master's, but turned to Solectria instead.
 
 Vacation: Annual long weekend in the Poconos, scheduled to coincide with an "electric vehicle challenge" race.
 
 Hobbies: Electric trains, especially those big enough to ride on. Also keeping aquarium fish; a tank in the office lobby has one tough-looking specimen, of uncertain pedigree.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Gauging Workfare's Employability

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE verdict is in: welfare doesn't work. Officials from President Clinton on down are vowing to create programs that require welfare recipients to work. In the argot of the movement, "only work works."
But moving from work promises to work programs is harder than it sounds. A record 15 million people now receive Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal program. Ten million are children. Of the five million adults, 95 percent are single women. Few have the kind of skills or experience attractive to private employers.
President Clinton has vowed to send Congress his work bill this spring. He has said it will expand training programs for welfare recipients and require those unemployed after two years to join a work program. But what kind of work? How long will the jobs last? What will happen, at the program's end, to those that have found no private jobs? What, without welfare, will sustain them? 
 "Work gives purpose and structure to our lives," said President Clinton in a Christmas Day address.
But as his work program takes shape, there are three questions that have attracted little attention:
<HBWhat about the children?
 Work proposals used to collide with the argument that young children need their mothers in the home. Day care was considered an unreliable, potentially harmful option. But the Administration plans to enroll mothers of 1-year-olds.
One reason for the changed attitude is that most middle-class mothers now hold jobs. If they have to work, the argument goes, then poorer mothers ought to work too.
There is also a sense that many welfare mothers, themselves young and uneducated, don't do a good job in the home. Work, the theory holds, will set a positive example.
But with a family values movement now pushing all parents to spend more time with their children, some advocates say poor women are also needed in the home. That is especially the case when home is surrounded by drugs, crime, gangs and other lethal lures. "There's such a double standard here," said David S. Liederman, director of the Child Welfare League of America.
Much depends upon the type of day care available. Noting the high costs involved, skeptics worry that poor women will be forced to choose between unreliable relatives and large, underfinanced public centers.
Pat Ruggles, an economist with the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, worries that bad day care will impede poor children, both intellectually and emotionally. "They're not going to develop into the kinds of people who can go out and get jobs," she said.
 
Where will the jobs come from?
 No one knows how many jobs a work program will need. A preliminary Administration estimate suggested the number could grow as high as 2.3 million.
But officials at the Department of Health and Human Services sharply dispute that figure. They argue that with improved training, expanded tax credits and universal health care most welfare recipients will find jobs on their own.
Perhaps, but the record is discouraging. The most successful training program yet studied, in Riverside, Calif., only reduced the welfare rolls by about 10 percent.
The Administration now argues that between 500,000 and a million people will hit the two-year limit. But even a work program of that size is an enormous undertaking.
Unions loathe such programs: why pay a unionized janitor $10 an hour, if a welfare recipient will work for the minimum wage? And politicians fear a big Government jobs program will prove costly and inefficient.
Supporters recall the Works Progress Administration: it built highways, airports, and bridges during the Great Depression.
Others are haunted by a more contemporary example, the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act. It created 750,000 jobs during the late 1970's, but many were considered boondoggles.
A confidential report for the Department of Health and Human Services sounded a note of caution. After surveying local officials, it concluded that creating 500,000 jobs was possible, but beyond that "the merely 'daunting' became the positively 'dubious.' "
"Expanding the program to 1 million slots was viewed as highly problematic," the report concluded, describing local officials as "tinged with trepidation."
 
Will real jobs soon follow?
 The theory is that a year's stint in a work program will build character, add skills and flesh out a resume. But the evidence gives reason to pause.
There were three well-known work programs for welfare recipients in the mid-1980's, in San Diego, West Virginia, and Cook County, Ill. Only the San Diego program led people to earn more money on their own. And the difference was modest.
In the 15 months after leaving the program, participants earned an average of only $3,802. That was 23 percent higher than people who had not joined the program. But it is nowhere near enough to support a family.
The author Mickey Kaus, an advocate of a large Government jobs program, argued that the studies posed the wrong question. The greater value of work programs, he said, is their ability to deter future generations from having children they cannot support.
"If people have to work for their welfare checks, maybe fewer people will go on welfare in the first place," he said.
