HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
The Great One's Greatest Goal Is Getting Close

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, March 4

 BODY:
His favorite goal always used to be the next one. But the prospect of his 802d goal, whether it emanates from a feathery deflection or a seismic slap shot, has become his immediate, and increasingly nerve-racking, obsession. Nobody in National Hockey League history has ever scored 802 goals. That's why it's a natural for Wayne Gretzky, whose supernatural skills seem perpetually undaunted by the unprecedented.
The actual record-breaker is still four goals into the future, but the hockey world persists in holding its breath and applying more pressure to the slender shoulders of the unlikely superstar, a willowy wraith in macho uniform, who has broken every barrier, be it statistical, economic or esthetic, of his sport. 
 "Wake me up when it's over," a bedraggled Los Angeles Kings captain said Thursday after enduring another anticlimactic evening on ice, this time against the Bruins. "I'm not blase about this one; if anything, I'm getting too nervous."
Gretzky, daring for the 61st time to shatter yet another record, is about to overtake Gordie Howe as the N.H.L.'s career leading goal scorer.
The trouble is, this quest for the final four goals is threatening to go on too long for the 33-year-old Gretzky, who has grown increasingly uncomfortable while what was supposed to be the thrill of the chase has turned into a vigil. Gretzky, who needed just 780 games to break the assist record that took Howe 26 seasons, 1,767 games and 1,850 points to build, is not accustomed to quixotic tasks.
Built like a greyhound in a business dominated by players with Howe's bulldog build, Gretzky can't imagine allowing Howe's record to survive much beyond this week's home-and-home series against Chicago.
Tempers, including his, are tightening. And Gretzky's equilibrium was further rattled by the news that John Candy, a friend and business partner, had died suddenly of a heart attack on a movie set in Mexico at age 43.
"About a month ago I was sitting around thinking about what I do when I stop playing, and I realized that it's just like Glen Sather told me when I was 22 or so, that your fun has to come from the rewards of working hard now because you never know what the future's going to bring," Gretzky said. "It didn't hit home then but it does now."
So now he is working on this record as the world waits.
The tractor-trailers carrying the equipment for several networks have lumbered along after him to every game for the past week; microphones and cameras are poised, opposing goalies' hackles are raised. Gretzky's father and mentor, Walter, called him on Monday to crab about his letting this particular pursuit of excellence drag on too long and turn into a distraction. At least that piece of pressure was welcome pressure.
It was the first time in two years that his father, still mending slowly from a stroke that nearly killed him in 1991, was agitated enough to pick up the phone and initiate a call to the son he once counseled daily. On Monday, he issued the same type of constructive critique that has kept Gretzky on the edge of his skate blades ever since his hockey genius first announced itself in a 372-goal peewee season for the Brantford Steelers in Ontario back when he was a scrawny 11-year-old.
 
Reliving Dad's Dream
 "My dad's dream was to play hockey, and he never really made it, so he lived his life kind of through me," said Gretzky. "But he always let me know I was no better or bigger than anybody else, and he would've cracked me me over the head if I'd acted like I was."
Tied to teams his entire life, Gretzky always made it point to be "just one of the guys." It was something he needed more than the goals, so he didn't act like a celebrity even if his talent anointed him one.
"Very few people who achieve the greatness he has have remained as respectful as he has to everyone around him," said Mark Messier, his comrade from Edmonton's dynasty years. "That's why he's truly an icon: nobody thought he'd be big enough, strong enough, fast enough or smart enough to survive in a big game like the N.H.L., but he kind of proved everybody wrong. As many ways as you can think of, he scored."
But history -- such a friend to Gretzky over the course of a nonpareil 15-year career in which he has won four Stanley Cups, collected 60 records and is leading the scoring race for the 10th season -- is in danger, at least briefly, of turning from enabler to albatross here.
 
Always Had Pressure
 "I don't ever remember not having pressure on me somehow from somewhere," Gretzky said. "I've had it both ways: externally from everybody's expectations and internally from wanting to prove anybody who doubted me wrong, to show people that, yes, I can do this job. The pressure is a fact of life now. As you get older, when the records stop being of the moment and start becoming longevity records, I think you get even more excited about them. At least, that's what this one's doing to me. Maybe I'm too excited about it."
Lately the Great One -- who earned that momentous moniker at 10 -- has almost gotten too antsy to remember how to score. He is acutely aware of what happened the last time he experienced a scoring block.
"The great turned to good for a while last year when I went 16 games without scoring a goal; I was just the Good One then," said Gretzky, who missed the first 39 games of that season because of a career-threatening herniated disk but made amends by picking up a league-leading 40 playoff points in steering the Kings to their first-ever Stanley Cup final.
Right now the world's greatest hockey player, a little worse for wear-and-tear after not scoring in a 6-4 loss to Boston, has drawn the curtains on the glare from a white winter afternoon, confronted a pot of coffee and collapsed on a sofa in his hotel suite. He's inked his jersey number, 99, onto the Band-Aid that protects the bunion on his right toe; he has signed his name, just for practice, neatly along the leg of his sweat pants.
 
Signature Gets Neater
 His jitters are turning him into an even worse doodler than ever; the bright side, he said, is that his signature is getting neater and neater. Whether a slap shot or a signature, practice makes prefect in the Gertzky household.
"My dad always told me that when people want your autograph, they don't deserve to get chicken scratch," he said. "Signing autographs is the easy part of all this; scoring goals is harder than people think, and to me, the biggest compliment is when somebody tells me I worked hard."
Gretzky is used to being in the glare of expectation, used to working hard for his laurels. Seven-hour shifts of pond hockey split only by a midday hot chocolate break on below-zero weekends will do that to a kid, particularly one who knows his mother had to settle for a sheet in lieu of living room drapes in order to pay for his $25 skates.
 
Record vs. Team
 But this record is starting to worry him because maybe, just maybe, it's getting in the way of his struggling team's scramble with the Sharks and Ducks -- those same franchises his high profile in Los Angeles helped put on the map -- for the final playoff spot in the Western Conference.
Gretzky knows he will break Howe's record and, just as he has done every other time such an honor has come his way, he will accept it with equal parts humility and hubris. When he claimed Howe's once unassailable assist record in 1989, he turned down the inevitable request to perform the ubiquitous "I'm going to Disneyland" promotion because he didn't want to commercialize a record both he and Howe, one of his idols, worked so hard to achieve.
More important to Gretzky than breaking the goal-scoring record is the grim foreknowledge that it will break his heart if his team, which this season signed him to a three-year $25.5 million deal that constitutes yet another Gretzky-made hockey milestone, doesn't make the playoffs.
"It will kill me," he said. "We just can't miss the playoffs; one record I'm probably the most proud of is that I've never missed the playoffs. To do that now, especially in the year that I'm breaking the scoring record, well, that would be bad. Devastating. My obligation to the Kings, and to this salary, which is astronomical and a little out of hand, was to make hockey go in California. But my priority is winning the championship."
To that end, Gretzky is tackling the tail end of this season, and the record, using a familiar four-letter word for motivation: fear. No in-your-face theatrics for this player, the one Howe referred to, with admiration, as a veritable wet noodle on skates.
"I always played in fear of making myself look bad, and with respect for my opponent's ability to make me look bad, and to this day I still play with the same attitude as I did when I was 12," said Gretzky.
 
From 1 Goal to 372
 The attitude was spawned when he was a 6-year-old on a team of older boys and it took him all year to score a single goal. Five years later, he had 372 in a single season, and the ensuing hoopla forced him to move away from home in search of anonymity at 14.
"It was so silly that I was 14 and had to leave my house and family just because I excelled as an athlete," said Gretzky, who drew the wrath of other players' parents and was a marked man in school -- where he did not excel.
Gretzky's first and last brush with high-level N.H.L. intimidation came in 1979 in his first game against Bobby Clarke's Flyers at the Spectrum.
"I was 18, and when I went out for the face-off my hands were shaking, and all of a sudden Bobby Clarke took his stick, cracked it over my head, got me in the stomach, spit all over the place, and he had no teeth.
"I thought, 'Wow, what am I getting myself into here,' " he said of the man he also recalled as his mother's favorite player.
"I went back to the bench and told Mark Messier, 'I'm going to be flying because there's no way I'm going to get hit tonight.' That's the fastest I ever skated in my whole career; the people there must have thought, 'Wow, is he quick.' "
There have been nights when he wished he could conjure up some Charles Barkley-esque trash talk backed up with some Barkley-esque brawn, but he has made up for his lack of bulk with a combination of skills unique to him.
 
Playing for 'Sweet Spot'
 According to his former coach, the Oilers' Glen Sather, no player is smarter than Gretzky: "It's like a golfer or a baseball player who hits the ball in the sweet spot every time. Wayne plays in the sweet spot."
According to Kings goalie Kelly Hrudey, no player is as generous as Gretzky, who learned long ago in Brantford that all those solo end-to-end scoring rushes made him the loneliest guy on the team.
"The most striking thing about Wayne, besides his will to win, is that he's the most unselfish player I've ever see," Hrudey said. "Before I knew him, I always thought of him as goal-oriented, but he's truly disappointed if he plays great but we still lose. He's accomplished everything a human being can accomplish, but nothing makes him happier than winning as a team."
Gretzky, who calls Howe, Maurice Richard, Phil Esposito and Mike Bossy "purer goal scorers" than him, will have this record, and others, before he's through. He would like another Stanley Cup, but if he believes that triple-digit scoring seasons are beyond him, he won't stick around to do a slow fade. And he definitely won't challenge Howe's record of being the N.H.L.'s only goal-scoring grandfather.
"I've kind of had my day in the sun, so to speak," he said, "but I think I'll always work. It's not like, when I retire from hockey, that'll be it for my life."
But first there is a goal, or four, to get, a playoff berth to secure and history-in-the-making forever looking him in the eye in the mirror.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Three Decades In Free Fall: The Sad Saga Of 140th Street

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Ray Wilkerson has been running his shop on West 140th Street since 1948, and feels a quiet pride in becoming, he thinks, Harlem's longest-serving dry cleaner. His walls are decorated with photos of generations of smiling children from the street, dressed in graduation caps and gowns.
But the pride goes only so far. Mr. Wilkerson has been trying to sell his business, but there have been no takers. This block, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Frederick Douglass Boulevards, has sunk, then sunk some more. 
 Once the sidewalks teemed with people, children cavorted on the stoop and the lobbies of buildings were attended by doormen and decorated with nice furniture. Now, nearly half the 36 tenement buildings are vacant or abandoned, and the others are only partially occupied and in glaring need of repair. Drugs and crime are rampant. Last week, the New York Urban League dubbed West 140th Street "the worst block in Harlem."
Of course, no one can say which block is the worst. But the Urban League is concerned enough to make West 140th Street a showpiece for a new strategy: focusing resources and attention on a small area to get the maximum impact. Last week it opened a satellite office in a decrepit city-owned building at No. 222. There, with a two-year budget of $250,000, it promises to work to organize residents and lobby for better services. If successful there, the effort may be expanded.
"I kept asking people what's the worst block in Harlem," said Dennis M. Walcott, president of the New York Urban League. "Person after person said 140th Street between Seventh and Eighth."
The street indisputably stands out because of better-looking, busier areas surrounding it. Just to the south is Striver's Row, two well-appointed streets of handsome brownstones. To the north is the Drew Hamilton development, now considered a well-staffed and well-maintained public housing complex, and the massive Bradhurst housing rehabilitation effort. Several other projects are under way to revitalize the area.
Just how did this once-thriving block get so bad? It began, old timers say, with an influx of transient renters. They could not pay enough rent to keep up properties, and services lapsed. By the mid-1960's, the old timers say, landlords began abandoning buildings, as they did elsewhere in the city. This accelerated in the 1970's, and has never stopped.
"There was almost total disinvestment by the private sector," said Frank Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.
Today, most buildings on the block are city-owned and operated. Some are boarded up and occupied by squatters and drug dealers. Others struggle to provide the barest of services, such as heat. "Those who are left can't afford to move," Mr. Wilkerson said.
And residents insist the deterioration has accelerated in the last decade.
"When I moved here in 1985, this was a nice block," said Daisy Durant, who lives in No. 227. "People lived like families."
Now, people say, garbage is thrown out windows, then picked up only sporadically by the city. Many front doors no longer have functioning locks. The block association is just a memory. Rats are common. Children, as much as maternally possible, are kept forever inside.
Capt. William McGuinness, executive officer of the 32d Precinct, said the block is indeed bad. On Thursday, 480 vials of crack were found in an abandoned apartment. Few people call to complain about the ubiquitous drug-dealing.
"The bad guys stick together on that block," Captain McGuinness said.
The voices of 140th Street tell the story.
"It's like we live in a twilight zone," said Bernice Woody, who lives with six grandchildren at No. 274. "There's no sense of community, no sense of nothing."
Ed Brown, superintendant of the city-owned building at No. 222, where the Urban League office will be, said a complaint about a radiator or roof leak generally wouldn't be answered for two months. "They don't fix up the buildings around here," he said.
Beth Reed moved to the street seven years ago to write a book about Harlem; she began a small program helping drug addicts.
"I at first thought of the block as a war zone, but then decided it was a burning house from which some can maybe be saved," she said. "In a war zone, you have a chance to win the war." DOUGLAS MARTIN

HEADLINE: LISTEN UP!

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
THERE was a time in New York when radio stations played a kind of music called rock-and-roll. It was the height of the reign of the WMCA Good Guys and Cousin Brucie at WABC, when Alison Steele was the Night Bird of WNEW-FM, when the image of a station was determined as much by the D.J.'s who picked the music as by the music itself.
 But that was long ago, before the Age of Narrowcasting, when market research and changing economics split the pop-music dial into a veritable asteroid belt of specialized rock formats: hard rock, soft rock, classic rock, modern rock, pure rock, adult rock, album rock and on and on. 
 And it was before other forms of music enjoyed by smaller segments of the listening public - classical, blues, traditional folk music - found themselves being crowded off the dial, too, casualties of a medium growing ever more vigilant about the bottom line.
 "The range of music focuses much more on the mainstream than it had in the past," said Barbara Malmet, an assistant professor of radio at New York University. "There was a time on the radio, when there was more tinkering, more experimental stuff going on."
 If anything, these changes have drawn more New Yorkers to the radio than ever before. Still, to some, the decline of classical music, the proliferation of shock jocks on talk radio and the growing number of stations specializing in every conceivable category or rock - are signs of a deterioration in quality and creativity, a turning away from the sophisticated music and talk that once was a staple of manyof the city's 70 or so radio stations.
 "Radio has been dumbed down, and what one used to get as fairly regular fare 30, 40 years ago is now confined solely to public radio," said Jules Feiffer, the writer and cartoonist, who says he spends much of hos workday drawing and listening to the radio. "The education listener seems to be told there is no room for him or her on the airwaves."
 The most recent example of radio's dumbing down, as far as classical-music lovers were concerned, was the sudden format change at WNCN-FM, which had been an outlet for classical music for many years. In December, the station's owner, the GAF Broadcasting Company, changed WNCN's call letters to WAXQ and its format to what it described as "pure rock," and in the process left New York with only one commercial classical station, WQXR-FM, which is owned by the City of New York, also offers classical music programming.
"I think there is a general cheapening going on, not just in radio, but in television, too, and it just carries over," said Leigh Harris, chairman of the Listeners' Guild, a group that was organized in the early 1970's to try to stop WNCN from abandoning classical music and now lobbies in behalf of listeners on a variety of broadcasting issues. Having lost the battle over WNCN, Mr. Harris says members of his group worry that classical music is in danger of fading from the commercial airwaves completely.
The current debate over a Giuliani administration proposal to sell WNYC as a revenue-producing measure has only intensified the general anxiety.
Lynn McVeigh, an associate professor and faculty adviser to WNYU-FM, the student-run station at New York University, said that commercial radio stations in New York were under increasing pressure from their corporate parents to turn a quick profit, and that types of music that do not draw large audiences or targeted listeners from certain demographic groups were more vulnerable.
"It is an era that is much more devoted to business than to broadcasters," Ms. McVeigh said. "A station is being purchased according to how much money it can make as quickly as possible. In doing that, you're getting a certain amount of homogenization on the air."
Still, even in this era of "narrowcasting" and "dumbing down" -- not to mention an ear- and mind-bending array of high-tech media options -- radio, old-fashioned radio, in New York can still be many-faceted and eclectic, a marketplace where fans of all kinds of music, jazz or Caribbean, big-band or Baroque, can find a parking spot on the dial.
"What you are finding with a real narrowing of the formats is that you've got a little bit of everything." said Ken Mueller, manager of the radio department at the Museum of Television and Radio in Manhattan.
But since much of this variety exists beyond the commercial mainstream, you have to know where to turn. To help the radio-dazed city dweller, The City asked several music critics for The New York Times to prowl the dial in search of the best bits in their areas of expertise. Here are their findings.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;
New Gig for the Old Gate?

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
For most of its 36 years, the Village Gate was a jazz landmark. Hundreds of musicians headlined there, from Duke Ellington, Aretha Franklin and Dizzy Gillespie to Stan Kenton, B. B. King and Sarah Vaughan.
Last month, when the Gate closed amid bankruptcy and eviction proceedings, its founder was already deep into a new dream: trying to find his musicians a permanent gig at their old stand. 
 Art D'Lugoff's idea is a National Living Jazz Museum and Hall of Fame. He envisions a performance space, museum, library, cafe and gift shop, along with lectures and programs for budding musicians. He has drummed up a City Council endorsement as well as name-brand support.
His advisory board includes Dave Brubeck, Stanley Crouch, Jules Feiffer, Betty Friedan, Lionel Hampton, Wynton Marsalis and Alvin Toffler. Stephen A. Briganti, president of the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, and Ralph Appelbaum, whose consulting firm is developing the Motown Museum in Detroit, have agreed to act as consultants.
Now comes parlaying such support into grants for feasibility studies. Mr. D'Lugoff said he had not calculated the cost, but Borough President Ruth W. Messinger wrote in a letter to him: "I expect to be able to offer some money from our discretionary funds to serve as seed money for this highly worthwhile project."
Nonetheless, the proposal faces big hurdles. In the 1970's, the New York Jazz Museum struggled in three midtown sites before folding. Some in the music business question Mr. D'Lugoff's ability to organize such a museum, considering the Gate's troubles. Still, Dan Morgenstern, director of the Institute of Jazz Studies at Rutgers University, said: "Art has nine lives and has always bounced back, full of ideas. Certainly the Gate would be an ideal location."
Mr. D'Lugoff does hold out hope of resuscitating the club, at 160 Bleecker Street, at Thompson Street. Its "temporary" closing came after years of declining bookings and attendance, soured investments and mounting debts, including back taxes. Compounding those problems, a new landlord is trying to raise the rent from $2,000 a month to $15,000 and has gone to court to break the remaining 12 years of the lease.
The Gate suffered from many factors, Mr. D'Lugoff said, including the recession and a reduced pool of jazz stars, as big names graduated to concert halls or retired. While some clubs have been hurt, others, like the Blue Note, say they are thriving.
"It's not an easy business," said Lorraine Gordon, who runs the city's oldest club, the 59-year-old Village Vanguard. "It could happen to anyone." As for the museum, she said: "It's a great idea. Just do it."
 BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA/CLINTON;
A Tradeoff: Trucks for Housing

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE 

 BODY:
It has taken decades -- not to mention a lot of political maneuvering and indirect, though fiscally powerful, Federal intervention -- but another piece in the Clinton urban-renewal project is about to fall into place.
Fran Reiter, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Community Relations, announced last week that the city had agreed to rehabilitate six buildings in the renewal area, from 50th to 56th Streets between 10th and 11th Avenues, and to meet several other requests made by Chelsea-Clinton leaders. 
 The agreement is a tradeoff with Community Board 4, which covers the area, for temporarily housing 60 sanitation trucks in the old bus depot at 30th Street and 12th Avenue. The city had faced losing $95 million in Federal funds for reconstructing the Williamsburg Bridge if it did not find a site for at least half the 120 trucks parked under it by Jan. 14. Most neighborhoods strongly opposed housing the trucks, but Board 4 agreed conditionally.
In exchange, the city acceded to the renovations and to three other requests: to help cut red tape for the Women's Interart Center, a local arts group that has been trying to expand its studio space; to remove a Sanitation Department parking location with 109 vehicles from Pier 59 by the end of the year, and to hasten the board's move to more spacious quarters.
"We're still pushing for our main demands: a commitment to consider the Clinton plan as a whole and to specify how long the trucks will be parked at the 30th Street site," said Ross Graham, who heads Board 4, which is to move into its new space on the 26th floor of 330 West 42d Street at the end of the month.
The Clinton plan, a community-sponsored initiative, calls for new low- or moderate-income housing while retaining a commercial-residential mix.
From the beginning the city and community have disagreed on how to develop the area, which was designated for renewal in 1969. Early on, dozens of buildings were razed and seven apartment buildings constructed with Federal funds before money ran out; many people moved out of the condemned area. The Koch administration then tried to encourage luxury residential development but was blocked by community opposition. In 1984, local leaders came up with the current plan, but the city dismissed it as impractical and too costly.
Under the new agreement, the six deteriorated apartment buildings, on 11th Avenue and on 52d Street, would be renovated with city funds once tenant approval is obtained. The cost has not been determined, but the renovation would proceed under the auspices of the Tenant Interim Lease program, which leads to tenant ownership, said Valerie Jo Bradley, spokeswoman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
The city has also agreed to begin the public-review process for the expansion of Interart and two other groups, Ensemble Studio Theater and Soundscape, which have created an artistic hub at 549 West 52d Street. The groups have a month-to-month lease because the city slated the entire area for demolition in 1969. Margot Lewitin, artistic director of Interart, said they have tried for 12 years to get a permit to build an eight-story rehearsal complex next door.
"It's a wonderful beginning," said John Glynn, executive director of the Clinton Preservation Local Development Corporation, sponsors of the renewal plan. "But it's too bad it has taken such a long time for the city to readjust to the thinking that neighborhoods do not have to be destroyed to be rebuilt." MARVINE HOWE
 
How the Deal Was Made
 The Department of Sanitation had to find a new home for 60 trucks parked under the Williamsburg Bridge or miss a Federal deadline, losing funds to repair the bridge. The quest, and the deals cut along the way, give a glimpse of how things get done in the city.
PUB-DATE: April 30, 1993:
Oct. 15, 1993: The State Court of Appeals upholds the ruling.
Dec. 30, 1993: City agencies, including the departments of General Services, Sanitation and Transportation, meet with Community Board 3 to discuss Seward Park on the Lower East Side. Board 3 rejects the idea.
Jan. 4: City agencies meet with six community boards to discuss Piers 40, 92 and 94 on the West Side, the M.T.A. bus depot at West 30th Street, Bridgemarket near the 59th Street Bridge, the Penn Rail Yards on the Upper West Side, and a site at Donald Trump's Riverside South project. Mr. Trump, it is decided, will charge too much. Bridgemarket is the initial favorite, but Councilman Charles Millard knocks out that suggestion. Officials turn to Pier 94 as the next-best site.

Jan. 22: Ms. Graham and Mr. Duane present a wish list to Fran Reiter, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Community Relations. She agrees to several points, including that the city renovate six buildings in Clinton's renewal area and that the garage be temporary; she gives no date for removing the trucks.

HEADLINE: F.Y.I.

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:

Big Yellow Letters
Q. What are those codes, in big yellow letters and numbers, that are stenciled on many city streets? The one I see most often is E-1. 
 A. Whenever a utility is planning to dig into the ground, all the other utilities are alerted; they, in turn, protect their pipes, cables and the like by placing marks on the streets showing where they are. E stands for electric, G for gas; you get the idea. The numbers have internal meanings within each company and indicate, for example, what type of cable is buried there.
 
Big Yellow Envelopes
 Q. Why does it usually take a large Manila envelope longer to be delivered in New York than a business envelope?
A. Postal technology has come a long way, but not to the point where large envelopes cannot stymie the system.
A standard personal envelope and the No. 10 business variety are both easily sorted by automated machinery, which, with its optical character-reading device, whips through unsorted mail and processes it efficiently and economically. Larger envelopes do not fit into the machine and therefore must go through a manual sorting device. Very large or odd-shaped envelopes, known in postal argot as "slugs," must go through the slowest form of sorter: humans who stick each piece individually into this or that slot.
 
Zoo Story
 Q. Why has the Children's Zoo in Central Park been closed for so long, with no outward signs of progress? Won't my child be in college by the time it reopens?
A. It may depend on how old your child is now. The Wildlife Conservation Society, which operates the zoo for the Parks Department, closed it in February 1992 because of "inhumane conditions for the animals, and because it was unsafe for people," said Alison Power, a spokeswoman for the society. "The buildings were dilapidated, the areas where animals were kept were too small, it was just not a good scene," she said.
The Children's Zoo had long been slated for restoration, and Ms. Power says that restoration will come to pass. "We are confident that there will be another children's zoo there in one form or another again," she said. But for now, she added, there simply isn't any money.
 
Midtown Why?
Q. Why is the 14th Street YMHA called the midtown Y?
A. This YMHA, on 14th Street at First Avenue, was started on the Lower East Side in 1903 by the Emanu-el Brotherhood and moved up to 14th Street in 1965. The origin of its name is simple: it was meant to serve the area from 14th to 59th Street. To have called it the downtown Y, members of the Y's board assumed at the time, would have suggested that the area it served ran from SoHo to the Lower East Side, said Fred Plant, a former president and member of the board.
 
Cab Riders' Rights
 Q. Recently I got into a cab with two friends and asked the driver to make three stops along the Upper West Side. His reply: "This isn't a bus." My cousin had a similar experience outside Madison Square Garden the other night, when she requested that a driver make two stops and he flat-out refused. Is this legal?
A. No. The Taxi and Limousine Commission rulebook says that all drivers must make as many stops as a passenger requests. To refuse to do so is as serious a violation as declining to pick up a passenger or to go to a certain neighborhood, said Bruce Schaller, director of policy development at the taxi commission.
The fines range from $200 to $500 to license suspension (after a third offense). Why do drivers refuse to do this? Mr. Schaller said he did not know -- "It's like asking why you had a hamburger instead of a tuna sandwich" -- but added, "The perception may be that a person will make more money if they don't have to stop and start."
But that's not your problem. If this happens again, you should take the medallian number and license number, both found in the credential holder, and call the commission's complaint line, (212) 221-TAXI. JENNIFER STEINHAUER

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Bed and Bronzes

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER 

 BODY:
"I HAVE a great big sculpture here at 47th and Madison," said James Knowles, referring to the 136-room mass of stone called the Roger Smith, a Depression-era hotel that he and his wife, Suzanne, have transformed into one of the more eccentric hostelries in New York. "I like to call it a hotel with an art bias."
Art is omnipresent at the Roger Smith, which recently emerged from a five-year, $8-million renovation. Hallways are adorned with changing exhibits; walls in the bar and restaurant, Lily's, are splashed with winsome murals; Mr. Knowles's abstract bronze panels, life-size busts and bold oil paintings fill the lobby. An antique farm table in the dining room is designated "the artists' table," for artists' get-togethers, and even the menu features "New American Art Cuisine." 
 New American Art Cuisine? "It has a lot to do with the presentation," the chef, Robert Giordano, explained.
Mr. Knowles, 50, painter, sculptor, classical guitarist, former rugby player and free-ranging philosopher, came into the hotel business late and reluctantly. In the 1980's, he was happily forging giant bronze figures at his foundry in Connecticut. Then in 1987 his father-in-law, Oscar de Lima, died, leaving behind the tired, threadworn Roger Smith.
Mrs. Knowles knew how to administer a hotel (there are 17 in the Roger Smith Winthrop chain, though the Manhattan hotel is the only one under family control). Mr. Knowles knew nothing about hotels. But he knows about art. They decided to revive the Roger Smith, but as a forum for art and artistic discussion.
Five years later, they appear close to their goal, both artistically and economically. The Roger Smith now falls into the category of specialty boutique hotel -- small, hip -- like the Royalton, Paramount and Chelsea. In 1987 its occupancy rate was about 65 percent; today, despite the recession, it is 74 percent, slightly above the local average.
"They have to work their niche to survive as a small hotel in New York City, which has so many giant hotels," said Neil Ostergren, vice president of marketing for Hospitality Sales and Marketing Association International, a hotel industry trade group. The art bias differentiates them from the other small hotels and makes them known to certain types of people as a place to go."
The Roger Smith's eccentricities attract mostly actors and musicians, among them the singers Nanci Griffith, Juliana Hatfield and Lyle Lovett and members of the bands Los Lobos, Midnight Oil and Soul Asylum.
Not many artists stay at the hotel, though they're offered discounts of $99 a room, opposed to the usual $125 to $160 (breakfast included). "That's because most live in New York," said James Fox, director of sales, adding that they do attend events at the hotel.
For instance, among recent participants at the hotel's bimonthly "brown-bag art lunches," at which artists, critics and gallery owners discuss their work, were Ivan Karp, a SoHo gallery owner; Barbara Toll, an art dealer, and the artists Philip Pearlstein, Mark Kostabi and Joseph DiGiorgio. In fact, the Roger Smith may be the only hotel with a curator on staff. Molly Barnes, who owns a Los Angeles gallery under her name and spends half her time in New York, organizes the lunches, oversees the hotel's exhibits and runs a newly opened art gallery, the Corner, in the former gift shop.
 Mr. Knowles, who has degrees from Yale and the University of Pennsylvania in painting and sculpture, sees art as a metaphor, a motivational tool, to encourage creative thought among his 90 employees. "I am not a hotelier, I am an agent of change," he said. "There is art throughout this hotel, the art of people expressing their creativity through their work. When you set out to make a portrait in bronze you have to first ask the mud what it will do, not tell it what to do." Mr. Knowles tends to talk like that.
At 6 feet 1 and 220 pounds, he resembles a rugby player more than a hotelier. An inveterate creator, he seems incapable of speaking without illustrating his thoughts at the same time -- on scrap paper, checks, bank statements, even the palm of his hand.
"This is a beautiful piece of sculpture!" he enthused about the refitted boiler room. "Look at those pipes!" The next stop was the laundry room. "See these people," he bellowed over tumbling dryers. "They are artists. Artists in laundry!" The artists nodded.
This is hardly your typical hotel pitch: "More than anything I want this hotel to be a place where good ideas can occur," Mr. Knowles said, drawing a circle with an arrow to emphasize his point. "New York City has a tremendous energy for ideas, and I want to create a warm and friendly atmosphere where those things can happen."
In the words of Willie MacInnes, a tour manager who stays regularly at the Roger Smith, "The hotel is really neat, no beyond neat." Last year he spent five weeks there with Midnight Oil. "It has a bit of a European warmth," Mr. MacInnes said, adding that the art lends a noninstitutional air.
The hotel's contemporary American decor -- with countrified touches like four-poster pine beds and early-American prints -- befits the vision of Mr. de Lima, who had named it for Roger Sherman, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, and John Smith, a colonizer of Virginia.
 The musical tradition at the Roger Smith actually predates the renovation. The hotel was once the haunt of Pete Seeger, Arlo Guthrie and Jim Croce. Perhaps the most legendary guest was R. Buckminster Fuller, who in the 1930's apparently found himself with no money and no place to stay. He was given free accommodations, sans bed, in the 18th-floor reception room. Tossing and turning, legend has it, he gazed up at the room's cove ceiling, covered with little triangles. And so, Ms. Barnes, the curator, insists, "That started him thinking about a geodesic dome made like that."
Visitors these days notice something different: four life-size Knowles bronze sculptures framing the hotel's entrance. "They give you a focus when you arrive," Mr. Knowles said. One New Yorker certainly focused on them last year; he was caught rolling one of the 400-pound pieces down the street on a hand cart.
Mr. Knowles's latest addition is the gallery at the hotel's Lexington Avenue corner, which specializes in younger artists who might not find space in traditional galleries.
"I would love to make this corner an art hub of Manhattan," Mr. Knowles said, dreaming, as usual, in exclamation points. "Wouldn't it be great to have sculpture on all four corners! It would make this such a special spot in the city!"

HEADLINE: Con Edison At Odds With Agency Over Power

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Setting the stage for a collision between two longtime partners, executives of the Consolidated Edison Company insist they will continue to seek a new power purchase contract with Hydro-Quebec, and the head of the New York Power Authority, which transports the power, called the utility's strategy "weird."
Con Edison, which serves 8.3 million people in New York City and Westchester County, gets power every summer from Hydro-Quebec, which has a surplus then. The two utilities have been negotiating to extend their 20-year deal beyond its current expiration date, at the end of 1998. 
 The Power Authority acts as a middleman, carrying the energy over its lines from the Canadian border to the metropolitan area. But now the authority, with an environmentally minded chief executive who took office on March 1, is discouraging an extension.
 
Low Demand Spurs Talks
 Con Edison, Hydro-Quebec and the Power Authority agreed in 1989 on an extension and expansion of the contract, but in the last few months, with demand for power pushed down by recession and with fuel prices low, all three agreed that re-negotiation was needed.
On Wednesday, S. David Freeman, the new president and chief executive of the authority, testified before a legislative hearing in Albany that New York State had more than enough power and did not need a new contract with Hydro-Quebec. The state's utilities might sensibly buy power on the spot market, on an hour-to-hour or day-to-day basis, he said.
He also said his agency should not be the middleman, although, he said, in accordance with Federal law it would continue to provide access to its transmission lines for Hydro-Quebec and Con Edison. The authority appears to be trying to create a political environment that is hostile to the contract, and it could also seek to hinder the deal by asking a high price for access to its lines.
 
Lower-Priced Power Possible
 On Friday executives of Con Edison, seeking to rebut the testimony, said they would continue to negotiate with Hydro-Quebec. Even though Con Edison has surplus generating capacity, said William A. Harkins, vice president for planning and inter-utility affairs, the utility might be able to buy power from Hydro-Quebec at a cost lower than making it here.
"We only have an interest in a contract we think we can write with Hydro-Quebec that's going to produce savings to our consumers," said Mr. Harkins. "If it doesn't, we ain't going to do it."
The 1989 deal all parties say is now obsolete would have been for about $5 billion. No price has been negotiated on the new agreement, but the price would be much lower, because it would involve about half as much power at a smaller cost per unit of electricity.
The revised contract would guarantee Con Edison 780 megawatts of capacity, the equivalent of a middle-sized power plant. Prices are still under negotiation, but Con Ed executives said that because Hydro-Quebec has such a large surplus of capacity in the summer, when its internal demand is low, Con Ed can rent it at very low cost, below the cost of maintaining Con Ed's own power plants.
Executives made their arguments in a conference call on Friday that they initiated.
 
'Environmental Concerns'
 Mr. Freeman, in a separate telephone interview, said of Con Edison, "It's obvious they have no sensitivity to the environmental concerns."
A fundamental principle of environmentalism, he said, was "to evaluate first and build later." But any deal that guaranteed Con Ed capacity, he said, would encourage Hydro-Quebec to continue a program of building new dams, and the environmental soundness of those dams is still under review. Consumers in New York State, he said, should not help finance construction in Canada before studies are complete on the effect of the dams on the environment around them, near Hudson's Bay in the far north of Quebec.
Some aboriginal people and environmentalists on both sides of the border are trying to stop the construction program, but the utility, which is owned by the province, has been pushing ahead, in part because of the economic stimulus that construction provides.
 
No New Dams May8 Be Built
 Con Ed and Hydro-Quebec insist that the more environmentally sound course is the contract they are negotiating, which, they say, would not require any new dams to be built. Hydro-Quebec says it will build enough dams to meet provincial demand with average rainfall, and that if rainfall is above average -- as it is half the time -- the surplus would be sold to New York. Hydro-Quebec has said the New York contract will not have any impact on its extensive construction plans.
If rainfall is below average, Con Ed would have the option each winter of sending electricity to Hydro-Quebec so that Hydro-Quebec would not have to draw down its reservoirs, in effect creating a surplus. Con Ed would get the electricity by burning oil or gas in its own plants, or by buying the power from other sources.
Using surplus water would reduce pollution in the New York City area, because Con Ed would burn less fuel, easing air pollution.
But Mr. Freeman said he opposed a long-term contract because New York State is "awash in power for the foreseeable future," which keeps prices low on the spot market. There is also a continuing surplus of natural gas, which in summer is a prime fuel for electric generation, he pointed out. "It's a bit weird to be talking about 20 years into the future," he said.
Con Edison, on the other hand, said the Power Authority might be growing reluctant to play middleman because environmentalists, including some elected officials, oppose new dams. Mr. Harkins said that the Power Authority derives no benefit from the existing contract, and its rationale for not getting involved might be, "Why should we get our teeth kicked in on this one."
But if an analysis shows a contract is good for consumers in New York City and Westchester, he said, the answer is, "because that's your job, fellas."
In addition, he said, Hydro-Quebec was certain to have surpluses, and it would surely sell them, rather than dumping water over the spillways of its dams without making any power. "All we're trying to do here is to have first dibs on that surplus energy when it's available," he said.
But Mr. Freeman said that for another reason it is much too soon for Con Ed to strike a deal. "They're free to pursue whatever they want, but the true value of the transmission in 1999 is something yet to be determined," he said. Summer is the peak period on the authority's transmission lines, he said, "and the rate we charge for that is yet to be determined." As a result, he said, Con Ed and Hydro-Quebec are facing "a big item in their equation that's a question mark."

HEADLINE: The View From: Union;
A School District That Has to Work at Spending Money

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WITH fewer than 65 children enrolled in nine grades, the Union Elementary School lavishes plenty of individual attention on its students. The school is nestled in a wooded area off a dead-end road in the rural northern Connecticut community. There are no houses or businesses nearby, and almost no traffic. Graduating students test well and integrate smoothly at Stafford High School.
"The kids are sheltered from a lot of what goes on in society today," said Cathryn A. Escalona, the teacher of the fifth and sixth grade at Union Elementary. "There's no violence here, no gangs here. The only thing you have to do here is teach." 
 But this year the state came in and ordered the school to increase its budget by 5 percent, or face fines and other penalties. The problem? The town was $26,000 below its state-mandated $634,000 minimum expenditure requirement. While that amounted to only about a half-mill in the local tax rate, it left some people more than a little annoyed.
 
'Why Did We Need Extra Money?
 "The feeling was, if we could run our schools and pay our bills and keep the doors open for 180 days, why did we need extra money?" the superintendent of schools, Richard M. Butler, said. "We do a lot better on some of the standardized tests than a lot of towns with a lot more money."
The town's First Selectman, Roy S. Bradrick Jr., who is also a lawyer, added: "Some people felt they didn't care if the state took us to court, it was ridiculous to spend it just because the state is ordering us to spend it."
As the chief of the bureau of grants processing at the Education Department, Robert Brewer, explained it, "The M.E.R. was intended to be a guarantee that schools would spend at least a certain amount. But it's now becoming a budget target in many towns."
Every year the state Education Department sends out letters to any school that is within 5 percent of its minimum expenditure requirement. A few years ago, that meant 10 or 12 letters; this year, it was an unprecedented 42, said an Education Department spokesman, Thomas W. Murphy.
Mr. Brewer said the problem was growing worse because the state has not increased education grants at the pace once promised, and because town tax collections have been hurt by the real estate downturn. In addition, many schools are seeing increases in enrollment, and the minimum expenditure requirement is based on enrollment.
"Four years ago, on average, school districts were spending 29 to 30 percent over their minimum expenditure requirement," Mr. Brewer said. "For 1993-94, we expect the margin will have narrowed to less than 15 percent. Many schools are a lot closer than that."
In many towns, in fact, the officials have grown to consider the minimum expenditure requirement as the standard for the school budget, and the school board must fight for anything above it. That, Mr. Brewer said, was never meant to be.
 
'Union Is an Exception'
 Should towns have to spend a certain minimum if they can prove they can provide a quality education for less? "We hear that argument sometimes," Mr. Brewer said. "But there aren't that many towns spending at or below the M.E.R. where student performance is good. Union is an exception."
Union is an exception in many ways. It's the smallest town in Connecticut, with 612 residents. While it's not a wealthy town -- per capita income is $16,667 versus $21,321 statewide, according to the Census Bureau -- it was ranked 129th out of 169 towns in a report titled "Indicators of Need" compiled by the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities. All the children come from families that speak English at home; very few students come from families receiving welfare.
Perhaps most important is the student-teacher ratio. Even with combined grades, the largest class (first and second grades) has 21 students, and the school hired a teacher's aide for that class this year. (The kindergarten has eight students.)
The school itself is a white building with aluminum siding that looks more like a large house than a hall of learning. There is an access ramp, but even in this winter's snows it was never shoveled -- no one needed it. The fifth- and sixth-grade classroom doubles as a town hall for meetings and other official functions.
"What we try to do is plan a class trip for the days when they need it for an election," Mr. Butler said. "Either that, or we move the class upstairs for the day, and double up."
Union Elementary is so small it does not even have a principal. Mr. Butler, the superintendent for nearby Ashford as well, comes in one day a week. He is part of an administrative council that includes two teachers and a secretary who oversee the day-to-day operations of the school.
It's a pitch-in-and-do-your-share kind of place. When Mr. Butler heard Greenwich was closing one of its elementary schools a few years ago and its books would be given to other schools, he and a teacher rented a U-Haul van, drove to Greenwich and cleaned out the library.
For many of the teachers, Union was their first job out of college and no one seems anxious to move on.
Ms. Escalona, who has been at Union Elementary nine years, said she likes the personal contact with the community. She stays in touch with the parents of her 18 students, through weekly progress reports and regular meetings, and the families are very supportive.
The only problem she had noticed was that with a combined class, a regular school day seemed too short. "You're teaching two maths and two spellings and two reading groups," she said, "and it's very challenging to get it all done in one day. But when we pointed that out they lengthened the school day by a half hour, which helped."
The librarian, Dorothy G. Davis, knows each student not only by name but also by reading preference. As students file in, she calls a couple aside to tell them of books she has that she knows they will like; without exception, they trust her judgment.
With so much personal attention it's not surprising that the children do well and that some people would be concerned about the school being ordered to spend more.
"The town has always funded us adequately. You'd always like a little more, of course, but we always get enough," Mr. Butler said. "You tell people we're $26,000 behind, and they ask why the state is bothering us. But it's an issue -- if they let Union get away with it, next it'll be New Haven."
 
Some Political Realities
 Mr. Bradrick said that in a meeting with a state education official, the first thing he was told was that Bridgeport was behind 5 percent on its minimum expenditure requirement, which amounted to millions of dollars, and for political reasons they could not let Union slide if it was similarly low.
"This is not negotiable," Mr. Bradrick said. "They tell you what you have to spend and you spend it. If you don't you'll be in Superior Court in a very short time. It would have been stupid to push the issue -- the case law is on the state's side, and the resources are on the state's side. So we cut the check."
But Mr. Bradrick said the problem would continue to plague Union as the minimum expenditure requirement keeps pace with inflation, probably going up faster than the town's tax collections will grow, unless there is a tax increase.
And towns cannot count the cost of transportation or special education towards the requirement. In a large city, the special education costs don't vary much from year to year, but in a small town like Union special education can cripple the school budget, Mr. Bradrick said. "You have one kid move in with special needs, take a $40,000 hit in special education, and it blows us right off the spreadsheet," he said.
 
Going on to High School
 Mr. Butler said another problem was that Union does not operate its own high school. The 35 students in grades 9 to 12 go to Stafford, where the town pays $6,000 a student a year, compared with $7,500 a year or more that other towns pay for high school students at other schools.
"If we were to pay $1,000 more for the 25 kids we sent to Stafford, it would have brought us up to the M.E.R.," Mr. Butler said. "We get a great deal from Stafford. It's kind of hard to brag about that, because you don't want Stafford to turn around and up the price."
The school ended up spending the $26,000 by hiring the teacher's aide for the first and second grades as well as buying books and new computers.
Mr. Bradrick said what bothered him was that no one checked to see what the towns were spending the money on. "Whether they spend it on a teacher's aide and books or on pizza doesn't make any difference. The state only cares that they spend it," he said.

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: NONFICTION

BYLINE: Charles Salzberg 

 BODY:

TRUE CRIME
ABOVE SUSPICION
By Joe Sharkey.
Simon & Schuster, $23. 
 If Mark Putnam wasn't the all-American boy, he was close. Handsome, athletic, intelligent, married to a beautiful woman and the father of two children, he was also fulfilling a childhood dream when he became an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. So what if his first assignment was in Pikeville, Ky., an economically depressed area in the Appalachians? The opportunity to shine was there, and Mr. Putnam, a straight-arrow go-getter from Connecticut, set out to impress his superiors. Early on, he met Susan Smith, a high school dropout and divorced mother of two, whose social set included drug dealers and bank robbers. Soon she settled into the role of F.B.I. informant. In "Above Suspicion," Mr. Sharkey tells how her unlikely relationship with Mr. Putnam resulted in adultery, then murder. However, the crime itself is not really the point for Mr. Sharkey, who previously wrote "Deadly Greed" and "Death Sentence." Rather, through his extensive interviews with Mr. Putnam and his wife, Kathy, the author gives us a close examination of the mind of an ordinary man driven to an extraordinary act. The book is sympathetic to Mr. Putnam, who is serving a 16-year prison sentence after pleading guilty to manslaughter, and he emerges not as admirable but certainly as understandable.
 CHARLES SALZBERG

HEADLINE: Alliances for Progress

SERIES: HEALTH CARE: SECOND OPINIONS -- An Occasional Series

BYLINE: By Paul Starr; Paul Starr, professor of sociology at Princeton University, worked on the development of the Clinton plan and is author, most recently, of "The Logic of Health Care Reform."

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
The obituaries are already being prepared for the regional purchasing alliances that are central to President Clinton's plan for health reform and Representative Jim Cooper's alternative.
But before the final verdict, the public has a right to know whether the critics have any real answers to the problems the alliances would address. 
 Today, insurers compete to avoid sick people, marketing selectively to the healthy and screening out those at high risk of illness through a variety of practices both crude and subtle. As a result, Americans' access to coverage and the price they pay for it depend on their personal characteristics, especially their job and health.
As health costs soar, people in the smallest firms, the self-employed and those outside the work force face the greatest barriers to coverage. Staggering administrative costs accentuate the problem: these Americans typically get only 60 cents in health-care benefits for every dollar they or their employers pay for premiums.
Rising health costs have also prompted many large employers to cut benefits or introduce a single health plan that restricts choice of physician. The employer's power to choose an insurer mattered little when virtually all companies offered a traditional fee-for-service plan. But with the rise of managed care, employers now choose which doctors and hospitals their workers and families use. This is an extraordinary usurpation: no one would tolerate an employer's dictating its employees' choice of schools or housing.
The alliances would shift the choice of a health plan from employers to individuals; they would not be insurers themselves but rather new gateways to the array of plans available in a community. They would use the economies of joint purchasing to cut the high administrative costs that plague the insurance market for small groups. And they would change the ground rules for insurance; any insurer wanting to do business would have to accept all comers, healthy or sick.
Under the Cooper and Clinton plans, the alliances would have to offer all qualifying plans -- with a few key differences. Mr. Cooper's alliances would serve only small businesses, Medicaid beneficiaries and those otherwise uninsured. The President's plan would extend choice to all consumers: more than 80 percent of those under 65 would participate in regional alliances offering a much broader array of health plans than individual employers can provide. Only the largest private companies (those with more than 5,000 employees) could run alliances of their own, and they would also have to provide a choice of at least three plans.
Also unlike the Cooper plan, the Administration's would require alliances to offer a fee-for-service option, in which people could continue to choose their own doctors, and would give the regional alliances and states the rate-setting authority to keep fee-for-service plans affordable.
Critics suggest that the President's aims can be achieved without the alliances, by such reforms of the insurance market as requiring insurers to charge the same premiums for all consumers regardless of health, employment or other personal characteristics. But the alliances are needed precisely to carry out those reforms.
If insurers can sign up individuals directly, they will seek out the healthy and shun the sick as surely as water rolls downhill. So it is critical that an independent body -- the alliance -- conduct the enrollment and prevent "cherry-picking."
If alliances are purely voluntary, as some Senate Republicans propose, employers with relatively affluent and healthy workers will stay out to avoid sharing in the costs of the unemployed and the poor. The secession of the healthy would sharply increase premiums, administrative costs (the alliances would need to market their services) and Government subsidies to make coverage affordable.
Critics object that the alliances represent a "new layer of bureaucracy." But the alliances would subtract more bureaucracy than they would add, eliminating costs associated with brokers and underwriters.
At the annual open enrollment, consumers would choose a plan -- and for most, that would be their only contact with the alliance all year. For the first time, benefits would come in easily compared, standard packages with uniform definitions and claim forms. If employees changed jobs while remaining in the same region, their coverage would generally be unaffected. This is simpler than today.
The idea of purchasing alliances is hardly new or untried. The Federal employees' health plan and the California Public Employee Retirement System have been buying health care for large groups of employees for years. They are easy to use, and their administrative costs are low. To be sure, alliances would have additional functions; for example, under the Clinton plan the alliances would determine the Government subsidies for low-income people. But that function must be lodged somewhere, even by the conservative proposals.
The great irony of the charge that the alliances would be too bureaucratic is that the moderate and conservative plans generally leave the current bureaucratic thicket unpruned and just add more complexity to it.
Lobbying on the issue has been lopsidedly against alliances for the simple reason that the groups that now dominate the health care industry do not want to confront the organized purchasing power of broad-based alliances. But if Congress doesn't create soundly structured alliances, it will have to find another way to provide coverage at an affordable cost.
That might involve opening Medicare to people under 65, as some members of Congress are now discussing. Medicare could compete with private carriers, operating an insurance plan that would be available to employers or individuals. But insurers would be likely to "cherry-pick," leaving Medicare with the most costly enrollees; that risk could be minimized by requiring insurers to offer any plan through alliances that they offered to employers, at no less favorable rates. This may not be what the industry wants, but guaranteed access to Medicare and private plans would be a powerful assurance to the public that choice will be preserved.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed; Series

HEADLINE: Let the Market Decide About Milk Hormone

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Farmers Eager to Test Drug to Get More Milk" (news article, Feb. 5), about bovine growth hormone, was very fair. I agree with and support "The Milk Brouhaha" (editorial, Feb. 10). But I must raise strong objection to "Make Them Label It" (letter, Feb. 21) by Michael K. Hansen and Jean M. Halloran of Consumers Union's Consumer Policy Institute. They are using misinformation to create a food scare. 
 Bovine growth hormone is simply the advancement of food technology. Its early ancestors are the tractor, pesticides and hybrid corn. Is this hormone bad for consumers? No. The Food and Drug Administration has conclusively proved that. The conjecture that there will be more antibiotics as a result of increased mastitis is a shamelessly false and demagogic attempt at creating a scare for political gain.
Right now if a farmer's milk tests too high for antibiotics -- and every load is tested -- the buyer dumps it and refuses to buy from the farmer until his milk tests clean. Most dairy farmers live a hand-to-mouth life, as it is, so the argument that they would jeopardize their livelihood and their families by using too many antibiotics or hurting their cows is blown-up verbiage thought up in a city office by people who have never met a farmer, let alone been on a dairy farm.
Is it bad for farmers? We're not sure yet. It will either devastate hard-hit small and medium dairy farmers (particularly in Wisconsin, Minnesota and Pennsylvania), or they will adapt and become more competitive. My feeling is devastation will prevail. Unfortunately, small and medium dairy farmers have been unwilling to adjust to modern economic reality. Vermont dairy farms have been reduced to a tourist attraction because of their inability to adapt to subsidy cuts and low market prices.
The Reagan and Bush Administrations responded to the power of the suburban vote and slashed farm subsidies 60 percent to 75 percent since 1983. The dairy program took the hardest hit. I disagreed with the depth of the cuts and the speed of their implementation. As a result, traditional dairy states like Minnesota and Wisconsin lost thousands of farms. Minnesota dropped from the No. 3 dairy state in 1980 to the No. 6 dairy state by 1994.
Small dairy operations of 60 to 100 cows were replaced by thousand-cow herds in California, New Mexico and more recently Idaho and Washington. Why? Market forces and advanced technology. That's what the American suburban voter wants.
There are real food safety problems in this country, especially in inspection of seafood and beef, and practically all imported food. But bovine growth hormone has been under intense scrutiny for 10 years.
Leave it up to the consumer-voter. Congress could have banned bovine growth hormone last summer, and it didn't. Neither would the Wisconsin and Minnesota legislatures.
Consumers want cheap, plentiful food. Market forces gave the incentive to bring bovine growth hormone this far, and only market forces can now reject it.
 
HANK SNYDER
West Hartford, Feb. 28, 1994
 
The writer has served as agriculture and food policy aide to Senators Robert W. Kasten Jr. of Wisconsin and Dave Durenberger of Minnesota.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 7, 1994

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1823 words

HEADLINE: U.S. DRUG INDUSTRY FIGHTS REPUTATION FOR PRICE GOUGING

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS with ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
When President Clinton stood before an audience at an Arlington, Va., health clinic last year and characterized the pharmaceutical industry as a bunch of price gougers, executives of the nation's drug companies had what their scientists might call a convulsive reaction.
After the initial shock, the industry sought strong remedies to counter the threat. In the 12 months since that speech, the drug companies have mounted a sophisticated campaign that has included frequent visits to Washington by their top executives, a multimillion-dollar advertising blitz, hefty campaign contributions to members of Congress and intense lobbying of the lawmakers who receive those donations.
 
Counteroffensive Moves
 Lodewijk J. R. de Vink, president of the Warner-Lambert Company, said: "The President's accusations put us immediately on guard, in a very defensive mode. We never anticipated that kind of frontal attack. We decided to mount a counteroffensive." 
 In the first 10 months of 1993, the pharmaceutical industry vastly increased its political donations, according to Citizen Action, a Washington-based research group. The drug industry's giving was up 20 percent compared with the same 10-month period two years ago, the equivalent period in the election cycle.
Steven P. Berchem, a spokesman for the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, also said the group spent $7 million on newspaper and magazine advertising to improve the "public perception" of the industry last year. The association stepped up the campaign and added television advertising in January and has budgeted $9 million for its television advertising and $4 million for print advertising this year.
 
Ailing Public Image
 The drug companies are still on the defensive, but appear to be gaining ground, as Congress prepares for the first votes on health care legislation. The situation is a case study of how one industry has been working to thwart an important part of the Clinton health plan, the effort to hold down drug costs.
Adding to the threat from the Clintons' decision to cast them as the villainous "special interests" in the health care debate along with the insurance industry, the drug companies received alarming news from their consultants last fall. The companies, which always portrayed themselves as devoted to saving lives while making profits, were told in a confidential report from McKinsey & Company that in the public mind they ranked as low as the tobacco industry, which threatens lives along with profits.
In response, some of the major drug companies decided that the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association was not nimble enough to counter the Clinton plan. They hired a leading Washington public relations company, Powell Tate, founded by Jody Powell, press secretary for President Jimmy Carter, to try to reshape the debate.
Their principal argument: Drug companies are the main source of new medicines, and limiting their profits would cripple the search for drugs to cure diseases like AIDS, Alzheimer's and cancer.
Dr. Sheldon C. Gilgore, chairman of G. D. Searle & Company, a subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, said the public did not fully understand the industry. "People believe that drugs are discovered by government or academia, and that we just sell them and make lots of money," he said.
After President Clinton's denunciation of drug makers, many people expected him to propose direct Federal regulation of drug prices. Yet such price controls were not included in the bill he sent to Congress in October. The bill did call for restrictions on drug prices for elderly Medicare beneficiaries and Federal review of prices charged for new drugs that offer a significant advance over existing therapies. To drug companies, these proposals were as unacceptable as price controls.
 
Winning Friends And Influence
 A recent Congressional hearing showed how the drug companies might be winning their fight. Several members of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on health warned that Federal review of drug prices would damage research to develop new cures. Almost all the lawmakers who criticized this part of the Clinton plan have received sizable donations from the pharmaceutical industry.
For example, Representative Edolphus Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, said he was convinced that the Clinton proposal would create a major obstacle to finding new drugs. "We can't count on continued research and development if we have this kind of Government regulation," he said, adding that he had received this message from many doctors.
Mr. Towns did not return telephone calls asking him to identify the doctors and to discuss whether he had, in fact, heard such arguments from drug industry lobbyists. In the last four years, Mr. Towns has received more than $30,000 in campaign contributions from drug companies.
The Administration's effort to curb drug prices comes at a time when radical changes in the market are already squeezing the profits of pharmaceutical manufacturers, long used to being among the most profitable of American companies.
Mariola B. Haggar, a securities analyst who follows the drug industry for Salomon Brothers, said prescription drug sales in the United States total $60 billion a year.
Ms. Haggar said the decline in profit margins for drug companies in each of the last two years was attributable to the huge growth of managed care. Drug companies find that they must offer discounts to get on the formularies of health maintenance organizations and other buyers. Formularies are lists of approved drugs that can be prescribed by doctors.
Drug company executives say that H.M.O.'s and other forms of managed care will soon account for more than half of the industry's sales in this country. "This industry has been extremely profitable, but the profits have been under pressure and we don't expect that pressure to abate soon," Ms. Haggar said.
Senator David Pryor of Arkansas, a close friend of the Clintons and a longtime critic of drug companies, said, "Their prices are unconscionable, and they simply can't justify them."
He added: "This is not like lipstick or perfume. These are drugs that people need to live, and now they're trying to brainwash Congress into believing that if they do not allow them to continue to set their own prices, they will give up trying to find a cure for cancer, for AIDS, for Alzheimer's."
But some members of Congress doubt whether the price restraint will last. At a hearing on drug prices on Feb. 8, Representative Henry A. Waxman, chairman of the health subcommittee, wondered aloud if it was just a ploy by drug companies to help them weather the threat of price controls.
The California Democrat said, "We have no way of knowing whether this change reflects a strategy on the part of the companies to moderate prices during the debate about health care legislation."
 
Fighting for Jobs In New Jersey
 The drug industry has many friends in Congress, but few so reliable as the New Jersey Congressional delegation. New Jersey is to pharmaceuticals as Texas is to oil, Louisiana to gas and Connecticut to insurance.
Pharmaceuticals account for nearly 60,000 jobs in New Jersey, the largest number of any industry. The state's two Senators and 13 House members count on campaign contributions from the state's drug companies. The industry's political action committees have given members of the delegation at least $400,000 in the last five years, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, a research group in Washington. That figure does not include donations from drug company officials.
The drug industry first flourished in New Jersey after the turn of the century when George W. Merck, the son of a German chemical manufacturer, bought 120 acres of land in Rahway. German and Swiss companies that dominated the chemical and nostrum industry soon followed. Merck, its headquarters now in Whitehouse Station, N.J., remains an industry leader.
The industry's power was demonstrated in January when the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce held its annual dinner in Washington for the state's Congressional delegation. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, told lawmakers that it was essential for them to oppose any elements of the Clinton health plan that would reduce pharmaceutical company profits.
Such a view is a bipartisan tenet of New Jersey politics. Mrs. Whitman's predecessor, Jim Florio, a Democrat, personally lobbied Mr. Clinton to forgo wide-ranging price controls on drugs.
The industry's entreaties to the Administration are complemented by the efforts of its friends in Congress. Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, is widely viewed as the industry's most effective defender in Congress. In recent years, Senator Bradley led a successful fight against legislation that would have prevented companies from raising prescription drug prices more than the Consumer Price Index and he helped retain much of the valuable drug company tax breaks for manufacturing in Puerto Rico.
Mr. Bradley said in an interview that the health of the drug industry in New Jersey was important to him as he considered such issues. "The reality," he said, "is that it employs the highest number of any industry in the state." He said he opposed price controls on drugs because he is generally opposed to price controls. And while he believes the tax breaks for companies in Puerto Rico are bad tax policy, it should be phased out rather than eliminated suddenly, which he said would provide an economic shock to Puerto Rico and the drug industry.
In his last campaign in 1990, Mr. Bradley received about $59,000 from the prescription drug industry, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research group. Mr. Bradley said suggestions that his positions were affected by such donations were ludicrous and it was for that reason he no longer accepts contributions from political action committees.
 
Objecting to Part Of Clinton Proposal
 President Clinton proposes to expand Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, to cover prescription drugs. Most drug companies agree that drugs should be part of the standard package of benefits under any health plan, in part because they can reduce the need for expensive services like surgery.
But drug companies strenuously object to other parts of the Clinton plan, especially the proposal for the Government to review the prices charged for innovative drugs to see if they were "reasonable."
The Government would also demand a discount, or rebate, on drugs dispensed to Medicare beneficiaries. The Secretary of Health and Human Services could deny Medicare coverage for new drugs if the Government could not negotiate "an acceptable rebate amount." For existing drugs, manufacturers would have to give the Government a discount equal to at least 17 percent of the retail price.
