HEADLINE: Fishing Fleet Trawling Seas That Yield Many Fewer Fish

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 6

 BODY:
For the volunteers who count fish returning from the sea to fresh water, this has been the loneliest year ever. The surging Pacific salmon and steelhead are gone; what the fish counters at the Puget Sound ship locks see when they stare at the glass wall separating them from the water is nothing but a reflection of their own faces.
Across the country, in Gloucester and New Bedford, Mass., the story is the same. After 350 years, the oldest American fishing area is largely barren of the great swarms of haddock, cod and flounder that sustained more than 10 generations of New Englanders and became millions of fish sticks. 
 The Atlantic fishermen have asked that the Government treat them like earthquake disaster victims. Last week, they honked their boat horns in Boston Harbor to draw attention to their plight. To some, it was a funeral dirge.
 
Echoes of a Sad Song
 From Chesapeake Bay, where oystermen are fading like fog in the afternoon sun, to the Gulf of Mexico, where grouper and red snapper are mostly a memory, people who pull fish from the sea for a living are singing the same sad song.
Government officials say most of the major commercial fishing areas in this country outside Alaska are in trouble; worldwide, 13 of the 17 principal fishing zones are depleted or in steep decline because of overfishing and pollution.
As for salmon in the Pacific Northwest, and three main commercial species in New England, the decline is catastrophic -- threatening to wipe out not only whole industries but also cultures and communities that depend on the catch.
 
A Year Without Salmon
 For the first time, there may be no ocean salmon fishing on the West Coast this year, a situationroughly akin to Georgia not producing any peaches.
Fishing communities in Massachusetts are in such bad shape that Gov. William F. Weld last week requested emergency financial aid from the Federal Government. Thousands of fishermen are in "immediate danger" of losing their homes and boats this spring, Mr. Weld said.
But aside from devotees of the taste of wild fish, consumers may not notice a shortage at the supermarket. In recent years, farm fish raised in pens in Norway or South America have flooded the market, driving down the price of fish.
In some cases, the lowered prices have led fishermen to harvest more ocean fish in compensation. About 40 percent of the nation's important saltwater species have been overfished, meaning more fish have been taken than there are young fish to replace them, according to a recent report by the National Marine Fisheries Service.
Who exactly is at fault in the decline is much debated. Old-time fishermen blame factory trawlers, boats the size of football fields that use sonar and satellite communications to track huge schools of fish in remote areas. The trawler owners blame small-boat operators who do not follow the rules, fishing out of season or using illegal nets. Environmentalists blame industries that have drained wetlands and dumped poisons into shallow bays.
Experts seem to agree on a few points. Pollution has indeed played a role, they say: Pacific salmon have disappeared because the freshwater streams where they spawn have been soiled or are blocked by dams. Restoring the streams in the Northwest may cost more than $2 billion.
But, the experts say, fishermen themselves are also to blame for taking more than the sea could give back in New England, the mid-Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico. "You can boil it all down to the fact that there are far too many fishermen and not enough fish," said Dick Schaefer, the conservation director of the national fisheries service.
Technology has made fishing so sophisticated that major marine areas can be cleaned out in a short time.
And the system set up to regulate these public resources is awash with conflicts of interest. Fishing in United States waters is regulated by eight regional councils, which themselves are dominated by the fishing industry. In most cases, the councils have been unable or unwilling to set fishing limits for themselves.
Critics say it is as if the national forests were handed over to the timber industry to decide how many trees to cut every year. The fishermen who defend the present system say the councils are weighted toward their industry because they are the most knowledgeable and have a self-interest in preserving fishermen's livelihood.
As a result, most fishing areas are free-for-alls, as fisherman try to catch as many fish as possible before a rival does. Congressional leaders say the councils will probably be remade this year as legislators consider reauthorizing the nation's fundamental fishing law, the Magnuson Act.
"If I had my druthers, these councils would be run by professional managers rather than political appointees," said Wally Pereyra, a member of one of the panels, the North Pacific Fishery Management Council, which covers Alaskan waters. "But as it is, if you removed people who have a stake in the industry, you'd probably have to excuse everyone on the council."
Like many members of these councils, Mr. Pereyra has a financial stake in what he is regulating. A marine biologist, he owns a share in a factory trawler that takes pollock from the Bering Sea.
 
More Demand for Fish
 Worldwide, fish provide more than half of all the animal protein consumed by people. As the global population has exploded, fishing has tried to keep up with the demand, growing by more than 50 percent in one generation's time.
But the oceans, which cover 70 percent of the earth's surface, may have reached the limit of what they can produce. Nine out of the world's 17 major fisheries are in serious decline, and four others are classified as commercially depleted, according to a report last summer by the United Nation's Food and Agriculture Office.
United States officials thought they could avoid becoming part of a global trend of overfishing when they passed the Magnuson Act in 1976. It expanded the coastal economic zone claimed by the United States from 3 miles offshore to 200 miles, effectively chasing away large foreign fishing fleets.
But with foreign fishermen gone, Americans began to build up their fleet, buying huge vessels and equipment with low-interest loans backed by the Government.
For several years, times were good. In the North Pacific, fishermen took in $1.5 billion a year for their Alaskan pollock. In the Gulf of Mexico, the number of shrimpers increased significantly, although this led to a large decline in the species of fish, like groupers and red snappers, that are accidently caught in the small-mesh shrimp nets.
And in New England, many fishermen had record years as they went after the bounty that had been claimed by boats from Russia, Germany and Spain.
 
Too Many Boats
 But now there are too many boats and not enough fish. Representative Gerry E. Studds, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, has proposed that the Government pay fishermen to get out of the business. Here in Seattle, home port for most of the North Pacific trawlers, fishermen spend as much time in bankruptcy court as they do mending nets.
"The problem of foreign overfishing has been replaced by even more serious overfishing by the American fishing industry," said Valerie Christy, a spokeswoman for the Marine Conservation Network, a coalition of major environmental groups.
With boat mortgages and equipment costs to meet, some fishermen are loath to limit their catch as a way of providing for future years, although some of their colleagues criticize that as shortsighted.
"The ocean is a farm," said Harold Lashley, a 78-year-old retired fisherman in Gloucester. "If you take away all the feed and the females, when it comes time to plant, you haven't got any seed. Leave it alone. Seed the ocean and allow the fish to grow."
To protect the fish that are left, the Government has closed a large part of Georges Bank, the continental shelf east of Cape Cod whose stocks of cod, haddock and flounder have been exhausted, and has approved a plan to restrict fishing days, reducing the catch off New England by 50 percent over the next five to seven years.
 
Signs of Life
 The measures were put in place only after the council that is supposed to regulate New England fishing was sued in Federal court. Similarly, on the West Coast, several groups are threatening lawsuits to force the regional council to protect fish species. The council considered a total ban on salmon fishing two years ago but did not proceed, and the region is now seeing the lowest number of fish returning to spawn in memory.
There are several bright spots in American fishing waters, primarily in areas with heavy regulation. New England lobster fishing has remained steady. Striped bass and mackerel have made strong comebacks on the East Coast after conservation measures were put in place. In Alaska, the nation's most productive fishing waters, the salmon catch last year was a record 200 million fish.
Some experts point to Alaska salmon as an example of how to manage fish. In Alaska, fishermen are allowed to go after the catch only after state officials determine that enough fish to sustain future generations have returned to spawning grounds. And there is a limit on the number of fishermen. Most other American fisheries are wide open, with no restrictions on the numbers of fishermen or the size of their catch. .
If present trends hold, not only will major American fishing areas continue to decline, but the culture that revolve around them may also disappear. The Magnuson Act requires fishing managers to consider preserving "a way of life" as they try to conserve fish. But putting that into policy has been difficult.
Mr. Lashley, the Gloucester fisherman, says his family has been in fishing for hundreds of years, but that will change. Mr. Lashley said his grandson, Michael Lashley, 28, "will definitely be the last fishermen in the family."

HEADLINE: Ukrainian Hints Deal on Warheads Is in Danger

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, March 6

 BODY:
As Russia's natural-gas company announced a further deep cut in supplies to Ukraine over the weekend, President Leonid M. Kravchuk suggested that the move could derail the deal to give up his country's large nuclear arsenal.
Speaking to the television of the Commonwealth of Independent States from Washington on Saturday night, Mr. Kravchuk said: "Fulfillment of all agreements, including agreements on nuclear commitments, is possible only if the economy works. If tomorrow factories come to a halt in Ukraine, and this is a reality if there is no gas, what carrying out of commitments can be spoken of?" 
 Mr. Kravchuk spoke after the White House doubled a foreign aid package to Ukraine, worth $700 million, in response to the former Soviet republic's ratification of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty last month and seeming commitment to relinquish its more than 1,600 nuclear warheads and become a nonnuclear nation.
At a meeting in the Oval Office on Friday, Mr. Kravchuk assured President Clinton that "Ukraine will fulfill its commitment" and announced that the first trainload of 60 nuclear warheads was on its way to Russia. Officials told the Itar-Tass news agency that it had arrived today.
 
Playing Its Trump Card
 In Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, Deputy Prime Minister Valery Shmarov tried to soften Mr. Kravchuk's statement, explaining that it would be hard for Ukraine to devote resources to disarmament while facing economic distress, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency reported.
Although Russian gas supplies were not specifically part of the three-way nuclear agreement signed with Mr. Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow in January, Ukraine is now playing its nuclear trump card in hopes of getting Moscow to resume gas deliveries despite Kiev's inability to pay $900 million Russia for previous shipments.
A clause in the agreement protects Ukraine "against economic coercion." But this guarantee -- if it even applies to Russia's request that it be paid world prices for gas -- does not come into effect until the Ukrainian Parliament ratifies the 1968 Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, a treaty that would formally establish Ukraine's nonnuclear status.
Russia's cuts of 1.7 billion cubic feet of natural gas on Thursday and 2.8 billion cubic feet on Saturday have left Ukraine with only about one-fifth of its normal gas supplies from Moscow.
As a result, factories have been ordered to reduce gas consumption by 75 percent so heat can still be provided to Ukraine's 52 million people through the end of winter.
Ukraine's current inability to reduce its debt is attributed to factories that have not paid the state for their energy consumption in months.
 
Western Customers Worried
 A long-term solution to Ukraine's energy problem is not simply financial: inefficient industry here consumes at least two times more energy than industry in developed nations. The dispute between Moscow and Kiev is also intertwined with a political dispute in which Russia has used Ukraine's $3.2 billion overall energy debt as a bargaining chip to gain Ukraine's share of the 350-vessel Black Sea fleet, which is based in Ukraine.
Russia's Western customers, primarily Germany, France and Italy, are worried that they too could be affected by a complete cutoff to Ukraine if the dispute is not resolved. More than 90 percent of Russia's natural-gas exports cross Ukraine, which could easily siphon gas from pipelines to the West.

HEADLINE: Ex-Mayor's Son Wins a Run-Off In New Orleans

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, March 6

 BODY:
Voters here elected State Senator Marc Morial to be their mayor in a run-off election on Saturday, apparently punishing his opponent for what they considered dirty campaigning. But polls suggested that they also had doubts that their new leader would be able to slow the city's economic slide, reduce crime or improve education.
The vote also broke along racial lines, in a city that is 61 percent black and 39 percent white. Mr. Morial, the 36-year-old son of the city's first black Mayor, won 85 percent of the black vote. His opponent, Donald Mintz, a 51-year-old white businessman and lawyer who ran unsuccessfully for mayor four years ago, won 91 percent of the white vote. 
 Final unofficial returns in the race gave Mr. Morial 93,094 votes, or 54 percent, to 77,730, or 46 percent, for Mr. Mintz.
In a primary election last month, Mr. Mintz led a field of candidates that included three whites and seven blacks. But on Saturday, said Edward Renwick, director of the Loyola Institute of Politics here, "There was a surge in the black vote over the first primary, and nearly all of that increase went to Morial."
Mr. Renwick partly credited good campaign work by the Morial forces, but he said another important factor was the persistence of accusations linking Mr. Mintz to anonymous campaign fliers with anti-black and anti-Semitic slogans.
 
Anger About Fliers
 Mr. Mintz acknowledged using the fliers in a national fund-raising effort, although he repeatedly denied creating them. By Election Day, interviews and polls showed that many black voters were angry about the fliers, and even some of Mr. Mintz's supporters said they would vote for him while holding their noses.
"I voted for Morial because he is black and understands the struggle of black people here," said Stacy Andrews, as she left the polls in the predominantly black Seventh Ward. "But I also voted for him because they were trying to discredit him."
In the racially mixed and economically diverse Black Pearl section, Pat Hamilton, a white voter, said she "lost a lot of respect for Mintz for using the fliers" but voted for him anyway. "I was taking a chance," she said.
 
Doubt About Improvements
 On May 2 Mr. Morial will take over the reins of city government from Mayor Sidney Barthelemy, who was barred by the city charter from seeking a third term. Eight years ago Mr. Barthelemy succeeded Mr. Morial's father, the combative and pioneering Ernest (Dutch) Morial, who is now dead.
Just as many voters in this city of 497,000 people reacted against the fliers, they also told pollsters for local news organizations that they doubted whether anyone could make significant improvements in life here.
Many seemed to recognize that forces beyond politics were behind the recent sagging of some of the city's economic pillars. Tim Ryan, an economist at the University of New Orleans, said the region's shipbuilding industry was an example of the bad luck that has struck in the last decade. The industry had a slump in demand for its vessels and off-shore drilling rigs as the oil and gas business declined, only to be hit again as cuts in military shipbuilding began in the 90's.
Through all of this, New Orleans, like other cities, has suffered from a shrinking tax base as businesses and the middle class moved to the suburbs, a 1992 study by the university's National Center for the Revitalization of Central Cities showed. But unlike most other cities it has been limited by state-imposed caps on taxing authority and barriers to the annexation of growing suburbs.
The city's major growth area has been tourism but that sector's continued growth appears to be threatened by increasing crime.
Both candidates said they were worried about the city's decline in economic diversity. Although the city's 6.1 percent unemployment rate is relatively low, most here insist with a religious conviction that far more people have dropped out of the work force and thus out of the statistics, which reflect only those looking for work.
Mr. Ryan said that even the increased employment many people had expected after the approval of a gambling casino in the city last year had not materialized as quickly as some had hoped. Because of delays from lawsuits and lease negotiations, the city is likely to gain only 3,600 new jobs from the casino legalization this year rather than the tens of thousands that had been expected.
In his victory speech on Saturday, Mr. Morial said: "Tomorrow we will start rebuilding the city in the physical sense and the spiritual sense. We don't plan to take a vacation."
Bob Tucker, the chairman of Mr. Morial's campaign, said today that the Mayor-elect had not "basked in victory," but had begun meetings to put together an administration and programs.
 
Last-Minute Swing
 Analyses of the voting showed that Mr. Morial's being the son of the city's first black Mayor cut both ways, because his father was greatly respected by most blacks for his assertiveness but was disdained by many whites who considered him brash and combative.
For some whites, this made the younger Mr. Morial seem to be a product of the old politics in the city, but lacking his father's savvy and experience. For many older blacks, said Prof. Silas Lee, a pollster and political scientist at predominantly black Xavier University here, the younger Mr. Morial could hardly live up to the political legend that his father had become to them.
It was only in the end with the issue of the fliers and a television commercial by Sybil Morial, Marc Morial's mother and a respected figure in the city, that older black voters came rushing to the younger Morial's defense, with one expressing the hope that he would prove to be "a chip off the old block."
"The older black voters were vulnerable for Morial, and they could have gone for Mintz," Professor Lee said. "But in the last month when they started running the ads with his mother speaking for him and having ads showing state legislators talking of his political skills and impressive record in one term in the State Senate, that helped. The timing was perfect, and it was perfectly targeted."

HEADLINE: Burmese General Bars Talks Soon With Arrested Democracy Leader

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: YANGON, Myanmar, March 6

 BODY:
The head of Burmese military intelligence, Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt, today ruled out early talks between himself and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the imprisoned democracy leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner, describing her attitude as "negative and counterproductive."
In an interview, General Khin Nyunt, who is widely seen as the most powerful member of the junta that runs Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, said he had sent senior military officers in recent weeks to meet with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. 
 Face-to-face talks between him and the democracy leader might be possible eventually, he said, but "this is a matter that is delicate, a matter on which we must ponder deeply."
 
No Timetable for Talks
 He offered no timetable for further talks or for the release of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who is in her fifth year of house arrest. And he repeatedly questioned her legitimacy as a political leader, her popularity among the Burmese public and even her patriotism.
"From what we see, her supporters are only from outside Myanmar," he said. "She has been portrayed as a great leader of the country basically by groups outside of the country."
Despite his harsh words, diplomats said the disclosure by General Khin Nyunt that he had sent representatives to speak with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi after her meetings last month with an American Congressman suggested that the junta was considering some sort of dialogue with her.
But it appears that it could now be months before the military makes a final decision about what to do with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, whose freedom has become a condition for Myanmar in its bid to restore full diplomatic relations and trade with the United States and other Western countries.
The possibility of direct talks between the general and Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was raised by the Congressman, Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat and member of the House Intelligence Committee who last month became the first non-family foreign visitor to see her since 1989.
 
Daughter of National Hero
 Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, the daughter of the army general who is considered the father of the nation, Aung San, immediately accepted the offer of talks and said that all issues were open for negotiation -- except her departure from the country.
General Khin Nyunt said today that it was impossible for him to consider a dialogue with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi until after full deliberations within the junta, which calls itself the State Law and Order Restoration Council, and within Government agencies overseen by the military.
"This is a very complex matter, and we will have to take many factors into account -- national politics, international relations," he said in his first interview with a Western news organization in two years. "This is not something that I alone can decide."
He said it was also important that the junta not be seen as bowing to the demands of foreign governments.
"It would not be good or appropriate that we do this or that because of external pressure, because the United States says this or that," he said.
But the general emphasized that Myanmar was eager for better relations with Washington, which has led the international community in efforts to isolate the junta over its human rights record. "We wish to go back to a good relationship," he said.
During and after the visit from Mr. Richardson in mid-February, General Khin Nyunt said, he sent "senior officers to meet with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi on my behalf."
 
'She Doesn't Think Much of Us'
 "Our impression is that she doesn't think much of us," the general said, "and so I think that she doesn't want to be serious."
He did not discuss details of the conversations between the officers and Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, except to say they had asked her "what it would take to fulfill her needs." Her attitude "on all these occasions was rather negative and counterproductive," he said.
General Khin Nyunt is described by diplomats here as a highly intelligent and calculating commander who is the first among equals in the junta, which assumed complete government power in 1988 in a violent crackdown on followers of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. His title within the junta is Secretary-1, and he is widely known by the Burmese public simply as "S-1."
Representative Richardson said after meeting the general that he was a "pragmatic individual who is sincere about wanting to resolve the divisions in his country."
General Khin Nyunt is considered a protege of Gen. Ne Win, the erratic, xenophobic leader of Burma from 1962 until his formal retirement in 1988, although apart from the loyalty they enjoy among their deputies and the fear they inspire among many Burmese, there seems little to connect the two. Where General Ne Win gathered political advice from soothsayers, General Khin Nyunt is said to seek out Western-educated economists and business leaders. General Ne Win enjoyed his leisure and made frequent holiday visits to Europe, while General Khin Nyunt impresses diplomats with his 18-hour workdays, seven days a week.
Unlike several colleagues, General Khin Nyunt has a reputation unstained by allegations of corruption. But there is grave concern among diplomats about his reputation, as head of military intelligence, for using brute force against opponents of the junta.
General Khin Nyunt speaks English, and he did not require translations of the questions asked today, but he responded in Burmese. His answers were carefully worded, especially when the questions involved a timetable for political change in Myanmar.
"If I say something and then it does not happen, it will not be good for me," he said with one of his occasional wily smiles.
 
Some Conciliatory Language
 At times during the two-hour interview, the 54-year-old general appeared conciliatory toward Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, repeatedly using the Burmese honorific "daw" when describing her.
"We still feel that she is our sister," he said. "We have no animosity or hatred towards her."
Still, most of his comments about the 48-year-old democracy leader and her movement were caustic and dismissive. He describes Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi as a political neophyte who allowed herself to be used as a "front" for Burmese Communists during public uprisings in 1988 and 1989.
"She rose up because of the Burmese Communist Party and its underground cells," he said. "She has no experience of life or work in this country. We deeply respect her father, General Aung San, but can you expect us to respect her only because she is her daughter?"
General Khin Nyunt suggested that even if he agreed to face-to-face talks, there would be little to negotiate.
"We don't see any reason why we should have to talk with her about the country's political future or economic status," he said. "There are 42 million people here, and they are not bothered by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi."
In fact, the general almost certainly knows that millions of Burmese are deeply bothered about her plight and view Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi as the country's best hope for democracy. In national elections in 1990, her political party, the National League for Democracy, won a landslide victory that was later annulled by the Burmese military.
 
Joined Democracy Movement
 Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who was educated at Oxford and is married to an Oxford don, Michael Aris, was living in the English university town when she was called home to Yangon in 1988 to tend to her ailing mother. During democracy demonstrations later that year in the capital, then called Rangoon, she was recruited into the movement.
She was placed under house arrest in July 1989 as part of a crackdown on the democracy movement -- which the Government has charged was actually under the control of Burmese Communists. Diplomats say 2,000 to 5,000 of her followers were killed in 1988 at the beginning of the crackdown. In 1991 she was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her efforts to restore democracy to Myanmar.
Sitting in a Defense Ministry reception room beneath a portrait of General Ne Win and a painting of Maha Bandoola, the great 19th-century Burmese general, General Khin Nyunt repeatedly turned to the question of whether Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi had given up her right to take part in Burmese politics by spending most of her life abroad.
"She left the country when she was 14," he said. "And after those years she would come here every year for three or four days, not more than a week, and apart from that she has been living all those years outside the country."
Her father was assassinated in 1947, when she was 2 years old.
Asked if Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was a patriot, the general paused a moment before answering. "Please think this through for yourself," he said. "She is married to Michael Aris, a British citizen; her two sons are British citizens." Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi considers her sons to be citizens of both Myanmar and Britain.
 
'A Good Front,' the General Says
 General Khin Nyunt said that in the late 1980's, members of the Burmese Communist Party, which had once mounted a powerful insurgent army, "started searching for a national leader, and they decided that she would be the most appropriate since she was the daughter of the national hero."
"It would be a good front to use her image for their aim to take over power in the country." She made the situation worse, he said, by criticizing the army publicly.
"She was making exhortations to destroy and disintegrate the armed forces," he said, insisting that the army's 1988 crackdown on her movement had saved the country from disintegration.
"The country was about to be destroyed completely, and we were compelled to come out to save the country," he said.
The army, he insisted, has no "craving for power" and will hand over power to a civilian-led government once a new constitution is drafted.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's followers say -- and most diplomats here agree -- that the Government's allegations of Communist infiltration of her democracy campaign are baseless, and that it is a spontaneous, legitimate movement intent on ending decades of military rule.
While some of her advisers may have had Marxist leanings, diplomats say, Communists do not dominate her movement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt, a leader of the Burmese military junta, ruled out early talks between himself and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the imprisoned democracy leader. But the general, seen here with aides, said talks might be possible eventually. (Peter Charlesworth/J.B. Pictures, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 4 High-Rises Torn Down By Newark

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 6

 BODY:
Four bleak high-rises that have long symbolized Newark's inability to provide decent shelter for its poor were torn down this morning, opening a new chapter in the city's struggle to rebuild its public housing after decades of neglect.
A rumbling explosion destroyed the four 13-story towers at the Christopher Columbus Homes, which were closed in 1990 after local officials, like many of their counterparts around the nation, decided that tall housing projects were ill-conceived social experiments often plagued by overcrowding, crime, vandalism and poor maintenance. 
 "This is the end of an American dream that failed," Mayor Sharpe James said at a ceremony before 3,800 pounds of explosives were detonated at the 38-year-old project, a pockmarked brick complex that glowers over Route 280 in the city's Central Ward.
The long-awaited demolition, shortly after 9 A.M., was one of the largest in the history of American public housing. It capped a seven-year legal battle in which housing advocacy groups demanded that the Newark Housing Authority build a new home for every one it razed.
 
A Harsh Spotlight
 The groups' Federal lawsuit cast a harsh spotlight on the authority, which for decades was so rife with patronage, corruption and mismanagement that Federal officials called it one of the country's worst. Graffiti-scrawled elevators often broke down, repairs were rarely made and drug dealing was commonplace.
Under a new executive director, Harold Lucas, the authority has made some strides in the last year. Last fall it was removed for the first time from a Federal list of troubled housing authorities.
As part of an agreement brokered by Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise of Federal District Court in Newark, the authority was allowed to tear down four of the eight Columbus towers because it had begun building nearly 1,800 town houses after years of delays. It will be permitted to destroy the other four after it starts a second phase of construction.
"This represents a victory," said Stephen Finn, executive director of the Newark Coalition for Low-Income Housing, which filed the lawsuit. "We are certain that if they had blown up Columbus when they wanted to, there would be no new housing today." But Mr. Finn said the authority still needed to make improvements, pointing out that it has about 3,000 vacant apartments out of nearly 11,000, even though it has about 7,500 families on its waiting list. The vacancies are mostly in high-rise buildings that officials want to tear down but cannot until they build replacements.
Before the lawsuit, Newark had wanted to pursue one of the largest public-housing demolition programs in the country. The city planned to tear down nearly 40 of its 46 towers, many of which had deteriorated so badly that they were considered unlivable. More than 30,000 people live in Newark's housing projects.
 
Similar Programs
 Other cities, including St. Louis, have undertaken similar demolition programs, and Philadelphia is considering one. Instead of tearing down its high-rises, Boston has renovated some of them, sharply reducing the number of tenants by creating bigger apartments and more open spaces.
The demolition in Newark today had an oddly festive air, with hundreds of residents gathering to watch on a crisp, sunny morning and dozens of city, county, state and Federal officials turning out to express their joy and relief that the towers were finally being turned into gnarled rubble.
Some residents applauded after the explosion. But not everyone.
 
'My Home for 20 Years'
 "I felt very sad when I saw them going down," said Annie Twitty, 52, the last president of the Columbus tenants' association. "I lived there, called it my home for 20 years. It shouldn't be something they should glorify. They still have a shortage of housing in Newark."
Columbus was built at a time when officials in many industrial cities thought that high-rise projects would be a safe and inexpensive way to house workers who moved north after World War II. But like the Cabrini-Green public housing development in Chicago and the Raymond Rosen Homes in Philadelphia, Columbus eventually earned a reputation as a depressing and frightening place.
"No human should ever have to live that way, no animal should ever have to live that way," a senior Federal housing official, James E. Baugh, said after he toured the Columbus project in the early 1980's.
The Housing Authority closed two buildings at Columbus in 1972, moving tenants to its other projects as it gradually shut the remaining six.
Gordon Cavanaugh, general counsel at the Council of Large Public Housing Authorities, a trade organization, said Newark faced perhaps the most daunting challenge of any major city in recreating its public housing because so many of its units are in towers.
"People in public housing are trying to basically take down buildings that shouldn't have been built in the first place," he said. "They have been impossible to manage properly. They are going to replace them with something that is more humane and more manageable."
 
100 Town Houses Completed
 That is the idea of the new town houses in Newark, which are financed by $200 million in Federal aid and reflect the latest thinking in public housing. They are to be scattered across the city so residents are not packed together, giving them more of a sense of living in their own home and making maintenance easier.
Nearly 150 town houses have been completed. Some are supposed to be built on the site of the Columbus project after it is entirely demolished.
To Brenda Evans and her family, the contrast between the towers and the town houses is stark. Ms. Evans, 31, an aide who works with mentally retarded people, moved from a 13-story project into one of the new town houses with her sisters and a nephew a few months ago.
 
A Small Playground
 The town house, at the corner of Livingston Street and Muhammad Ali Avenue, is in a quiet little complex of 20 homes that seems like a pocket of suburbia. The buildings surround a small playground on a patch of grass.
"These are so much better," she said as her nephew, Skyler Evans, 7, played on the swings outside. "They should blow up all those buildings. It's like you were homeless there -- everyone is cramped on top of each other. Here, my nephew can go out and play and we don't have to worry about guarding him."
A neighbor, Edna Lacewell, a former tenants' leader at the sprawling William P. Hayes Homes, said she was happy in her new town house. But she said the towers were still feasible, maintaining that the Housing Authority was blaming design flaws to cover up for its poor management.
"It's not a bad idea," she said. "It's a bad idea when the Housing Authority doesn't screen the families moving in. Now, anyone who wants to move into the complexes can. It makes a difference. I hope they don't tear all of them down. People need some place to live."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The town house, at the corner of Livingston Street and Muhammad Ali Avenue in Newark, is part of a complex of 20 homes that seems like a pocket of suburbia instead of an urban public housing project. Skyler Evans, 7, left, and Sherelle Header played on a swing set over the weekend. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK REAL ESTATE IS BACK
New York City's commercial real-estate brokers and landlords are unanimous: Buildings are filling up. Average midtown rents have stopped their slide. Landlords are getting more from tenants and giving them less. Some companies are even buying buildings again. All told, brokers and landlords say, the real-estate recession is ending. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
THE IRON AGE LIVES AGAIN
Ironworkers have had a slow time of it lately in New York City, settling for maintenance chores like bridge repair instead of building skyscrapers. But a majestic project on the East Side, the first stage in the construction of an $842 million addition to New York Hospital between 68th and 70th Streets, is filling the union hall and bringing back the swagger. B3. 

SHEIK REPORTEDLY AIMED AT ARMY
Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the Egyptian cleric who prosecutors say inspired a conspiracy to blow up several New York landmarks, told his followers "to inflict damage to the American Army," according to transcripts of talks with an informer. Fifteen men will stand trial in September in the conspiracy case, which the authorities say was aimed at the Hudson River tunnels, the United Nations and the Federal Building in lower Manhattan. B4.
 
KEEPING A FIREFIGHTING PLEDGE
A three-year battle to reopen an engine company in Richmond Hill, Queens, culminated in victory for local residents when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made good on a campaign pledge and declared Engine Company 294 officially back in business. The reopening silenced an outcry against a financial decision that neighbors say delayed the response time of firefighters and caused the loss of 12 lives. B3.
 
U.S. REPORTS FLAW IN JET'S TAIL ENGINE
A hangar examination of the Continental Airlines jet that aborted a takeoff and skidded off a runway at La Guardia Airport in a snowstorm last week found that one of its two tail-nested engines does not turn properly, a spokesman for the Federal agency investigating the accident said. B3.
 
MEETING DEFUSES A PROTEST
A scheduled protest by Arab-Americans in Midwood, Brooklyn, against the militant Zionist group Kahane Chai was called off at the request of a local Jewish politician. Instead, Jewish and Arab leaders met for 75 minutes in the basement of a police station. B2.
 
REGION
 
UNITED WAY TRIES TO UNITE
Faced with shrinking charitable contributions but growing demands for assistance, United Ways in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are moving to overhaul their regional association to streamline the organization. The changes will reduce the decision-making powers of the 32 individual United Ways in the region. B5.
 
CAR-SHARING EXPERIMENT ON ROUTE 80
A perpetual rush-hour traffic jam in Morris County may be relieved today when the New Jersey Department of Transportation opens its new "diamond express lanes" on a busy 10-mile strip of Interstate 80 between Route 15 and Interstate 287. The new lanes are reserved in morning and evening rush hours for vehicles carrying two people or more. B5.
 
COMPASSIONATE PAROLE TOUCHES FEW
The medical parole program, intended to let New York State's sickest inmates die with dignity near family and friends, is up for renewal by the Legislature. But in two years, only 30 of 447 applicants have been released, while more than 110 inmates have died while awaiting news on medical parole. Legislators and corrections officials say the law has been too strict, and they are considering ways to release more terminally ill prisoners. B5.

HEADLINE: Tokyo's Magic Kingdom Outshines Its Role Model

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: URAYASU, Japan

 BODY:
The air was bone chilling, but the admiring throngs hardly noticed one afternoon as a blue-eyed Snow White smiled engagingly and the Seven Dwarfs performed their antics, singing the tune every child raised on Disney fare knows: "Hi-ho! Hi-ho! Shinpai nai utai tsuzukeyo!"
If home is where the cash registers ring loudest, it would be hard to imagine Mickey Mouse and his friends ensconced more comfortably anyplace other than this bustling plot of landfill on the shores of Tokyo Bay, at Tokyo Disneyland. 
 With 16 million visitors last year, each spending on average about $85, the park, less than 10 miles from downtown Tokyo, has surpassed the original Magic Kingdoms in the United States in attendance.
Indeed, the way the Dwarfs' song has been translated into Japanese is apt -- "Don't worry about a thing, let's continue singing!"
What a contrast with the financial train wreck outside Paris known as Euro Disneyland, where the only thing park officials are singing these days is the blues.
Euro Disneyland, which opened in the spring of 1992 with soaring expectations, reported a $905 million loss for the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, and it lost $94 million more in the three months after that. Its parent, the Walt Disney Company in California, took a $350 million charge last year as a result.
Back in Japan, a market that Disney entered a decade ago with misgivings, it is a different story entirely.
The Oriental Land Company, the owner of Tokyo Disneyland, enjoyed a pretax profit of $202 million in the fiscal year that ended last March 31. And that was in the middle of the worst recession here since the end of World War II.
 
Translating American Icons
 A look at these two overseas parks offers some harsh lessons in the vexing uncertainty of translating American icons into other cultures, and in how important timing can be for such overseas moves. As much as it has been overshadowed by the European disaster, and as different as Japan is from the West, the 11-year-old Tokyo theme park is an enormous success. Increasingly, it is drawing affluent young people from all over Asia.
No, Cinderella does not wear a kimono here, and Winnie the Pooh has not forsaken his beloved honey for sushi. In fact, except for some subtle but telling changes, Tokyo Disneyland is a near replica of the American original.
Almost all the signs are in English, with occasional lines of Japanese and, now that other Asians are coming here, Chinese. The white-and-red Japanese flag is never flown, but various versions of the Stars and Stripes flutter from atop reproductions of American-style buildings.
It is so sanitized and precise in its depiction of an unthreatening, fantasy America that, in an odd sort of way, the park has become totally Japanese. And that, of course, is just the way the Japanese want it. Indeed, the park is reminiscent of the traditional Japanese garden, which reproduces a tightly confined version of nature that is supposed to be more satisfying and perfect than the real thing.
 
Enjoying the 'Japanese Dream'
 When Japanese come to Tokyo Disneyland, said Masako Notoji, a professor at Tokyo University who has written extensively on the peculiar hold Tokyo Disneyland exercises over people here, "they are enjoying not the American Dream, but their own Japanese Dream."
Some here even suggest that the managers of this park pull off the Disney ideal better than their American mentors.
"This might be the most perfect Disneyland in the world," Sanshiro Kobayashi, a spokesman for the theme park, said. "Because of the Japanese character, our park is probably a little cleaner."
If this contrast between the fortunes of the European and Japanese theme parks seems confusing, you have plenty of company. The Walt Disney Company studied the Japanese and European sites extensively, and yet it still failed to anticipate the enthusiasm here and the difficulties in France. That has cost it dearly.
"I used to say that cultures have no boundaries," said Noboru Kamisawa, executive vice president of Oriental Land. "But look at Euro Disneyland. Now I think that there may be cases where Disney is not accepted so readily."
 
A Hard Sell at First
 In fact, things began here on a shaky note. When Oriental Land first brought the idea of building a Magic Kingdom in Japan to Disney executives two decades ago, it was a hard sell, according to Mr. Kamisawa.
At that time, Oriental Land was a struggling developer, trying to figure out how to make some money from a large tract of landfill it owned just a few miles outside of central Tokyo. The privately held company was formed by the Mitsui Real Estate Development Company and the Keisei Electric Railway Company, who remain its principal owners.
Because of a deal with a local township, Oriental Land was obliged to use the plot for a public leisure activity, but it had failed to come up with any workable plans. Mr. Kamisawa said the company had gone to Disney in California, desperate for help in running a big theme park.
After some persuading, a competition with another site near Mount Fuji and several years of delays, Disney finally decided to go ahead with the project here. But it took a cautious course and rejected a chance to buy an interest in the park. That decision has cost the company hundreds of millions of dollars.
"I think Disney regretted that they refused our offer," Mr. Kamisawa said with more than a touch of understatement. "I think they had this in mind when they decided to take an interest in Euro Disneyland."
Disney has control over many aspects of the Tokyo park's design and operations, but it only collects royalties from the park's intake -- about 10 percent of the revenue from admission and rides, and 5 percent on the sale of food, drinks and souvenirs.
To make things worse, Disney also hurt itself by cashing in early on anticipated future royalties. In 1988, it arranged a complex financial transaction, selling its rights to the park's future royalties. It received $700 million up front for 20 years worth of royalties.
The company refuses to comment on the transaction, but reports at the time said the deal had locked it into an exchange rate of 124 yen to the dollar. The dollar has since declined sharply, below 105 yen recently.
That movement would have sharply increased the dollar-denominated profits Disney would have earned. But because of the transaction, it appears to have forgone such gains.
Oriental Land remains a privately held company, but its principal owners have reportedly agreed to raise fresh capital and list its shares publicly next year to finance a large addition. The company is planning to expand the site by constructing a large marine park, also in cooperation with Disney.
Who would have thought a people whose history is a tapestry of samurai warriors, rice farmers and Buddhism would have taken so quickly to Mark Twain, the Old West and Peter Pan? And who would have thought that Europeans would be so much less enamored of the Disney retinue?
Ms. Notoji explains. "To Japanese, the fakeness of Disneyland is not evident because they only had fantasy images of these things before," she said. "Europeans see the fakeness because they have their own real castles, and many of the Disney characters come from European folk tales."
Even Oriental Land misjudged to some extent. The company built a pavilion here, where it shows a movie on how contact with foreign cultures has influenced Japan over the centuries. The show is nearly deserted much of the time.
 
Superb Timing
 But a few yards away, another Tokyo Disneyland feature is usually packed -- a shop filled with souvenirs from the other Magic Kingdoms, catering to the Japanese traveler's passion for purchasing mementos to give away as gifts at home.
Tokyo Disneyland has also benefited from superb timing -- one of the reasons, analysts say, that Euro Disneyland has done so poorly. While the European Magic Kingdom opened in the midst of a deep recession, the Tokyo park opened in 1983, early in one of the most economically vibrant decades in recent Japanese history.
"The 1980's was a decade of great economic affluence and an era when Japanese society started to feel a part of world culture," Ms. Notoji of Tokyo University said. "Tokyo Disneyland really became a symbol for many people of Japan's entry into world culture."
Mr. Kamisawa of Oriental Land added: "When people looked for a model of an affluent society at that time, they looked to the United States. It was as natural for us to enjoy Disneyland as it was for Japanese to go to McDonald's."
As it happened, McDonald's was establishing itself around the same time as Japan's largest fast-food chain.
"It was like we were buying Disneyland," Ms. Notoji said. "We took the foreignness out of it and digested it. It came out as something with an American character, but for the Japanese it is Japanese."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Euro Disney Debt Talks
 PARIS, March 6 (Reuters) -- Banks that are creditors to Euro Disney said last week that there had been progress in talks aimed at reaching a rescue package for the debt-burdened theme park outside Paris. The park's debt amounts to $3.61 billion.
 A report by the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick found recent business and management measures taken by Euro Disney were on the right track, the banks said.
 Euro Disney recently adopted measures to shore up business, like cutting the entry price to visitors in the off-peak period. It laid off some 950 workers late last year to reduce costs.

HEADLINE: Big Decisions Before Spring Planting

SERIES: A Year on the Farm: First of a series of occasional articles on one family's business.

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BROADLANDS, Ill.

 BODY:
It is more than two months before David Rothermel starts running flat out to plant corn and soybeans on nearly 3,000 acres here in central Illinois, but the tall 39-year-old farmer with the neatly trimmed beard is still pretty busy by most people's standards.
There are hours spent on big decisions, like which strains he will plant, how he will spend close to $100,000 on fertilizer and a similar amount on chemicals, and how he will market his crops. Many more hours are gobbled up by smaller chores, like a trip last week to Paxton, Ill., to get an irrigation engine repaired. 
 Whether it all pays off will not matter much outside the small circle of two full-time employees, investors who own a large part of his farm and, of course, the rest of his family -- his wife, Judith, and their daughters, Christine, 9, and Patricia, 11.
 
 
Willingness to Innovate
 But in the longer term, the world clearly needs smart decisions by American farmers like Mr. Rothermel, who have large operations and a willingness to innovate.
"We have to grow as much food worldwide in the next 40 years as we have in the last 14,000," said Dean Kleckner, head of the Farm Bureau, a group based in Park Ridge, Ill., with more than four million members, including Mr. Rothermel.
The New York Times will be following this year's planning, labor and results on the Rothermel farm in a series of articles running through December. The Rothermel home -- a white tree-sheltered two-story farmhouse, which the family shares with a golden retriever and assorted cats -- was built 50 years ago when Mr. Rothermel's grandfather was farming the rich land here, about 150 miles south of Chicago.
About 98 percent of American farms are still operated by families like the Rothermels, but there are far fewer farmers and far greater differences among them than Mr. Rothermel's grandfather could have imagined.
Indeed, while policy makers in Washington and some farm advocacy groups talk of a mythical "average family farmer," agricultural economists say attempts to draw useful insights from such averaging are doomed by the disparities in size, specialization, and most of all, between those who rely largely on their farms for income and the majority who have substantial nonfarm earnings.
Mr. Rothermel is part of a crucial minority that operates farms big enough to generate annual revenues of more than $500,000. Families like the Rothermels owned slightly more than 2 percent of the nation's farms in 1992, but accounted for more than 35 percent of the output as measured in cash receipts. Farms that are almost as large accounted for another big chunk, so that the top 5 percent, with revenues of $250,000 and more, accounted for more than half the total output.
The larger farms are not only dominating production but are also the quickest to adopt new technology. And they are leading the way toward what some experts call the industrialization of agriculture, a process in which more farmers work directly under contract to food processors.
The trend is farthest along in the poultry and hog segments, but in regions where food processors have set up big purchasing stations, as Frito-Lay has done just north of here, in Sydney, Ill., large grain farmers have also begun to grow much if not all of their crops for the processors.
The size of Mr. Rothermel's operation offers little protection from the swings in income that characterize most forms of farming. In recent years his operating income has ranged from a drought-driven loss of $12,000 to a profit of more than $150,000. Mr. Rothermel's margin for error may be thinner than usual this year. The storms that caused widespread floods in the western reaches of the Corn Belt last year also pelted eastern Illinois, leaving much of his farm wetter than normal.
That is just one of his worries. Fertilizer, seed and pesticide prices have inched up. The contract he was offered for this year's crop by Frito-Lay, the snack food subsidiary of Pepsico Inc. that bought most of his corn last year, left less room than ever for profit. Still, the calm-mannered Mr. Rothermel is quietly upbeat.
"I typically go into the year as an optimist," Mr. Rothermel said. "Most farmers do."
 
 
Better Chance
 Mr. Rothermel stands a better chance than most farmers of seeing his optimism rewarded. Through smart real estate investments after the drought in 1988, financed largely through a partnership with a childhood friend, longstanding relationships with a family in Chicago that owns farmland and access to land owned by his father and father-in-law, Mr. Rothermel owns or rents 2,900 acres in a 100-mile stretch running north from here to Dwight, Ill.
While a few Illinois farms are bigger than 10,000 acres, Mr. Rothermel's total is still about five times larger than the average for the state. That gives him plenty of opportunity to use more efficient equipment and strike better bargains with suppliers than most of his peers. And there are fringe benefits, like a recent vacation to Las Vegas, Nev., paid for by Trisler Seed Farms Inc. Trisler is a Fairmount, Ill.-based seed company from which Mr. Rothermel buys enough seed to qualify as a dealer, even though he rarely sells a single bag to his neighbors.
Mr. Rothermel's track record has helped make him a preferred supplier of corn for Frito-Lay and seed companies. Such contract crops do not yield as much an acre because they require specific seeds to be used, but they are priced at premiums to the market and usually are more profitable.
One hub of winter activity is the Rothermels' home office, where they watch as prices, weather and news bulletins from a farm computer service zip across their computer screens. In recent weeks, Mr. Rothermel has begun selling call options on the Chicago Board of Trade, in essence putting an upper limit on how much he can profit from a part of his crop in return for payments now from those buying the options.
 
 
Vast Knowledge
 "Farmers today spend a lot more time on marketing and financial decisions than in the past," Mitch Morehart, an agricultural economist with the United States Department of Agriculture, said. "The knowledge you have to have to be really successful is vast."
The biggest decision for Mr. Rothermel this winter was probably the one he made in early February to contract with Frito-Lay for 120,000 bushels of corn this year, just a third of the amount the company had offered to buy.
"Frito was paying $1 over the Board of Trade price for white corn when they started here in the 1980's, but now it's down to 30 cents for white corn and just 10 cents for yellow corn," Mr. Rothermel said. While praising Frito-Lay's local managers, he complained that the pricing of the snack food giant, based in Plano, Tex., seemed to be driven by "number crunchers down there who don't know anything about growing corn."
Part of Mr. Rothermel's calculation that Frito-Lay's price had become only marginally beneficial was his belief that he could get substantially higher yields and better tolerance of different weather conditions from newer seed varieties offered by companies like Pioneer Hi-Bred International than from the seeds on Frito-Lay's authorized list. That list is updated each year, but it is built from varieties that have been around long enough to have proven track records of producing corn with the characteristics that Frito-Lay needs to run its processing plants most efficiently.
Another consideration is that Mr. Rothermel had faced a need to spray more pesticides and other chemicals on fields where he had produced corn year after year. By cutting back on his contract with Frito-Lay, he can rotate some of the fields to soybeans, which will wipe out many of the corn-eating insects that have accumulated in his fields. Rotation is especially attractive now because soybean prices are higher than they have been in several years.
Mr. Rothermel said he and other local farmers had talked about collective bargaining with companies like Frito-Lay or forming tighter affiliations with processors. Neither option is an entirely comfortable one given the traditional penchant of farmers for making their own decisions. "It's not in our nature," Mr. Rothermel said of unionizing.
Mr. Rothermel's decision to cut back on his commitment to Frito-Lay encouraged other negotiations like those that led to a seed corn contract with Crow's Hybrid Corn Company, covering more than 400 acres, nearly as much as the total acreage of an average Illinois farm. Each contract creates spinoff tasks. Mr. Rothermel, for example, has already begun calling his neighbors to find out what they will be planting in nearby fields so he can figure out how many breakrows he must plant around the seed corn to make sure it is protected from unwanted pollen.
It does not take many such details to spell the difference between success and failure, according to Danny A. Klinefelter, a professor at Texas A & M's Department of Agricultural Economics who studied the factors that separated a group of top farmers, netting an average of $50,000 annually, from another group that lost $25,000 annually over a six-year period in the 1980's. In most categories, from yield to input costs, the performance difference averaged 5 percent or less.
"I liken it to the .300 hitter in baseball," Professor Klinefelter said. "He only gets one more hit every 20 times at bat than the .250 hitter, but he's an all-star."
In agriculture though, even the best prepared performers cannot get all-star output without plenty of luck. What Mr. Rothermel is hoping for most from now until planting in May is several long stretches of dry weather.

HEADLINE: United Way Affiliates Plan Changes in Regional Governing Board

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH 

 BODY:
Faced with shrinking charitable contributions but growing demands for assistance, United Way affiliates in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are moving to overhaul their regional association to streamline the organization.
Advocates of the proposed reorganization hope it will raise more money and trim operating costs, but the changes are also likely to draw some objections since they will reduce the decision-making powers of the 32 individual United Way affiliates in the region. 
 The proposed changes in the United Way of Tri-State organization will give the leaders of major corporations more seats on the governing board, which decides how funds are collected and then distributed through the 32 local United Ways. The money helps support 1,700 health and human service agencies including those providing child care, drug rehabilitation and help for the disabled and elderly.
 
A Wider Outlook
 Critics of the current system say it encourages each local United Way to operate with its own interests exclusively, ignoring the wider economic and social needs of the entire region. The plan being considered repeatedly emphasizes the advantages of a more regional outlook, and by implication regards the existing arrangement as too parochial, a criticism also voiced by members.
Bill Martin, executive director of United Way of Hudson County, N.J.,said the 32 local United Way affiliates must face new realities. "If they need more money," he said, "they must get out and work for it, not sit back saying 'I'm entitled to it, gimme, gimme, gimme.' "
A board member of one of the largest United Ways, who spoke on condition of anonymity, attacked the plan as a "naked grab for power by the corporations" that donate to United Way, and argued it could damage the organization as a whole.
 
Regional Board to Be Reduced
 But George Harvey, chairman of the Tri-State board and the chairman of Pitney Bowes, said the wide majority of the membership is likely to favor the plan when it is presented for approval on March 31, saying the objections came only from a few participants "because there always is some resistance to change."
Under the plan, the regional board would be reduced from 74 members to between 30 and 40, with three-fourths of those seats going to corporate heads and labor leaders, and 5 to representatives of United Ways -- all of whom are unpaid volunteers. Another 2 seats would also go to local United Ways chosen to ensure both urban and suburban interests are covered adequately. If the larger board of 40 is approved, 3 other seats will go to community or academic leaders. Under the current system, half the board's seats now go to officials of local United Way affiliates.
Tri-State is a singular regional organization in the United Way system. It was created in 1977 to accommodate the region's major corporations, which wanted to run fund-raising campaigns to cover not only their headquarters but also other plants or offices within the region where their employees work and live.
 
Major Companies Cut Back
 In the last campaign, 158 major companies raised $108.3 million, about 8 percent less than the previous year. The poorer showing clearly reflected cutbacks at major companies in the area, as 68 percent of the funds raised come from employees' payroll deductions and corporate gifts.
The plan being considered calls for the distribution of funds to be based on a formula considering the needs of each United Way, how much it raised and how deeply it was involved in helping benefiting agencies that might otherwise not function without its help.
Because of continued corporate cutbacks, Tri-State officials said even less money may be raised this year. The 32 local United Way affiliates run campaigns at smaller companies and keep these resources, leading some executives, including Mr. Martin, to say they should work harder on these fund-raising drives.
 
Changes Long Sought
 Over the years, there have been at least four studies calling for reforms in Tri-State's operations, but the current plan is the most significant, said Ralph Gregory, president of the United Way of Westchester and Putnam, who also runs the advisory group made up of the professional employee heads of the 32 member organizations. He expressed disappointment that advisory members were not included earlier in drafting the reorganization plan, and he expressed concern that the local United Way affiliates would not receive more seats on the reconstituted board to insure that varied local United Ways received adequate representation.
The reorganization plan moves into a sensitive area by calling for more uniform financial reports from the 32 members. If local United Way affiliates do not comply, Tri-State would withhold the members' funds for six months; noncompliance for another six months could lead to the funds being redistributed.
Financial problems at local United Ways have embarrassed the organization in the past. In May 1992, the head of accounting at the United Way of Westchester and Putnam pleaded guilty to stealing $283,000 from the organization. Though an insurance concern made up for the embezzled funds, Tri-State and the local United Way disagreed about who should get the money. Tri-State officials contend it should go back to all the partners because Tri-State advanced funds to Westchester to cover the theft.
 
Shifts in Personnel
 The Tri-State organization itself is undergoing changes: Betty Beene, its president for five years, has told board members she wants to leave when her contract ends next February.
"I'm committed to guiding the organization through the adoption and implementation of its plan for the revitalization of the organization," she said. A transitional board will be proposed March 31 and function until a permanent board is elected during the summer.
Tri-State will continue to search for ways to cut costs, she said, and will move its headquarters to rent-free space given by Chemical Bank at 110 John Street in lower Manhattan, with the present quarters at 99 Park Avenue will be leased to bring in revenue, she said. In addition, staff in the last few years has been cut by more than 40 percent and will decline further.
On an upbeat note, she said the board of directors voted last week to welcome back the United Way of Central New Jersey. That affiliate, with its headquarters in New Brunswick, withdrew last year after objecting to the distribution of campaign proceeds.
"In the past few years, we've spent entirely too much time deciding how to divide the pie," she said. "We need to concentrate on making the pie bigger."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A one-two combination staggers the cable television industry.

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin 

 BODY:
THE last few weeks have not been happy ones for cable television companies.
Not only did the Federal Communications Commission announce that cable rates were being rolled back by 7 percent, but the huge $33 billion merger between the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc. fizzled. 
 Those two events, for the next few years at least, will transform what had been a dynamic growth- and investment-oriented business into a more defensive, cautious industry.
For investors, the change means that cable shares should not be bought for their own intrinsic potential, but based on how highly their assets are valued by a potential buyer. And the price those assets will probably fetch is a good bit lower than it was only a week ago.
"The only reason to be investing in the cable business at this juncture is as a takeover play," said Christopher P. Dixon, a cable analyst for Paine Webber Group. "No one knows what the cash flow prospects for these companies will be over the next two to three years. In a week, we have gone from a seller's to a buyer's market."
Frederick Moran, a vice president of Salomon Brothers, said cable companies in big attractive markets are likely takeover targets. Cablevision, which operates in the New York metropolitan area, and Adelphia, which has operations in the Northeast and Florida, fall into this category, he said.
According to estimates from Salomon Brothers, the F.C.C.'s rate rollback will deprive the industry of as much as $3 billion in revenue, and another $15 billion in lost borrowing power.
Much of that debt and cash flow would have been used to finance the capital spending that analysts say is crucial to turn telephones, computers and cable into the information superhighway.
"The industry will have trouble generating enough free cash flow to find the necessary funds to build the superhighway," Mr. Moran said. "That will delay its construction, perhaps as much as five years."
But skeptics said they wondered whether the highway, even if it did get built, would generate the demand necessary to justify the billions of dollars needed to create it.
Stephen Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley, said that last year Americans spent about $160 billion on all forms of multimedia, from televisions and personal computers to videocassettes and movies.
That was more than double the level of a decade ago, and about equal to what was spent on cars and trucks. With real disposable income growing at a snail's pace, Mr. Roach said he was not sure if the benefits of the superhighway would be sufficient to entice consumers to spend even more.
Analysts have acknowledged the risk, and said the days when technological advances created their own demand, as they did in the 1980's, were largely gone. "Near term, the picture isn't very good," said Jessica Reif, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company.
But she recommended two stocks, Tele-Communications and Comcast, which has a hand in the wireless communications alliance announced last week between Nextel and MCI Communications.
"I am very comfortable with the stocks at these valuations," she said. Since January, Tele-Communications has dropped 22 percent and Comcast has fallen more than 12 percent, but the shares of both companies rose on Friday. Tele-Communications gained $1.75, to $23.50, in Nasdaq trading. Comcast rose $1.125, to $21.125, in Nasdaq trading.
A safer but probably less lucrative way to invest in what Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley called the new American dream is in the companies that will buy cable operators.
This group certainly includes the regional telephone companies. The collapse of the Bell Atlantic merger and the F.C.C.'s ruling have given them time to ponder their options.
"The playing field has tilted in favor of the regional Bells," Mr. Moran said. "By handicapping the cable industry's ability to upgrade their services, the Bells have essentially been given time to get into video and other related services."
Entertainment companies are the other obvious group that may make a play for cable companies, Mr. Dixon of Paine Webber said. "Companies like Time Warner and Disney are clearly in the catbird seat," he said.

HEADLINE: Let the Market Decide About Milk Hormone;
The Health of Cows

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"When the Geneticists' Fingers Get in the Food" states, "scientists keep insisting that there is nothing to be concerned about" when bovine growth hormone is used to make cows into "veritable milk machines" (The Week in Review, Feb. 20). But many scientists are very concerned. 
 Forget about the question of hormones in the milk. It's a diversionary issue, the least of our worries about bovine growth hormone.
We are concerned about the health of the cows: excessive milk production reportedly makes them suffer continuously from bruised udders and brings on an early death from metabolic stress.
This is a cruel way to treat a gentle creature.
And we are also concerned because the increased incidence of infection among herds receiving the hormone requires increased use of antibiotics, which in turn raises the specter of transfer of antibiotic resistance from cow bacteria to human pathogens. There are several known ways for this to happen. Antibiotic resistance is a real threat to human health.
We are concerned about stimulating hormone-treated cows to eat more fodder to produce more milk when there is already a milk surplus, which taxpayers are subsidizing.
We are concerned about the results of reliable studies that predict that more than one-third of America's remaining small dairy farmers will be driven out of business by bovine growth hormone.
Not only will this be a kind of cultural genocide, but it will also leave us dependent on comparatively few, large dairy farms, which are likely to be highly unstable for agricultural and economic reasons.
Scientists who are also responsible members of society do not restrict their concerns about their inventions in order to help sell a commercial product.
 
DAVID EHRENFELD
Professor of Biology, Rutgers U.
New Brunswick, N.J., Feb. 27, 1994

HEADLINE: New Refugees May Still Leave Vietnam

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Boat People: A Chapter Closes" (editorial, Feb. 22): 
 Since South Vietnam collapsed in 1975, more than 1.5 million Vietnamese have fled by boat (and a few by land) to other countries in Southeast Asia. With the major exception of 1979, when thousands were pushed back, temporary asylum has been granted, pending resettlement in third countries; the only country towing off new Vietnamese arrivals the last few years has been Malaysia.
On Feb. 14, a United Nations meeting ended special status for refugees from Vietnam. Almost all the remaining asylum seekers in camps in the region have been declared economic migrants, with no choice but to return to Vietnam. The conference stopped short of sanctioning forced repatriation in 1995.
It is regrettable that the United States, which led the way for 19 years in maintaining the temporary framework for boat people, almost adopted a position more radical than the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to force Vietnamese home next year. To set a date for forced repatriation would permit, even encourage, countries of asylum to make their own forced repatriation deals with Vietnam without monitoring.
Let us hope voluntary return can be promoted instead, based in part on the improved economic prospects in Vietnam following the lifting of the United States trade embargo. (A small number of asylum seekers who have a well-founded fear of persecution if returned to Vietnam should be permitted to resettle.)
The United Nations conference did not spell out the right of future asylum seekers from Vietnam to a hearing before subjecting them to repatriation. Though the flow of refugees from Vietnam has virtually ended, the United Nations refugee agency and United States embassies in the region should be alert for new asylum seekers with legitimate claims as refugees.
 
LIONEL A. ROSENBLATT
President, Refugees International
Washington, Feb. 25, 1994
