HEADLINE: Commercial Realty in New York Shows Signs of a Strong Recovery

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
They cannot agree on how much space still languishes empty, or on what the average rents are. But on some things, New York's commercial real-estate brokers and building owners are unanimous: Buildings are filling up. Landlords are getting more from tenants and giving them less. Some companies are even buying buildings again. All told, brokers and landlords say, the real-estate recession is ending.
"If February's numbers are an indication of what the rest of 1994 will look like, the New York real-estate market is in for a sustained period of recovery," said Barry Gosin, chief executive officer of Newmark & Company Real Estate. 
 Peter L. Malkin, a lawyer who is part owner of the Empire State Building and several other Manhattan properties, agreed. "We have definitely turned the corner," he said.
Average midtown rents, which have plunged from about $40 a square foot per year five years ago to as little as half that amount now, have stopped their slide. The Edward S. Gordon Company, a large brokerage company, says average asking rents -- the rents at which landlords market space, but which can usually be negotiated downward -- are $31.16 a square foot a year now, and brokers and landlords say they are inching up even more.
Concession packages -- months of free rent and landlord contributions toward the cost of customizing a tenant's space -- are tightening, too.
Mr. Malkin says the value of the concessions he has had to offer has declined by one-third to one-half over the last half year or so. Brokers report that all landlords are increasingly tightfisted.
"For the first time in four years, tenants can expect to pay more for the same space tomorrow than they will same space tomorrow than they will today," said Jerry L. Cohen, a vice chairman of Cushman & Wakefield, another large real-estate brokerage firm.
Although they vary from source to source, the numbers are uniformly indicating that vacant office space is diminishing. Newmark says that in February the empty space in the most expensive part of town -- from Third Avenue to Fifth Avenue, from 42d Street to 57th Street -- dropped to 14 percent, the first time it has fallen below 15 percent in three years.
Cushman & Wakefield puts the vacancy rate for midtown's best buildings, regardless of neighborhood, at 14.8 percent at the end of February, down from 16.3 percent about a year ago. Edward S. Gordon is just slightly more conservative, citing a 15 percent midtown vacancy rate.
All those numbers are still way above the 8 percent vacancy rate that real-estate experts have traditionally considered a sign of a healthy market, but it is a trend heading in a direction that the brokers and landlords find heartening.
 
Even Second-Rate Space
 And the figures include empty space in second-rate buildings, as well as oddly configured spaces. Large blocks of space -- those of over 100,000 square feet or so -- in the best buildings have grown exceedingly scarce, and tenants who need them will pay a premium to get them.
"A couple years ago we figured space supply and demand would reach equilibrium by 1997," said Stephen B. Siegel, Edward S. Gordon's president. "Now we think it'll happen by the end of next year."
New York is not alone in recovery. Throughout the country, with the possible exception of Southern California, low interest rates, the scarcity of new construction and a general sense of a strengthening economy have translated into a reviving commercial real-estate market.
Still, Julien J. Studley Inc., a national real-estate brokerage company, reported that New York, San Francisco and the District of Columbia were the only major United States markets where tenant effective rental rates -- the rents paid per square foot, subtracting the value of the concessions -- increased last year. Julien J. Studley, the company's owner, says that particularly in New York, tenants are clamoring to get leases signed before rents go up again.
"One of the clearest signs of recovery in New York is that the pressure to close deals isn't from the building owners anymore," Mr. Studley said.
Not all the news has been good for the real-estate industry in the city. The downtown financial district is awash in space. And those developers who had highly publicized fiscal troubles -- Olympia & York is probably the most well known, but there are others -- have found it almost impossible to get back on their feet. Brokers, afraid that their commissions will not be paid, and tenants, afraid the buildings will not be properly maintained, still shun their properties, even when they have managed to keep them out of bankruptcy.
New York's emerging real-estate recovery represents a confluence of local and national factors. The generally strengthening economy has given many corporate tenants new confidence, and thus a greater willingness to expand. And, since development of new commercial space has been at a virtual standstill over the last four years, those corporations have been filling up existing buildings.
 
Shifting to a Service Economy
 "Not only are we seeing fewer tenant bankruptcies, but existing tenants are taking more space," said Stephen Green, chairman of S.L. Green Real Estate, who says that the 20 Manhattan office buildings his company owns or manages are about 96 percent occupied.
The shift to a service economy in New York has also largely ameliorated the impact of the flight of corporations elsewhere. Over the last 15 years, numerous corporations, including Union Carbide, American Airlines and J.C. Penney, have left New York for Texas, Connecticut and other states.
To make matters worse, many corporations have tried to streamline their decision-making processes by eliminating several layers of management jobs -- exactly the type of headquarters jobs that have traditionally been situated in New York. Even when the economy picks up, few management experts expect those jobs to be restored.
But many of Manhattan's vacant corporate buildings have filled up nonetheless. Avenue of the Americas from 42d Street to 59th Street, once called Corporate Corridor because of the high concentration of corporate headquarters, has turned into Barrister Boulevard as law firms have taken over the empty corporate space.
Banks and financial services companies, many of which have come back in better shape than they were before the 1987 stock market crash, have also moved to midtown. Morgan Stanley, Kidder Peabody, Bear Stearns and Mastercard have all bought or rented huge chunks of space.
 
A Return to Speculation
 Speculative money is also coming back to the market. The British developer Howard Ronson recently bought 383 Madison Avenue, the obsolete building between 46th and 47th Streets that once housed the Manhattan Savings Bank and the advertising agency B.B.D.O., and that has been vacant for a decade. Mr. Ronson plans a new office building on the site. He refused to discuss details, but brokers who know him say he does not have specific tenants in mind.
Corporate tenants are also predicting a space squeeze, and building sales are up. In the last few years, Morgan Stanley paid $176 million for 1585 Broadway, a 41-story building near 47th Street; Bertelsmann A.G. paid $119 million for 1540 Broadway, a 44-story building a few blocks south, and Mutual of America paid $130 million for 320 Park Avenue, a 34-story building near 50th Street.
Thomas F. Pergola, a Chemical Bank vice president who handles financing of owner-occupied buildings, said Chemical Bank closed some $130 million worth of owner-occupied transactions last year, up from $110 million in 1992. But more significant is the fact that he entered this year with more than $300 million in financing deals in the pipeline -- the first time the level of transactions in progress broke $300 million since the end of 1988, just before the real-estate recession hit.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 11, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Monday about New York City's commercial real estate recovery referred incorrectly to a transaction involving 383 Madison Avenue. A developer, Howard Ronson, has announced an agreement to buy the property, but has not done so yet. He expects to assume ownership in September.

HEADLINE: U.S. Urges the Burmese Military To Talk to Imprisoned Laureate

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The United States expressed surprise today that a leader of the Burmese military junta had ruled out early talks with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the imprisoned democracy campaigner and Nobel peace laureate.
The United States urged the military dictatorship to open "a genuine dialogue" with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi as soon as possible, said a State Department spokesman, David Johnson. 
 "We're disappointed by the decision not to enter into discussions with the detained opposition leader," he said. "We deplore her continued house arrest, now nearing five years."
The head of Burmese military intelligence, Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt, said in an interview on Sunday that face-to-face talks between him and Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi might eventually be possible, but indicated that no decision would be made soon.
He described her attitude as "counterproductive" and harshly questioned her legitimacy as an opposition politician, emphasizing that she was married to a Briton and had lived abroad for three decades before returning to her country in 1988.
 
New Sanctions Possible
 Administration officials suggested that they might step up sanctions against Myanmar, formerly Burma, because of the military's failure to open a dialogue with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. Washington has already suspended all economic and military aid, imposed an arms embargo, ended some low tariffs that had applied to its products and blocked the International Monetary Fund and World Bank from making loans to the country.
State Department officials had hoped that the military's decision to let Repesentative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat, meet last month with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was a signal that the general was ready to meet with her face to face.
Last summer the Administration began a comprehensive review of policies toward Myanmar. One Administration official said the remarks made by General Khin Nyunt would weigh against any easing of policy.
"This obviously will be a new input in our policy considerations, and it's not a positive one," said Thomas Hubbard, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs.
 
House Arrest Since '89
 Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was put under house arrest in Yangon, formerly Rangoon, in July 1989 as part of a crackdown against the democracy movement. Her party, the National League for Democracy, won national elections in 1990 by a landslide, but the military voided the results.
In pressing the military to open talks with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, Mr. Johnson said "we understand" that the military "has not ruled out the possibility of a dialogue in the future." So "we urge them to begin at the earliest possible time," he said.
Mr. Richardson suggested after visiting Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi last month that General Khin Nyunt was "a pragmatic individual" who might be ready for such talks. He could not be reached for comment today.
American officials heatedly disputed General Khin Nyunt's assertion that support for Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was sparse among the Burmese. "That flies in the face of reality," said one State Department official. "Her party won 80 percent of the seats in the election."

HEADLINE: Dow Rallies by 23.92 Points, to 3,856.22

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In a week with few significant economic statistics to jangle their nerves, the financial markets will likely play the game of "When Will (Not if) the Fed Raise Interest Rates Again?" So the stock market rallied yesterday in moderate trading, when the Federal Reserve Board did nothing and long-term rates on bonds declined.
Stocks like Caterpillar, Allied Signal and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing benefited, as well as defense stocks like Northrop and United Technologies, after the announcement of Martin Marietta's plans to acquire Grumman. 
 Both the stock and bond markets will continue to play the waiting-for-the-Fed game today and probably until March 22, when the Fed's policy- making committee meets to consider why traders and investors seem to be demanding higher short-term interest rates to fight inflation although there is little evidence of rising prices.
 
 
Dow Gains 23.92 Points
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 23.92 points yesterday, to 3,856.22, and the Standard & Poor's 500, which rose 2.17 points, to 466.91, both started upbeat and moved sideways for most of the session.
David D. Holt, vice president for research and strategy at Wedbush Morgan Securities in Los Angeles, said the early stock jump was a result of an unusual consensus in Europe, where all the leading equities exchanges closed higher. "There was a global market imbalance of demand over supply," he said. "The U.S. computers recognized it; they went ding-a-ling and executed buy orders."
But even after the rally, the Dow was still 122 points off its Jan. 31 peak of 3,978.36 and the S.& P. 500 was 15 points off its Feb. 2 peak of 482.
If, as some analysts are predicting, the stock market "corrects" 10 percent in price over the next few weeks or months, then the Dow will have to drop below 3,600 and the S.& P. 500 to around 434.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.50 points, to 795.05. The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 1.37 points to 259.07 on relatively light volume of 285.6 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,443 to 762. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.58 points, to 469.06.
January consumer credit numbers were reported after the market closed yesterday, but they are likely to have little impact today because the market is focusing on February data or imminent March data for trading decisions.
Still, the credit numbers support a low-inflation view. But they will probably be discounted by the market because harsh winter weather discouraged consumer purchases and a major earthquake disrupted California's economy.
The most active stock yesterday, with volume of 7.2 million shares, was Intel, whose new version of its Pentium microprocessor will be incorporated into the personal computers of such leading manufacturers as Hewlett-Packard, Digital Equipment and Compaq. The new Intel chip is said to be 50 percent faster than earlier versions. Intel closed up 1 5/8 at 71 1/4.

HEADLINE: THE WHITEWATER INQUIRY;
Bringing Another Presidency and Inquiry to Mind

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
His own travails in the Whitewater affair have nothing in common with the Watergate scandal that drove Richard M. Nixon from office 20 years ago, President Clinton insisted today at a news conference in which he fought his political corner as tenaciously as Mr. Nixon ever did.
"We're not covering anything up," he said. "We are opening up." 
 Had the Clinton White House been as forthcoming as the President suggested it had, Mr. Clinton might have had no reason to dispute the parallel.
In that case, the focus would have remained on the Whitewater transactions themselves, long ago and far away, which are hard to follow and lacking in evident drama. The whole thing might have dried up. But now the spotlight has shifted from the Ozarks to Washington, and words like "subpoena" and "cover-up" have caught public attention. There is now no chance that things will quiet down this year.
The shift in focus, which also happened in Watergate, is of much greater importance this time than two decades ago. The original accusations against Mr. Nixon related to actions during his term as President, but those against Mr. Clinton predated his election in 1992. Suspicions of a cover-up, however, have taken investigators right into current White House activities.
The two cases have obvious differences. Watergate involved gross abuses of power, including the misuse of the F.B.I., among other agencies. Whitewater, on the record to date, has produced nothing approaching that.
 
Grudging Responses
 It is certainly true that Bill Clinton did not dig in his heels as hard or as long as Richard Nixon did. So far, there is less evidence of an effort to block investigators. But Mr. Clinton and his staff did not react to the first set of Whitewater disclosures, or the second or third, by "opening up."
For weeks the White House resisted the appointment of an independent counsel. It admitted only in December that crucial documents had been removed in July from the files of Vincent W. Foster Jr., the Clinton aide who killed himself, and given to the President's lawyer. For a time, Bernard W. Nussbaum, the soon-to-depart White House counsel, said Mr. Clinton might refuse to yield Whitewater documents on grounds of attorney-client privilege.
At every turn, the White House responses to inquiries from reporters investigating the matter have been late, incomplete and grudging.
There are other similarities between Watergate and Whitewater, starting with controversy over documents and whether they have been shredded.
Mr. Nixon liked to dismiss the Watergate scandal as "a third-rate burglary," long after it was clear that it was not the break-in but the abuses of power associated with it that constituted the biggest liability. Mr. Clinton, likewise, often says that the Whitewater episode is rooted in a small-time land deal 16 years ago in which he and his wife lost money.
 
Distracting Questions
 Defending his wife as a woman who has a "moral compass as strong as anybody's in America," Mr. Clinton sounded as defensive as Mr. Nixon used to in proclaiming the virtues of those who worked alongside him.
Two days after Mr. Nussbaum was cast to the wolves, Mr. Clinton found himself answering Whitewater questions at what was supposed to be a news conference on problems in Russia and other former units of the Soviet Union. He said he had more important things to do than defend his conduct, and he asserted that "the American people will be outraged if anybody uses this as an excuse for not doing the people's business."
On April 30, 1973, the day he announced the departure of H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman, among others, Mr. Nixon said much the same thing.
"It is essential," he said, "that we not be so distracted by events such as this that we neglect the vital work before us, before this nation, before America, at a time of critical importance to America and the world."
 
Pressure on Democrats
 Mr. Nixon was never able to turn back, full time, to the business of governing. More and more revelations, some directly related to Watergate but most not, kept him on the defensive until he finally resigned. In Mr. Clinton's case, much will depend on what new disclosures, if any, lie ahead.
Democrats on Capitol Hill have maintained a more-or-less united front so far, refusing demands from Republican colleagues for an investigation even though they investigated similar episodes during the Reagan and Bush eras. But that front may be cracking under the pressure of accusations that the Democrats are guilty of applying a partisan double standard.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, became on Sunday the first ranking Democrat on the Hill to suggest that he would consider the possibility of Whitewater hearings.
If disclosures keep coming, and especially if there are any further hints that the White House is trying to steer the investigation, some Democrats' partisan loyalties will surely give way to self-preservation. All of the seats in the House and a third of those in the Senate, after all, will be up for grabs this November, long before Bill Clinton faces the electorate.
 
Similar Reputations
 Like Mr. Nixon, Mr. Clinton is vulnerable in a crisis of this sort because of the ambiguous reputation that preceded him into Presidential politics.
Both men have always been widely admired for their intelligence, their political skills and their grasp of complex public questions. But both have long been dogged by questions of trustworthiness. One brought the nickname "Tricky Dick" into the Oval Office, the other "Slick Willy."
The events of last weekend were sufficiently striking that top Republicans and Democrats have for the first time begun wondering aloud, discreetly of course, whether Whitewater could eventually become serious enough to cost Mr. Clinton a second term.
Early as it is, with so many more events to unfold before 1996, the damage is already substantial, if not necessarily to the President's standing with the public, then clearly to his ability to influence legislators. And if he is unable to push through his already beleaguered legislative proposals, including health care reform and the reorganization of the welfare system, he could lose ground with voters.
The consensus so far, voiced by an influential Democratic senator: "A second term looks less routine, especially if the economy turns sour."
 
THE MEETINGS IN QUESTION
 
 President Clinton today acknowledged that he was briefed some time last October on the decision by the agency overseeing failed savings and loans to ask for a criminal investigation by the Justice Department into the failure of Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan in Arkansas, a request that named the Clintons as possible beneficiaries of illegal actions. While Mr. Clinton said he did not remember who briefed him or when, the meeting was one of a series that have recently come to light concerning the referral by the agency, the Resolution Trust Corporation.
 
Sept. 29, 1993 -- Jean Hanson, the Treasury Department's general counsel, meets in the office of Bernard W. Nussbaum, the White House counsel, to warn him of the R.T.C's plan to ask for a Justice Department investigation.
 
Oct. 8, 1993 -- R.T.C. formally asks the Justice Department to look into the matter.
 
Oct. 14, 1993 -- A meeting is held in Mr. Nussbaum's office to discuss how to handle inquiries from news organizations about the status of the Whitewater investigation. In addition to Mr. Nussbaum, the meeting includes Mark D. Gearan, the White House director of communications; Bruce Lindsey, a senior adviser to Mr. Clinton; Ms. Hanson; Josh Steiner, now chief of staff to Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen; and Jack DeVore, then Mr. Bentsen's press secretary.
 
Oct. 31, 1993 -- First press reports of the R.T.C. referral appear.
 
Feb. 2, 1994 -- Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman, also the acting head of the R.T.C., meets with Mr. Nussbaum, Ms. Hanson, Harold M. Ickes, the deputy chief of staff, and Margaret A. Williams, Hillary Rodham Clinton's chief of staff. Mr. Altman acknowledges the meeting before a Senate committee on Feb. 24, saying he held the briefing to give the White House a "heads up" on how the R.T.C. would proceed on potential civil claims arising out of Madison's failure.

HEADLINE: Long Islanders Shocked by Grumman's Merger

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BETHPAGE, L.I., March 7

 BODY:
The name Grumman has been synonymous with jobs and economic security on Long Island for more than five decades, so today's announcement that Grumman was being acquired by Martin Marietta, and that still more layoffs might result, shocked many here.
"I'm sorry to see it go," said Lynn V. McDonald, a 69-year-old engineer who spent 30 years at the Grumman Corporation and worked on almost every plane the company produced, as well as the Lunar Module that landed on the Moon. 
 "I'm only a retiree on the outside looking in," said Mr. McDonald, who lives a block south of Grumman's airfield here. "But it must be a lot tougher on those inside, because I don't stand to lose my job."
 
Retirees Also Concerned
 Indeed, although some Grumman employees said the merger might expand their career opportunities, others feared that they might soon join the thousands of employees laid off by Grumman in recent years. And some retirees expressed concern about their pensions and other benefits.
David Griangano, a senior engineer with 10 years at Grumman, said his fellow workers had "a feeling something was about to happen."
"Today confirmed our suspicions," he said. "Now we really don't know what to expect."
Economists said they feared that the Martin Marietta Corporation, which is based in Bethesda, Md., would feel no loyalty toward Long Island and would move more jobs to plants elsewhere to cut costs.
 
'Doesn't Auguer Well'
 "This doesn't augur well for Long Island," said Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "It may be good for Grumman stockholders, but it sends a negative message as far as the well being of Long Island's economy."
Spokesmen for both Grumman and Martin Marietta declined to comment on the long-term outlook for Long Island employment.
Norman R. Augustine, the chairman and chief executive of Martin Marietta, said, however, that consolidation would take considerable time and that the merger would have no short-term impact on Long Island.
"We want to grow the corporation, not shrink it," he said.
Renso L. Caporali, Grumann's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement yesterday that Grumman had concluded last year that it had to make a significant strategic move. "We looked at a number of different approaches and combinations, and this is far superior to any of our other options," he said.
 
Politicans Optimistic
 Local officials chose to view the merger with optimism.
Calling it a "perfect match," the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, said, "Long Island's economy is changing, and this is a move in the right direction."
The Nassau County Executive, Thomas Gulotta, said, "Without the merger, Grumman, as a smaller company, probably would not have been able to survive, and all its jobs would have been lost."
The name of the merged company has not yet been determined, but Mr. Gulotta said that he understood that Grumman would be a part of it, since it "still carried a certain value in bidding on certain projects."
Dr. Koppelman noted that Grumman's work force on Long Island was now down to fewer than 8,900 employees from a peak of 23,000 in 1986 and 11,600 a little under a year ago. "And if Martin Marietta says someday soon, 'Hey, let's centralize,' that could be the death knell for Grumman on Long Island," he added.
Grumman, Long Island's leading non-governmental employer for many years, fell behind the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, with 12,500 employees, last year.
According to a study released today by the New York State Assembly subcommittee on the Long Island economy, the loss of manufacturing jobs on Long Island results from the high cost of electricity on Long Island, high property taxes and an inability to finance expansion.
The subcommittee surveyed 743 chief executives of companies with more than 100 employees and concluded that if these three major issues were not addressed, Long Island would see a "continued dramatic decline in its job base."
 
 
Effect of Previous Cutbacks
 Martin R. Cantor, the subcommittee's chief economist and a former Suffolk County commissioner for economic development, said the manufacturing and construction sectors accounted for 76 percent of the 105,000 jobs lost on Long Island since October 1987 and that the loss of 55,500 manufacturing jobs in the last seven years had cost Long Island's economy $3 billion. Cutbacks at Grumman accounted for nearly half of those lost manufacturing jobs, Mr. Cantor said.
The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation was formed in 1929 by Leroy Randle Grumman in an abandoned garage in Baldwin, 20 miles east of mid-Manhattan. Its first contract was making repairs on wing floats for Navy planes.
Grumman redesigned the floats and before long was manufacturing not only new floats, but entire planes for the Navy, including a carrier-based single-engine fighter, the XFF-1, nicknamed "Fifi." As World War II approached, Grumman concentrated its efforts at a Bethpage production plant and moved its corporate headquarters here.
 
 
Wildcat With Folding Wings
 It developed the F4F Wildcat fighter that had wings that folded much like a bird's for compact storage at sea. Later generations of Grumman fighters included the F6F-5 Hellcat and the twin-engine F7F-3N Tigercat night fighter.
By 1947, Grumman had switched to jet engines. Its F9F-2 Panther set a new standard for carrier-based fighter plane performance and reliability. Subsequent jets included the F9F-9 Tiger with its Coke-bottle fuselage designed to reduce wave drag in supersonic flight. A later version, the F-14 Tomcat, was regarded as the most advanced fighter in the world and became one of Grumman's mainstays in 1970's.
Aircraft production on Long Island effectively ceased this year when Grumman closed its plant at Calverton, laid off several hundred employees and shifted the work to a Florida plant.

HEADLINE: Politicians Discovering An Issue: Immigration

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EL PASO, March 5

 BODY:
In the seven months since hundreds of Federal immigration agents were deployed along the banks of the Rio Grande here, the traffic of illegal workers from Mexico has all but stopped.
But the flow of politicians to the border here has surged: From across Texas, Washington and California, Republicans and Democrats want to see, and be seen at, a get-tough effort to control immigration. 
 "It's election time," Mayor Larry Francis of El Paso, an independent, said as he took in the panoramic view of the border from his 10th-floor office, "and the border is a hot topic."
Many Republicans have argued that both legal and illegal immigrants burden American social services, while Democrats have played down the costs. But now, even Democrats, who stayed clear of such debates as they relied on ethnic and civil rights groups for support, are joining the chorus, albeit cautiously.
The politicians are prompted by polls showing that the issue is gaining in importance among voters who, polls say, are increasingly worried about the economic impact of immigrants and their effect on American culture.
 
Issue in Elections
 The politics of immigration is getting even more attention because of big elections this fall in New York, California, Florida, Illinois and Texas, which get the greatest share of immigrants. Immigration is also taking a high profile in Congress and the White House, where President Clinton, eager to appeal to moderates, is calling the issue a priority.
But if many are calling for a more aggressive attitude toward immigrants, they do not speak with one voice. Some politicians, particularly conservatives, advocate not only intensified patrols of the borders but also curbing or eliminating access to public services for illegal immigrants. Others, like Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, are also taking aim at legal immigrants. Mr. Simpson introduced legislation this week to cut legal immigrants into the United States to about 500,000 a year from 675,000.
Rather than emphasize legal immigration, the governors of New York, California, Florida, Illinois and Texas -- all of whom are running for re-election this year -- have focused on illegal immigrants. Asserting that their actions are driven by budgetary, not political, considerations, the governors have threatened to sue the Federal Government for help in providing federally mandated services to undocumented immigrants.
Even Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, a son of immigrants who is known for praising immigrants, was more sober in a recent radio interview, saying: "They are part of our great strength. They will be a nourishment for our future," adding, "They are also expensive."
 
Perilous Issue for Democrats
 Immigration is especially perilous for Democrats as they seek to turn it to their advantage -- or, at least, prevent Republicans from keeping the issue as their own -- without alienating core supporters. The exception, of course, is organized labor and increasingly blacks, who look wearily upon immigrants as competition.
In Texas, where Democrats have historically welcomed immigrants to integrate the border towns, Gov. Ann W. Richards has been particularly cautious; she needs to keep her stronghold among Hispanic voters in South Texas to win re-election. But her decision to join in the suit against the Federal Government shows how serious the issue has become.
Mark McKinnon, a Democratic strategist in Austin, Tex., said: "Immigration is a potential powder keg kind of issue. It plays to the politics of fear, and the politics of fear can be very persuasive. You're hearing the Governor saying some things now that she wasn't saying three years ago."
There is reason for concern. Both legal and illegal immigrants cost Texans more than $4 billion in 1992 for education, health care and other services beyond what they paid in taxes, according to a study published this week by Donald Huddle, an economist at Rice University.
 
Fierce Oratory in California
 Federico F. Pena, the Secretary of Transportation, is scheduled to come here next week, the latest in a string of Administration officials and other politicians who have applauded the United States Border Patrol for lining the border with agents. The holes that aliens had punched into the border fences are now repaired, and the crackdown has been well received by many here.
But even the Border Patrol is well aware of the sensitivities involved. The program, originally called "Operation Blockade," has had its name changed to the less intimidating "Operation Hold the Line."
The oratory is fiercest in California, where an anti-immigrant mood seems to reflect that state's dire economic situation. Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, is espousing the toughest controls. He called for a constitutional amendment to deny citizenship to the children of illegal immigrants, which is now guaranteed by law.
Such proposals do not play as well in other states, as Jim Mattox, a Senate candidate in Tuesday's Texas primary, discovered. Early in the campaign, Mr. Mattox, a Democrat, advocated stationing United States troops on the border as part of an effort to use unneeded military assets in crime-fighting at home. Hispanic voters, whom Mr. Mattox had been close to for years and who are an important voting bloc in Texas, were furious. Mr. Mattox's Democratic rivals attacked as well, forcing him to play down the issue.
Vanna Slaughter, coordinator of the Texas Immigration and Refugee Coalition, a new statewide advocacy group for immigrants, said, "We were really quite appalled by it because Jim Mattox for most of us has been a pretty friendly individual."
Mr. Mattox defended his proposal, but acknowledged that he had underestimated the reaction.
"My opponents said there would be tanks running up and down the border with rifles aimed at everyone," he said in an interview. "You've got activists on all sides who are trying to defend our current immigration policies, which are impossible to defend."
As the United States continues to admit a record number of legal immigrants and refugees, and they settle largely in relatively few states, the issue will only intensify.
The Gallup Poll reported last year that 65 percent of Americans believe the number of legal immigrants to the United States should be decreased, twice the number who felt that way 30 years ago.
Bill Ong Hing, a professor at Stanford Law School who specializes in immigration, said he feared that the rush to tighten immigration had resulted in hastily drafted measures that penalize migrants for domestic economic problems that were not their fault. "It's opportunism on the backs of immigrants," he said.
But Representative Lamar Smith of San Antonio, chairman of the House Republican task force on illegal immigration, says it will be hard to fight that attitude.
"Individuals who want to protect illegal aliens are going to be seen as people who are putting the interests of illegal aliens ahead of the interests of taxpayers and workers," Mr. Smith said. "And that's a dangerous position to be in."

HEADLINE: U.S. MOVES TO EASE BEIJING SANCTIONS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CANBERRA, Australia, March 7

 BODY:
In a gesture of good will toward Beijing, the Clinton Administration has begun to pave the way for the Hughes Aircraft Company to launch a commercial satellite from China.
If the Administration gives its approval within the next few weeks, as expected, it will represent the second time this year that the United States has eased punitive economic sanctions against China. 
 The latest step, reported today by Secretary of State Warren Christopher as he arrived here for talks with Prime Minister Paul Keating, comes as Washington presses Beijing to substantially improve its human rights record so the Clinton Administration can extend China's preferential trade benefits when they expire in June. The launching would put an Australian communications satellite in orbit.
Senior Administration officials, including Mr. Christopher, who is to make his first trip to China as Secretary of State later this week, have denied that Washington is changing its sanctions policy toward China, but the Hughes decision is bound to be interpreted in Beijing as another gesture in line with the Administration's six-month-old policy of intensified political and economic engagement.
 
Pentagon Aide to Beijing
 Indeed, as part of the strategy to engage China rather than to isolate it, Frank Wisner, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, will accompany Mr. Christopher to Beijing and stay to discuss ways to upgrade the two countries' military relationship, senior Pentagon officials said today. Mr. Wisner will be the highest-ranking Pentagon official to visit China since the 1989 crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators.
Last August the Administration imposed sanctions on an estimated $1 billion in high-technology trade with China, after Beijing shipped missile technology and components to Pakistan in violation of international accords.
The sanctions affected the planned launchings of seven commercial satellites on Chinese rockets. In November, on the eve of President Clinton's meeting with President Jiang Zemin of China, Mr. Clinton's national security advisers agreed to keep the sanctions in place unless China signed a formal agreement adhering to the principles of the international arms accord.
But in early January, the White House reversed itself and approved the launching of two commercial satellites from China, one by Martin Marietta, the other by Hughes. White House lawyers said satellites that did not include items on the State Department's munitions list could be approved for export.
Mr. Christopher said tonight that approval of the launchings would be consistent with United States law because Hughes had reconfigured the satellite to remove sensitive coding equipment. That means the satellite would need only Commerce Department licensing, a much easier process.
Asked about the wisdom of allowing the launching when Washington is pressing China on human rights and on the missile accord, Mr. Christopher said it "simply sends a signal of even-handed treatment."

HEADLINE: Paul K. Feyerabend, 70, Anti-Science Philosopher

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Prof. Paul Karl Feyerabend, a gadfly philosopher of science who asserted that scientists have no particular claims on truth, died on Feb. 11 in Geneva. He was 70.
He died of a brain tumor, said officials at the University of California at Berkeley, where he taught from 1959 until he reached emeritus status in 1990. He held a concurrent appointment at the Polytechnic Institute of Zurich. 
 Dr. Feyerabend died just days after finishing the final chapter of his autobiography, on which he had worked for more than a decade. University officials in Berkeley said his friends reported that he was still able to write with his right hand despite growing paralysis.
Dr. Feyerabend held that the rationality of science did not really exist and that the special status and prestige of scientists are based on their own claims to objective truth. He once said that "conceited and intimidating scholars, covered with honorary degrees and university chairs," can be tripped up by a lawyer able to look through the jargon and expose the ignorance behind dazzling displays of omniscience.
"Scientists have more money, more authority, more sex appeal than they deserve," Dr. Feyerabend said in a 1979 article in Science magazine, "and the most stupid procedures and the most laughable results are surrounded with an aura of excellence. It is time to cut them down to size."
To that end, he became a prolific author of articles and books. His best known works are "Against Method" (1975), which was translated into 19 languages, "Science in a Free Society" (1978) and "Farewell to Reason" (1987), a collection of essays.
Dr. Feyerabend was one of the most radical challengers to the long-accepted notion that science is rational and progressive. If there was progress in science, he insisted, it was because scientists broke every principle in the rationalists' rule book and adopted the principle that "anything goes."
Individual theories are not consistent with one another, Dr. Feyerabend held, and since there is no single "scientific method," scientific success flows not only from rational arguments, but also from a mixture of subterfuge, rhetoric, conjecture, politics and propaganda.
 
Served in German Army
 He was born in Vienna and served in World War II as an officer in the German Army, winning the Iron Cross for bravery. In 1945, while fighting the Red Army on the Eastern front, he was shot in the back; the wound left him with a severe limp.
He studied history, physics and astronomy at the University of Vienna, where he received his Ph.D. in 1951. Dr. Feyerabend then became an admirer and protege of the philosopher Karl Popper of the London School of Economics, whose scientific rationalism he later tried to refute.
Besides his teaching posts at Berkeley and Zurich, he taught at the University of Bristol in England, the Institute of Fine Arts and Science in Vienna, Yale University and the Free University in Berlin.
He is survived by his wife, Grazia Borrini Feyerabend.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

HEADLINE: Consolidation of Contractors Suits the Pentagon

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The proposed merger of the Grumman Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation fits snugly in the Defense Department's post-cold-war strategy to maintain a smaller but robust base of military contractors.
The end of the cold war has left military contractors scrambling to survive on a shrinking Pentagon budget for jets, ships and tanks. The Pentagon's purchases of new weapons and equipment have declined 64 percent since 1985, military industry analysts say. 
 Defense Secretary William J. Perry has urged military contractors to carry out an orderly consolidation that preserves America's ability to develop the most advanced technology at affordable costs and to expand again if unforeseen security threats emerge down the road.
 
 
Retrenching Is Half Done
 For the Pentagon, the tricky part in all this has been to steer the shrinking industry in the desired direction but to intervene as little as possible. "We're not going to try to manipulate the consolidation of the defense industry, but we want to encourage it," Mr. Perry told reporters in September.
Pentagon officials and industry analysts say the process of consolidation is only about half completed.
"Such mergers and realignment in the defense industry is an inevitable result of the downsizing, and a private deal arrived at between two highly successful companies to become a single, integrated, more efficient company is very much along the lines that Bill Perry is trying to promote," John M. Deutch, the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Technology, said in an interview.
In this transition, Martin Marietta has quickly emerged as one of the most aggressive companies. It bought General Electric's aerospace division in 1992 and announced its intent to buy General Dynamics' space system division last year.
The fate of Grumman, however, illustrates the opposite side of the acquisition equation. "Frankly, the world was going to get an awful lot tougher for people in our business," Renso L. Caporali, Grumman's chairman, said today.
 
 
Commercial Applications
 Pentagon officials say they want not only a smaller, healthy military industry, but one that is more flexible. Mr. Perry and other senior Pentagon officials have sought to encourage companies to produce both military and commercial products, or at least to preserve their arms-making capability.
At the same time, the Pentagon and Congress have pledged to overhaul the cumbersome system the military uses to buy nearly $50 billion of new equipment each year. The Defense Department is also rewriting regulations to allow the military to buy more commercial products. Such equipment is less expensive than items built to military specifications, which were deemed necessary during the cold war.
Underlying the Pentagon's push for consolidation and all the other reforms is the military's desperate need to cut costs. Commanders face a choice between paying for a costly acquisition system, including an inefficient industry, or using that money to pay and train troops, and keep them ready for combat.
In pursuing this course, the Pentagon is walking a political high wire. It encourages consolidation but is also trying to be sensitive to communities affected by plant closings and base shutdowns by offering economic incentives to cushion the blow.
"While this is painful for local communities, this is good for the Defense Department because it reduces overhead, and is good for the economy because it frees up capital now tied up in excess capacity," said Loren B. Thompson, deputy director for National Security Studies at Georgetown University. Indeed, the pain on Long Island will be felt in the elimination of an unspecified number of jobs that Martin Marietta said today was needed to improve the efficiency of the combined company.
 
 
 
Subsidized Industries
 The consequences of unfettered consolidation extend only so far. In contrast to the Bush Administration, the Clinton White House has said it will subsidize a few critical industries that cannot produce widely used commercial products. For example, the Navy is seeking to spend $2.3 billion to buy a Seawolf submarine that it says it does not need. But Pentagon officials say it would be more expensive to reopen production lines if they are closed than to run them at low levels.
Asked if he was in essence picking winners and losers in this industrial shakeout, Mr. Perry said last fall, when he was Deputy Defense Secretary: "I don't see it that way. We're determining capabilities we need and taking action."
Industry analysts say there is still enough excess capacity -- and accompanying cost inefficiencies -- to warrant broader consolidation.
"The Pentagon wants industry to sort it out themselves so Government doesn't have to do it for them," said Richard Bitzinger, a military analyst for the Defense Budget Project, an independent research organization. "They don't see a situation arising yet where there are dangerous monopolies exercising an unfair advantage. It's the best way to preserve the best parts of an industry at the least direct cost to the Government."

HEADLINE: Head of Transit Authority Opposes Merger for Police

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
The president of the New York City Transit Authority yesterday condemned a plan by the Giuliani administration to merge the city's three police forces, saying it would weaken safety on the subways. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he still thought the authority's parent board would enact his proposal.
Speaking at a hearing of the City Council's Committee on Transportation, the Transit Authority president, Alan F. Kiepper, said the Mayor's plan to consolidate the New York City Police Department, the housing police and the transit police into one entity would lead to an increase in subway crime, which has been declining in the last four years. 
 "The customers of the subway system would suffer," Mr. Kiepper said. "It's obvious we have an effective policing system for the subway. Why disturb that? What's to be gained? We might save a little money, but at what price?"
The Transit Authority was one of several agencies to present testimony yesterday as the Council considered the impact of Mr. Giuliani's budget plans. In a separate hearing on welfare programs, the committee chairman lashed out at administration officials for being unable to explain how a planned 3,626-person reduction in the Human Resources Administration's work force would affect programs and services.
 
A Campaign Cornerstone
 The plan to merge the three police forces was a cornerstone of Mr. Giuliani's mayoral campaign last year. The Mayor has maintained that consolidating the three police forces, with a total of 38,000 members, would make a more efficient force and save millions of dollars in administrative overhead costs each year.
At a news conference yesterday after Mr. Kiepper's testimony, Mr. Giuliani said that although the plan would be subject to approval by the Transit Authority's parent board, "I'm hopeful that the support to do it is there."
Mr. Kiepper also said he thought any merger would require approval by the State Legislature. "There is a state law which authorizes the Transit Authority to establish a police department to police the subways," he said.
In a first step toward merging the police forces, Mr. Giuliani has planned to consolidate the various forces' administrative offices, emergency services and detective bureaus. Mr. Kiepper said that plan, too, "is ill advised." He continued: "A police department has to have the support services and the administrative arm. To say they should operate without that makes a clumsy arrangement."
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the parent body of the agency that runs the city's subways and buses, has not taken an official position on the matter, although the authority's chairman, Peter E. Stangl, has opposed the plan. The M.T.A. is governed by a board with 14 voting members appointed by the governor. Four of them are nominated by the mayor.
 
Nominees for Board
 On Saturday, Mr. Giuliani nominated Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, Transportation Commissioner Elliott G. Sander, and Joseph J. Lhota, director of economic development initiatives, for the board. Prema Mathal-Davis, Commissioner of the Department for the Aging under Mayor David N. Dinkins, holds the fourth mayoral position on the board.
Cecily Bailey, a spokeswoman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, said Mr. Cuomo was open to merger proposals but would be "looking for the support by the affected parties."
At the hearing on welfare, Stephen DiBrienza, chairman of Council Committee on General Welfare, became incensed after the Human Resources Commissioner, Marva L. Hammons, told him that the staff reduction was still at "a planning stage."
 
Summoned to Testify
 In response, Mr. DiBrienza, a Democrat-Liberal from Brooklyn, unexpectedly summoned Linda Gibbs, the deputy director of the Mayor's budget office, to testify. She said that all agencies had been told to reduce their staffs by 16 percent through the severance program but that it was up to the commissioners to decide which positions would be removed.
Mr. DiBrienza lashed back, calling the answers "offensive and somewhat secretive and mysterious for no reason."

HEADLINE: A Fading Political Powerhouse;
New York Democrats Complain to Washington of Needs Ignored and Favors Forgotten

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
For 12 long years, as the Democratic politicians who led New York endured deep Republican spending cuts and cold shoulders from Washington, their perpetual cry was that pointed Brooklynese lament: "We was robbed!" They took it for granted that Bill Clinton's victory, sped at several turning points by strong New York support, would change all that.
But now, with perhaps as many New Yorkers holding senior jobs in the White House and Federal agencies as at any time since the New Deal (when the President was a former New York Governor), New York officials complain that New York itself is what's taken for granted, and their rising cry is, "What have you done for us lately?" 
 The griping covers a range of ground, from broad policy to plain old pork to the presence on the White House staff of a special assistant whose chief responsibility is the political care and feeding of California, the state that has long since supplanted New York as the nation's political powerhouse, with 54 electoral votes to New York's 33, and that is much less securely in the Clinton camp.
"We like to think we had a lot to do with electing President Clinton," said Representative Thomas J. Manton, the Queens County Democratic leader, who backed Mr. Clinton early and now frets about lack of patronage and attention. "Maybe we didn't have as much to do with it as we thought."
 
'Sometimes You Scratch Your Head'
 Or as Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn put it: "There's no question we have more access, and it can make a difference. But sometimes you scratch your head and wonder what it brings you."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is facing a potentially tough re-election campaign and who has never had smooth relations with Mr. Clinton, was so exercised at the thought that New York's influence might be waning that he proposed moving its 1996 presidential primary from April to early March, to compete with California, which moved its primary up from June. There is similar talk in New Jersey, which Mr. Clinton won for the Democrats for the first time since 1964.
Clinton Administration officials freely concede the President's debts to New York, where his victory in the Democratic primary staved off the last real threat by Edmund G. Brown Jr., where the Democratic Convention nominated him and where he won 50 percent of the vote in the general election, a feat exceeded only in his home state of Arkansas. He is to visit the city again on Thursday, one of a half-dozen trips there since taking office, to highlight his proposals for youth service and fighting crime. But they say New York is just one of a handful of important big states, like New Jersey, that Mr. Clinton needs to win again.
Mr. Cuomo and the congressional delegation can recite their grievances like a chorus: The proposed cuts in the current budget for home-heating aid to the poor and for mass-transit operating subsidies, the fears about how regional health-insurance pools could punish places with lots of poor people and how changes in medical education could hurt a state that trains 15 percent of the nation's doctors, the loss to Stanford University of a $36 million high-energy physics laboratory that had seemed a lock for Cornell.
 
Deep Cuts in Reserves
 The latest blow came last week when the Defense Department proposed to cut 5,217 slots from the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps Reserves in New York -- more than any other state and twice as many as in California, which has half again as many reserves to begin with. The Army said that reservists in the Northeast had much poorer recruitment and retention rates, but New Yorkers say something broader is afoot.
"This administration is definitely tilted toward California," said Representative Sherwood Bohlert, a moderate Republican from the Mohawk Valley. "There's just no doubt about it."
It is an old complaint. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan noted that the New Deal itself did not especially favor New York, though its creators were New Yorkers.
"The Roosevelt Administration was populated by officials whose policy it was to develop the South and the West pretty much at the expense of the Northeast, especially New York," the Senator wrote last year in his annual report on the gap between New York's contribution to Federal taxes and its receipts in Federal aid. "Hence the Tennessee Valley Authority, the great Western dams, the credit programs and so through that great array of New Deal programs."
In fact, many New Yorkers acknowledge, their expectations were impossibly high, so that the shifts in priorities and the empathy with urban problems that Democrats in the White House have brought seem cold consolation, while complaints that might have been small beer a few years ago loom large.
The truth is that many of the New Yorkers in big jobs, like Harold M. Ickes, the deputy chief of staff; Robert E. Rubin, the chief assistant for economic policy; Bernard W. Nussbaum, the White House counsel who resigned under pressure last weekend, and Roger C. Altman, the deputy treasury secretary, have been so busy shaping global policy or embroiled in political woes like the Whitewater affair that New York is the last thing on their minds.
 
A Tough Sell
 "When people become high officials of the Government, they stop being New Yorkers or Chicagoans or Angelenos," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the former chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. "They become Government officials."
Moreover, while the President's proposals in fields like health, welfare and crime might be good for New York, many of the specifics that would most help the state remain a tough sell on Capitol Hill, even with Mr. Moynihan's standing as the first chairman of the Senate Finance Committee from the Empire State in more than 150 years.
For example, Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Moynihan spent months trying to persuade the White House to change the formula for the Federal contribution to Medicaid, which is based on a state's per capita income, and takes no account of the number of poor people, labor costs or medical needs. The result is that the Federal Government pays 80 percent of Medicaid costs in a state like Mississippi and just 50 percent in states like New York and California.
The White House sent its bill to Congress without changing the formula to New York's advantage, since doing so would hurt many more states than it would help, and Mr. Moynihan is left to make common cause with other rich states like California and round up the votes for change, an uphill battle.
Administration officials cite the way such hard realities can bind even rival states as proof that they are not playing favorites.
"I don't know the source of the upset, but I do know the process is we've been talking both with the state and the delegation," said John P. Hart, deputy director of the White House's office of intergovernmental affairs. "We believe New York wins under the President's health proposals, and the whole effort is staffed with a multitude of New Yorkers, who are very sensitive to its needs."
 
'A Critical State'
 The White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said that California's natural and economic disasters had made it a "special case," but that the President had no intention of taking New York for granted. "New York is a critical state," she said.
There are realities, however.
"Unfortunately, Clinton is anxious to make universal some standards which are already quite high in New York, in terms of programs like health care and so on," said former Representative Barber B. Conable of upstate Alexander, N.Y. "That may not be a bad idea, but it means almost inevitably there'll be some watering down of programs in New York."
Hugh L. Carey saw New York-Washington tensions from both ends, as a Brooklyn Congressman when the state had 41 House members -- 10 more than now -- and then as Governor in the fiscal crisis.
"New Yorkers are born not to be satisfied," he said. "This is the launching of a major aircraft carrier, and you can't expect it's going to go sailing down the waves the first day."
From this perspective, New York's record appears mixed, though calculating it is impossible, because the current budget year, this President's first, is unfinished, and the fight is just beginning for the coming year. For many proposed cuts in the President' current budget -- drafted under tight spending caps imposed by past deficit-reduction agreements -- there are compensating benefits. Thus mass-transit operating funds would be trimmed, but money for construction would increase; money for housing would be cut, but other programs for the homeless expanded.
Even the opposition party, in the person of New York City's new Republican Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, is cautious. "The story isn't over," said Alice Tetelman, Mr. Giuliani's new lobbyist here. "The fight over welfare and health reform is just beginning, and when you look at the role that Senator Moynihan and Congressman Rangel are going to play, I'm optimistic that New York's needs will receive the attention they deserve."
 
More Than Equal
 Cabinet officers like Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who was raised in Harlem, and Donna Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, who grew to prominence as president of Hunter College, visit New York often. Their bureaucracies are filled with New Yorkers who return phone calls and requests for help from people back home.
But Administration officials quietly acknowledge that is not the point. They say the New Yorkers want to be preeminent, not just equal to the other big states, like Ohio, Illinois, Michigan and New Jersey, that are important to the President but less important than California, where his poll standings were shaky long before the recent earthquake led him to send billions of dollars in aid.
"Maybe we should be doing more just for New York; we probably should," one senior agency official said. "But that opens up a whole can of worms, with a lot of other states in line."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Climb As Cost of Oil Declines

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Buoyed by a decline in oil prices and a rally in European bonds, Treasury prices rose and yields fell yesterday for only the sixth time since the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates on Feb. 4.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond rose 12/32 yesterday in late trading to 934/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the prices, fell to 6.79 percent, from 6.83 percent on Friday. Still, the yield has risen about half a percentage point since the Fed acted. 
 Dealers said the European bond trading set the tone for trading in New York. Treasury bonds were already up a quarter of a point in Europe even before the New York market opened. Gerald A. Guile, senior manager of fixed-income securities at Advest Inc., said the European rally was apparently started by traders who had sold bonds short last week, only to find themselves scrambling to buy securities yesterday to cover those short positions as prices rose. In a short sale, a trader sells a borrowed security in the expectation of profiting by buying it back at a lower price.
 
Inflation Worries Assuaged
 The decline in crude oil added strength to the Treasury market's rally, because the drop portends low inflation. Oil producers at a weekend meeting of the Gulf Cooperation Council showed no sign of cutting production in the face of declining production.
Analysts also said the Treasury market was relieved that the Federal Reserve made no move yesterday to nudge up short-term interest rates. About the only move the central bank made was to add reserves to the banking system at its normal time of intervention.
Louis Crandall, chief economist for R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said the Fed's move to inject funds into the banking system was a confirmation of the status quo. Economists said the injection reflected a shortage of reserves in the banking system, rather than a change in interest rate policy.
Yields on intermediate- and shorter-term Treasury notes also fell yesterday. And the rate for the one-year bill fell two basis points, to 4.05 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Volatile Market
 Analysts at MMS International noted that the Treasury market was characterized by extreme volatility last week, continuing the bearish trend that has been in place since the Fed pushed up the Federal funds rate on Feb. 4. Nevertheless, these analysts saw prospects for a rebound on the long end. Some analysts, contending that the longer-term inflation fears are exaggerated, expect the long end of the yield curve to stabilize in the weeks ahead.
Inflation, which erodes the returns on fixed-income securities, has become an obsession for some investors, leading to some extreme reactions to any sign of rising prices. Some analysts and traders blame the Fed for the market's inflation scare, contending it tightened when it did not appear to be necessary. Others said the Fed's slow response heightened the concern about inflation.
William B. Shea, senior vice president for government bond trading at the Nikko Securities Company International Inc., said two days of extremely trading high volume last week proved troublesome for short positions. "Technically, when you have a climax to selling, it will be followed up by buying," Mr. Shea said. "But the little investor should remain cautious and stay at the front of the yield curve, inside the two-year maturity."
He added, "They are better off waiting for a confirmed bottom on the long end of the market."
 
Traders See Opportunity
 Yesterday the Treasury sold $25.2 billion in bills, but aside from the weekly auctions, no new supply of Government securities is due until the Treasury's monthly two- and five-year note auctions on March 22 and 23. Traders said the respite might give the bond market a little window of opportunity to bounce, if demand outstrips supply, pushing prices higher and rates lower.
At the weekly Treasury auction yesterday, the average discount rate for a three-month bill was 3.52 percent, up from 3.40 percent last week; it was the highest since June 29, 1992, when it was 3.59 percent. The average discount rate for the six-month maturity was 3.75 percent, up from 3.61 percent last week; it was the highest since June 22, 1992, when it was 3.77 percent.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Up Again But the Monthly Pace Eases

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Consumer credit rose $6 billion in January -- the eighth straight increase -- but at a slower pace than the previous month.
Borrowing climbed at a 9.1 percent annual rate, following an 11.5 percent increase in December, revised from the previously reported 11.2 percent, and a 10.7 percent rise in November, the Federal Reserve said yesterday. 
 The December increase was $7.5 billion.
The January rise was smaller than many economists predicted, but they did expect a slower pace, based on a previously reported five-tenths of 1 percent drop in retail sales because of harsh winter weather in much of the nation and the Los Angeles earthquake.
The latest rise brought outstanding debt to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $796.1 billion.
The Fed said growth in revolving credit, which includes credit cards, accelerated in January while growth in auto and other consumer loans slowed.
Many economists expect consumer spending, which represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, to level off this year after a buying binge in the final months of 1993 that helped fuel a strong expansion in the economy in the fourth quarter.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told the Thrift Depositor Protection Oversight Board yesterday: "Our economy is doing quite well and it looks as if it will continue to do so for the foreseeable future. What we've been striving for is long-term sustainable growth with low inflation, and that's what's resulted thus far."
By category, the Fed said auto loans in January rose at a 2.7 percent annual rate, to $279 billion, after a 6.4 percent increase in December. Revolving credit picked up 14.2 percent, to $284.8 billion, exceeding the previous month's 9.5 percent rise. Other consumer loans climbed 10.6 percent, to $232.3 billion, after a 20.4 percent jump in December.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Talk of Lower German Rates Helps Dollar Gain on Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly mixed yesterday, firming against the German mark on renewed talk about lower German interest rates but slipping against some other European currencies.
In New York, the dollar rose to 1.7210 marks in late trading from 1.7190 marks on Friday. But the British pound edged up to $1.4902 from $1.4900. 
 News that the large I. G. Metall engineering workers' union had reached a tentative agreement with management raised hopes for a cut in German credit market rates, possibly as early as tomorrow.
 
 
One Obstacle Removed
 The I. G. Metall deal averted a potentially crippling strike only hours before its planned start yesterday.
Many analysts suspected that a strike, along with concerns about unsettlingly high German money supply numbers, would prevent Germany's Bundesbank from easing rates because of concerns about inflation.
But dealers said the wage agreement removed one obstacle to a German easing and supported the dollar.
The dollar tends to benefit from lower German interest rates, which diminish the attractiveness of mark-denominated assets.
"The feeling is that the wage settlement gives the Bundesbank more room to cut interest rates," Bruce English, vice president and head of institutional sales at ABM-AMRO Bank, said. "It makes the dollar a little bit more attractive."
While inching higher against the mark, the dollar failed to make strong gains. Increased attention to the Whitewater affair surrounding the Clinton Administration has made some traders jittery.
"There's talk in the market that if the situation gets any worse it's going to start pressuring the dollar," David Durst, vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company, said.
The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.60 yen, down from 105.65 yen on Friday.
Some traders said the dollar seemed to have bottomed out against the yen. As such, they said they had begun to shift their focus toward stronger American economic fundamentals and away from the trade tensions between Washington and Tokyo.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4408 Swiss francs, down from 1.4410; 5.8445 French francs, down from 5.8455; $1.3558 (Canadian), up from $1.3573 (Canadian), and 1,691 Italian lire, up from 1,687.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
April Contract for Crude Oil Plummets 47 Cents, to $14.10

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Oil prices fell sharply yesterday, approaching their five-year lows, on the growing belief that the world's major oil producers would not cut output even as consumption declines in the second quarter.
A Gulf Cooperation Council meeting over the weekend failed to discuss OPEC oil production quotas, a clue that no reductions were planned at a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in three weeks. 
 Demand for petroleum subsides in spring after the Northern Hemisphere's winter heating season and before the peak summer driving season.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for April delivery dropped 47 cents, to $14.10 a barrel. Near the close of trading, the May crude oil futures contract hit a low of $14.08, and many see a test of $13.75, the nearby contract's five-year low hit in December.
Cyrus Tahmassebi, Ashland Oil's chief economist, predicted that OPEC would continue its quota of 24.5 million barrels a day.
Demand for OPEC's oil is seen as shrinking to 23.7 million barrels a day in the quarter beginning in April, and non-OPEC producers continue to pump at a brisk pace.
"But if prices continue to go down the next few days, it may force OPEC to take action and that may mean a cut," Mr. Tahmassebi said.
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to meet March 25 in Geneva.
"I think the market is factoring into prices right now a rollover" of the OPEC quota, said Victor Yu, trader at the Nikkhah Energy Group.
"It is expected to get colder here later this week, but for all intents and purposes the heating oil season is almost over," he added.
Among other energy contracts, April heating oil fell 1.52 cents, to 43.37 cents a gallon; April unleaded gasoline shed 1.38 cents, to 43.75 cents a gallon, after hitting a new contract low, and April natural gas sank 2.1 cents, to $2.167 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Sinking oil prices helped push down inflation-conscious precious metals, which have been under pressure because of concern that the Federal Reserve would increase interest rates. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, April gold dropped $1.70, to $376.90 an ounce, and May silver lost 6.3 cents, to $5.207 an ounce. April platinum, traded at the New York Mercantile Exchange, declined $1.80, to $393.50.
The Fed has said it is keeping an eye on gold prices as an inflation indicator, and may raise interest rates to keep a lid on the economy and inflation.
