HEADLINE: NASA Budget Cuts Raise Serious Concerns Over Safety of Shuttle

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.

 BODY:
DESPITE a picture-perfect blastoff of the space shuttle Columbia on Friday and recent euphoria over the successful repair of the Hubble Space Telescope, funds for upkeep of the nation's shuttle fleet have been going down steadily, touching off a debate over whether the space agency is being forced to cut corners and raise the risk that its temperamental spaceships might break down or blow up.
Private experts say a rush of belt-tightening is threatening safety. But the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, while conceding that it is trimming fat, insists that nothing is being done that would endanger the lives of astronauts. NASA officials say no program change will weaken the agency's commitment to put safety first at all times. 
 The winged spaceships are the world's most complex and dangerous vehicles for the routine transport of people. The risk of catastrophic failure during the shuttle's fiery eight-and-a-half-minute ascent to orbit, the most dangerous part of the flight, is estimated by NASA at about 1 in 75 missions and by private experts at about 1 in 60. In theory, lapses in maintenance could make those numbers even gloomier.
The Challenger disaster eight years ago, in which six astronauts and a high school teacher died, was seen as partly a result of tight budgets that caused declines in maintenance and repair. Joints on booster rockets were known to be weak, but replacements arrived too late to prevent a blowtorch-like leakage of burning fuel and the deadly explosion.
In December, new questions were raised about the booster rockets, which had begun firing unevenly. Critics charged that this type of unevenness could break the spacecraft apart in mid-flight.
The latest focus of worry is a system that has long been considered one of the spaceship's riskiest: the high-pressure pumps that feed liquid hydrogen to combustion chambers for explosive burning. Each of the shuttle's three main engines is fed by one of these high-pressure fuel pumps.
The 3.5-ton pumps are each about the size of an automobile engine but generate an astonishing 75,000 horsepower. This is achieved largely by spinning them at 37,000 revolutions per minute, more than 12 times as fast as the crankshaft of a car zipping along at 60 miles per hour. These rotations put huge stresses on the 122 turbine blades, each about the size of a half-dollar and each producing about 700 horsepower. The exit pressures from the pump are so great that hydrogen fuel, if shot straight up, would rise 34 miles.
"The pumps have been a source of concern from day one," Dr. Seymour C. Himmel, a senior member of NASA's Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel, said in a telephone interview. The high-pressure pumps and similar gear long ago led NASA to conclude that the shuttle's main engines have the highest risk of catastrophic failure of any shuttle system, higher than even the booster rockets that touched off the Challenger disaster.
NASA officials say apprehension about the pumps recently soared when defects were found in a number of their internal welds, after an anonymous tip led to inspections. While no flaw was discovered in the all-important turbine blades, the problematic welds have been banned from flight hardware and have prompted a major inquiry.
"We're under the gun to reduce resources to the shuttle," said Dr. Daniel R. Mulville, a senior official in the safety office at NASA headquarters in Washington. "It's a challenge, but our approach is not to compromise safety."
Joseph J. Trento, a former Congressional aide who follows the shuttle program for the National Security News Service, a private group based in Washington, said the weld troubles arose when NASA, as part of a cost-cutting move, began letting the manufacturer rather than Federal inspectors verify its pump-assembly work.
In general, Mr. Trento said, NASA is playing with fire by trying to run the shuttle on the cheap. "They're keeping the thing together with baling wire and matchsticks," he said. "The budget is being cut and nobody is paying attention."
Funds for shuttle operations have fallen for several years in a row, according to NASA. The budget went from $4.074 billion in the fiscal year 1992 to $3.870 billion in 1993 and $3.601 billion in 1994. In the proposed 1995 budget that President Clinton recently presented to Congress, the funds would drop further still, to $3.381 billion. If corrected for inflation, that is less money than shuttle operations were getting at the time of the 1986 Challenger disaster.
 
Warning of Calamity
 Daniel S. Goldin, NASA's Administrator and a proponent of streamlining in what many have seen as a bloated agency, recently told Congress that the budget could fall no further without raising the risk of calamity.
"This is it," he said. "We can't get any closer to the bone." Mr. Goldin added. "Based on what we know today, we cannot cut human space flight any further without impacting on safety."
While this might seem like budgetary grandstanding, a wide variety of experts, including NASA engineers, say the situation is serious.
One way NASA has trimmed its shuttle budget over the years is by deferring or stretching out costly safety improvements. For instance, work was halted a couple years ago on a replacement high-pressure fuel pump. While the current pump has more than 300 welds, the new one was to have no welds at all and was to incorporate a host of new high-technology materials, vastly increasing its reliability and making it virtually fail-safe. But it would also weigh hundreds of pounds more, negating one reason the lighter-weight welded pump was originally developed.
Another way NASA is trying to cut costs is by reducing inspections of shuttle parts and repair procedures. Inspections skyrocketed after the Challenger disaster. Experts estimate that every time a worker touches the shuttle with a tool that action will, on average, be checked by seven inspectors at one point or another. In all, Congressional experts say, some two million signatures and approvals are needed before any shuttle thunders off the launching pad.
Dr. Himmel of NASA's Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel said that self-inspection was a broad trend within NASA and industry. And it is fundamentally healthy, he argued. By focusing on building in quality rather than on weeding out poor work, the result is a better product, he said. In theory, any problems are caught by final inspections.
"They're trying to change the culture so that the people who do the work are given a large part of the responsibility for the quality," he said. "Inspection is often just people stamping a piece of paper."
He added: "There's always some degree of risk when you change a system. But managers are suppose to monitor that carefully."
The risks for shuttles became evident when the weld flaws in the high-pressure pump slipped past final inspectors, though, according to NASA officials, none slipped far enough through the parts system to be relied upon during the launching of a shuttle into space.
NASA officials say that a report on Sunday in The Daily News of New York that the Columbia went into space with flawed welds was not accurate. Otto K. Goetz, manager for the shuttle's main engine at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., said in response to the article: "We are not flying with faulty welds. If they don't meet the rigorous standards, we don't fly."
 
Problem Is Reported
 Dr. Mulville of NASA headquarters said the weld problem was disclosed anonymously on Nov. 15 through NASA's Safety Reporting System, which was set up after the Challenger disaster. Five kinds of welds in the high-pressure pumps were reported to be faulty, he said. Quick inspections found that the welds were out of alignment. Adjoining pieces were mismatched, weakening the joints. Particularly troubling was weld No. 51, which could not be rewelded without taking the pumps apart.
No moving parts had flawed welds. Instead, the flaws were located on interior casings and areas of the pump that helped direct the flow of hydrogen. And the welds were to operate under enormous pressures, in one case about 7,500 pounds per square inch. At worst, Dr. Mulville said, their failure would cause the collapse of a hydrogen-carrying pathway, causing the pump and its engine to seize up and come to a screeching halt.
"It's a safe shutdown," said Dr. Mulville, "not a catastrophic failure."
Dr. Goetz said all pumps with serious alignment problems in their welds had been prohibited from space flight until a NASA Materials Review Board decided what to do. One option now being considered, he said, is simply to reduce the number of times a suspect part is allowed to power a shuttle. For instance, weld No. 51 is normally allowed to undergo the rigors of a shuttle flight 36 times, but that number might be lowered to the high 20's, Mr. Goetz said, to reduce the risk of a breakdown.
The other option, he said, which would be costly, would be to repair and rebuild the pumps from the bottom up.
Mr. Trento, who has gathered NASA documents on the problem through the Freedom of Information Act, said the situation also involved charges of fraud.
After NASA was alerted to the problem, Mr. Trento said, the agency found that inspection documents had been falsified, apparently in an effort to prevent the delay of the Hubble repair mission in December. "The F.B.I. was brought in and is conducting a criminal probe," Mr. Trento said in an interview.
The manufacturer of the pump, the Rocketdyne Division of Rockwell International, based in Canoga Park, Calif., said it had no comment on the pump issue and directed all questions to the space agency. A number of NASA officials said they would have no comment on any F.B.I. investigation regarding the pump or anything else.
The Justice Department recently made public allegations of fraud on the part of several NASA employees and contractors and declared that its investigations were continuing.
 
Action on Alternative Pump
 Last month, after the weld problems came to light, NASA requested and got permission from Congress to renew development work on the alternative high-pressure fuel pump, which is being built by Pratt & Whitney. It is unclear whether the agency's move was related to the discovery of the weld flaws.
The episode is one of a number of recent events where tight budgets and schedules seem to be squeezing the shuttle. Late last year it was reported that the shuttle's boosters had shown large variations in their thrust, prompting a spate of NASA investigations and accusations by critics that the problem was a time bomb waiting to go off.
NASA officials deny any danger, saying the thrust variations do not represent a serious problem. Even the worst foreseeable spike, they say, would be well within the protective limits set for the shuttle. But that assertion was made after NASA lowered the safety margins early last year to keep the shuttles flying.
John E. Pike, head of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group based in Washington, said the series of recent actions did not build confidence in the future prospects for the world's most complicated flying machine.
"This pattern of activity, of cutting back on safety, of issuing waivers, of flying with problems, strikes me as leading to a situation where the inevitable is going to happen sooner rather than later," he said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Readings Back to Normal
 CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 7 (Reuters) -- Pressure readings were back to normal today in the Columbia's hydraulic system, relieving concerns that the 14-day mission would have to be cut short.
The positive assessment came after three days in which the space shuttle was plagued by an apparent ice buildup in one of its three auxiliary power units. The devices supply hydraulic pressure to operate the shuttle's wing flaps and landing gear. Space officials said the blockage was gone today.


GRAPHIC: The first few minutes of a shuttle flight, while its three main engines are firing, are the most dangerous. Some NASA critics contend that corners have been cut on maintenance and inspection, especially of the high-pressure fuel pumps that feed the engines.
 
"High Pressure, High Risk"
Diagrams: "8 1/2 Perilous Minutes"
 The fuel-delivery system of each main engine has a maze of pipes and valves for circulation of liquids and gases. Hydrogen-rich steam drives turbines of two high-pressure turbopumps (1 and 2) before entering hot gas manifold (3). The hot gas is transferred from the turbines to the main injector (4), where it is mixed with additional liquid oxygen from the oxidizer turbopump (2), for explosive combustion.
 
"Lots of Power in a Small Pump"
 Each of the three 75,000-horsepower fuel pumps weighs about 3.5 tons each, approximately the size of an automobile engine.
 
"Welds Raises Questions"
 Inside each turbopump are rotors bearing 122 half-dollar-size blades, moving at 37,000 revolutions per minute. The safety of key welds in their housing has been questioned, especially that of one weld, No. 51, on the circumference. A plan for a replacement pump with no welds has been reactivated after years of delays because of tight budgets.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Promise To Open The Books

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., March 7

 BODY:
With more than 70 players acting as the receivers, Richard Ravitch threw out the first pitch tonight in the negotiations between the players and club owners for a new collective bargaining agreement. It was more than ceremonial.
In explaining that the owners wanted to achieve "cost certainty" for their business, Ravitch told the players he would share with them all the financial information he and his staff used in hammering out thousands of revenue-sharing plans, one of which the owners finally accepted in January. 
 "Dick said there is nothing they won't turn over," Donald Fehr, head of the players' union, said after a two-hour meeting at a Tampa hotel. "Given the kind of proposal they want, it would be difficult not to give us everything."
 
Absence of Name-Calling
 Nevertheless, it was the kind of step the union and its players are not used to having the owners and their labor negotiators take. The offer by Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, doesn't mean the two sides will have an easier time reaching agreement on the salary cap the owners want. But it helps make for a civilized start.
"Our staffs will be in contact to see if we can arrange the transfer of the data to see if we can make sense out of it," Fehr said. "We want to replicate what the owners went through to get to their revenue-sharing plan. We'll see if we share the same conclusions of their economic analysis."
Fehr and Ravitch and their staffs initially met twice in January 1993, weeks after the owners voted to re-open the labor contract. But the talks then were suspended while Ravitch pursued his effort to get the owners to agree to share a greater portion of their local revenue.
 
Buck Now on Players' Desk
 That plan is in place, but its implementation depends on the players' acceptance of a salary cap. Fehr suggested that the message the players got from Ravitch leaves open the possibility of a change in the revenue-sharing plan.
"They want cost certainty and everything else is flexible," Fehr said. "We take that to mean the revenue-sharing plan is negotiable."
Not that the players are prepared to accept a salary cap that would produce even an amended revenue-sharing plan.
Ravitch said: "We told them our objectives are to produce an economic system in baseball that provides the owners with cost certainty, that we want the right to bargain for the aggregate cost of playing baseball and achieve a system which would enhance competitive balance among clubs. The players' reaction was, 'Why do you want a changed system? How is this different from the past?' "
 
Details No, Dialogue Maybe
 Ravitch did not give the players a detailed proposal, even though that apparently is what the large group came to hear.
"It was intentionally not detailed," Ravitch said. "In the past, when baseball submitted a detailed proposal, we were told it was rigid and it was trashed. Our intention was to state our objectives and elicit their reaction so we could work out a process where we could share revenue information with the players and explain how our revenue distribution system came about."
Fehr said that given the time that has passed since the re-opening of the agreement, the players were frustrated when a proposal was not forthcoming. More frustrating, he said, was the players' presence at the figurative bargaining table with no owners in sight.
 
Players 73, Owners 0
 "The players care an awful lot about baseball and working with the owners," Fehr said, "and if the owners shared that view, they would be here. We had 70-odd players here. Not a single owner will come."
The owners have said that Ravitch is their sole negotiator, and that he, along with his staff -- and not they -- will be at the bargaining sessions.
Although no roll was taken, it appeared that 73 players from at least 10 teams attended the session. Bernie Williams and Steve Howe of the Yankees came from Fort Lauderdale on the other coast. Kevin Brown of Texas came from Port Charlotte, a couple of hours' drive from the south.
Players from Arizona will have a chance to attend the next meeting, scheduled for March 30 in Phoenix.

HEADLINE: Push for Environment Institute

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
IN the belief that environmental policy is often made in scientific ignorance, a broadly based group of scientists, businessmen, environmentalists and politicians has been promoting the establishment of a new Federal institute to guide and finance long-term research on the environment.
After five years of effort, the institute's backers have secured substantial bipartisan support in Congress. And with the appointment today of a leader with international stature on environmental issues to head the campaign, the backers have high hopes that environmental science will soon no longer be, as they see it, the poor stepchild of the Federal research establishment. 
 "It seems this is an idea whose time has come," said Dr. Richard E. Benedick, the new president of the Committee for the National Institute for the Environment, a national, nonprofit organization with more than 5,000 members. Dr. Benedick, a career diplomat who recently retired from the State Department, is perhaps best known as a chief architect of the 1987 Montreal Protocol, the international agreement to protect and restore the earth's ozone layer.
 
Some Political Realities
 Dr. Benedick's optimism about creating an institute for the environment may have to be put on hold. Its key backers in the House of Representatives, where legislation to establish the institution has been introduced, say serious consideration will probably be deferred because of Congress's preoccupation with front-burner issues like health care.
The Clinton Administration has not committed itself on the question, although Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt has endorsed it. Carol Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, who has been trying to strengthen that agency's science base, said that while she is "for more environmental research, absolutely," it would be important to know what research the institute would pursue.
Nevertheless, there seems little doubt that the proposal has won wide support. Its sponsors range from Representative George E. Brown Jr., a liberal California Democrat who heads the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, to Newt Gingrich, the conservative Republican whip from Georgia. There is also support in the Senate, but no legislation has yet been offered there.
The institute's backers see it as filling a critical but neglected niche in Federal support for science. More than 20 Federal agencies engage in environmental research costing about $5 billion a year, according to a 1993 study by a National Research Council committee. But most of that research serves the agencies' limited agendas and is aimed at short-term regulatory questions.
As a result, advocates of the new institute say, research is conducted in a piecemeal manner that lacks focus on long-term changes in the environment. A Carnegie Commission study in 1992 characterized much of the existing research as "diffuse, reactive and focused on short-range, end-of-the-pipe solutions."
The backers contend further that most Federal environmental research fails to tap the expertise of academia, is done by Government employees and is not usually subjected to the peer-review process through which scientific research is customarily validated. As a result, when policymakers ask questions, the answers are fragmentary and their validity is open to question, the advocates say.
All of this, they add, makes it more likely that environmental policy will be set primarily on political rather than scientific grounds, and even that policy paralysis will result. "The lack of political will to act is due in part to lack of understanding of environmental problems and controversy over the best course of action," the committee says in one of its publications.
The National Research Council panel found no strong commitment to environmental research at the top levels of government. Environmental matters, it found, have been regarded as less important than those involving the military, health and transportation. There is no comprehensive research effort for the environment as a whole, the panel concluded, nor is there any coordinated national plan for environmental research.
Other independent studies have found that existing environmental research heavily favors the physical sciences over research on the impact of environmental change on living things, including people.
 
Focus on Specific Issues
 The shortage of Federal support reverberates in academia, where it exerts a depressing effect on ecological research, advocates of the new institute say. In fact, one early spur to the campaign for the institute was the realization that a lack of Federal dollars leads universities to place a lower priority on ecological research.
Administrators "had simply determined that they could not afford ecologists," Dr. Henry F. Howe, an ecologist at the University of Illinois at Chicago who is vice chairman of the committee for the environmental institute, wrote last year in The Environmental Professional, a journal.
As Dr. Howe, Dr. Benedick and other backers of the institute see it, the institute would address all these shortcomings. Like the National Science Foundation and the National Institutes of Health, a new institute would identify gaps in knowledge and set research priorities. It would award research grants competitively and enter into research contracts on particular subjects.
Unlike the National Science Foundation, which focuses on basic research, the environmental institute's priorities would be directed at specific policy issues like global warming and biological diversity. The overall goal would be to develop basic understanding of all the interlocking physical, biological, technological, economic, social and political causes of environmental problems.
No existing research organization is equipped to do all this, the institute's advocates say, and they argue that it would not duplicate research already being pursued by other agencies. While there is no guarantee the institute would solve the basic problem, Dr. Benedick said, "enough people have come to a conclusion that it would provide a proper focus of intellectual power on these issues."
Dr. Benedick cites the scientific effort that led to the Montreal Protocol as an example of the kind of policy research that the new institute would pursue. In that instance, an ad hoc scientific group working for the United Nations studied the causes and remedies of a weakening in the earth's protective ozone shield.
"We agreed that if these experiments were done in a certain way, we'd all have to buy off on the results," Dr. Benedick said. And so, there was an unusual consensus among policymakers about what should be done. But the ozone case was an exception, Dr. Benedick said, and the hope is that the new institute would make it the rule.
 
Need for Independence
 Other ways to achieve this goal have been proposed, including reorganizing and consolidating existing Federal agencies to sharpen the research focus. But Dr. Benedick and his colleagues believe that the leading environmental research agency must be independent. Otherwise, Dr. Benedick said, it could be swallowed up by the needs and agendas of existing agencies.
The campaign for the institute is under way at a time when Federal money is scarce, but Dr. Benedick said it would start small with a budget of $50 million to $130 million, which might grow to $500 million or $600 million, mostly for research grants, in five years.
A bill to establish the institute has gained 66 sponsors in the House. Its chief sponsors are Mr. Brown and Representative James H. Saxton, Republican of New Jersey. Mr. Saxton said he thinks the prospects for passage are "pretty good" because the institute would provide lawmakers with a better foundation on which to build policy, because the solutions to most environmental problems lie in science and because business and the economy would be protected from unnecessary regulation resulting from "overreaching."
But Mr. Saxton said that because of the heavy press of Congressional business, he was "not as optimistic about action in this session as I was six or eight months ago."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
LDDS FILES REQUEST FOR LONG-DISTANCE SERVICE TO CUBA

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
LDDS Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a request to provide direct long-distance telephone service to Cuba. The agreement between LDDS and EmtelCuba, the communications arm of the Cuban Government, must be approved by the Federal Communications Commission and the United States Department of the Treasury. 
 In July, the Clinton Administration decided to permit American telephone companies to expand links to Cuba. The decision was in response to a surge in calls to Cuba through Canadian companies, evading the economic embargo of Cuba and charging higher rates than American companies. A.T.& T. maintains limited service to Cuba. LDDS, based in Jackson, Miss., is the nation's fourth-largest long-distance carrier.

HEADLINE: Mitchell's Surprise Transforms Politics in Maine

BYLINE: By KATHARINE SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., March 7

 BODY:
So many candidates, so little time.
Senator George J. Mitchell's surprise decision not to seek re-election has produced an outbreak of campaign fever here among all sorts of politicians, from erstwhile governors to legislative batboys. 
 Even before Mr. Mitchell announced his decision on Friday, more than a dozen candidates were vying to replace Gov. John R. McKernan Jr., a Republican who cannot seek a third term.
Now, with Mr. Mitchell's Senate seat open, a new field of candidates has emerged. And with both of Maine's two United States Representatives expected to seek to succeed Mr. Mitchell, a multitude of other candidates, including at least a dozen state legislators, are eyeing the sudden possibilities in the House.
 
'Creative Chaos'
 "Everyone has been burning up the phone lines," said Jim Mitchell, the Senator's nephew, who is also chairman of the state Democratic party and a possible Congressional candidate himself. "The dam has broken, there are a lot of opportunities, and everyone is rethinking their political futures."
Ben Coes, executive director of the state Republican Party, had similar observations. "Everything has crashed through; people are flying everywhere," he said. "It's creative chaos."
On Saturday, when Mr. Mitchell held a news conference in Portland's City Hall to discuss his decision not to run again in November, several local politicians worked the room. The atmosphere is especially intense because people who had not planned to run for office this year suddenly have to gather 2,000 signatures by April 1 to get on the June primary ballot.
Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican who has represented half of Maine in the House since 1978, was the first to jump into the Senate race. With time so short, Ms. Snowe announced her decision in a news release today from Washington. She barely had time to consult her husband, Governor McKernan, who is traveling in South America to promote Maine products.
 
Delegation of Freshmen
 "Usually, you want to prepare for these things," she said.
Maine's other House member, Thomas H. Andrews, a Democrat who received Mr. Mitchell's blessing last week, is all but certain to enter the race, possibly on Tuesday.
If both Ms. Snowe, 47, and Mr. Andrews, 40, win their primaries, it could set up a classic clash in the fall between Maine's more conservative north, represented by Ms. Snowe, and its more liberal south, represented by Mr. Andrews. Democrats slightly outnumber Republicans among Maine voters, but even more are independent or belong to minor parties.
Mr. Mitchell's departure raises the prospect of wide-open races this year for four of the state's five major offices -- the Senate seat, the governorship and the two seats in the House. The term of Maine's other Senator, William S. Cohen, a Republican, is not up until 1996.
For an economically precarious state like Maine, which lost 40,000 jobs when New England's high-tech boom went bust in the late 1980's, freshmen in Washington could spell disaster.
Mr. Mitchell is credited with directing substantial aid to his home state, from millions to rebuild bridges and highways and restore passenger train service between Portland and Boston, to money for studies of potato blight, a prime concern of impoverished farmers in Aroostook County.
As majority leader, Mr. Mitchell was also able to persuade Administration officials to change executive orders to protect Maine from certain recycling and fishing rules that would have hurt its important paper and fishing industries. And he prevented, for the moment, the closing of the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard, averting the loss of thousands of jobs.
"We're in for a period of significant adjustment," said Duane (Buzz) Fitzgerald, the chief executive of Bath Iron Works, the state's largest private employer. "The biggest thing on the minds of people in Maine right now is the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard and the Brunswick Naval Air Station, since there will be another round of base closings in '95."
 Mr. Mitchell's absence from the next part of the base-closing process is forcing companies doing Pentagon-related work to look at prospective successors. "We need to talk about what we need to do politically, tactically and strategically, including finding a candidate to back," said Mr. Fitzgerald.
 
 
Worry in Washington
 The Mainers who have benefited from Mr. Mitchell's tenure are not the only people worried about his departure.
With Mr. Mitchell the fifth Democratic Senator to call it quits this year, Democrats in Washington are becoming edgy about their 56-to-44 hold on the Senate. Although three Republican incumbents are also stepping down, the Clinton Administration's preoccupation with the Whitewater investigation and Mr. Mitchell's lame-duck status could scotch Democratic efforts at meaningful legislation this year and imperil their majority.
Mr. Mitchell's seat, once considered safe, could easily slip from the Democratic column. Independent and maverick candidates have often appealed to Mainers, and more than a third of the state's voters are unaffiliated or attached to minor parties. Democrats, who claim 33 percent of voters, only slightly outnumber Republicans.
Implacably Republican since before the Civil War, the state's conservative, mainstream image was long captured in the slogan, "As Maine goes, so goes the nation." But since 1936, when only Maine and Vermont voted for Alf Landon over Franklin D. Roosevelt, the state's quirky electorate earned itself a revised slogan: "As Maine goes, so goes Vermont."
Maine has voted for the loser in more Presidential elections than any other state, and it seems particularly fond of candidates who promote themselves as outsiders. Jesse Jackson and Edmund G. Brown Jr. have done well here, and Ross Perot earned a bigger percentage of the vote here than anywhere else, beating out a Maine resident named George Bush.
Still, the 60-year-old Mr. Mitchell, along with his mentor, former Senator Edmund S. Muskie, has helped bring respectability to Democrats here, and few doubt that he would have been a shoo-in for re-election.
Some here hope that Mr. Mitchell's decision to bow out while things are going well for him will become his lasting legacy and inspire other office-holders to do the same.
"There is universal respect here for the fact that he is leaving while he is on top rather than being, say, indicted," said Rick Barton, the former state Democratic Party chairman. "That's a wonderful gift to the political system, if it will be received."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 19, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on March 8 about politics in Maine misstated the state's record in Presidential elections. Maine has voted for the loser more often than any other state only since 1936, not throughout the history of the country.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Digital Will Cut 6,000 Jobs in Europe

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation confirmed yesterday that it planned to lay off 6,000 employees, or 20 percent of its European work force, within the next 12 to 18 months.
In an internal memorandum sent out this weekend and dated yesterday, Vincenzo Damiani, the recently appointed president of Digital Europe, told the company's European managers that estimates he had made last month on projected cutbacks were accurate. Mr. Damiani, who left I.B.M. to join Digital Europe on Jan. 1, was quoted in the press in February as anticipating cutting as many as 5,000 to 6,000 workers from Digital's European work force of 29,000 employees. 
 The struggling computer giant does 64 percent of its business outside the United States. Digital's European operation accounted for nearly half of the company's $14 billion in revenues in 1993 and European employment peaked in 1991 with 41,000 employees.
In an interview with Reuters in February, Mr. Damiani said he was examining the "right size" for Digital Europe as part of a plan for reviving revenue growth and cutting costs. "My fundamental mind-set is in determining how many people we need rather than how many people we need to cut," he said.
 
Cuts From the Bottom Up
 Nikki Richardson, a spokeswoman for the parent company, said the cutbacks were part of Digital's continuing program of staff reductions and that the European cuts would come from the bottom up, as is being done in the company's United States operations.
With two large European acquisitions in the early 1990's, Digital added nearly 11,000 employees just as it began to reduce the rest of its work force. The company, based in Maynard, Mass., currently has 92,300 employees worldwide.
William M. Steul, Digital's chief financial officer, estimated in January that the company would end the fiscal year with approximately 85,000 employees. Mr. Steul said the European market, particularly in Germany, France, Britain and Italy, had been weak for two years.
Mr. Steul noted that the dollar's strength against European currencies continued to hurt Digital's revenues. But he said he expected to see a recovery in the company's European business later this year and next as the economy there turns around.
Digital surprised analysts with a net loss of $72 million in its fiscal second quarter, which ended Dec. 31, 1993. That loss, along with a 12 percent revenue decline, signaled that the company's turnaround efforts were moving more slowly than anticipated.
Digital's stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $31.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Legislators Drop a Ban On Plastic Packaging for Foods

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 8

 BODY:
Six years ago, environmentalists cheered as the Suffolk County Legislature approved a bill banning a host of plastic products, from hamburger containers to polystyrene cups. Although its champions heralded it as a measure that should be adopted nationwide, the restrictions never really took effect.
Efforts to enforce the stringent law, which permitted biodegradable food containers only, were repeatedly postponed by the 18-member Legislature as delicatessens, retail food stores and fast-food chains requested more time to find substitutes that were cost-effective and environmentally acceptable.
 
Recycling Instead
 But today, the Legislature adopted an amendment eliminating the ban on plastics that would push for more recycling instead. 
 "It's just a beginning," said Legislator Thomas Finlay, a Republican, after his proposal was adopted by a vote of 11-7.
Sipping from a can of soda made of recyclable aluminum, Mr. Finlay said, "The next step is to expand the law and make recycling mandatory."
The bill now goes to County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, a Republican, who is expected to approve it.
Among those who voted against the measure was Legislator Maxine S. Postal, the Democratic minority leader.
"This isn't going to solve the problem," she said. "In reality we're worse off than we were six years ago."
Another opponent, Legislator Nora Bredes, a Democrat who supports environmental causes, said, however, that the old ban "needed to be expanded, not repealed."
The original law to ban plastics was held up by litigation by the plastics industry. The law became an embarrassment even to many environmentalists, who now accept that plastics, when compacted in a landfill, are not much worse than paper.
The plastics ban was enacted when the worst recession in decades was increasing concerns about the burdens of government, and about laws that add to the cost of everyday life.
Environmentalists shifted their focus to a state-by-state drive for laws that pressure the packaging industry to produce lighter packaging, and, like Mr. Finlay's proposal, promote recycling and create markets for recycled products.
During public comment before today's vote, Patricia Brodhagen, a spokeswoman for the New York State Food Merchants Association, which long opposed the plastics ban, urged support of the revised law.
"It strikes a balance between a compelling need to relieve business of an enormous economic burden, and the desire to accomplish waste reduction."
Thomas K. Cullen, vice president of the King Kullen Grocery Company, said that the food industry had been "singled out" by the plastics ban. He said the amended law would "provide relief for that industry and encourage local commercial recycling efforts."
Although Suffolk's plastic's ban failed, it is credited by supporters with pressuring the plastics industry to address long-neglected environmental concerns and prodding McDonald's and other fast-food chains to abandon their plastic foam packaging in favor of cardboard boxes and sacks made from recycled paper.
 
Recycling Refuse
 The new measure would encourage consumers to place plastic refuse in plastic barrels so it could be recycled into supermarket shopping bags and other recyclable products.
In an effort to break the impasses of the last six years, Mr. Finlay's measure allows large establishments like hospitals, nursing homes, cafeterias and schools to comply by setting up programs to separate polystyrene packaging and arrange to have it transported to recycling facilities. Each program would be certified by the County Health Department.
The bill also encourages towns and villages to create dropoff sites for polystyrene materials that homeowners separate from their garbage. Retail food establishments will be able to meet new Health Department rules when they put workable collection and recycling programs in place. Retailers can offer consumers a choice between biodegradable paper packaging or nonbiodegradable plastic containers.
Mr. Finlay hopes to encourage a market for the recyclable materials by providing a mandated source of supply. The bulk would come from large institutions, like hospitals, school cafeterias and corporations, which would provide a constant, dependable stream of used plastic.

HEADLINE: Mayor Details Buyout Offer for City Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Negotiating with New York City's municipal unions for the first time, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani offered yesterday to pay workers $5,000 to $10,000 each in cash and provide up to a year of health benefits to entice about 7,600 of them to leave the municipal payroll, administration officials said.
As part of its offer, the Mayor's office told the unions that it would allow workers to collect pay for unused vacation days and sick leave, in payments spread out over the next three years. That could amount to "extraordinarily large pots of money," one of the officials said. The offer also included unemployment insurance in most cases, the official said, and a job retraining program. 
 Still, with a median salary of $31,434 in most city agencies, excluding teachers and employees of independent agencies like the Health and Hospitals Corporation, the administration's offer represents at most a few months of salary for most workers.
 
Talks Described as Positive
 That raises questions about how many city workers would be willing to accept the severance offer, which could save as much as $261 million over the next 16 months if accepted by as many workers as the administration hopes. The offer is a vital part of the Mayor's plan to balance the city's $31.2 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins in July.
After the meeting, Stanley Hill, the chairman of the Municipal Labor Committee, described the initial talks as positive. But he declined to comment specifically on the administration's severance offer.
Mr. Hill, the executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, did say that the Mayor's office gave only a broad outline of its proposals and did not identify all the jobs it intends to include under the offer.
"From the point of view of our first time at the table, it was positive," Mr. Hill said. "There's still some very tough negotiations to deal with; I want to make that clear."
Raymond D. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit fiscal monitoring group, said it was difficult to predict how successful the offer would be. For example, he said, the threat of layoffs might not provide enough incentive if a worker has built up enough seniority to be reasonably well protected.
"The whole thing is a crap shoot," he said. "It's hard to tell how to react. But there might be a lot of people who are one year from retirement who might take $10,000."
The proposal emerged as the Mayor's office and the city's municipal unions met face to face yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of District Council 37, on Barclay Street, a few blocks from City Hall.
While the city's municipal unions announced last week that they would accept a severance program, the details of the packages must still be hammered out in negotiations over the next few days and could change considerably. "It's a fluid situation," said another official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
 
Promised Job Cuts
 The Mayor still needs the approval of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation to use $200 million in a surplus fund to pay for the severance packages. The Mayor hopes the packages will eliminate about half of the 15,000 jobs that he has promised to cut from the 216,000 workers paid entirely by the city.
Quentin B. Spector, the corporation's executive director, said yesterday that the administration had outlined its proposals to the corporation's board of nine directors but had left some questions unanswered.
The unions asked the Mayor's lead negotiator, the Commissioner of Labor, Randy Levine, to return with more details. A meeting was not set, but administration officials said it was important to move quickly in order to offer the severance packages before the end of March.
To succeed, the Mayor's plan also requires a major concession from the unions that would grant the city more flexibility in reassigning workers from agency to agency, making it easier to fill holes in essential services, something the unions have opposed in the past. In return, the Mayor's office would offer cash incentives to workers shifted to new agencies.
If the unions agree, the severance packages would be offered to about 70,000 employees in every agency except the uniformed services, the Board of Education and the independent agencies or authorities, like the Health and Hospitals Corporation or the Housing Authority. Employees with hard-to-replace skills would also be exempted.
The Mayor and his aides said that if the severance packages do not entice at least 7,600 workers to leave their jobs, the administration will have to resort to layoffs by the end of the fiscal year on June 30 to keep the city's budget balanced.
Managers and administrators would be eligible for the severance packages, as well as rank-and-file workers.
Under the proposal at yesterday's meeting, an employee with up to two years' experience would receive $5,000, or four weeks' pay, whichever is greater. The payment then rises based on years of experience, reaching a maximum of $10,000 for employees with at least five years on the job, said an
official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Polluted Soil Frozen and Vaporized

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J.

 BODY:
For more than 100 years, until 1978, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and its predecessors manufactured methane gas from coal and oil here on the banks of the Passaic River. Now, nearly 15 years after the plant was closed, the legacy of that production is 16,000 cubic yards of soil contaminated by a malodorous mixture of hydrocarbons, including benzene, a chemical suspected of causing cancer.
That much contaminated soil, if spread over a football field, would be more than 12 feet deep. And Public Service, under orders from the state to clean up the land, is paying a contractor $27 million for the job. 
 The contractor, Seaview Thermal Systems, hopes its experimental technique -- which involves freezing the surrounding soil to a depth of nearly 30 feet and covering the site with a giant tent as the work proceeds -- may serve as a model for cleaning up hundreds of similarly contaminated sites around the nation.
 
Local Gas Manufacture
 From the mid-19th century until shortly after World War II, many utilities manufactured gas locally for street lights and cooking. Then giant pipelines were built, and natural gas was pumped from fields in the Southwest to customers in the Northeast and Upper Midwest.
All the gas-making plants eventually closed; the one in Paterson was shut 15 years ago. But in the decades they operated, coal or oil was heated to drive off the gas, which left coke or heavy oil that could be burned for heat.
"The tar literally dripped out of the coke as it was moved out of the ovens," said John J. Tyrrell, an engineer with Seaview Thermal Systems of Blue Bell, Pa. "Most of it was stored in pits, but some of it dripped on the ground during shipment."
 
2,000 Polluted Sites
 These old gas-manufacturing sites are a major pollution problem for utilities. There are an estimated 1,800 to 2,000 such sites across the country, mostly in downtown locations. Besides the 13-acre site that Seaview is cleaning up in Paterson, Public Service has 37 others throughout New Jersey.
Most of the sites are adjacent to environmentally vulnerable waterways, since coal was largely shipped by barge. Indeed, it was an oil slick on the Passaic River five years ago that led public health officials in Paterson to conclude that the Public Service site was the culprit.
The simplest, albeit crudest, way to clean the contaminated soils is to burn them, and that has been done in less populous areas. But hazardous-waste incineration is increasingly unpopular, particularly in densely populated areas like northern New Jersey, because of fears of toxic emissions.
"Air permits are hard to obtain in New Jersey," said Joseph E. Rosina, gas plants manager for the utility.
 
Houses Preclude Incineration
 And William B. Packer Sr., principal owner of Seaview Systems, said that incineration would not be an option in Paterson because there are houses within 50 yards of the contaminated site. "Incinerators rightly suffer from 'Nimby' syndrome," Mr. Packer said, using the acronym for "not in my backyard."
So Public Service searched for a new technology and settled on an approach that promises to all but eliminate air emissions. Moreover, Seaview's approach produces materials that can be re-used, in this case clean dirt, water and a mix of hydrocarbons resembling heavy heating oil that can be sold to refineries for blending with crude oil.
Because the cleanup technique will recycle all the materials, rather than letting any hazardous waste remain, Public Service hopes to stave off future regulatory and liability costs.
 
Soil to Be Vaporized
 Seaview intends to dig up the contaminated soil and heat-treat it in a chemically inert atmosphere to vaporize -- but not burn -- the hydrocarbons and ground water it contains. The cleanup of the site, the largest parcel of clear land in the city, is just getting started and is expected to take a little over two years.
Seaview purchased rights to the technique, which Browning-Ferris Industries, the big trash hauler, developed before it decided to quit the hazardous waste business several years ago. In theory, it is simple: the contaminated soil is placed in sealed, electrically heated cylinders that are 8 inches in diameter and 20 feet long. To prevent combustion in the mixture, all the oxygen is replaced with nitrogen, then it is heated to 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit. The heat vaporizes the water and hydrocarbons -- even the heavy, asphalt-like materials -- but without oxygen, they cannot catch fire.
The gases are condensed in a 15-foot tower known as a distillation column, where the water is separated from the hydrocarbons, which can be sold to petroleum refineries for rendering into gasoline and other fuels. The clean soil is to be used to refill the pits being excavated, and the water is to be reinjected into the soil.
"All your hydrocarbons boil by 1,200 degrees, so if you heat the soil to 1,800, you will drive everything off," Mr. Packer said.
 
Process Is Complex
 Although simple in theory, the process is complex in execution because of the proximity of the river and the need to keep noxious odors from reaching nearby houses.
Public Service started by driving sheets of steel into the ground along the riverbank to block water flow at the site. Then Seaview devised a method for isolating the most contaminated two areas on the site: an underground tar-storage tank beneath the spot where a gas manufacturing building once stood, and the ground under a former storage tank.
Because some of the heavy hydrocarbons are denser than water, they have seeped through 27 feet of soil down to bedrock. Since that level is below the local water table, the excavators risked flooding from the surrounding area, which could contaminate large amounts of water that would then have required costly treatment as hazardous waste.
The solution was to build a "freeze wall" around each of the sites, that is freezing the soil surrounding the work areas to contain the surrounding ground water. This was accomplished by drilling 216 shafts, spaced three to four feet apart, through the soil and an additional 10 feet into the bedrock. Then a brine solution, chilled to below 0 degrees Fahrenheit was pumped through them for six to eight weeks to establish a frozen zone four to five feet thick.
 
Plastic Lining Used
 Once this water barrier was established, excavation began in February on the old tar pit, which is closer to the river. The refrigeration will continue -- largely unaffected by the temperatures above ground -- for as long as it takes to take to remove the contaminated soil, line the area with plastic sheeting as an extra measure of security, return the cleaned soil and cap the excavation with additional layer of plastic sheeting and more clean soil.
But freezing the surrounding soil does little to control the pungent smell of the hydrocarbons as they are unearthed. To control the smell, Seaview has erected large tents over the working area, maintaining the air inside at a slight negative pressure, so any airflow is in rather than out. The air exhausted from the tents is passed through activated charcoal, which absorbs the hydrocarbon vapors. Workers inside the tent wear filtration masks.
Although this is the first full-scale commercial application of the technology, Mr. Rosina of Public Service said it appeared that the technique was more environmentally benign and economical than digging up the soil and hauling it to a remote location for incineration.
"We decided this was the only game in town," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Seaview Thermal Systems has recently set up a contaminated soil clean-up site in Paterson, N.J. A process of vaporizing hydrocarbons through high heat will be employed in a location where Public Service Electric and Gas formerly manufactured methane gas from coal and oil. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)
 
Diagram: "Cleaning Soil With Heat, Not Fire"
 In the past, cleaning up soil contaminated with tar, oil, creosote and other hydrocarbons meant burning, which often entailed hard-to-obtain burning permits and hard-to-molify opposition fron neighbors, who did not want soil pollution turned into air pollution. Seaview Thermal Systems says its new method sidesteps both obstacles by using heat to extract they hydrocarbon pollutants for recycling instead of burning them off.
 
1. Contaminated soil is dug up and placed in a closed heating chamber. To prevent combustion, the chamber's atmosphere is a non-flammable gas like nitrogen instead of air.
 
2. Soil is heated above 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit by an electric heater. At that temperature, even the most viscuous hydro-carbon contaminants, like asphalt, will evaporate out of the soil, leaving it as clean as ordinary soil.
 
3. The vapor that was driven off the soil in the heating chamber is condensed. Hydrocarbons are separated from the water and nitrogen gas that came out of the heating chamber with them.
 
4. Water, nitrogen gas and liquid hydrocarbons are each filtered and purified for reuse. The liquid hydrocarbons accumulate in an oily mixture that can be used as raw material for a crude oil refinery to make various petroleum products.
 
(Source: Seaview Thermal Systems)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
A former TV star is reborn as an all-too-human spokeswoman for a Weight Watchers' campaign.

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky 

 BODY:
NO matter what celebrity Kathleen Sullivan might once have enjoyed as a Famous Person for ABC Sports and CBS News, she has demonstrated a remarkable willingness to play the role of Everywoman in leading America into the perilous world of dieting.
Perilous, because diets don't always work. They're hard. They can be lonely. Some diet companies are not always straight with consumers. And who wouldn't rather eat chocolate ice cream and potato chips? 
 Further, specific diets are a difficult sell no matter how desperate people may be to slim down, and that's essentially why Ms. Sullivan was so attractive to Weight Watchers International Inc. as a spokeswoman for a new program called Superstart!
First, she fitted the demographic profile as "our prototypical member," Jeff Myers, a marketing vice president at Weight Watchers, said. "She's 40 years old, pleasing in her physical appearance, but in her own words, someone who has let herself go a little bit and the weight has crept up."
Yet resonating in that description were four years of emotional baggage, as Ms. Sullivan has revisited in scores of interviews since the print and television campaign began in January. The painful points: loss of her job as a host of "CBS This Morning" in 1990, the subsequent death of her father and a divorce.
If all that drove her into hiding from public view, it also seemed to humanize her by the time she re-emerged as a corporate pitchwoman in a campaign in which she provides periodic updates on her weight loss. Not even she realized it right away, long accustomed to the arbitrary distance generally kept between the well known and the anonymous. But through the early weeks of the campaign, a trip to the grocery store or a walk down the street invariably resulted in casual encounters with people emboldened as never before to make contact.
"Like a woman who followed me off a plane just to thank me," Ms. Sullivan recalled in an interview last week. "She had lost four pounds and said she couldn't have done it if she had not seen the ad campaign."
If the campaign has been a fairly stunning experience for Ms. Sullivan, it has dazzled the management of Weight Watchers, a subsidiary of the H. J. Heinz Company. By all available measures, business has increased significantly for 1994, improving the company's estimated 50 percent share of the weight-control market, and the only apparent variable has been Ms. Sullivan.
Mr. Myers said that despite cold weather and heavy snows in the East, an earthquake in California and the plodding pace of economic recovery, Weight Watchers had seen regional membership gains of 5 percent to more than 20 percent. And those increases came during a time, industry officials say, when fewer Americans are participating in organized diet programs.
"A spectacular success in a bad year," Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, the chairman, president and chief executive of Heinz, said of the campaign results.
But why? For years, weight-loss companies have used endorsers as a hook, Weight Watchers among them, with the actress Lynn Redgrave. Brooke Shields recently signed with Slim-Fast. Jenny Craig has become a persona in her own right, starring in her own commercials.
Yet Ms. Sullivan provides more than celebrity endorsement. Her return to prominence as a soldier in the battle of the bulge has turned a mirror on most Americans. Like them, she succeeds, fails and tries again. That her star once shined so brightly only made her thud that much louder. Yet, here she is again, standing, dusted off, the amazing shrinking woman.
Dennis Branoff, the owner of 90 Weight Watchers operations in Michigan and Indiana, said he heard it from staff members almost daily. He recalled one woman's reaction to seeing Ms. Sullivan in a commercial: "I remembered her story, her fall from grace. I empathize with that."
Even in ascent, it has not been easy for the former newscaster. She crossed that line from journalist to paid informer, and has been criticized. It happens a lot with journalists who do that, but they're not always worse for the wear. Linda Ellerbee told wonderful stories as a television reporter, then sold Maxwell House coffee and made enough money to open an independent production company, and now tells wonderful stories again as a television reporter, this time to children and teen-agers. Mary Alice Williams, a former newscaster for CNN and reporter for NBC News, now speaks the virtues of Nynex.
Ms. Sullivan has endured her share of verbal darts and arrows since the campaign began. Doesn't bother her, she said. Besides, she's a smaller target now.

HEADLINE: Lines Drawn in a War Over a Milk Hormone

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis., March 4

 BODY:
A month after a genetically engineered dairy hormone went on sale to farmers, leaflets, labels and advertisements have proliferated in food markets here in a war of words over the hormone's usefulness and safety. On one side are the drug's maker and dairy industry giants; on the other, a coalition of dairy processors and consumer groups.
At stake is consumer acceptance of dairy products made with milk produced by cows treated with the drug. 
 It is enough to make people like Kathy Steele, a 37-year-old dietitian and mother of three, nervous about a food that until now has enjoyed a reputation for wholesomeness.
"I'm very much concerned about this hormone, to the point that I buy only the brand of milk that I know doesn't have it," Ms. Steele said in an interview at Copps supermarket here as she corralled her children, Michaela, Annie and James, and carried a friend's baby, Brian Maki, in a child backpack. "I know the Government says things are safe that turn out not to be safe. You can't always trust what they say."
 
'It's Caused a Commotion'
 Steve Schofield, the dairy manager at Copps, said he had heard scores of customers express the same concerns. "It's caused a commotion," Mr. Schofield said. "People don't want the hormone, and they want to know if they're getting it in their food. We're getting 25 calls a day, 6 or 10 letters a day, and if you stand down by the dairy cases, people come up all the time and ask you about it."
Mr. Schofield says milk and dairy sales have not fallen in his store, one of Madison's largest supermarkets. But he added that cheese products with labels that say they are free of the hormone are selling briskly.
The drug, manufactured by the St. Louis-based Monsanto Company, is variously known as B.S.T., for bovine somatotropin, or rB.G.H., for recombinant bovine growth hormone. It increases milk production in cows by stimulating the animals' milk-producing metabolic systems.
The Food and Drug Administration, which approved the drug in November, says that it is safe and that milk produced by hormone-treated cows cannot be distinguished from milk from untreated cows.
In 1986, Wisconsin farmers protested the hormone's development because they feared it would lead to surpluses and declining farm incomes. Since then, no new farm technology has generated as much economic evaluation, scientific analysis or political attention as B.S.T., especially in this state, which has more dairy farms than any other.
Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, was an early and vocal opponent of the hormone and rode the issue all the way to Capitol Hill. When farmers criticized the University of Wisconsin in the late 1980's for proposing to study B.S.T., Donna E. Shalala, then the university's chancellor and now the Secretary of Health and Human Services, became a prominent defender of the hormone.
 
Drug's Sale Is Strong
 Now that the hormone is being sold, many dairy farmers are buying it. Monsanto said sales had been especially strong in New York, where the company and veterinarians estimate that 10 percent of dairy farmers are using B.S.T. In Wisconsin, where milk production is the foundation of a $10 billion dairy industry, 4 percent to 6 percent of the state's 29,000 dairy farmers are treating their cows, farmers and Monsanto agreed.
Despite the Government's insistence that milk from treated cows is safe, dairy industry surveys indicate that shoppers are nervous about the hormone's use and that many would like labels on foods from herds treated with the hormone.
It is just such concerns that worry Monsanto, which spent at least $300 million on the drug's development and has staked much of the company's future on other genetically engineered products to be used in agriculture.
The company has responded by developing a political and legal strategy to resist calls for product labels. With the help of the top executives of the $64 billion national dairy industry, the company persuaded the drug agency to establish guidelines on Feb. 8 for labeling only milk from untreated cows.
The Government did not require labels on milk from treated cows, saying the hormone naturally occurs in all milk. Any label saying or suggesting that some milk or dairy products were "hormone-free" would thus be false, misleading and illegal.
Monsanto has gone even further by hiring two Washington law firms to police the food industry for advertising and labeling that the company says it believes violate the guidelines or the drug agency's marketing laws. So far, the company has sent letters to six small food companies warning that their advertising or labels were "false and misleading," said Lisa Watson, the manager of health and consumer affairs for Monsanto.
On Feb. 18, Monsanto sued two milk processors, Swiss Valley Farms, a dairy cooperative in Davenport, Iowa, and the Pure Milk and Ice Cream Company in Waco, Tex., who informed customers that their cows were not treated with the hormone.
 
Right to Inform Consumer
 "We contend that these companies falsely implied to consumers that their products are more wholesome and in other ways superior to products that come from milk from B.S.T.-treated cows," Ms. Watson said.
In interviews, executives at the two processors said they had done nothing wrong and would fight the lawsuits. "The main issue, and perhaps the only significant issue, is the right of a food seller to inform the consumer what may or may not be in the food product," said John Palmer, a claims manager for the MSI Insurance Company in St. Paul, which is handling the lawsuit for Swiss Valley Farms.
Several food industry executives said Monsanto was trying to intimidate retailers and prevent consumers from getting the information that many want. "They are afraid that if labeling becomes widespread, it will kill the hormone, which it would," said Bob Wills, the owner of Cedar Grove Cheese, a small manufacturer in Plain, Wis., that was the first company in this state to label its products.
The red labels, approved by the State Department of Agriculture, say Cedar Grove cheeses are "producer certified rB.G.H. free." Since affixing the labels to his cheese, Mr. Wills said sales had increased at least 20 percent.
"It's amazing the lengths people will go to find our product," Mr. Wills said in an interview in his home by the cheese plant, which, he says, now operates 21 hours a day to fill orders.
Perhaps the most visible evidence of changes in milk buying habits prompted by the hormone's use is in natural food stores in Madison, as well as in New York, Atlanta, San Francisco and other cities. Store owners said sales of milk and cheese from untreated cows were soaring.
"This hormone is an issue with us," said Lori Tooker, who was shopping here with her family at the Magic Mill natural food market, where the dairy manager said sales had climbed 30 percent in a month. "We really don't know if it's safe. We feel it's been pushed on the dairy industry."

Sales of cheese with the labels, right, have been rising. (Photographs by Morey Gash for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Trying to Rescue a Soured Oil Bet

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
From an office on Madison Avenue, a former oil trader turned Italian sculpture expert is quietly unraveling what some have said is one of the biggest bad bets in the commodities business.
Since mid-December, Nancy Kropp Galdy has been working 12 to 18 hours a day, sometimes seven days a week, trying to make the most of a mountain of oil futures contracts that have already produced $1.35 billion in losses. 
 By her account, she runs on adrenaline much of the time. She doesn't know when her job as a hired gun will end or even what she'll be paid when it does. All in all, it's an improbable scene.
But then, she's no everyday oil trader and the task is extraordinary: she is playing a critical behind-the-scenes role in the increasingly contentious rescue of one of Germany's largest industrial companies, Metallgesellschaft A.G.
 
A $1.9 Billion Bailout
 The mining and engineering conglomerate stunned world financial markets in December by disclosing that huge oil futures losses on the New York Mercantile Exchange had pushed it to near bankruptcy. Only a hastily arranged $1.9 billion bailout by creditor banks in January averted disaster.
Executive heads have rolled in the United States and Germany, and public charges, countercharges and lawsuits are now flying. But almost overlooked in the fracas is the fact that Metallgesellschaft came away holding contracts representing a staggering 160 million barrels of oil, and something had to be done with them.
Ms. Kropp Galdy has been trying to unwind that enormous position with as much gain and as little pain as possible. So far, she and a team of experts have cleared away about half the contracts. Since the remaining positions are spread across the gamut of energy products, from oil to gasoline, outside experts said there was no way to determine the remaining value of the company's position. Not surprisingly, it is a topic that the company and Ms. Kropp Galdy will not discuss. But there is a lot of money -- and a lot of risk -- still to be dealt with.
It's not a glamorous job, and Ms. Kropp Galdy purposely keeps a low profile. That's partly strategic. In the oil trading game, it pays not to tip your hand, especially if competitors know you're under pressure.
 
'Caught Up in It'
 "You know you are doing this for a limited period of time, and you get caught up in it," she said in an interview. "But this is not a job that one person can do alone. You pull on all the expertise you can draw on."
Asked why she undertook such an assignment, Ms. Kropp Galdy speaks of challenge and loyalty, not money or glory. "You feel an intense responsibility to do your best," she said. "We have not yet talked about remuneration, but we will, and they will be fair. Those things are not important. When you do something like this you do it by need."
It's certainly not a job she sought. Once an oil trading virtuoso who helped to put Morgan Stanley & Company in the business, first in New York and later in London, Ms. Kropp Galdy, who says her age is 40-something, chucked the high-stakes commodity game four years ago for a life of art and culture in Florence, Italy.
There, she learned the language and immersed herself in 15th-century sculpture, while her husband, Thomas Galdy, a former oil broker, established himself as a private dealer in Old Master drawings. After 11 years trading oil, she was burned out. "It takes a while to come down, but I had no regrets," she said.
When Metallgesellschaft's problems broke into the open last year, however, Ms. Kropp Galdy's days at home inevitably became numbered, burnout or not.
For one thing, she's well regarded by her peers. "In our business, you get to know who the leading names are fairly quickly," said Richard D. Black, a partner at the London law firm of Middleton Potts, shipping and commodity trading specialists. "Morgan Stanley was a big player in the market and Nancy was the head trader and good at her job."
Plus, the New York Mercantile Exchange, where energy futures contracts are traded, is not known as a benevolent place, and Metallgesellschaft's problems -- if not actual trading positions -- were no secret. Not everyone could cope with those conditions.
"The job she has is that of a Mississippi gambler who has the mind of a computer and nerves of steel," said Peter Beutel, an oil trader and president of Cameron Hanover Inc., a Bronxville, N.Y., research, brokerage and money management firm.
 
Second Time Around
 But Ms. Kropp Galdy says she felt an even stronger pull. She had worked through a similar crisis in 1988 for Germany's largest commercial bank, Deutsche Bank A. G., a big Metallgesellschaft shareholder and a leader of its rescue party.
That job delayed the start of Ms. Kropp Galdy's new life for about eight months, while she worked to extricate Klockner & Company, a trading company Deutsche Bank had taken over, from hundreds of millions of dollars of potential losses. It also left her with strong memories and loyalties.
In that instance, she and her husband were at Gatwick Airport near London, right after she left Morgan Stanley, when during a phone call a friend frantically insisted that the Deutsche Bank chairman, Albert Herrhausen, known in the German press as the "Almighty Supreme Being," was looking for her.
"I sort of stopped and said this is totally absurd. Yeah, Mr. Rockefeller wants Nancy to call him," Ms. Kropp Galdy said. But after getting past Mr. Herrhausen's secretary on the second try, she realized it was true.
According to Ms. Kropp Galdy, Mr. Herrhausen said: "A lot of people in Germany tell me you are the one to help us. Will you come? I said sure. Thomas was standing there saying, 'Sure, what?' I told him we were going to Germany."
This time, Ms. Kropp Galdy was only slightly more prepared. In early December, as news of Metallgesellschaft's problems hit front pages across Europe, the Galdys were interested readers at home in Florence.
"We sort of made a lot of stunned comments," Ms. Kropp Galdy recalled, "and Thomas made a joke, saying, 'Well, since Deutsche Bank is involved, you'll probably get a phone call tomorrow.' I said no way, it won't happen. That was too long ago."
 
Call From Germany
 But it happened. Less than 24 hours later, Renaldo Schmitz, a Deutsche Bank director and chairman of the Metallgesellschaft supervisory board, was on the phone. (Mr. Herrhausen was no longer at the helm; he was killed by a bomb planted by German terrorists in his Mercedes limousine in 1989.)
"He introduced himself and we spoke about Herrhausen," she said, a conversation that "definitely affected" her. "I said I felt very committed to helping Deutsche Bank," she said. "It was an important conversation."
After that, deciding what to do didn't take long. "I called him back in half an hour," Ms. Kropp Galdy said. "But before I called him I had started to pack."
Ms. Kropp Galdy, as a consultant to the MG Corporation, Metallgesellschaft's American subsidiary, would not discuss specific strategy. She said her team's objective in managing the trading book was the same as it was in the Klockner case: "get as much money back as possible."
For Metallgesellschaft, that book started growing in earnest last spring, when its American subsidiary offered refined products like gasoline and heating oil to customers under fixed price contracts that extended as long as 10 years.
The company seemed to hedge those long-term commitments against a rise in crude oil prices by buying short-term energy futures and over-the-counter derivatives contracts. In theory, if MG had to pay more for the oil it would supply to its customers, it could offset the cost with profits made as the value of its futures contracts also rose.
But some traders figured MG was speculating heavily on a rise in short-term prices.
 
Prices Moved Down
 Oil prices did not rise. Instead, crude oil prices reached their lowest level in five years in the first week of December, while gasoline hit a seven-year low. Indeed, MG's positions were so enormous that they pushed down prices, partly because market participants were willing sellers of spot contracts to MG.
Philip K. Verleger, a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, estimated recently that without MG's presence in the market, the spot contract gasoline price would have been 2 to 5 cents a gallon higher in the fourth quarter.
Faced with huge declines in the value of its hedging contracts, MG became subject to margin calls from the futures exchange. Holders of futures contracts are expected to cover their losses on a daily basis if they want to hold on to their positions.
The positions were so big that MG was incapable of meeting its margin calls. That failure precipitated the crisis and led to the eventual bailout by its creditors.
MG has denied speculating on oil prices, but will not comment on how its hedging strategy led to its giant losses.
In January, bitter winter weather drove spot prices up for gasoline, heating oil and crude, making Ms. Kropp Galdy's job a bit easier. "I hate cold weather, but we will take whatever help we can get," she said. Prices have softened since.
Some market watchers suggest that if MG has somehow been able to maintain its positions, the January price rise may have cut the company's losses, and may have even turned them into a profit. But the amount needed to accomplish that -- numbers like $1 billion are bandied about -- apparently was just too big.
"Retrospectively, it appears to me that MG may have overreacted, and turned paper losses into actual losses," said Mr. Beutel, the Bronxville researcher. "If they had left everything alone, they would have made some money."
W. Arthur Benson, the senior vice president who developed MG's trading strategy, certainly thinks so. On Feb. 28, scarcely three weeks after he was dismissed by MG, Mr. Benson sued MG and Deutsche Bank in Federal District Court in Maryland, contending that the company could have avoided more than $1 billion in losses if his strategy had not been abandoned. He is seeking $1 billion in damages.
In the lawsuit, he asserts that Ms. Kropp Galdy's strategy of liquidating the company's positions "resulted in price speculation which created losses of some $1 billion."
Experts familiar with MG's situation say they do not put much stock in those claims. "If they hadn't gotten out of the market, the market wouldn't have rallied," Mr. Verleger said. "From everything I hear, Nancy Kropp has done an amazingly good job of holding things together."
MG and Ms. Kropp Galdy declined to discuss the suit, or how it or any other litigation might affect the way the MG group she is part of trades.
And she chose not to speculate on how she might respond if the telephone rings again in the future, and another Deutsche Bank official is on the line. "It depends," she said. "When you put this much out, you have to care."
