HEADLINE: Clinton to Unveil Jobs Bill That Focuses on Retraining

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
President Clinton on Wednesday will announce a jobs bill that would mark a shift in Government emphasis from providing temporary relief for laid-off employees to trying to meet the needs of workers whose jobs will not reappear, even in an improving economy.
The proposal would focus on retraining and job placement for the unemployed by establishing one-stop career centers, financed by Federal and state funds. 
 White House and Labor Department officials say the centers would provide an array of counseling services, like information on resume writing and assistance in obtaining unemployment benefits.
 
Billed as Major Initiative
 The proposed legislation, which Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has been promoting in speeches and private meetings around the nation, has been billed as one of the Administration's major initiatives.
It would cost about $13 billion over five years, but Labor Department officials said almost all the money for the retraining and job placement programs would come from merging programs for displaced workers and from shifting money within the department's budget.
Under the proposal, which the Administration calls the Re-employment Act, programs for workers displaced by specific changes in the economy -- by downsizing in the military industry, for example, or by the effects of the North American Free Trade Agreement -- would be combined into a single, broader program for laid-off workers.
The goal is to streamline a system so complicated that workers who were employed at the same factory sometimes now have entirely different benefits even if they lost similar jobs at the same time.
 
2 Years of Training Aid
 Under the Administration's plan, workers could get financial aid for as long as two years if they are enrolled in certain retraining programs, like nursing school, that require long periods of study yet offer graduates a reasonable chance of stable employment.
Other elements of the proposal include a computerized national jobs bank to help the unemployed identify what work is available, and where, and personal assistance in the details of job searches, like how to how to dress for an interview. Relief services for the unemployed would continue.
The President will announce the new plan just five days before a conference he has called on worldwide unemployment. The conference, which convenes on Monday in Detroit, will bring together labor specialists from around the world for two days of meetings in which participants will study labor markets, changing technologies and world unemployment problems.
In recent speeches, Mr. Reich has argued that policy makers' basic concept of unemployment protections should shift. "We need to turn the unemployment system into a re-employment system," he said last week in an address to students at the Johns Hopkins School for Advanced International Studies.
 
'Years of Work'
 Mr. Reich and other Labor Department officials describe the new legislation as an effort to deal with an employment pattern in which people who have lost their jobs are not finding new ones. The effort would treat jobless workers as clients, not just as financial dependents, and would link benefits more closely to education and training.
Putting these concepts into practice will be difficult, labor specialists say. "No one has really stood back and asked what it would take to consolidate and reduce the system," said Andrew B. Hahn, a professor of public policy at Brandeis University. "On the ground, it is going to take years of work to implement."
But Mr. Hahn said he basically supported the Administration's proposal "because it has become kind of a mantra in the social policy field that our policies are too fragmented."
Public support for the measure may be easier to garner now than in years past, he added, because increasing numbers of middle-class workers have lost jobs through corporate layoffs and industry readjustments.
"They have had to use the system," Mr. Hahn said, "and they have been reacting with horror to the colossal nightmare of programs we have now."

HEADLINE: Postal Service Seeks 3-Cent Rise For First-Class Stamp in Early '95

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
The United States Postal Board of Governors today approved a proposal to increase the price of a first-class stamp by 10.3 percent, to 32 cents from 29 early in 1995.
The plan, announced by Postmaster General Marvin T. Runyon and the postal board's chairman, J. Sam Winters, is part of an increase in all postal rates. 
 Second-class rates would jump 10.2 percent. Third-class rates -- used most often for bulk or "junk" mail -- would jump 10.3. Parcel post rates would increase 13.2 percent. The cost of sending a postcard would go up 2 cents, to 21 cents from 19, and express mail would cost an additional dollar, or $10.95. For first-class mail, the charge for each additional ounce after the first ounce would increase to 25 cents from 23.
The proposal now goes before the independent Postal Rate Commission, which is expected to hold hearings and make a decision within 10 months.
Mr. Winters said the new rates would "provide a small but sufficient increase" in revenue to operate in the black. The Postal Service is expected to have a $1.3 billion deficit this year.
Mr. Runyon added that the proposal, the smallest his organization had requested in 25 years, was two points below the rate of inflation over the last four years. The last increase -- to 29 cents from 25 -- was proposed about four years ago and took effect in February 1991.
For the average American, the increase would mean an additional $8 to $9 a year for stamps.
 
Break for Bulk Mail
 The last time the post office raised rates, it drew the most anger from third-class mailers, whose material amounts to 38.4 percent of the total amount of mail and who saw a 26 percent increase then.
This time around, the bulk mailers seem pleased.
"Ten percent versus 26 percent" is an obvious improvement, said Robert Kamerschen, the chief executive of Advo Inc., the nation's largest third-class mailer.
Arthur B. Sackler, the managing director of a coalition of big corporations, called the approach fair and balanced.
The post office usually follows a waltz-like rhythm: the first year after prices go up, it makes money. The second, it breaks even. The third year, it loses.
This time, the Postal Service waited four years before requesting a rate increase. Many credit Mr. Runyon, who cut 33,000 jobs since starting his job in 1992, for making the post office more efficient.
"He's broken the three-year cycle," said Moe Biller, the president of the American Postal Workers Union, which represents 360,000 postal workers. "He's a far more efficient, competent man than his predecessor and an incredibly gutsy guy."
Every penny that the post office adds to the cost of a stamp results in $920 million in revenue.
Sitting in a warehouse in Kansas City, Mo., almost 19 billion first-class "G" stamps, or nondenominated stamps, which will assume the value of the new stamp, are ready for distribution.
The Postal Service has also printed two billion "make up" stamps, which will supplement all the leftover 29-cent stamps that consumers have stored away in their desks.

HEADLINE: House Panel Begins Deliberations on a Health Bill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Congress today entered a new phase in its effort to revamp the nation's health care system as a House subcommittee began deliberations on a bill substantially different from President Clinton's proposal.
The Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health began analyzing the bill, proposed by its chairman, Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, with lawmakers of both parties saying they felt they were participating in a historic process. 
 "Few issues grip the American people as deeply as the health care crisis," said Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia. "Health care is a basic right of all individuals. It's not a privilege."
Lobbyists for doctors, dentists, psychologists, small businesses and other interests swarmed over Capitol Hill today as the subcommittee took up health care legislation after 36 days of public hearings. Just after the panel convened, President Clinton spoke to trade association executives defending his proposal and expressing optimism about its future.
 
A Test of Strength
 Mr. Clinton said he was not distressed by recent obituaries for his health plan. "I have seen a lot of endeavors in which I was involved over the last 15 years given up for dead," he said.
The ranking Republican on the subcommittee, Representative Bill Thomas of California, said he would push for an up-or-down vote on the President's proposal, just to show that it lacked support. "The American people deserve a test of strength for the President's plan," he said.
But Mr. Stark said he expected no votes till next week. At the moment, he does not have a majority for his proposal in the 11-member subcommittee, but he said he might be able to forge such a majority with help from other Democrats.
Mr. Stark's bill would expand Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, to cover people who are unemployed, people who have no connection to the labor force and low-income people now in the Medicaid program, as well as part-time, temporary and seasonal workers.
 
Leaner Benefits Package
 Mr. Stark's plan, like the President's, would require employers to pay at least 80 percent of the cost of health insurance for their workers. In addition, he suggested a new Federal payroll tax, equal to eight-tenths of 1 percent of wages and salaries. But he made clear that he was open to other ways of financing his plan.
Mr. Stark said his proposal would achieve the President's goal of guaranteeing health insurance for all Americans while controlling medical costs. But he proposes a leaner package of benefits, with less coverage for mental health services and long-term care.
Mr. Stark would not require consumers or employers to obtain coverage through purchasing groups like the alliances proposed by Mr. Clinton. Under Mr. Stark's proposal, the Government could directly regulate doctors' fees and hospital charges but would not regulate health insurance premiums, as Mr. Clinton wants to do.
The prospects for Mr. Stark's proposal in the full Ways and Means Committee, on the House floor and in the Senate are unknown. But White House officials said they were pleased to see one Congressional panel moving ahead with health legislation.
Under Mr. Stark's proposal, employers with more than 100 employees would have to contribute to the cost of health insurance for their workers beginning Jan. 1, 1995. For employers with 100 or fewer employees, a similar requirement would take effect Jan. 1, 1997. These smaller businesses could enroll their workers in the new Federal program, known as Part C of Medicare, or they could buy private insurance.

HEADLINE: California Listing Its Debt

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
In a move that could shake up a traditionally staid market, California began listing about $3.3 billion in municipal debt for trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
California, the first state to list tax-exempt bonds on the exchange in years, hopes to create more demand for its debt and thus pay lower interest rates on new state bonds. 
 The listing puts the California bonds on the exchange's computerized trading system, which lets brokers and dealers review the latest offers and enter bids on the bonds.
The move has the potential to change the behavior in a market dominated by conservative investors who usually hold bonds until the principal matures -- up to several decades later. The improved access to information may entice more investors to buy and sell bonds prior to maturity.
The listing comes at an opportune time for the tax-free market, which faces mounting pressure from Federal regulators to disclose more information about bonds.

HEADLINE: Bonn Journal;
Now Breathing Down Kohl's Neck Is Big Socialist

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
If Germans could choose Chancellors the way Americans pick Presidents -- voting for them by name on the ballot -- a 46-year-old state Governor would beat Helmut Kohl by a landslide, all the public opinion polls indicate.
Rudolf Scharping, a Social Democrat, is giving Mr. Kohl the most serious political challenge he has faced since he became Chancellor in 1982. 
 Soaring budget deficits, unemployment of more than four million and the $100-billion-a-year cost of German unity have made the Chancellor an unpopular man.
But Germans vote for parties, rather than picking their leader directly, and they will not vote until Oct. 16.
In the meantime, Mr. Scharping is trying to sell himself to voters as a new face who is not a shot in the dark. If Germans elect the Social Democrats, his message goes, they will be getting a responsible, middle-of-the-road party that will put their country on a safe and solid footing after Mr. Kohl's center-right Christian Democratic alliance led it into a morass.
 
The Beard Will Stay
 Mr. Scharping, a jogging and bicycle enthusiast, stands out in a crowd. He is a big man, though not as large as the man he wants to replace -- bronzed, with a deep baritone voice and a shock of brown hair and horn-rimmed glasses, which give him a serious look. He also has a beard, although no German Chancellor since World War II has worn one. But he insists that if he takes over, it stays.
"I don't want to join the Government, I want to lead it," he said here the other day, alluding to frequent speculation that German political parties are all so unpopular that they may have to form a grand coalition that unites the present Government and its opposition.
If Mr. Scharping is to lead, the Social Democrats will have to win more votes than the Christian Democratic alliance, which won 43.8 percent in the 1990 election. Recent polls showed Mr. Scharping's party with the support of 38 percent to 41 percent, compared to 32 to 35 percent for Mr. Kohl's party.
Mr. Scharping became the youngest leader in the history of his party last summer after a scandal forced the resignation of his predecessor. Since he took over, his message has been that the pacifist, antinuclear, anti-American policies that relegated the Socialists to the opposition for so long are over.
Like Mr. Kohl before him, he is the Premier of the state of Rhineland-Palatinate, and has been a politician all his life, though he became Premier only in 1991. He studied political science at the University of Bonn and has held party office since 1974, when he became a national vice chairman of its youth wing.
About the most dramatic moment of his career occurred in 1968 when the party expelled him for a year for taking part in an antimilitary protest against a fund-raising concert for the German military band. He lives with his wife and three daughters in Mainz, the Rhineland-Palatinate state capital, and not in Bonn.
But if Mr. Kohl could make the leap, he believes, so can he. He has the enthusiastic support of Helmut Schmidt, who was his party's last Chancellor, before it veered left in the early 1980's and disavowed Mr. Schmidt's decision to accept American intermediate-range nuclear missiles on German soil.
The missiles are gone now, and so is the Soviet Union, but Mr. Scharping says he is proud that his state is home to 150,000 Americans in uniform.
He went to Munich early in February to persuade NATO defense experts and ministers that if he is elected Germany will be just as loyal an ally as it is now. "NATO was and remains an essential complement to the integration process within the European Union," he told them. "On this question there is no disagreement among Social Democrats today. This has not always been the case."
Mr. Scharping's party supports participation by German troops in United Nations peacekeeping operations, provided there is a guarantee that they will not be involved in combat. "A Social Democratic Chancellor will not make the German Army available for an operation like the war in the Persian Gulf," he said in Bonn the other day, but then neither did Mr. Kohl in 1991.
 
Differences Are Slight
 On domestic and economic issues, the differences between Mr. Scharping and Mr. Kohl are even less striking. This Social Democrat does not even object to privatization of public services. "Whoever can do the best job of making them dependable, affordable, and universally available should do it," he said the other day.
Like Mr. Kohl, he has told the labor unions, his biggest single constituency, that German economic competitiveness requires lower labor costs, and that shorter working hours can save jobs, but only at lower wages.
As for the welfare state, he says: "The state soaks up 50 percent of gross national product as it is. We don't want to make it even higher."
But until the problems of rebuilding formerly Communist eastern Germany have been solved, he said, the Social Democrats are for a 10 percent surcharge on the individual income tax starting next year, instead of the 7.5 percent surcharge the Christian Democrats say they will impose.
Mr. Kohl has been doing his best to dispel the notion that there is not much difference between the parties, digging up old allegations that the Social Democrats -- and Mr. Scharping personally -- were ready in the late 1980's to concede to East German demands that Bonn stop granting automatic citizenship to people who fled the Communist Government.
If the Social Democrats had been in power, the Chancellor tells the 16.5 million people in the east, unification might never had happened in 1990. Mr. Scharping dismissed the argument as "mudslinging," and promised that if elected he would ould do a better job of repelling right-wing neo-Nazis than the Christian Democrats.

HEADLINE: $1 Million Religion Prize for Capitalism Defender

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

 BODY:
Michael Novak, a scholar known for formulating a theological defense of capitalism, has won a prize of nearly $1 million established by one of capitalism's most successful practitioners.
Mr. Novak, whose religious arguments linking democracy and capitalism influenced opinion in Eastern Europe and are echoed in Pope John Paul II's writings, was named the winner yesterday of the 1994 Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion. 
 The prize, created 22 years ago by Sir John M. Templeton, an American-born British subject who is widely considered the dean of global investing, honors a person judged to have advanced the world's understanding of religion. Valued at 650,000 -- $968,500 at yesterday's exchange rate -- the prize will be awarded by Prince Philip at Buckingham Palace on May 4.
Sir John, who is active in the Presbyterian church, stipulated that the prize money should always surpass that of the Nobel Prizes, which he felt had overlooked religion. He sold his money management firm, Templeton, Galbraith & Hansberger, for $913 million in 1992 and now, at the age of 81, lives in the Bahamas.
Previous winners include Mother Teresa and the Rev. Billy Graham. Last year's winner was Charles W. Colson, the former special counsel to President Richard M. Nixon who established a prison ministry after serving seven months for his role in the Watergate cover-up.
Mr. Novak, a 60-year-old Roman Catholic who once studied for the priesthood, was a proponent of many of the changes in Catholic teachings and practices introduced by the Second Vatican Council, which he covered on special assignment for Time magazine in 1963. He was an outspoken opponent of the war in Vietnam while teaching religious studies at Stanford University in the mid-1960's.
In the 1970's, when he also taught at the State University of New York at Old Westbury, L.I., and at Syracuse University, Mr. Novak moved into the ranks of neoconservative thinkers and politicians. In 1978, he became a resident scholar in religion and public policy at the conservative American Enterprise Institute in Washington.
Encountering opposition to capitalism in politically active religious circles, Mr. Novak in 1982 wrote "The Spirit of Democratic Capitalism" (Simon & Schuster) arguing that capitalism and democracy were mutually supportive embodiments of Christian principles. He also wrote several books criticizing the socialist elements in Latin American liberation theology.
Drawing bitter criticism from many of his former liberal allies in the church, Mr. Novak also organized opposition to the American Catholic bishops' pastoral letters on nuclear weapons and on the economy in the mid-1980's. At a news conference yesterday in Manhattan, he said he had largely agreed with the bishops' final versions of those documents.
In her memoirs, Margaret Thatcher, the former British Prime Minister, said Nr. Novak's writings had influenced her views on "quality of life" issues. Lady Thatcher served on the nine-member panel of judges who awarded the prize. The panel also included James Billington, the Librarian of Congress, and George Gallup Jr., the pollster.
 
The Needle's Eye
 Mr. Novak said he would use much of the prize money to finance scholarships at colleges where he studied and to support Crisis, the conservative Catholic monthly that he edits.
Asked about the New Testament's warnings against riches, Mr. Novak replied, "The more you have, the stricter your judgment will be, and the more you are responsible for."
Sir John, who attended the news conference, added, "I just hope we haven't kept Michael out of the kingdom of heaven."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Nagging Inflation Fears Push Bond Prices Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of United States Treasury securities reversed early gains yesterday amid the nagging fears of inflation and concern about the timing of the Federal Reserve's next move to raise short-term interest rates. The selloff in bonds pushed interest rates to the highest level since June.
Follow-through strength from overseas bond markets and comments by a Federal Reserve governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, in a Baltimore speech to the Commercial Finance Association Monday night provided the market with an early lift. But the selling began to pick up steam by midsession after Mr. Lindsey's comments were put in context. 
 The 30-year Treasury declined by 26/32 of a percentage point, to 9210/32 , as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.86 percent, from 6.79 percent on Monday. Rates on short-term maturities were also higher, with the three-month bill at 3.54 percent, up from 3.50 percent, and the six-month bill at 3.77 percent, up from 3.73 percent.
Intermediate maturities like 3-year and 10-year notes also felt the brunt of selling. The yield on a 3-year note rose seven basis points, to 5.31 percent, and the 10-year rose eight basis points to 6.39 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 
 
'Three Something'
 According to traders, the reports on their computer screens in the morning said that Mr. Lindsey of the Fed indicated that short-term interest rates would be "three something."
"Not many people took it serious," David A. Ader, managing analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said. "But apparently some took it as a sign that the Fed would not tighten again."
Soon after the market moved on reports of Mr. Lindsey's remarks, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Board in Washington said that the comment was not intended as a forecast. It was meant to be humorous, the spokesman said.
According to a text of Mr. Lindsey's speech, it does appear that he meant the comment as a joke. In opening his speech, he said: "As economic and investment professionals, you've all come to appreciate how easy it is to make a forecast these days. Whatever the question, the answer is three. What will real growth be? About three. What will inflation be? About three. What about short rates? Three something.
"Tonight, however, I am going to resist the temptation of just uttering the number three and sitting down."
Analysts said the confusion in the market did not help Fed credibility yesterday.
 
 
'Some Traders Saw Otherwise'
 Mr. Ader noted that people who own a lot of Treasury securities had no patience with the attempted clarification by the Fed spokesman. "The market's retreat appeared to coincide with the spokesman's comments and the release of fourth-quarter nonfarm productivity, which should have been good for the market," Mr. Ader said. "But unbelievably, some traders saw otherwise."
Mr. Ader believes the strong revision by the Labor Department of the fourth-quarter productivity gain to an annualized 6.1 percent, the largest increase in more than seven years, and the drop in unit labor costs at an annual rate of 3.1 percent should have provided further evidence to the market that inflation was not a problem.
"The gain in productivity is good for the market, and to be taken as inflationary is a counter-read by the market," Mr. Ader said. "People just look for excuses in a bearish market."
Productivity measures the time, effort and cost of producing goods. Rising productivity suggests businesses are improving their efficiency and delivering goods at competitive prices and lower costs, analysts say.
With the selling under way and people's impatience running out, the market "just gave up the constructive optimism that it had started the session with," Mr. Ader said. The weekly Johnson Redbook report on United States department store sales, which was somewhat strong, had little impact, he said.
"This suggests that we're going to see some more weakness" in bond prices and higher interest rates over the near term, Mr. Ader said. He expects trading will be choppy, with the market in a narrow range as prices approach those of last week, but do not fall much lower.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Remains Static; Gold Ends Higher in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar barely moved against some other leading currencies for a second day yesterday as fund managers stayed on the sidelines after recent turbulence in global securities markets.
Traders were also believed to be waiting for fresh news on American and German interest rates. 
 Gold prices rose after falling in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery closed at $377.70 an ounce, up 80 cents from Monday.
The dollar traded in a tight range against other currencies. "This is one of the slowest days we've seen in a long time," Matt Porio, a vice president at Chase Manhattan, said.
He and others said major fund managers were absent after suffering losses in recent weeks on volatile bond and stock markets.
"Now everybody's kind of shell-shocked and waiting on the sidelines," David Durst, a vice president at Bear, Stearns, said.
Traders were apparently watching for indications of whether the Federal Reserve Board might soon nudge interest rates higher. They were also awaiting today's announcement by the German central bank of its new rate for two-week repurchase agreements, which the bank uses to influence the money market.
The rate for the variable repurchase agreements is expected to fall slightly, perhaps one-tenth of 1 percent or even one-twentieth of 1 percent, traders said.
A larger cut in German rates could have the effect of helping the dollar at the expense of the mark. Higher interest rates often increase a currency's popularity by translating into a higher return on deposits in that currency. Lower rates often do the opposite.
In Tokyo yesterday, the dollar closed at 105.54 yen, up 0.04 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar fell to 105.30 yen. In New York, the dollar ended at 105.37 yen, down from 105.50 Monday.
The Canadian dollar rose to 73.77 United States cents, up from 73.68. The British pound finished at $1.4884, cheaper than $1.4905 late Monday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.7143 German marks, down from 1.7185; 1.4380 Swiss francs, down from 1.4405; 5.8240 French francs, down from 5.8380, and 1,690 Italian lire, up from 1,689.

HEADLINE: Productivity Had Big Jump In 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The productivity of American companies rose in last year's fourth quarter by the largest amount in more than seven years, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But for all the talk of America's newly achieved competitiveness, the new numbers failed to show that corporate America has regained its old ability to rapidly increase its efficiency, the department said.
Productivity -- that is, the quantity of goods and services that the nation's workers produce in a given hour -- rose at an annual rate of 6.1 percent in the fourth quarter. That rise, covering all business except farming, was the best showing since the first quarter of 1986, when productivity rose by 6.9 percent. Most of last quarter's gain was in manufacturing, where productivity advanced by a very strong 7.2 percent.
 
 
Debate Over Data
 The latest productivity figure, which is a sharp revision from the previous estimate of 4.2 percent, renewed a debate that flares up whenever the Labor Department releases productivity figures. On one side are those who argue that American business, and particularly manufacturing, has finally returned to the high levels of productivity growth that prevailed until 1973. As a result, they say, American companies are now as competitive as German and Japanese companies. That view has been invoked frequently by companies to justify the layoffs of thousands of workers considered a drag on efficiency. 
 "There have been 60,000 layoffs in telecommunications alone this year," Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said. "That is not job shifting; that is upheaval. We have become through this downsizing far more productive and cost efficient than we were in the past."
The Clinton Administration has resisted this view. Most of the fourth-quarter gain reflected the improving economy rather than big gains in corporate efficiency, according to Edwin Dean, chief of the productivity division at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"I would be conservative and take the position that we have not really changed that much; we have not become all that more efficient," Mr. Dean said. "One can explain a lot of this improvement by noting that there was slack in the system as a result of the recession, and as the economy has recovered, the slack has been used up. People have simply worked harder to fill all the orders, and so their productivity has risen."
Some of the figures released yesterday support Mr. Dean's argument. What the work force produced to satisfy the rising national demand increased by 9.3 percent, for example, while total hours worked went up by only 2.2 percent -- the implication being that people worked harder within their scheduled hours.
 
 
Sharp Revision
 The 6.1 percent figure released yesterday represented an unusually sharp revision from the previous estimate. It was based on new data that showed output for exports to have been much greater in the fourth quarter than previously tabulated.
If the Clinton Administration is correct that most of the gain in productivity is a result of the upturn in the economy, then as long as the upturn continues, the productivity gains might be expected to continue as well; corporate America would have less justification for the layoffs and job eliminations it says are necessary to achieve higher productivity.
"Clinton has to deliver on his promise of eight million new jobs to get re-elected," Mr. Roach said. "But if companies keep laying off and downsizing, he has a problem. So the Administration talks against the productivity rationale for the job cuts."
Productivity growth was significantly higher in the post-World War II period, rising at an average annual rate of 2.5 percent from 1948 to 1973, and supporting strong growth in American living standards.
 
 
Durable Goods
 That average declined to less than 1 percent a year after 1973, despite bursts of improvement following the 1974 and 1982 recessions, and the recession that ended in 1991. With the strong fourth-quarter showing, productivity for last year rose by 1.7 percent, with most of the gain coming in the manufacture of such durable goods as computers and other electronics equipment, machinery, cars and trucks. Productivity among durable goods manufacturers rose at an annual rate of 12.3 percent in the fourth quarter.
For all of 1993, manufacturing productivity rose by 5.1 percent, on top of a rise of 4.2 percent in 1992 -- the strongest two-year showing in more than 15 years.
The productivity report also suggested that inflationary forces in the economy were weak. The Labor Department said that unit labor costs -- the labor cost to produce a car, a pair of shoes or some other product or service -- had declined in the fourth quarter at an annual rate of 3.1 percent. It was the largest quarterly drop in more than a decade, and the second consecutive quarterly decline.
"It has been 31 years since we have had two consecutive quarterly declines in unit labor costs," Mr. Roach said. "That indicates extraordinary control over labor costs, which is only possible when productivity is rising more than the norm."

HEADLINE: Martin Marietta Gobbles Up Grumman

 BODY:
In the latest mega-dollar deal in the defense industry, the Martin Marietta Corporation has agreed to buy the Grumman Corporation for $1.9 billion. Grumman, the venerable Long Island aerospace company, founded in 1929, is just another in a long line of military contractors to fold its wings as Pentagon procurements slow to match a vastly shrunken threat.
Defense jobs will continue to disappear. That is not the consequence of consolidation in the industry, but of smaller Pentagon budgets. Grumman's work force, for instance, is down to 18,000, from 33,700 in 1987. Many more layoffs are likely with the end of F-14 production and cancellation of other carrier-based aircraft. 
 That will mean even harder times around Grumman's Bethpage, L.I., headquarters. Washington and Albany need to do what they can to ease the plight of the unemployed.
The defense industry was overdue for major contraction. While many companies began diversifying, Martin Marietta and Grumman remained heavily dependent on defense, which accounts for at least 85 percent of their revenues. Such businesses have to eat or be eaten by others in the industry.
For Grumman the choice was clear: Find a buyer that valued its expertise in defense electronics, information systems and surveillance aircraft, like the Navy's E-2C Hawkeye and the Army-Air Force's JSTARS. Martin Marietta will now become the world's largest defense electronics company.
Some worry that consolidation will reduce competition. But the defense industry has never been very competitive. Seldom did more than two companies bid on a big contract. And losers often won, as the Pentagon tried to keep production lines going by spreading contracts around.
With the downsizing at the Pentagon, there are too few defense contracts to spread around. To promote competition, Washington needs to break down the wall between military and non-military production, eliminating the overly specific requirements and reams of classified paperwork that have kept new entrants out of defense work.
The Clinton Administration is trying harder than any of its predecessors to do just that. If it succeeds, it might make the defense business more competitive, and at less cost to taxpayers.

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: In America;
Cigarette Smoke and Mirrors

BYLINE: BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
For years the tobacco industry, which has been unceasingly inventive in developing ways to champion its treacherous products, has tried to spread the peculiar notion that it would be bad for the economy if too many Americans wised up and kicked the cigarette habit.
The reasoning is as follows: Sharply reduced tobacco consumption, resulting in sharply decreased sales of tobacco products, would hurt not only tobacco-producing states but all other states as well. Businesses related to the production, sale and distribution of tobacco would shut down, people would be thrown out of work, and state and Federal governments would lose the substantial revenues they realize from taxes on tobacco. 
 A number of studies have been commissioned by the industry to show that the economic impact of tobacco is huge. Thus kicking the habit may be good for your health, but the industry warns that it may be harmful to others. By putting out that last cigarette, you could be putting someone out of a desperately needed job. The children of tobacco salesmen and distributors could be forced to go hungry. And by not paying your fair share of cigarette taxes you could be contributing to the national deficit.
Consider the "Save Our Jobs" rally scheduled for today in Washington. Thousands of cigarette workers plan to demonstrate in opposition to proposed hikes in Federal tobacco taxes.
As many as 9,000 workers are expected from just one plant, the giant Philip Morris U.S.A. complex in Richmond, which produces half a billion cigarettes a day. Somebody has to smoke all those cigarettes or somebody else is out of work. Hard-core smokers are a dying breed, so others are needed to take up the slack. In light of current employment conditions, reaching for that next pack of Marlboros could be seen as one's civic duty -- like paying taxes but without the compulsion of law. Smoking as an act of altruism.
Well, perhaps not.
A careful new study, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association and released just yesterday, disputes the economic findings of the tobacco industry studies. In particular, the new study asserts that a sharp decline in smoking will not hurt the economies of non-tobacco-producing states and will not lead to decreased employment.
In fact, the study, by a pair of researchers at the University of Michigan, found just the opposite: "Reducing or eliminating tobacco product spending in Michigan will increase employment in the state, as well as health."
The researchers, Kenneth E. Warner, a professor of public health policy and administration, and George A. Fulton, a research scientist in the Department of Economics, said their findings were based on a computerized study of the Michigan economy and could be applied to other non-tobacco states.
"The [tobacco] industry's estimates greatly exaggerate tobacco's economic importance," the study says. "Implicitly, they treat the resources devoted to tobacco product production and distribution as disappearing if sales decline or cease altogether. However, the amount of economic activity associated with tobacco product sales would not disappear if consumers decreased their spending on tobacco products. Rather, it would be redistributed as consumers use the same money to purchase alternative goods and services.
"Just like spending on tobacco, this alternative spending would generate employment and tax revenues associated with the production, distribution, and sale of purchased goods and services."
In Michigan, consumers spend about $1.8 billion a year on tobacco products. That's a lot of cash to be redirected in a state's economy.
Toward the end of their study, Mr. Warner and Mr. Fulton addressed the issue that the tobacco industry cannot allow itself to acknowledge: Smoking makes people sick and that's a boon to the health care sector.
"Thus," says the study, "by producing illness, tobacco generated economic activity (jobs and incomes) in the health care industry in Michigan, just as it did in tobacco retailing and wholesaling."
The merchants of death don't mention that when they're bragging about how terrific smoking is for the economy.

HEADLINE: Prices for Recycled Materials Have Become Low and Attractive

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In response to Mark Shantzis of Hi-Rise Recycling Systems in "Recycling Creates More Problems Than It Was Meant to Solve" (letter, March 2), I would like to clarify a few points about the markets for recyclable materials and the economics of recycling in the United States. 
 Mr. Shantzis refers to a "growing mountain of unused bottles and cans" because recyclable materials are being "priced out of the market." In actuality, prices for most major recyclable commodities have declined during the economic recession, making them a more economically attractive feedstock for manufacturers. Economics studies have also indicated that using recycled materials can lower a manufacturer's energy costs or other operating expenses.
Corporate America plays a critical role in stimulating the recycling marketplace, by purchasing recycled products and marketing consumer goods made from recycled material. I believe that businesses can do even more for recycling, but disagree with Mr. Shantzis's statement that "corporations have not been particularly aggressive in marketing recycled products to consumers."
For instance, 600 companies that have joined the National Recycling Coalition's Buy Recycled Business Alliance spent more than $10.5 billion on recycled products and materials last year, an increase from the $2.7 billion the founding 25 corporations spent the year before. In New York, daily newspaper publishers (including The Times) voluntarily agreed to increase their use of recycled newsprint; those publishers have already exceeded their goals.
Contrary to Mr. Shantzis, recyclable materials markets have grown by leaps in the last few years, thanks to the market development efforts of New York and other states. The issue is not if a community has a market for recyclable materials, but what price it can get for them.
The average cost of processing recyclables at a materials recovery facility is about $50 a ton (not $130 a ton, as Mr. Shantzis indicates), and the cost is picked up by municipalities, not manufacturers, as he states. These economic issues can be worked out, however, by continued efforts by businesses, states and communities to develop markets and optimize cost-effective methods of collecting, processing and using recovered materials.
 
MARK LICHTENSTEIN
 Pres., Natl. Recycling Coalition
 Washington, March 3, 1994

HEADLINE: Beyond Auto Shop: An Experiment in High School Job Training

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 26

 BODY:
Kim Jabbie, a high school freshman, spent three hours at a local morning radio station the other day. She visited with Josh Reynolds, the producer of the show. She tried speaking into the microphone. She watched as he wrote copy. It seemed like fun.
Soon, she will visit Emanuel Hospital here, to see what health workers do.
And, at the end of the school year, 
 Kim, who is 14, will decide what she wants to do when she grows up.
Her decision will help guide what courses she takes and what summer jobs she gets. The program, at Roosevelt High School here, is one of the most aggressive efforts in the country to address shortcomings in job training. Freshmen visit workplaces, sophomores sign up for one of six career tracks, and juniors and seniors get internships or jobs in their chosen vocations. Right now it is a pilot program; Roosevelt is one of six Oregon high schools where the experiment is going on. But by the 1996-97 year, all high schools in the state will be required to have similar programs.
The effort started two years ago, when Oregon became the first state to require all public high schools to teach job skills, particularly to students not planning on college. The program is being watched by the White House and the Education Commission of the States as they look for ways to increase the competitiveness of American workers. There is already evidence that the program is helping retain students who are most likely to drop out.
Under Oregon's school-to-work program, all students take a core curriculum of academic courses, but lessons carry career-related applications. In English, for instance, students who pick careers in health care might write a paper on health costs. In earth science, students in natural resources might learn to test soil acidity or experiment with erosion.
 
Concern About Pigeonholes
 The emphasis on training for work -- a tenet of the Clinton Administration's education legislation now before a Congressional conference committee -- has drawn its share of critics. They say students may be just as vulnerable to getting pigeonholed as students were in the old vocational education programs, when low achievers wound up in auto mechanics and hairdressing classes.
The critics say that 10th graders are too young to make intelligent career choices. "The one thing that I found the most fault with was the age," said Gary D. Watts, senior director of the National Center for Innovation, the research arm of the National Education Association, the biggest teachers' union. "There is nothing magic at 16. Do these kids know what is at stake? I don't think so."
For all the criticism, parents like Miss Jabbie's mother, Korra, believe the program has merit. At the least, she said, it will give her daughter a realistic view of work. "It's a positive thing," Mrs. Jabbie said.
For her part, Kim came away from her visit to the radio station, KEX-AM, with many of her questions answered about the communications business. "This is something I think I would like to do," she said in a cab on her way home.
One surprising benefit of the plan is that it appears to have lowered the dropout rate significantly. Two years ago at Roosevelt, the 9th-grade dropout rate was 16 percent. Today it is 6 percent.
Oregon officials use that information and other arguments to counter the criticism. They have said repeatedly that their plan is flexible enough to allow students to move from any of the six career paths if they feel they made the wrong decision.
The officials also said they are committed to financing the program, despite recession-induced cuts in state financing and a property-tax limit approved by voters two years ago. At Roosevelt High School alone, designing and introducing the job-training curriculum and retraining teachers has cost nearly $200,000 in the three years it has been in effect. But state and local officials hope for a share of the more than $1 billion that the Federal Government plans to spend for such programs through the 1997 fiscal year.
"We are very clear that these programs are about increasing options, not foreclosing options for students," said Augusta Kappan, the assistant secretary for vocational and adult education at the Education Department.
She said the Oregon school-to-work program combines these elements of three other job-training models widely embraced by public schools:
*Career academies, in which a high school operates under one professional theme with ties to businesses in that industry.
*Technical preparation schools, emphasizing connections with community colleges, allowing students to train for a job while attending school.
*Cooperative education, which includes putting students in jobs they are interested in as careers while in school.
Although it will be years before officials can determine how well the Oregon program works, the Roosevelt plan has drawn early support from the people most affected: the students.
"This is great!" said Jonathan Cyphers, a 15-year-old sophomore, as he spent a morning at the North Portland Veterinary Clinic. "I love animals. I could do this."
In three hours, he watched a veterinarian and two technicians spay a Labrador named Katrina and neuter a stray cat, Muggins, and got a primer on drugs to cure ailing animals.
Jonathan is enrolled in health occupations, which offers a curriculum heavy in science as well as mathematics, English and history. The student said the exposure to health professions (he had already visited Emanual Hospital here) will help him make better decisions about what college courses to take. After watching a parade of pets and strays growl and hiss their way to surgery, he said he would consider veterinary medicine. "I could go either way," he said.
And for those students who do not plan on higher education, the program offers a chance to look over skilled jobs, like that of technician at the North Portland animal clinic.
"Kids really get tired thinking they have to go to school eight more years to become a veterinarian," said Molly O'Brien, the clinic's office manager. "A lot of them have expressed interest in becoming a technician." That, she said, requires two years of community college.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 15, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 9 about a high school job-training program in Portland, Ore., misstated the surname of the Education Department's assistant secretary for vocational and adult education, who described benefits of the program. She is Augusta Kappner, not Kappan.

HEADLINE: BOXING: NOTEBOOK;
Bowe Keeps His Glove in HBO View

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI

 BODY:
Riddick Bowe, who seemed so invincible only a few months ago, seemed so much history yesterday.
 The name of Bowe, the former heavyweight champion of the world, rarely came up as the people who run the careers of the current champions, Lennox Lewis and Evander Holyfield, spoke of an eventual showdown between the pair next November. 
And Bowe? He is fighting South Africa's Francois Botha in June. Nothing more for now. But the paths of Holyfield and Lewis are well-plotted by HBO, which wants a unified title for the most altruistic of reasons: it's good business.
 But as Seth Abraham, who runs HBO Sports, said yesterday, "In boxing, everything is subject to change." And HBO is keeping its options open. Thus, Bowe's fight with Botha is being televised by -- you guessed it -- HBO.
 Thus, a Bowe victory, and perhaps unexpected losses along the way by Lewis and/or Holyfield -- and Bowe is back.
 
Is Anti-Bowe Plot Afoot?
 Rock Newman, Bowe's manager, believes an anti-Bowe plot is afoot, hatched by Dan Duva, who promotes Holyfield, and Frank Maloney, who manages Lewis.
 "Try as they might," Newman said yesterday, "there is a very calculated and mean-spirited attempt to keep Riddick out of the heavyweight picture." He pointed out that after Bowe lost his two titles to Holyfield in November, Bowe dropped to fourth in the rankings of the World Boxing Association and International Boxing Federation.
 "Lewis's people manipulated the rankings," charged Bowe's attorney, Milt Chwasky. With Bowe ranked so low, Holyfield doesn't have to worry about a mandatory return fight.
 Nonetheless, this is the course that Lewis and Holyfield are on: Lewis, the World Boxing Council king, faces Phil Jackson, father of six, on May 6 in Atlantic City. Lewis will presumably win, and then fight Oliver (Atomic Bull) McCall. Meanwhile, Holyfield defends his two titles against Michael Moorer on April 22. That will be followed by a bout in August against an opponent to be determined. And then, the title fight in November.
 "I'd rather not say anything about a man when he's down," said Lewis's manager, Maloney, yesterday when asked about Newman. "But I will say that Rock enjoyed it when other people were down and he could call the shots."
 Newman did not deny this.
 "I was difficult to deal with," he conceded, "because I demanded the lion's share and those sleazebags couldn't stand it. No matter what they do or say, Riddick will be the heavyweight champion of the world again."
 Bowe's weight, which two months before his title defense had soared to 288 pounds, is "just where we want it," Newman said yesterday. He claimed that Bowe weighs 265 pounds. If so, that is still 30 pounds above the weight he expects to be for Botha.
 Such things are unimportant to Newman, planning the return to titlehood.
 "We'll be back," he said, and added with no humor in his voice, "and we're going to have fun in the process."
 
Skipping Class for Ring
 Seth Braunstein, one of Jesse Ferguson's co-managers, will skip school next week.
 Next Wednesday, four days before his 37th birthday, Ferguson, a former victim of Bowe's, faces Frank Bruno, a former victim of Lewis's, in London, Braunstein will take off from classes at the University of Chicago, where he is continuing his work toward a degree.
 "I'm taking five economics classes in 10 weeks," said Braunstein. "I never finished and I thought, if I don't do it now, I never will."
 He and his partner in boxing, Greg Cohen, have taken on their second fighter. His name is Tony Simon, out of Detroit, and he made his debut in Scranton, Pa., last Sunday with a one-round knockout of Terry Thompson.
 
Self-Serving Ad Agency
 Kevin Kelley, the newly crowned World Boxing Council featherweight champion who is his own advertising agency, continues to put his name out there. He has had it pasted on the sides of private cabs in his native Queens. He has a new line of engraved pencils which he distributes, along with buttons and posters. He also has a title fight coming up the night of the Lewis-Jackson affair. Kelley faces Jesse Benavides.

HEADLINE: CLINTON PLAN SEES WELFARE COSTING $6 BILLION A YEAR

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
A draft of the Administration's welfare plan offers the first cost estimates of President Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it," outlining significant new expenditures on child care, training and work programs.
The projections are preliminary and could undergo major changes as Mr. Clinton and his aides resolve several policy issues. But the cost of the programs, which the Administration projects at $6 billion in 1999, and the means of financing it, are likely to be central points in the debate when Congress takes up the issue this year. 
 Welfare rolls are at record highs; the Government now spends $23 billion a year on Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program.
Republican leaders in Congress as well as the President have proposed sweeping changes in welfare that would require recipients to join work programs. While the public may hear those calls as promises to save money, both parties have said they will increase spending in the initial years.
 
Why Plans Cost More
 The Clinton plan would spend $15 billion in the first five years in addition to the $23 billion a year being spent on Aid to Families With Dependent Children. That is actually $5 billion less than a bill being put forward by 162 House Republicans.
The plans to enroll welfare recipients in work programs cost more than simply mailing checks because the Government has to hire additional supervisors and provide child care to the single parents in the program.
The annual cost of the Administration's program, as outlined, would grow to $6 billion by 1999. But because the program is being phased in over more than a decade, that figure significantly underestimates the eventual costs, which will begin escalating in the sixth year and beyond.
 
Painful Hunt for Revenue
 The draft does not say how the money will be raised. Budget laws require new spending to be offset by program cuts or tax increases, and some officials say the painful hunt for revenue may force a smaller program.
The costs of the Clinton plan escalate sharply in later years because by then increasing numbers of welfare recipients will exhaust a time limit and be forced to work. Because Congressional budget rules have a five-year accounting period, the Administration is not forced to explain how those later costs will be borne.
But past attempts to overhaul the welfare system have faltered when the money ran low, and long-term financing is crucial. "It's a real concern," said Sid Johnson, director of the American Public Welfare Association, which represents state welfare officials. "You have to keep you eye on the long-term ball and what you're committing yourself to."
David T. Ellwood, an Assistant Secretary of Health, and Human Services who is a co-chairman of the group drafting the President's plan, expressed confidence that future financing would keep pace. "We're not playing budget games," he said. "We're going to do the right thing."
Mr. Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it" was among his most successful campaign themes, and he has promised a bill this spring. The plan would expand training programs and then require parents still unemployed after two years to work.
The draft of the plan, which was circulated among Cabinet members last week, also outlines policy disputes that have begun to divide the Administration. One of the most important is: should mothers who work part time at low-wage jobs be allowed to collect supplementary welfare payments after the two-year limit expires?
The officials favoring that provision are led by Mr. Ellwood. They say part-time work is the first step out of dependency, but it often is not enough to support a family. Depriving part-time workers of supplementary welfare payments, they say, would force some mothers to increase their work hours, thus spending less time with their children, or fall deeper into poverty.
The officials expressing concern about the supplementary payments are led by Bruce Reed, a White House aide who is the other co-chairman of the group drafting the plan. They contend that continued welfare payments to part-time workers could encourage people to remain on government aid.
Mr. Reed said his concerns are less political than substantive. "I want to make sure that everything we do steers people toward self-sufficiency as quickly as possible," he said.
A copy of the draft was provided by an Administration official who feared the plan could wind up hurting poor families. The issues it describes are sufficiently sensitive that the Administration scheduled an unusual briefing today in response to questions about the paper from The New York Times.
Officials distributed the draft to other reporters on the condition that they not quote from it, and the officials spent an hour praising the provisions, on the condition they not be identified.
The $6 billion annual spending contains several provisions that have escaped much notice. It includes $945 million, for instance, in additional welfare payments to two-parent households, as an incentive to keep families together. It also includes $2 billion for child care to working poor families who are not on welfare, as a means of keeping them off the rolls. And it includes $250 million for a demonstration project in which the Government would make child support payments if an absent parent fails to do so.
The plan also projects potential cost savings, including $150 million a year if states are allowed to deny additional cash to parents who conceive additional children while on welfare, and $50 million a year by requiring mothers under the age of 18 to live at home.
But the plan would spend only $690 million a year on the work program itself in 1999. That is a fivefold increase from the previous year, however, and the amount would continue to escalate as more people reached the time limit.
No one knows how high it will ultimately grow. By 1999, the Administration predicts, 130,000 welfare recipients would have exhausted the two-year limit and joined the work program. But there are five million families on Aid to Families With Dependent Children, and one official has estimated that from 500,000 to 2.3 million will eventually reach the time limit.

PERSON: DEPARLE, JASON; CLINTON, BILL (PRES) BILL CLINTON (92%); 

LOAD-DATE: March 10, 1994
